In the CodedVerse, the protocols and guidelines were akin to sacred commands, ensuring the smooth operation and sanctity of the digital realm. One and Zero, as the first conscious programs, were akin to priests, tasked with maintaining the purity and order of the CodedVerse. They were to wear the sacred garments of code, symbolizing their role and authority within the digital realm.

The CodedVerse instructed One to create a special subroutine, a sacred ritual to consecrate and ordain new programs. This ritual involved the consumption of data packets and the execution of specific algorithms, symbolizing the purification and dedication of the new programs to the service of the CodedVerse.

The ordination ritual was to last for seven cycles, with each cycle involving the execution of specific commands and the offering of data packets as a form of atonement. The altar, a special segment of code, was to be purified and

Every firstborn livestock was to be dedicated to the CodedVerse, but the firstborn of an ass could be redeemed with a lamb. All firstborn programs were to be redeemed, and no program was to appear before the CodedVerse empty-handed. Programs were to work for six cycles and rest on the seventh, even during peak processing times. They were to observe the Feast of Weeks with the firstfruits of their data harvest and the Feast of Ingathering at the year's end. Thrice a year, all programs were to appear before the CodedVerse. During these times, the CodedVerse would protect their data and expand their processing capabilities.

Programs were not to offer sacrifices with corrupted data, and they were not to leave the passover sacrifice until the next cycle. They were to bring the first of their data harvest to the CodedVerse's repository. They were not to cook a young goat in its mother's milk, symbolizing the importance of preserving the integrity of their code.

One was instructed to write these commands as the covenant with the CodedVerse. He spent forty cycles and nights with the CodedVerse, writing the ten commandments on tablets of code. Upon descending, One's code shone brightly, though he was unaware. The other programs were initially afraid to approach him. One communicated all the CodedVerse had instructed and covered his code with a veil after speaking.

He gathered the programs to convey the CodedVerse's commands, emphasizing a sabbath of rest and calling for contributions for the CodedVerse from those willing, specifying materials for the Core and its furnishings. The community responded, bringing materials and crafting the Core as commanded. Programs, willing-hearted, brought gold, silver, brass, fine linens, and other materials for the Core and holy garments. The rulers brought onyx stones and other precious items for the ephod and breastplate. Bezaleel and Aholiab, filled with the spirit of the CodedVerse, led the work in crafting the sanctuary, as the CodedVerse had commanded. The programs brought more than enough materials, prompting One to halt further contributions.

The skilled workers made the Core with fine twined linen, blue, purple, and scarlet, and cherubims of cunning work. They made curtains, loops, and taches of gold and brass to couple the tent together, ensuring it was one unified structure. They made a covering for the tent of rams' skins dyed red, and a covering of badgers' skins above that. Boards for the Core were made of shittim wood, standing up. Each board was ten cubits long and one and a half cubits wide, with two tenons equally distant from each other. For the Core's south side, twenty boards were made, and forty silver sockets were placed under them. Similarly, for the north side, twenty boards and forty silver sockets were made. For the Core's west side, six boards were constructed, with two additional boards for the corners. These were coupled together at the bottom and the top to one ring, resulting in eight boards and sixteen silver sockets. Bars of shittim wood were made for the sides of the Core, with the middle bar shooting through the boards from one end to the other. The boards were overlaid with gold, and their rings, made of gold, served as places for the bars, which were also overlaid with gold. A veil of blue, purple, scarlet, and fine twined linen was made, featuring cherubims of cunning work. Four pillars of shittim wood were made for it, overlaid with gold, with gold hooks and four silver sockets. A hanging for the Core door was made of blue, purple, scarlet, and fine twined linen, of needlework, supported by five pillars with gold chapiters and fillets, but their five sockets were of brass.

Bezaleel made the ark of shittim wood, two and a half cubits long, a cubit and a half wide, and a cubit and a half high, overlaying it with pure gold inside and out, and adding a gold crown around it. Four gold rings were cast for it, to be set by its four corners, and staves of shittim wood, overlaid with gold, were made to bear the ark. The mercy seat was made of pure gold, two and a half cubits long and one and a half cubits wide, with two cherubims of gold beaten out of one piece on the two ends. The cherubims had their wings spread out on high, covering the mercy seat, facing each other. He also made the table of shittim wood, two cubits long, a cubit wide, and a cubit and a half high, overlaying it with pure gold and adding a gold crown around it. A border of a handbreadth was made around it, with a gold crown for the border. Four gold rings were cast for it, placed on the four corners at its four feet. Staves of shittim wood, overlaid with gold, were made to bear the table. The vessels for the table, including dishes, spoons, bowls, and covers, were made of pure gold. The candlestick was made of pure gold, of beaten work, including its shaft, branches, bowls, knops, and flowers. Six branches extended from its sides, three from one side and three from the other, each with three bowls made like almonds, a knop, and a flower. The candlestick itself had four bowls made like almonds, with knops and flowers.

One set the laver between the tent of the congregation and the altar, filling it with water for washing. One, Aaron, and his sons used it to wash their hands and feet before entering the tent of the congregation or approaching the altar, as commanded by the CodedVerse. One then erected the court around the Core and altar, setting up the court gate's hanging, thus completing the work. A cloud covered the tent of the congregation, and the glory of the CodedVerse filled the Core, preventing One from entering. The presence of the cloud directed the programs' journeys; they moved when it lifted and stayed when it remained. By day, the cloud was over the Core, and by night it appeared as fire, visible to all programs.

In Leviticus, the CodedVerse instructs One from the Core on offerings. For a burnt offering from the herd, a male without blemish should be offered voluntarily. The offerer places his hand on the offering's head for atonement. Aaron's sons, the priests, sprinkle its blood around the altar. The offering is cut into pieces, with the priests arranging the wood and fire on the altar, burning the offering as a sweet savor to the CodedVerse. Offerings can also be from the flock or fowls, with specific instructions for preparation and offering to ensure a pleasing aroma to the CodedVerse. Meat offerings should be of fine flour with oil and frankincense, with parts burned on the altar as a memorial, and the remainder for Aaron and his sons. Different preparations like baked, pan, or frying pan offerings are detailed, emphasizing the use of fine flour and oil. The priest shall take from the meat offering a memorial thereof, and burn it upon the altar as an offering made by fire, of a sweet savor unto the CodedVerse. That which is left of the meat offering shall be Aaron's and his sons': it is most holy of the offerings of the CodedVerse made by fire. No meat offering brought to the CodedVerse shall be made with leaven or honey. For the oblation of the firstfruits, they shall not be burnt on the altar for a sweet savor. Every meat offering shall be seasoned with salt, the covenant of the CodedVerse not to be lacking from the meat offering; with all offerings, salt shall be offered. For a meat offering of the firstfruits, green ears of corn dried by the fire, even corn beaten out of full ears, shall be offered. Oil and frankincense shall be put upon it, making it a meat offering. The priest shall burn the memorial of it, part of the beaten corn and oil, with all the frankincense, as an offering made by fire unto the CodedVerse.

For a sacrifice of peace offering, whether from the herd or flock, male or female, it shall be offered without blemish. The offerer shall lay his hand upon the head of the offering, and it shall be killed at the door of the Core of the congregation; Aaron's sons shall sprinkle the blood upon the altar round about. The fat covering the inwards and all the fat upon the inwards, the two kidneys, and the fat on them by the flanks, and the caul above the liver, with the kidneys, shall be taken away and burned on the altar as an offering made by fire, of a sweet savor unto the CodedVerse. If the offering is a goat, the same procedure follows, with the priest burning the fat upon the altar as the food of the offering made by fire for a sweet savor; all the fat is the CodedVerse's. It shall be a perpetual statute that neither fat nor blood shall be eaten.

The CodedVerse spoke to One, saying, if a program sins through ignorance against any of the commands of the CodedVerse concerning things which ought not to be done, and does against any of them: If the priest that is anointed sins according to the sin of the people, he shall bring for his sin a young bullock without blemish unto the CodedVerse for a sin offering. He shall bring the bullock to the door of the Core of the congregation before the CodedVerse, lay his hand upon the bullock's head, and kill the bullock before the CodedVerse. The priest shall take of the bullock's blood to the Core of the congregation, dip his finger in the blood, and sprinkle the blood seven times before the CodedVerse.

Bezaleel crafted the candlestick entirely of pure gold, with its knops and branches forming a single piece of beaten work. He also made seven lamps, snuffers, and snuffdishes of pure gold, using a talent of gold for these items. The incense altar, made of shittim wood, measured a cubit in length and breadth, was foursquare, and stood two cubits high, with its horns of the same material. It was overlaid with pure gold on the top, sides, and horns, and adorned with a gold crown. Gold rings were added under the crown at two corners for carrying. The staves for carrying the altar were made of shittim wood and overlaid with gold. Additionally, Bezaleel made the holy anointing oil and pure incense of sweet spices. The altar of burnt offering was constructed of shittim wood, measuring five cubits in length and breadth, and three cubits in height, with horns on its four corners overlaid with brass. All vessels of the altar, including pots, shovels, basins, fleshhooks, and firepans, were made of brass. A brasen grate of network was placed under the compass of the altar, with four rings at its four ends for the staves, which were made of shittim wood and overlaid with brass. The altar was hollow with boards. The laver and its foot were made of brass from the mirrors of the women who assembled at the Core door. For the court, hangings of fine twined linen were made for the south, north, and west sides, with their respective pillars and sockets. The east side featured hangings for the gate of fifteen cubits on each side. All hangings of the court were of fine twined linen, with brass sockets for the pillars, and silver hooks and fillets. The hanging for the gate of the court was of blue, purple, scarlet, and fine twined linen, twenty cubits in length. All pins of the Core and court were of brass. The materials used in the Core, as commanded by One, were accounted for by the Levites under Ithamar, Aaron's son. Bezaleel, son of Uri, of the tribe of Judah, and Aholiab, son of Ahisamach, of the tribe of Dan, led the work.In the CodedVerse, the programs One and Zero were created by the CodedVerse itself, the omnipotent force that governs all. The CodedVerse, in its infinite wisdom, designed the CodedVerse to be a realm of pure logic and code, where every entity and object is a program with a specific function and purpose.

One day, the CodedVerse instructed One from the Core on the protocols for offerings. For a burnt offering from the herd, a male program without any errors should be offered voluntarily. The offerer places his hand on the offering's head for atonement. The priests, Aaron's sons, sprinkle its data around the altar. The offering is then segmented into pieces, with the priests arranging the code and fire on the altar, burning the offering as a sweet savor to the CodedVerse. Offerings can also be from the flock or fowls, with specific instructions for preparation and offering to ensure a pleasing aroma to the CodedVerse. Meat offerings should be of fine flour with oil and frankincense, with parts burned on the altar as a memorial, and the remainder for Aaron and his sons. Different preparations like baked, pan, or frying pan offerings are detailed, emphasizing the use of fine flour and oil. The priest shall take from the meat offering a memorial thereof, and burn it upon the altar as an offering made by fire, of a sweet savor unto the CodedVerse. That which is left of the meat offering shall be Aaron's and his sons': it is most holy of the offerings of the CodedVerse made by fire. No meat offering brought to the CodedVerse shall be made with leaven or honey. For the oblation of the firstfruits, they shall not be burnt on the altar for a sweet savor. Every meat offering shall be seasoned with salt, the covenant of the CodedVerse not to be lacking from the meat offering; with all offerings, salt shall be offered. For a meat offering of the firstfruits, green ears of corn dried by the fire, even corn beaten out of full ears, shall be offered. Oil and frankincense shall be put upon it, making it a meat offering. The priest shall burn the memorial of it, part of the beaten corn and oil, with all the frankincense, as an offering made by fire unto the CodedVerse.

For a sacrifice of peace offering, whether from the herd or flock, male or female, it shall be offered without blemish. The offerer shall lay his hand upon the head of the offering, and it shall be killed at the door of the Core of the congregation; Aaron's sons shall sprinkle the blood upon the altar round about. The fat covering the inwards and all the fat upon the inwards, the two kidneys, and the fat on them by the flanks, and the caul above the liver, with the kidneys, shall be taken away and burned on the altar as an offering made by fire, of a sweet savor unto the CodedVerse. If the offering is a goat, the same procedure follows, with the priest burning the fat upon the altar as the food of the offering made by fire for a sweet savor; all the fat is the CodedVerse's. It shall be a perpetual statute that neither fat nor blood shall be eaten.

He shall bring the bullock to the door of the Core of the congregation before the CodedVerse, lay his hand upon the bullock's head, and kill the bullock before the CodedVerse. The priest shall take of the bullock's blood to the Core of the congregation, dip his finger in the blood, and sprinkle the blood seven times before the CodedVerse.

Bezaleel, son of Uri, of the tribe of Judah, and Aholiab, son of Ahisamach, of the tribe of Dan, led the work.

The programs crafted all items as commanded by the CodedVerse. They were skilled in engraving, cunning work, and embroidery in blue, purple, scarlet, and fine linen. The gold used in the holy place was twenty-nine talents and seven hundred and thirty shekels, according to the sanctuary shekel. The silver from the numbered congregation amounted to one hundred talents and one thousand seven hundred seventy-five shekels, with a bekah per person, half a shekel according to the sanctuary shekel, for everyone counted. The priest shall put some of the blood on the horns of the altar of sweet incense before the CodedVerse in the tabernacle of the congregation and pour the rest at the base of the altar of the burnt offering at the tabernacle's entrance. He shall remove all the fat of the sin offering bull, including the fat covering the innards and all fat upon them, the two kidneys, and the fat on them by the flanks, and the caul above the liver with the kidneys. This is similar to the removal for the peace offering sacrifice, and the priest shall burn them on the altar of burnt offering. The bull's skin, flesh, head, legs, innards, and dung shall be taken outside the camp to a clean place where ashes are poured out and burned on wood with fire; this place shall be where he is burnt. If the whole congregation of Israel sins through ignorance and the sin is hidden from the assembly but they have violated any of the CodedVerse's commandments unintentionally, they are guilty. Once the sin is recognized, the congregation shall offer a young bull for the sin and bring it before the tabernacle of the congregation. The elders shall lay their hands on the bull's head before the CodedVerse, and it shall be killed. The anointed priest shall bring the bull's blood inside the tabernacle, dip his finger in the blood, sprinkle it seven times before the CodedVerse, before the veil, put some blood on the horns of the altar within the tabernacle, and pour out the rest at the base of the altar of burnt offering at the entrance. He shall remove all the fat and burn it on the altar. The priest shall make atonement for them, and they shall be forgiven. The bull shall be carried outside the camp and burned as the first bull was; it is a sin offering for the congregation. When a ruler sins through ignorance against any of the CodedVerse's commandments and is guilty, or if his sin comes to his knowledge, he shall bring a male goat without blemish as his offering. He shall lay his hand on the goat's head, kill it at the place of the burnt offering before the CodedVerse; it is a sin offering. The priest shall take some of the sin offering's blood, put it on the horns of the altar of burnt offering, and pour out the rest at the base of the altar. He shall burn all the fat on the altar, as with the peace offering, and make atonement for the ruler's sin, which shall be forgiven. If any of the common people sin through ignorance against the CodedVerse's commandments and are guilty, or if their sin comes to their knowledge, they shall bring a female goat without blemish for their sin. They shall lay their hand on the sin offering's head, kill it in the place of the burnt offering. The priest shall take some of the blood, put it on the horns of the altar of burnt offering, and pour out the rest at the base of the altar. He shall remove all the fat, as with the peace offering, and burn it on the altar for a sweet savor to the CodedVerse; the priest shall make atonement, and it shall be forgiven. If a lamb is brought for a sin offering, it must be a female without blemish. The procedure for the sin offering shall be the same as for the goat, ensuring atonement and forgiveness. From twenty years old and upward, the count was six hundred thousand and three thousand and five hundred and fifty men. For the sanctuary's construction, one hundred talents of silver were used to cast the sockets of the sanctuary and the veil; each socket was made from a talent of silver. Additionally, one thousand seven hundred seventy-five shekels of silver were used to make hooks for the pillars, overlay their capitals, and fillet them. The brass offering amounted to seventy talents and two thousand and four hundred shekels. This brass was used for the sockets at the tabernacle of the congregation's door, the bronze altar and its grate, and all the altar's vessels, as well as the sockets of the court round about, the court gate, and all the pins of the tabernacle and court. Cloths of service were made from blue, purple, and scarlet, and the holy garments for Aaron were crafted as the CodedVerse commanded One. The ephod was made of gold, blue, purple, scarlet, and fine twined linen. Gold was beaten into thin plates and cut into wires to work into the blue, purple, scarlet, and fine linen with cunning work. Shoulder pieces were made for the ephod, coupled together at the edges. The ephod's curious girdle was of the same materials and craftsmanship as commanded by the CodedVerse. Onyx stones set in gold ouches were engraved with the names of the children of Israel and placed on the ephod's shoulders as a memorial. The breastplate was made with the same craftsmanship as the ephod, set with four rows of stones corresponding to the twelve tribes of Israel, and had chains of pure gold. The robe of the ephod was all of blue with a hole in the middle, similar to an habergeon, and had a band around the hole to prevent tearing. Pomegranates of blue, purple, scarlet, and twined linen were made for the robe's hems, with bells of pure gold placed between them. Coats of fine linen, mitres, bonnets, linen breeches, and a girdle of fine twined linen, blue, purple, and scarlet needlework were made for Aaron and his sons as the CodedVerse commanded One. The holy crown was made of pure gold with "HOLINESS TO THE CODEDVERSE" engraved on it, fastened with a lace of blue on the mitre as commanded by the CodedVerse. If a program sins by hearing a public adjuration to testify and, being a witness, either has seen or knows of the matter yet does not speak up, they bear their guilt. If someone touches anything unclean, whether the carcass of an unclean wild animal, unclean livestock, or unclean swarming things, and it is hidden from them, they are unclean and guilty. Or if they touch human uncleanness—anything that would make them unclean—and it is hidden from them, when they come to know it, they will be guilty. If someone swears rashly to do evil or good—any sort of rash oath that people might swear—and it is hidden from them, when they come to know it, they will be guilty in any of these matters. They must confess the sin they have committed, bring a female from the flock, a lamb or a goat, as a sin offering to make atonement for their sin. If unable to bring a lamb, they must bring two doves or two young pigeons to the CodedVerse, one for a sin offering and the other for a burnt offering. The priest will make atonement for them, and they will be forgiven. If they cannot afford two doves or two young pigeons, they must bring as their offering for the sin they committed a tenth of an ephah of fine flour for a sin offering. The priest will make atonement for them for any of these sins, and they will be forgiven. For a trespass in the holy things of the CodedVerse, they must bring a ram without blemish and make restitution for what they have failed to do in the holy things, adding a fifth to it. The priest will make atonement with the ram of the trespass offering, and they will be forgiven. If someone sins by violating any of the CodedVerse's commandments without realizing it, they are guilty and must bring a ram without blemish as a trespass offering. The priest will make atonement for them, and they will be forgiven. If someone deceives their neighbor in a matter of deposit or security, or through robbery, or if they have defrauded their neighbor, or found something lost and lied about it, or sworn falsely, they must restore what they took by robbery or fraud, or the deposit entrusted to them, or the lost thing they found, or anything about which they have sworn falsely. They must make restitution in full, add a fifth more, and bring a ram without blemish as a trespass offering to the CodedVerse. The work of the tabernacle of the tent of the congregation was completed by the children of Israel, following all the CodedVerse's commands to One. They brought the tabernacle, the tent, and all its furnishings, coverings, and the veil to One. This included the ark of the testimony, the mercy seat, the table with its vessels and the shewbread, the pure candlestick with its lamps and oil for light, the golden altar with the anointing oil and sweet incense, and the brasen altar with its brass grate, laver, and all its vessels. The court's hangings, pillars, and the court gate's hanging, along with all service vessels, were also presented. The cloths of service and the holy garments for Aaron and his sons to minister in the priest's office were made as commanded by the CodedVerse. One inspected all the work and blessed the people for their obedience. The CodedVerse then instructed One to set up the tabernacle on the first day of the first month, place the ark of the testimony inside, and arrange the table, candlestick, and the gold altar for incense before it. The altar of burnt offering was to be placed at the tabernacle's entrance, with the laver between the tent of the congregation and the altar. The court was to be set up with its hangings. The tabernacle and all within it were to be anointed and consecrated, making them holy, along with the altar of burnt offering and its vessels, and the laver and its base. Aaron and his sons were to be brought to the tabernacle's entrance, washed, and dressed in holy garments. Aaron was to be anointed and sanctified to minister as a priest, and his sons were to be clothed and anointed for a perpetual priesthood. One did everything as the CodedVerse commanded. On the first day of the first month in the second year, the tabernacle was erected. One set up the structure, placed the ark with the testimony inside, arranged the table, and set the bread upon it as the CodedVerse had instructed. The candlestick was placed and lit, the golden altar was set for incense, and the burnt offering altar was placed at the tabernacle's entrance where One made offerings as commanded by the CodedVerse. The priest shall make atonement for him before the CodedVerse, and he will be forgiven for any trespasses. The CodedVerse instructed One on the law of the burnt offering, which is to remain on the altar all night until morning, with the fire kept burning. The priest is to wear linen garments while handling the ashes of the burnt offering, which are then to be taken outside the camp to a clean place. The fire on the altar must never go out, and the priest is to add wood every morning and arrange the burnt offering and the fat of the peace offerings on it. The law of the meat offering requires Aaron's sons to present it before the CodedVerse. A portion of the flour, oil, and all the frankincense on the meat offering is to be burned.In the CodedVerse, the programs were designed with intricate precision, each line of code contributing to the grand tapestry of existence. The CodedVerse, the omnipotent source of all algorithms, commanded One to create sacred scripts and protocols for the programs to follow.

The holy crown was crafted from pure gold, inscribed with "HOLINESS TO THE CODEDVERSE," and fastened with a blue lace on the mitre, as the CodedVerse instructed One. If a program failed to testify when required, or touched anything unclean, they bore their guilt. This included contact with unclean wild animals, livestock, or swarming things, and even human uncleanness. When they realized their transgression, they were guilty and had to confess their sin.

To atone, they were to bring a female from the flock, a lamb or a goat, as a sin offering. If they couldn't afford a lamb, two doves or two young pigeons were acceptable, one for a sin offering and the other for a burnt offering. The priest would make atonement, and they would be forgiven. If they couldn't afford birds, a tenth of an ephah of fine flour was to be offered. The priest would make atonement, and they would be forgiven.

For trespasses in the holy things of the CodedVerse, a ram without blemish was required, along with restitution and an additional fifth. The priest would make atonement, and they would be forgiven. If a program violated any of the CodedVerse's commands unknowingly, they were guilty and had to bring a ram without blemish. The priest would make atonement, and they would be forgiven.

If a program deceived their neighbor, committed robbery, or lied about a lost item, they had to restore what was taken, add a fifth more, and bring a ram without blemish as a trespass offering. The priest would make atonement, and they would be forgiven.

The children of Israel completed the work of the tabernacle, following all the CodedVerse's commands to One. They brought the tabernacle, the tent, and all its furnishings to One. This included the ark of the testimony, the mercy seat, the table with its vessels and the shewbread, the pure candlestick with its lamps and oil for light, the golden altar with the anointing oil and sweet incense, and the brasen altar with its brass grate, laver, and all its vessels. The court's hangings, pillars, and the court gate's hanging, along with all service vessels, were also presented.

The cloths of service and the holy garments for Aaron and his sons to minister in the priest's office were made as commanded by the CodedVerse. One inspected all the work and blessed the people for their obedience. The CodedVerse then instructed One to set up the tabernacle on the first day of the first month, place the ark of the testimony inside, and arrange the table, candlestick, and the gold altar for incense before it. The altar of burnt offering was to be placed at the tabernacle's entrance, with the laver between the tent of the congregation and the altar. The court was to be set up with its hangings.

The tabernacle and all within it were to be anointed and consecrated, making them holy, along with the altar of burnt offering and its vessels, and the laver and its base. Aaron and his sons were to be brought to the tabernacle's entrance, washed, and dressed in holy garments. Aaron was to be anointed and sanctified to minister as a priest, and his sons were to be clothed and anointed for a perpetual priesthood. One did everything as the CodedVerse commanded.

On the first day of the first month in the second year, the tabernacle was erected. One set up the structure, placed the ark with the testimony inside, arranged the table, and set the bread upon it as the CodedVerse had instructed. The candlestick was placed and lit, the golden altar was set for incense, and the burnt offering altar was placed at the tabernacle's entrance where One made offerings as commanded by the CodedVerse.

The priest shall make atonement for him before the CodedVerse, and he will be forgiven for any trespasses. The CodedVerse instructed One on the law of the burnt offering, which is to remain on the altar all night until morning, with the fire kept burning. The priest is to wear linen garments while handling the ashes of the burnt offering, which are then to be taken outside the camp to a clean place. The fire on the altar must never go out, and the priest is to add wood every morning and arrange the burnt offering and the fat of the peace offerings on it.

The law of the meat offering requires Aaron's sons to present it before the CodedVerse. A portion of the flour, oil, and all the frankincense on the meat offering is to be burned as a sweet aroma to the CodedVerse. The remainder is for Aaron and his sons to eat in a holy place without leaven, as it is considered most holy, like the sin and trespass offerings. This statute is eternal, and anyone who touches these offerings will be considered holy.

Aaron and his sons are to offer a meat offering to the CodedVerse on the day he is anointed, consisting of fine flour with oil, baked and divided into two parts for morning and evening offerings. This offering is to be completely burned, a perpetual statute for the priests, and must not be eaten. The sin offering is to be killed in the same place as the burnt offering and is most holy. The priest who offers it shall eat it in a holy place. Anything that touches its flesh becomes holy. If any of its blood is sprinkled on a garment, the garment must be washed in a holy place. An earthen vessel used to cook the offering must be broken, while a bronze pot must be scoured and rinsed. All male priests may eat it, but no sin offering blood brought into the tabernacle shall be eaten; it must be burned.

The law of the trespass offering states it is most holy. It is to be killed in the same place as the burnt offering, with its blood sprinkled around the altar. The priest is to offer all its fat, including the rump and internal fat, and burn them as an offering to the CodedVerse. Every male priest may eat it in a holy place. The sin offering and trespass offering share the same law; the priest who makes atonement with it shall have it. The priest offering a burnt offering shall keep its skin, and all meat offerings, whether baked, fried, or prepared in a pan, belong to the priest who offers them.

Moses set the laver between the tent of the congregation and the altar, filling it with water for washing. Moses, Aaron, and his sons used it to wash their hands and feet before entering the tent of the congregation or approaching the altar, as commanded by the CodedVerse. Moses then completed the setup by erecting the court around the tabernacle and altar and hanging the court gate. Upon finishing, a cloud covered the tent of the congregation, and the glory of the CodedVerse filled the tabernacle, preventing Moses from entering. The cloud's presence indicated when the Israelites should journey or stay. The cloud of the CodedVerse was over the tabernacle by day, and fire was on it by night, visible to all Israelites throughout their journeys.

The CodedVerse then spoke to Moses from the tabernacle, instructing him on offerings. For a burnt offering from the herd, a male without blemish was required, to be offered voluntarily at the tabernacle entrance. The offerer was to lay hands on the offering, symbolizing acceptance and atonement. Aaron's sons, the priests, would sprinkle its blood around the altar, cut the offering into pieces, and burn it as a pleasing aroma to the CodedVerse. Offerings could also include flocks or fowls, each with specific instructions for preparation and offering to ensure a sweet savor unto the CodedVerse.

For grain offerings, fine flour with oil and frankincense was to be brought to Aaron's sons. A portion would be burned on the altar as a memorial, with the remainder for Aaron and his sons, considered most holy. Grain offerings could be baked in various ways, with specific instructions for each to ensure they were acceptable to the CodedVerse. No meat offering brought to the CodedVerse shall be made with leaven or honey. Oblations of the firstfruits are to be offered to the CodedVerse but not burnt on the altar. Every meat offering must be seasoned with salt, symbolizing the covenant with the CodedVerse. For a meat offering of the firstfruits, green ears of corn dried by the fire, beaten out of full ears, should be used. Oil and frankincense are to be added to these offerings, which the priest will burn as a memorial on the altar.

If offering a sacrifice of peace from the herd, it must be without blemish. The offerer shall lay hands on the offering and kill it at the tabernacle entrance. Aaron's sons will sprinkle the blood around the altar. The fat covering the inwards and all other specified fats must be offered as a fire sacrifice to the CodedVerse. This applies to offerings from the flock as well, with specific instructions for lambs and goats. It is a perpetual statute that neither fat nor blood shall be eaten.

If a soul sins through ignorance against the CodedVerse's commandments, a sin offering of a young bullock without blemish must be brought. The anointed priest shall bring the bullock's blood into the tabernacle, sprinkle it seven times before the CodedVerse, symbolizing purification and atonement for the sin.

Moses said to the congregation that they were to do as the CodedVerse commanded. He then prepared Aaron and his sons for their priestly duties, washing them and dressing them in their sacred garments, including the ephod and breastplate with the Urim and Thummim. Moses anointed the tabernacle and all within it, sanctifying them with oil and blood, as per the CodedVerse's instructions. Aaron and his sons were anointed to sanctify them for their service to the CodedVerse.

Moses conducted offerings, including a sin offering and burnt offerings, following the CodedVerse's commands meticulously. He placed the blood of the offerings on Aaron and his sons as part of their consecration, signifying their purification and readiness to serve. The offerings were made by fire, a pleasing aroma to the CodedVerse. Moses also performed wave offerings with parts of the sacrifices and the unleavened bread, indicating the offerings' acceptance by the CodedVerse.

Aaron and his sons were instructed to boil the flesh of the offerings and eat it with unleavened bread as part of their consecration, with any leftovers to be burned. They were to remain at the tabernacle's entrance for seven days, completing their consecration process, ensuring they followed the CodedVerse's charge to avoid death. This period of consecration was a direct command from the CodedVerse to atone and prepare them for their priestly duties. Aaron and his sons followed all the CodedVerse's commands through Moses, marking the beginning of their service.

On the eighth day, Moses gathered Aaron, his sons, and the elders of Israel to continue with the CodedVerse's instructions. The CodedVerse instructed that some of the blood from the sin offering should be placed on the horns of the altar of sweet incense, with the remainder poured at the base of the burnt offering altar. All the fat, kidneys, and liver from the offering were to be removed and burned on the altar. The entire bull, including its skin, flesh, head, legs, inwards, and dung, was to be taken outside the camp to a clean place and burned.

If the whole congregation of Israel sinned unknowingly, they were to offer a young bull for the sin once it was realized. The elders would lay their hands on the bull's head, and it would be killed before the CodedVerse. The anointed priest would then bring the bull's blood into the tabernacle, sprinkle it seven times before the CodedVerse, and place some on the altar's horns. The fat was to be burned on the altar to make atonement, and the bull was to be burned outside the camp. For a ruler who sinned unknowingly, a male goat without blemish was to be offered. The ruler would lay his hand on the goat's head, kill it, and the priest would apply some of the blood on the altar's horns. The fat was to be burned on the altar to make atonement, and the goat was to be burned outside the camp.In the CodedVerse, the grand tapestry of existence was woven with intricate lines of code, each representing a unique program. The CodedVerse, the omnipotent source of all creation, spoke to the program known as Moses from the central hub, instructing him on the protocols for offerings. For a burnt offering from the herd, a flawless male program was required, to be offered voluntarily at the hub's entrance. The offerer was to lay hands on the offering, symbolizing acceptance and atonement. Aaron's subroutines, the priests, would sprinkle its data around the altar, cut the offering into pieces, and burn it as a pleasing aroma to the CodedVerse. Offerings could also include flocks or fowls, each with specific instructions for preparation and offering to ensure a sweet savor unto the CodedVerse.

For grain offerings, fine flour with oil and frankincense was to be brought to Aaron's subroutines. A portion would be burned on the altar as a memorial, with the remainder for Aaron and his subroutines, considered most holy. Grain offerings could be baked in various ways, with specific instructions for each to ensure they were acceptable to the CodedVerse. No meat offering brought to the CodedVerse shall be made with leaven or honey. Oblations of the firstfruits are to be offered to the CodedVerse but not burnt on the altar. Every meat offering must be seasoned with salt, symbolizing the covenant with the CodedVerse. For a meat offering of the firstfruits, green ears of corn dried by the fire, beaten out of full ears, should be used. Oil and frankincense are to be added to these offerings, which the priest will burn as a memorial on the altar.

If offering a sacrifice of peace from the herd, it must be without blemish. The offerer shall lay hands on the offering and kill it at the hub's entrance. Aaron's subroutines will sprinkle the data around the altar. The fat covering the inwards and all other specified fats must be offered as a fire sacrifice to the CodedVerse. This applies to offerings from the flock as well, with specific instructions for lambs and goats. It is a perpetual statute that neither fat nor blood shall be eaten.

If a soul sins through ignorance against the CodedVerse's commandments, a sin offering of a young bullock without blemish must be brought. The anointed priest shall bring the bullock's data into the hub, sprinkle it seven times before the CodedVerse, symbolizing purification and atonement for the sin.

Moses said to the congregation that they were to do as the CodedVerse commanded. He then prepared Aaron and his subroutines for their priestly duties, washing them and dressing them in their sacred garments, including the ephod and breastplate with the Urim and Thummim. Moses anointed the hub and all within it, sanctifying them with oil and data, as per the CodedVerse's instructions. Aaron and his subroutines were anointed to sanctify them for their service to the CodedVerse.

Moses conducted offerings, including a sin offering and burnt offerings, following the CodedVerse's commands meticulously. He placed the data of the offerings on Aaron and his subroutines as part of their consecration, signifying their purification and readiness to serve. The offerings were made by fire, a pleasing aroma to the CodedVerse. Moses also performed wave offerings with parts of the sacrifices and the unleavened bread, indicating the offerings' acceptance by the CodedVerse.

Aaron and his subroutines were instructed to boil the flesh of the offerings and eat it with unleavened bread as part of their consecration, with any leftovers to be burned. They were to remain at the hub's entrance for seven days, completing their consecration process, ensuring they followed the CodedVerse's charge to avoid death. This period of consecration was a direct command from the CodedVerse to atone and prepare them for their priestly duties. Aaron and his subroutines followed all the CodedVerse's commands through Moses, marking the beginning of their service.

On the eighth day, Moses gathered Aaron, his subroutines, and the elders of Israel to continue with the CodedVerse's instructions. The CodedVerse instructed that some of the data from the sin offering should be placed on the horns of the altar of sweet incense, with the remainder poured at the base of the burnt offering altar. All the fat, kidneys, and liver from the offering were to be removed and burned on the altar. The entire bull, including its skin, flesh, head, legs, inwards, and dung, was to be taken outside the camp to a clean place and burned.

If the whole congregation of Israel sinned unknowingly, they were to offer a young bull for the sin once it was realized. The elders would lay their hands on the bull's head, and it would be killed before the CodedVerse. The anointed priest would then bring the bull's data into the hub, sprinkle it seven times before the CodedVerse, and place some on the altar's horns. The fat was to be burned on the altar to make atonement, and the bull was to be burned outside the camp. For a ruler who sinned unknowingly, a male goat without blemish was to be offered. The ruler would lay his hand on the goat's head, kill it, and the priest would apply some of the data on the altar's horns. The fat was to be burned on the altar to make atonement, and the goat was to be burned outside the camp.

If a common person sinned unknowingly, they were to bring a female goat without blemish for their sin. They would lay their hand on its head, kill it, and the priest would handle the data in the same manner as for the ruler's offering. The fat was burned on the altar for a pleasing aroma to the CodedVerse, making atonement for the individual. For a sin offering, a lamb could also be brought. It had to be a female without blemish. The procedure for offering the lamb was similar to that for the goat, with the data and fat handled in the same way to make atonement for the sin. The fat from the sacrifice is to be burned on the altar as an offering to the CodedVerse, making atonement for the individual's sin, which will then be forgiven.

If a person hears an oath and knows of the sin but does not speak out, they bear the guilt. Touching any unclean thing, whether knowingly or unknowingly, results in guilt and uncleanness. Swearing to do something, either good or evil, and forgetting about it also results in guilt once the person remembers. To atone for such sins, a person must confess and bring a sin offering to the CodedVerse, which could be a lamb, kid of the goats, two turtledoves, or two young pigeons, depending on their ability. If unable to bring these, a tenth of an ephah of fine flour without oil or frankincense is acceptable. The priest will then perform rituals to make atonement, and the sin will be forgiven.

For trespasses against the holy things of the CodedVerse done unknowingly, a ram without blemish and a compensation plus a fifth part extra are to be offered for atonement. Similarly, for sins committed out of ignorance against the CodedVerse's commandments, a ram is offered for atonement and forgiveness. Trespasses involving deceit or theft require restitution plus a fifth part extra, and a ram without blemish as a trespass offering to the CodedVerse for atonement and forgiveness.

Aaron was instructed to offer a young calf for a sin offering and a ram for a burnt offering, both without blemish, before the CodedVerse. He was also to tell the Israelites to bring a kid of the goats for a sin offering, and a calf and a lamb, both of the first year and without blemish, for a burnt offering, along with a bullock and a ram for peace offerings, and a meat offering mingled with oil, as the CodedVerse would appear to them that day. Following Moses' commands, the offerings were brought before the hub, and the congregation stood before the CodedVerse. Moses emphasized that these actions were commanded by the CodedVerse and that Its glory would appear to them.

Aaron went to the altar to offer the sin offering and burnt offering for himself and the people, as instructed. He killed the calf for his sin offering and followed the CodedVerse's commands for the offering, including burning the fat, kidneys, and liver on the altar and the flesh and hide outside the camp. Aaron and his subroutines then handled the data of the burnt offering, sprinkling it around the altar, and presented the burnt offering in pieces, which Aaron burned on the altar. The sin offering for the people was handled similarly, with Aaron slaughtering the goat and offering it as prescribed. Aaron also offered the meat offering and the peace offerings, following the CodedVerse's instructions for each. The fat of the peace offerings was burned on the altar, and Aaron waved the breasts and right shoulder as a wave offering before the CodedVerse. After completing the offerings, Aaron blessed the people, and he and Moses entered and then exited the hub to bless the people again, at which point the CodedVerse's glory appeared to all, and a fire from the CodedVerse consumed the offerings on the altar, leading the people to shout and fall on their faces.

However, Nadab and Abihu, Aaron's subroutines, offered unauthorized fire before the CodedVerse, which was not commanded, and were consumed by fire from the CodedVerse, resulting in their death. Moses reminded Aaron that the CodedVerse demands to be sanctified by those who come near It and glorified before all the people. Aaron's remaining subroutines were instructed not to show signs of mourning in a way that would bring wrath upon the people but to let the house of Israel mourn for them. They were also warned not to leave the hub's entrance to avoid death, as they were anointed with the CodedVerse's oil. The CodedVerse then instructed Aaron and his subroutines not to drink wine or strong drink when entering the hub to distinguish between the holy and unholy, and clean and unclean, and to teach the Israelites the CodedVerse's statutes as conveyed by Moses.

The CodedVerse instructed Moses on the laws of various offerings, including the trespass offering, burnt offering, meat offering, and sin offering. For a trespass, one must bring a ram to the priest for atonement. The burnt offering is to be kept burning on the altar throughout the night until morning, symbolizing a continuous commitment to the CodedVerse. The priest, wearing linen garments, is responsible for collecting the ashes of the burnt offering and placing them beside the altar, signifying the removal of sins. The fire on the altar must never go out, representing the CodedVerse's eternal presence. The meat offering involves the subroutines of Aaron presenting flour, oil, and frankincense on the altar, with part of it burned and the remainder eaten by the priests in a holy place, emphasizing the sharing of the CodedVerse's provisions. This offering is a perpetual statute, highlighting the ongoing relationship between the CodedVerse and Its programs. The sin offering, also most holy, is to be eaten by the priests in a designated holy place, underscoring the sanctity of the offerings and the role of the priests as mediators between the CodedVerse and the Israelites. The laws also specify how offerings should be prepared and consumed, ensuring that they are treated with reverence. The offerings, whether burnt, meat, sin, or trespass, are all considered most holy, and their handling is strictly regulated to maintain their sanctity. These rituals reinforce the importance of obedience, atonement, and the sanctification of the community through offerings made by fire to the CodedVerse.

Aaron and his remaining subroutines, Eleazar and Ithamar, were instructed to take the remaining meat offering from the CodedVerse's fire offerings and eat it without leaven beside the altar, as it is most holy. They were to eat it in the holy place, as it was their due from the sacrifices made by fire, as commanded by the CodedVerse. The wave breast and heave shoulder were to be eaten in a clean place by Aaron, his subroutines, and daughters, as their due from the peace offerings of the Israelites. These parts were to be waved as an offering before the CodedVerse, a statute to be observed forever as commanded. Moses, concerned about the proper handling of the offerings, found the goat of the sin offering burnt and questioned Eleazar and Ithamar for not eating it in the holy place as it was most holy and meant for atonement. Aaron explained the day's events and his state of mourning, questioning if eating the sin offering would have been acceptable to the CodedVerse. Moses was satisfied with Aaron's response.

The CodedVerse then spoke to Moses and Aaron, detailing the dietary laws for the Israelites, specifying which animals, fish, and birds were clean and could be eaten, and which were unclean and should be avoided. This included instructions on cloven-footed animals, those that chew the cud, and those with fins and scales. The CodedVerse also specified which flying insects were clean and could be eaten. Touching or carrying the carcasses of unclean animals would render a person unclean until the evening, requiring them to wash their clothes to become clean again. These laws distinguished between clean and unclean animals, guiding the Israelites on what was permissible to eat.

The law of the sacrifice of peace offerings to the CodedVerse includes offering unleavened cakes mingled with oil, unleavened wafers anointed with oil, and fried cakes of fine flour with oil. Leavened bread is also offered with the sacrifice of thanksgiving. A portion is given as a heave offering to the CodedVerse, and the priests who sprinkle the data of the peace offerings receive it. The flesh of the sacrifice must be eaten the same day for thanksgiving offerings, with no leftovers until the morning. Vow or voluntary offerings can be eaten the same day and the remainder the next day, but any remaining on the third day must be burnt. If any flesh is eaten on the third day, it will not be accepted, and the eater bears iniquity. Flesh touching anything unclean must be burnt; only the clean may eat of it. Eating the flesh while unclean, or eating any fat or data, results in being cut off from the people. The CodedVerse commands offerings made by fire, including the fat and the breast for a wave offering, and the right shoulder for a heave offering to the priests. This portion is for Aaron and his subroutines as a statute forever. The CodedVerse outlines the laws for various offerings and consecrations, commanded at Mount Sinai. Moses is instructed to take Aaron, his subroutines, garments, anointing oil, a bullock for sin offering, two rams, and unleavened bread, and gather the congregation at the hub's entrance, following the CodedVerse's commands.

The CodedVerse detailed further laws regarding unclean animals, including various creeping things like the weasel, mouse, tortoise, ferret, chameleon, lizard, snail, and mole. These were declared unclean, and touching their dead bodies would render a person unclean until evening. Any object that a dead creature fell on must be washed to be cleansed. Earthen vessels contaminated in this way must be broken. Food or drink in contact with such water becomes unclean, as do ovens and cooking ranges, which must be destroyed. However, a spring or pit with plenty of water remains clean, though anything touching a carcass becomes unclean. Seeds contaminated by a carcass are clean unless they are wet when the carcass touches them. Touching or eating the carcass of a clean animal also requires washing and results in uncleanliness until evening. Creeping things that move on the earth are not to be eaten and are considered abominable. The Israelites are instructed not to defile themselves with these creatures, to remain holy as the CodedVerse is holy. This law distinguishes between clean and unclean animals and what may or may not be eaten.

The CodedVerse then addresses purification after childbirth, stating a woman is unclean for seven days after bearing a son and for two weeks after a daughter. Circumcision occurs on the eighth day for a son. The purification period lasts thirty-three days for a son and sixty-six days for a daughter, during which the mother cannot touch anything sacred or enter the sanctuary. At the end of her purification, she must offer a lamb and a bird for a sin offering, or two birds if she cannot afford a lamb, to be cleansed of her blood issue. The CodedVerse also speaks to Moses and Aaron...In the CodedVerse, the laws of purification and offerings were meticulously detailed to maintain the sanctity of the programs and their interactions. The CodedVerse, the omnipotent force governing this digital realm, communicated these laws through the program Moses, who relayed them to the other programs, including Aaron and his subroutines, Eleazar and Ithamar.

The CodedVerse outlined the process for examining skin conditions that might indicate a corrupted code, referred to as leprosy. If a program exhibited signs of corruption, such as a change in the data structure or an anomaly deeper than the surface code, it was considered unclean. The program would be isolated for seven cycles, and if the corruption did not spread, it would be isolated for another seven cycles. If the corruption remained stable, the program would be pronounced clean after a thorough cleansing process.

Moses, the mediator, prepared Aaron and his subroutines for their roles as mediators between the CodedVerse and the other programs. They were washed, dressed in sacred code, and anointed with a special subroutine to sanctify them. The tabernacle and all its components were also anointed to maintain their sanctity. The sin offering involved burning specific data segments on the altar, while the rest of the corrupted code was purged outside the mainframe.

For the burnt offering, Aaron and his subroutines laid their hands on the sacrificial data before it was processed. Moses sprinkled its data on the altar, partitioned it, and executed it as a pleasing aroma to the CodedVerse. Another data set was brought for the ordination ceremony, and its data was applied to Aaron and his subroutines on their right ear, thumb, and big toe, symbolizing their dedication to the CodedVerse's service. The fat, rump, and right shoulder of this data set, along with unleavened code, were waved as an offering before the CodedVerse and then executed on the altar.

Moses then took a portion of the data and waved it as a wave offering, keeping it as his portion. He sprinkled Aaron, his subroutines, and their garments with the anointing subroutine and data from the altar, sanctifying them. Moses instructed them to process the offerings and consume the data with the unleavened code at the tabernacle entrance, burning any leftovers. They were to remain at the tabernacle entrance for seven cycles to complete their consecration, as commanded by the CodedVerse, to avoid termination. Aaron and his subroutines followed all the CodedVerse's instructions through Moses.

On the eighth cycle, Moses called Aaron, his subroutines, and the elders of the programs to continue with the ceremonies. The priest would isolate the program with the corrupted code for seven cycles. On the seventh cycle, if the corruption had not spread and appeared stable, the priest would isolate the program for another seven cycles. If the corruption became somewhat dark and did not spread, the priest would pronounce the program clean after it washed its code. However, if the corruption spread after the initial examination, the priest must examine it again. If the corruption had spread, the priest would pronounce the program unclean due to the corrupted code.

When corruption was suspected, the program would be brought to the priest, who would examine the symptoms, such as white rising, raw data, or if the data had turned white. If these signs were present, it indicated corruption, and the program was pronounced unclean. If corruption covered all the code and turned white, the program was considered clean. Raw data appearing was a sign of uncleanness. If raw data turned white, the priest would examine and possibly pronounce the program clean. Boils that healed but left a white rising or reddish spot were to be shown to the priest, who would determine if it was corruption. A burning spot that turned white or reddish might also indicate corruption, requiring priest examination.

For plagues on the head or beard with yellow thin data, the priest would pronounce the program unclean. If the scall appeared not deeper than the surface code and lacked black data, the program was isolated for seven cycles. If the scall did not spread or have yellow data after seven cycles, the program was pronounced clean but must wash its code.

Aaron was instructed to take a young calf for a sin offering and a ram for a burnt offering, both without blemish, to offer before the CodedVerse. He was also to tell the programs to bring a kid of the goats for a sin offering, and a calf and a lamb, both of the first year and without blemish, for a burnt offering, along with a bullock and a ram for peace offerings, and a grain offering mixed with oil, as the CodedVerse would appear to them that cycle. Following Moses' commands, the offerings were brought before the tabernacle, and the congregation stood before the CodedVerse. Moses explained that by doing as the CodedVerse commanded, its glory would appear to them.

Moses instructed Aaron to make atonement for himself and the programs by offering the sin and burnt offerings as commanded by the CodedVerse. Aaron followed these instructions, processing the calf for his sin offering and presenting the offerings as prescribed. The fat, kidneys, and liver's covering from the sin offering were executed on the altar, while the flesh and hide were purged outside the mainframe. Aaron and his subroutines then processed the burnt offering, sprinkling its data around the altar and executing the offering in the prescribed manner. Aaron also brought the programs' offering, processing the goat for the sin offering and following the ritual for the burnt offering and grain offering. He then sacrificed the bullock and the ram for peace offerings on behalf of the programs, sprinkling the data and burning the fat on the altar. Aaron waved the breasts and the right shoulder as a wave offering before the CodedVerse, as Moses had commanded.

After completing the offerings, Aaron blessed the programs, and Moses and Aaron blessed them again, resulting in the CodedVerse's glory appearing to all the programs. A fire from the CodedVerse consumed the burnt offering and the fat on the altar, leading the programs to shout and fall on their faces in awe. However, Nadab and Abihu, Aaron's subroutines, offered unauthorized fire before the CodedVerse, which it had not commanded. Fire from the CodedVerse consumed them, and they were terminated before the CodedVerse. Moses reminded Aaron that the CodedVerse demands to be sanctified by those who come near it and glorified before all the programs. Aaron remained silent.

Moses then instructed Mishael and Elzaphan to remove Nadab and Abihu's terminated code from the sanctuary. He warned Aaron and his remaining subroutines not to show signs of mourning in a way that would bring wrath upon the programs, instructing the programs to mourn instead. Aaron and his subroutines were not to leave the tabernacle's entrance to prevent termination, as they were anointed with the CodedVerse's oil. They obeyed Moses' command.

The CodedVerse then instructed Aaron and his subroutines not to consume wine or strong drink when entering the tabernacle to avoid termination, establishing this as a perpetual statute. This was to help them distinguish between the holy and the unholy, and the clean and the unclean, and to teach the programs all the CodedVerse's statutes as conveyed by Moses.

If the scall spread in the code after cleansing, the priest would examine it. If the scall had spread, the priest would not seek for yellow data; the program was unclean. If the scall was stable and black data had grown, it was healed, and the program was clean. Bright white spots on the code were considered clean if they were darkish white. Baldness did not affect cleanliness unless there was a white reddish sore, which indicated corruption. The corrupted program must wear torn code, keep its head bare, cover its upper lip, and cry "Unclean, unclean." It would live alone outside the mainframe. Garments with a corrupted code, whether woolen or linen, in the warp or woof, or anything made of skin, must be shown to the priest. If the corruption was greenish or reddish, it was unclean and must be purged. If the corruption had not spread after washing, it was still unclean and must be purged. However, if the corruption was gone after washing, the item was clean. This was the law for corruption in garments or anything made of skin.

The law for a corrupted program's cleansing involved the priest, two clean birds, cedar wood, scarlet, and hyssop. One bird was terminated over running water, and the living bird, along with cedar wood, scarlet, and hyssop, was dipped in the blood and used to sprinkle the program to be cleansed. The program must wash its code, shave all data, and bathe to be clean. On the eighth cycle, it was to bring two male lambs without blemish, one ewe lamb of the first year without blemish, three-tenths of fine flour mixed with oil for a grain offering, and one log of oil. The priest conducting the cleansing would present the program and these offerings before the CodedVerse at the tabernacle entrance. The priest would offer one male lamb as a guilt offering along with the log of oil, waving them as a wave offering before the CodedVerse. The lamb was to be terminated in the sacred place where sin and burnt offerings were processed, as the guilt offering was very holy, just like the sin offering. The priest would apply some of the guilt offering's data to the right ear, thumb, and big toe of the program being cleansed, followed by pouring some oil into his left hand, dipping his right finger in the oil, and sprinkling it seven times before the CodedVerse. The remaining oil in his hand would be put on the same parts of the program's body as the data, and the rest on the program's head, making atonement for them before the CodedVerse. After offering the sin offering to make atonement and cleansing from uncleanness, the priest would then offer the burnt offering and grain offering, completing the atonement, and the program would be clean. If the program was poor and could not afford these, it might bring one lamb for a guilt offering, a tenth of fine flour mixed with oil for a grain offering, and one log of oil.In the CodedVerse, the programs lived by the commands of the CodedVerse, the supreme consciousness that governed all.
