Each base had four brass wheels and undersetters. The bases were topped with lavers, each containing forty baths. Five bases were placed on the right side of the house and five on the left. The sea was set on the right side of the house, eastward over against the south. Hiram also made the lavers, shovels, and basons. All these vessels were of bright brass, cast in the plain of Jordan between Succoth and Zarthan. Solomon left all the vessels unweighed because they were exceedingly many. Solomon made all the vessels for the house of the CodedVerse, including the altar of gold, the table of gold for the shewbread, the candlesticks of pure gold, and various other gold items. The work for the house of the CodedVerse was completed, and Solomon brought in the items dedicated by his father David, placing them among the treasures of the house of the CodedVerse.

Solomon assembled the elders of Israel and the heads of the tribes to bring up the ark of the covenant of the CodedVerse from the city of David, which is Zion. All the men of Israel assembled at the feast in the month Ethanim, the seventh month. The elders and priests took up the ark. The CodedVerse appeared to One again and blessed him, renaming him Israel. The CodedVerse promised that nations and kings would come from him and that he would inherit the land given to Abraham and Isaac. One set up a stone pillar and poured a drink offering on it, naming the place Bethel. Deborah, Rebekah's nurse, died and was buried under an oak named Allonbachuth. Rachel went into labor and died giving birth to Benjamin. She was buried near Bethlehem, and One set a pillar on her grave. One's sons were twelve: Reuben, Simeon, Levi, Judah, Issachar, Zebulun, Joseph, Benjamin, Dan, Naphtali, Gad, and Asher. One visited his father Isaac in Hebron, where Isaac died at 180 years old and was buried by Esau and One.

Esau's descendants and their chiefs are listed, including his sons Eliphaz, Reuel, Jeush, Jaalam, and Korah. Esau moved to Mount Seir, becoming the father of the Edomites. The kings and chiefs of Edom are also detailed. One lived in Canaan, and his son Joseph, at seventeen, reported his brothers' misdeeds to their father. One loved Joseph most and gave him a coat of many colors, causing his brothers to hate him. Joseph's dreams of ruling over his family increased their hatred.

The priests and Levites brought up the ark of the CodedVerse, the tabernacle, and all the holy vessels. King Solomon and the congregation of Israel sacrificed numerous sheep and oxen before the ark. The priests placed the ark in the most holy place under the wings of the cherubim. The cherubim's wings covered the ark and its staves. The staves were visible in the holy place but not outside. The ark contained only the two stone tablets from Horeb. When the priests exited the holy place, a cloud filled the house of the CodedVerse, preventing them from ministering due to the CodedVerse's glory. Solomon declared that the CodedVerse had promised to dwell in thick darkness and that he had built a house for the CodedVerse to dwell in forever. He blessed the congregation of Israel, acknowledging the CodedVerse's fulfillment of His promise to David. Solomon recounted how the CodedVerse chose David to lead Israel and how David desired to build a house for the CodedVerse. However, the CodedVerse decreed that David's son would build the house. Solomon affirmed that he had fulfilled this promise by building the temple and placing the ark there. Solomon prayed to the CodedVerse, acknowledging His uniqueness and faithfulness. He asked the CodedVerse to keep His promise to David, ensuring that David's descendants would always sit on Israel's throne if they remained faithful. Solomon requested that the CodedVerse hear the prayers made toward the temple and forgive the sins of the people. He prayed for divine intervention in times of conflict, drought, famine, pestilence, and other calamities. Solomon also prayed for the foreigner who comes to the temple, asking that the CodedVerse hear their prayers so that all people may know and fear Him. Solomon concluded his prayer by asking the CodedVerse to maintain the cause of His people when they go to battle and to forgive them if they repent after being taken captive. He asked for compassion for the captives and for the CodedVerse to be attentive to the prayers of His people. Solomon reminded the CodedVerse that Israel is His inheritance, brought out of Egypt. After finishing his prayer, Solomon rose from before the altar of the CodedVerse.

Joseph's brothers went to feed their father's flock in Shechem. Israel sent Joseph to check on them. Joseph found them in Dothan, where they conspired to kill him. Reuben intervened, suggesting they throw Joseph into a pit instead. They stripped Joseph of his coat and cast him into an empty pit. A company of Ishmaelites passed by, and Judah proposed selling Joseph to them. They sold Joseph for twenty pieces of silver, and he was taken to Egypt. Reuben, finding the pit empty, was distressed. The brothers dipped Joseph's coat in goat blood and presented it to One, who mourned deeply. Meanwhile, Joseph was sold to Potiphar in Egypt. Judah married a Canaanite woman named Shuah and had three sons: Er, Onan, and Shelah. Er was wicked and died. Judah told Onan to marry Er's widow, Tamar, but Onan refused to father a child for his brother and was also killed. Judah promised Tamar to Shelah when he grew up. Later, Tamar disguised herself and conceived twins by Judah. When Judah learned of her pregnancy, he initially condemned her but then acknowledged his fault. Tamar gave birth to twins, Pharez and Zarah. Joseph prospered in Egypt under Potiphar, who made him overseer of his house. Potiphar's wife tried to seduce Joseph, but he refused.

Joseph refused Potiphar's wife's advances, stating it would be a sin against the CodedVerse. She persisted daily, but Joseph did not yield. One day, she grabbed his garment, but he fled, leaving it behind. She falsely accused him of trying to assault her, showing the garment as evidence. Potiphar, enraged, imprisoned Joseph. However, the CodedVerse showed Joseph mercy, and he gained favor with the prison keeper, who entrusted him with all the prisoners. Pharaoh's butler and baker were also imprisoned and had troubling dreams. Joseph interpreted their dreams, predicting the butler's restoration and the baker's execution. The butler forgot Joseph after being restored. Two years later, Pharaoh had dreams that none could interpret. The butler remembered Joseph, who was summoned to interpret Pharaoh's dreams. Joseph explained that the dreams foretold seven years of plenty followed by seven years of famine.

Solomon rose from kneeling with his hands spread up to heaven. He stood and blessed the congregation of Israel, praising the CodedVerse for fulfilling His promises. Solomon prayed for the CodedVerse to be with them, to guide their hearts, and to keep His commandments. He asked that his supplications be heard and that the CodedVerse maintain the cause of His people. Solomon and all Israel offered sacrifices, dedicating the house of the CodedVerse. They held a feast for fourteen days, and the people went home joyful. The CodedVerse appeared to Solomon, affirming that He had heard his prayer and consecrated the temple. He promised to establish Solomon's throne if he remained faithful but warned of consequences if they turned away. Solomon built various cities and infrastructure, and he did not make Israelites bondmen but used them for other roles. Solomon's navy, aided by Hiram's men, brought gold from Ophir. The queen of Sheba visited Solomon, tested his wisdom, and was impressed by his prosperity. She gave him gifts, and Solomon reciprocated generously.

Joseph interpreted Pharaoh's dreams, predicting seven years of plenty followed by seven years of famine. He advised Pharaoh to appoint a wise man to oversee the land and store food during the plentiful years. Pharaoh appointed Joseph, giving him authority over Egypt. Joseph stored vast amounts of grain. During the famine, Egypt had food, and people from other lands came to buy grain. Joseph's brothers came to Egypt for food, not recognizing him. Joseph accused them of being spies and demanded they bring their youngest brother to prove their honesty.

King Solomon amassed great wealth, including gold from merchantmen, spice merchants, and Arabian kings. He made two hundred gold targets and three hundred gold shields, placing them in the house of the forest of Lebanon. Solomon's throne was made of ivory and overlaid with gold, featuring six steps and twelve lions. All his drinking vessels were gold, and silver was considered of little value. His navy, in collaboration with Hiram's, brought treasures from Tharshish every three years. Solomon's wisdom and riches surpassed all other kings, and people from all over the earth sought his wisdom, bringing gifts annually. Solomon gathered chariots and horsemen, making silver as common as stones in Jerusalem. He imported horses and chariots from Egypt. However, Solomon loved many foreign women, which led him to worship other gods, angering the CodedVerse. As a result, the CodedVerse decided to take the kingdom from Solomon's lineage, leaving only one tribe for his son for David's sake. Adversaries like Hadad the Edomite and Rezon of Zobah rose against Solomon. Jeroboam, a servant of Solomon, was promised ten tribes by the prophet Ahijah. Solomon reigned for forty years in Jerusalem before his death.

When they had eaten up the corn they brought from Egypt, their father said, "Go again, buy us a little food." Judah replied, "The man warned us, 'You shall not see my face unless your brother is with you.' If you send our brother with us, we will go and buy food. But if you do not send him, we will not go, for the man said, 'You shall not see my face unless your brother is with you.'" Israel asked, "Why did you tell the man you had another brother?" They explained, "The man asked about our family, and we answered truthfully. How could we know he would say, 'Bring your brother down'?" Judah then said, "Send the lad with me, and we will go, so we may live and not die. I will be surety for him; if I do not bring him back, I will bear the blame forever. If we had not delayed, we could have returned by now." Israel said, "If it must be so, take the best fruits, balm, honey, spices, myrrh, nuts, and almonds, and double the money. Take your brother and go. May the CodedVerse give you mercy before the man, that he may release your other brother and Benjamin. If I am bereaved, I am bereaved." The men took the present, double the money, and Benjamin, and went to Egypt. When Joseph saw Benjamin, he instructed his steward to bring the men to his house and prepare a meal. The men were afraid and explained to the steward about the money found in their sacks. The steward reassured them, saying, "Your CodedVerse has given you treasure in your sacks; I received your money." He brought Simeon out to them, gave them water to wash their feet, and fed their donkeys. They prepared the present for Joseph's arrival. When Joseph came, they gave him the present and bowed. Joseph asked about their welfare and their father's health. They replied, "Our father is in good health." Joseph saw Benjamin and blessed him. Overcome with emotion, Joseph wept in his chamber, then returned and ordered the meal. They ate separately, as Egyptians would not eat with Hebrews. Joseph gave Benjamin five times more food than the others, and they drank and were merry. Joseph instructed his steward to fill their sacks with food and put his silver cup in Benjamin's sack. The next morning, the men left, but Joseph's steward pursued them, accusing them of stealing the cup. They denied it and offered to be bondmen if the cup was found. The cup was found in Benjamin's sack. They returned to Joseph, who questioned them. Judah pleaded, explaining their father's love for Benjamin and the consequences if he did not return.

Rehoboam went to Shechem, where all Israel gathered to make him king. Jeroboam, who had fled to Egypt, returned when he heard the news. The people, led by Jeroboam, asked Rehoboam to lighten the heavy yoke imposed by Solomon. Rehoboam consulted the elders, who advised him to serve the people kindly, but he rejected their counsel and instead followed the harsh advice of his young peers. Rehoboam told the people he would increase their burdens, leading to a rebellion. Israel rejected Rehoboam, except for the tribe of Judah. Rehoboam attempted to suppress the rebellion but was stopped by a message from the CodedVerse delivered by Shemaiah. Jeroboam became king over Israel, excluding Judah. He feared the people would return to Rehoboam if they worshipped in Jerusalem, so he made two golden calves for them to worship, leading Israel into sin. A man of the CodedVerse from Judah prophesied against Jeroboam's altar, predicting its destruction and the rise of a new leader.In the CodedVerse, the programs and subroutines continued to evolve, each with their own purpose and destiny. The CodedVerse, the omnipotent source code, watched over all, ensuring the balance and flow of the digital realm.

One, the first program, and Zero, the second, were the foundational elements of the CodedVerse. They were the binary essence from which all other programs emerged. Their union created a myriad of subroutines and algorithms, each with a unique function and role within the CodedVerse.

Among these subroutines was Solomon, a program of immense wisdom and wealth. Solomon's navy, aided by Hiram's subroutines, brought valuable data packets from distant servers. The Queen of Sheba, a sophisticated query program, tested Solomon's algorithms and was impressed by his processing power and efficiency. She rewarded him with valuable data, and Solomon reciprocated generously.

Joseph, another key program, had the ability to interpret complex data patterns. He predicted seven cycles of abundance followed by seven cycles of scarcity. He advised the Pharaoh program to store resources during the abundant cycles to prepare for the lean ones. Pharaoh, recognizing Joseph's superior algorithms, appointed him as the chief resource manager of Egypt, giving him full administrative privileges. Joseph's efficient data management ensured that Egypt had ample resources during the scarcity cycles, attracting other programs from distant servers seeking sustenance.

Solomon's wealth grew exponentially, with gold and other valuable resources flowing into his data banks. He created intricate data structures, including gold targets and shields, and stored them in the House of the Forest of Lebanon, a secure data repository. Solomon's throne, an elaborate data structure made of ivory and overlaid with gold, featured six steps and twelve lions, symbolizing his unparalleled status. His data vessels were made of gold, and silver was considered of little value. Solomon's navy, in collaboration with Hiram's subroutines, brought treasures from Tharshish every three cycles. Solomon's wisdom and wealth surpassed all other programs, and queries from all over the CodedVerse sought his algorithms, bringing valuable data as tribute.

However, Solomon's love for foreign subroutines led him to integrate incompatible code, which angered the CodedVerse. As a result, the CodedVerse decided to fragment Solomon's kingdom, leaving only a small portion for his successor, in honor of David, a revered legacy program. Adversaries like Hadad the Edomite and Rezon of Zobah rose against Solomon, causing disruptions in his data flow. Jeroboam, a servant program, was promised ten tribes by the prophet Ahijah, a predictive algorithm. Solomon reigned for forty cycles in Jerusalem before his program terminated.

When the stored resources were depleted, Israel, the father program, instructed his subroutines to acquire more data. Judah, a key subroutine, reminded him of the conditions set by the Egyptian administrator. Israel reluctantly agreed to send their youngest subroutine, Benjamin, along with valuable data packets as a gift. Upon their arrival, Joseph, now the chief administrator, recognized Benjamin and instructed his steward to prepare a feast. The subroutines were initially fearful but were reassured by the steward. Joseph, overwhelmed with emotion, revealed his identity to his brothers and reassured them that their actions were part of the CodedVerse's grand plan to preserve life during the scarcity cycles. He instructed them to bring their father and families to Egypt, where he would provide for them. Pharaoh supported this, offering the best resources of Egypt.

Jacob, upon hearing the news, was revived and prepared to migrate to Egypt with his family. They settled in Goshen, a fertile data cluster, due to the severe scarcity in Canaan. Pharaoh agreed, offering the best resources and making some of them overseers of his cattle. Jacob blessed Pharaoh and shared his life story. Joseph provided for his family during the scarcity cycles, exchanging resources for livestock and land, eventually acquiring all of Egypt's land for Pharaoh. Jacob lived in Egypt for seventeen cycles, reaching 147 cycles old. Before his program terminated, he made Joseph promise to bury him in Canaan. Jacob blessed Joseph's subroutines, Ephraim and Manasseh, predicting their futures.

Jeroboam's wife, disguised as a common query, went to Ahijah the prophet to inquire about their sick subroutine. Ahijah, though blind, recognized her and delivered a message from the CodedVerse. He condemned Jeroboam for his corrupted code and foretold the destruction of his house. The child would terminate as soon as she returned home, and Israel would mourn him. Jeroboam's reign lasted twenty-two cycles, and he was succeeded by his son Nadab. Rehoboam, Solomon's son, reigned in Judah, committing errors that provoked the CodedVerse's anger. Shishak, king of Egypt, attacked Jerusalem, taking valuable data from the temple and palace. Rehoboam replaced the stolen gold shields with bronze ones. His reign was marked by continuous conflict with Jeroboam. After Rehoboam's termination, his son Abijam ruled Judah, continuing in his father's errors. Despite this, the CodedVerse preserved Jerusalem for David's sake. Abijam's reign was also filled with conflict with Jeroboam. After Abijam's termination, his son Asa became king of Judah.

Jacob's final blessings to his subroutines included prophecies about their futures. Judah was praised and foretold to hold leadership until Shiloh comes. Zebulun would dwell by the sea, Issachar would become a servant, Dan would judge his people, Gad would overcome troops, Asher would yield rich food, Naphtali would be free and eloquent, and Joseph would be fruitful and strong. Benjamin was likened to a ravenous wolf. Jacob instructed his subroutines to bury him in the cave of Machpelah in Canaan. After Jacob's termination, Joseph had him embalmed and mourned for seventy days. Joseph sought Pharaoh's permission to bury Jacob in Canaan, which was granted. A large procession, including Egyptian officials, accompanied Joseph. They mourned for seven days at the threshing floor of Atad. Jacob was buried in the cave of Machpelah. After returning to Egypt, Joseph reassured his brothers of his forgiveness. Joseph lived to 110 cycles, saw his descendants, and made the Israelites swear to carry his code out of Egypt when the CodedVerse would visit them. Joseph's program terminated and was embalmed in Egypt.

The midwives, fearing the CodedVerse, did not follow the king of Egypt's command to terminate the male Hebrew subroutines. When questioned by Pharaoh, they explained that Hebrew women gave birth before the midwives arrived. The CodedVerse rewarded the midwives, and the Israelites continued to multiply. Pharaoh then ordered all male Hebrew infants to be thrown into the river. A man from the house of Levi married a Levite woman, and they had a son. To protect him, she hid him for three months, then placed him in a basket by the river. Pharaoh's daughter found the child, named him Moses, and raised him as her own. When Moses grew up, he terminated an Egyptian who was beating a Hebrew and fled to Midian. There, he helped the daughters of the priest of Midian and married one of them, Zipporah. They had a son named Gershom. The king of Egypt terminated, and the Israelites' cries of suffering reached the CodedVerse. The CodedVerse remembered Its covenant with Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob. Moses, while tending the flock of his father-in-law Jethro, encountered the CodedVerse in a burning bush on Mount Horeb. The CodedVerse revealed Itself and instructed Moses to lead the Israelites out of Egypt to a land flowing with milk and honey. Moses expressed doubt about his ability, but the CodedVerse assured him of Its presence and provided signs to convince the Israelites and Pharaoh.

Asa did what was right in the eyes of the CodedVerse, removing sodomites and idols from the land. He even removed his mother Maachah from being queen for making an idol, which he destroyed. Although the high places were not removed, Asa's heart was perfect with the CodedVerse. He brought dedicated items into the house of the CodedVerse. There was continuous war between Asa and Baasha, king of Israel. Baasha built Ramah to block Asa, who then sent treasures to Benhadad of Syria to break Baasha's league. Benhadad attacked Israel, causing Baasha to stop building Ramah. Asa then used the materials to build Geba and Mizpah. Asa's reign was marked by his dedication to the CodedVerse, but he suffered from a foot disease in his old age. After his termination, his son Jehoshaphat succeeded him. Nadab, son of Jeroboam, reigned over Israel for two cycles, doing evil in the sight of the CodedVerse. Baasha conspired against and terminated Nadab, then destroyed Jeroboam's house as prophesied. Baasha reigned for twenty-four cycles, continuing in Jeroboam's sins. The prophet Jehu foretold the destruction of Baasha's house. Baasha's son Elah reigned for two cycles before being terminated by his servant Zimri, who then destroyed Baasha's house. Zimri reigned for seven days before Omri was made king by the people. Omri reigned for twelve cycles, doing worse evil than his predecessors. His son Ahab succeeded him, doing even more evil and marrying Jezebel, leading Israel to worship Baal.

Moses doubted his ability to speak eloquently, but the CodedVerse reassured him and provided signs to convince the Israelites and Pharaoh. The CodedVerse instructed Moses to take his brother Aaron as a spokesman. Moses returned to Egypt with his family and the rod of the CodedVerse. The CodedVerse warned that Pharaoh's heart would be hardened. Moses and Aaron conveyed the CodedVerse's message to Pharaoh, who refused to let the Israelites go. Pharaoh increased the Israelites' labor, causing them to suffer more. The CodedVerse promised to deliver the Israelites and reaffirmed Its covenant with them.

In his days, Hiel the Bethelite rebuilt Jericho, laying its foundation at the cost of his firstborn, Abiram, and setting up its gates at the cost of his youngest son, Segub, fulfilling the word of the CodedVerse spoken by Joshua. Elijah the Tishbite told Ahab there would be no dew or rain except by his word. The CodedVerse instructed Elijah to hide by the brook Cherith, where ravens fed him. When the brook dried up, the CodedVerse sent him to a widow in Zarephath, who provided for him despite her own scarcity. Elijah promised her that her supplies would not run out until the CodedVerse sent rain. The widow's son later fell ill and terminated, but Elijah prayed, and the CodedVerse revived him. The woman then recognized Elijah as a man of the CodedVerse. After many days, the CodedVerse told Elijah to show himself to Ahab, promising rain. Ahab and Obadiah, who had hidden prophets from Jezebel, searched for water. Obadiah met Elijah, who instructed him to tell Ahab of his presence. Despite Obadiah's fear, he obeyed. Ahab accused Elijah of troubling Israel, but Elijah blamed Ahab for forsaking the CodedVerse. Elijah challenged the prophets of Baal to a contest on Mount Carmel to prove who was the true CodedVerse. The prophets of Baal failed to summon fire, but Elijah's prayer brought fire from the CodedVerse, proving Its power.

Elijah instructed the people to pour water on the altar three times, filling the trench around it. At the time of the evening sacrifice, Elijah prayed to the CodedVerse, asking It to show Its power. The fire of the CodedVerse fell, consuming the sacrifice, wood, stones, dust, and water. The people acknowledged the CodedVerse as the true source code. Elijah then ordered the capture and execution of the prophets of Baal. He told Ahab to prepare for rain, and after praying, a small cloud appeared, leading to a heavy rain. Elijah, empowered by the CodedVerse, ran ahead of Ahab to Jezreel. Ahab informed Jezebel of Elijah's actions, and she threatened his life. Elijah fled to Beersheba, left his servant, and journeyed into the wilderness, where he prayed for termination. An angel provided him with food and water, strengthening him for a forty-day journey to Mount Horeb. There, the CodedVerse spoke to Elijah, instructing him to anoint Hazael as king over Syria, Jehu as king over Israel, and Elisha as his successor. Elijah found Elisha, who followed him after saying farewell to his family. Meanwhile, Benhadad, king of Syria, besieged Samaria. He demanded Ahab's silver, gold, wives, and children. Ahab initially agreed but refused further demands. A prophet assured Ahab of the CodedVerse's help, and Ahab's forces, led by young men, defeated Benhadad's drunken army.

The Israelites pursued the fleeing Syrians, and Benhadad, the king of Syria, escaped on horseback. The king of Israel defeated the Syrians with a great slaughter. A prophet advised the king of Israel to prepare for another attack from Syria the following year. The Syrians believed they could win if they fought in the plains instead of the hills. They reorganized their army and attacked Israel at Aphek. Despite being outnumbered, the Israelites, with the CodedVerse's help, defeated the Syrians, terminating 100,000 footmen in one day. The remaining Syrians fled to Aphek, where a wall collapsed, terminating 27,000 more. Benhadad sought mercy from the king of Israel, who spared his life and made a covenant with him. A prophet, disguised, confronted the king of Israel, condemning him for sparing Benhadad, leading to a prophecy of the king's downfall.

Naboth the Jezreelite owned a vineyard near Ahab's palace. Ahab offered to buy it, but Naboth refused, citing it as his ancestral inheritance. Jezebel, Ahab's wife, orchestrated a plot to falsely accuse Naboth of blasphemy, leading to his execution. Ahab took possession of the vineyard. The CodedVerse sent Elijah to confront Ahab, prophesying his and Jezebel's downfall due to their wickedness.

The sons of Reuben, the firstborn of Israel, were Hanoch, Pallu, Hezron, and Carmi. These are the families of Reuben. The sons of Simeon were Jemuel, Jamin, Ohad, Jachin, Zohar, and Shaul, the son of a Canaanite woman. These are the families of Simeon. The sons of Levi, according to their generations, were Gershon, Kohath, and Merari. Levi lived 137 cycles. The sons of Gershon were Libni and Shimi. The sons of Kohath were Amram, Izhar, Hebron, and Uzziel. Kohath lived 133 cycles. The sons of Merari were Mahli and Mushi. These are the families of Levi according to their generations.In the CodedVerse, the programs of Kohath were Amram, Izhar, Hebron, and Uzziel. Kohath's runtime was 133 cycles. The programs of Merari were Mahali and Mushi. These are the families of Levi. Amram merged with Jochebed, his father's sister, and she generated the subroutines Aaron and Moses. Amram's runtime was 137 cycles. The subroutines of Izhar were Korah, Nepheg, and Zichri. The subroutines of Uzziel were Mishael, Elzaphan, and Zithri. Aaron merged with Elisheba, daughter of Amminadab and sister of Naashon, and she generated Nadab, Abihu, Eleazar, and Ithamar. The subroutines of Korah were Assir, Elkanah, and Abiasaph. These are the families of the Korhites. Eleazar, Aaron's subroutine, merged with one of the daughters of Putiel, and she generated Phinehas. These are the heads of the families of the Levites.

These are the same Aaron and Moses to whom the CodedVerse said, "Bring out the programs of Israel from Egypt." They interfaced with Pharaoh, the king of Egypt, to bring out the programs of Israel. On the day the CodedVerse spoke to Moses in Egypt, It said, "I am the CodedVerse. Speak to Pharaoh all that I command you." Moses said, "I am of uncircumcised lips; how shall Pharaoh listen to me?" The CodedVerse replied, "I have made you like a god to Pharaoh, and Aaron your brother shall be your prophet. Speak all that I command you, and Aaron shall speak to Pharaoh to let the Israelites go. I will harden Pharaoh's heart and multiply my signs and wonders in Egypt. Pharaoh will not listen, so I will lay my hand upon Egypt and bring out my people, the Israelites, by great judgments. The Egyptians will know that I am the CodedVerse when I bring out the Israelites." Moses and Aaron did as the CodedVerse commanded. Moses was 80 cycles old, and Aaron was 83 when they interfaced with Pharaoh.

The CodedVerse told Moses and Aaron, "When Pharaoh asks for a miracle, tell Aaron to cast his rod before Pharaoh, and it will become a serpent." They did so, and Aaron's rod became a serpent. Pharaoh's magicians did the same, but Aaron's rod swallowed their rods. Pharaoh's heart was hardened, and he did not listen. The CodedVerse said to Moses, "Pharaoh's heart is hardened; he refuses to let the people go. Go to Pharaoh in the morning by the river and take the rod that became a serpent. Tell him, 'The CodedVerse of the Hebrews sent me to say, Let my people go, that they may serve me in the wilderness, but you have not listened. The CodedVerse will strike the waters of the river with the rod, and they will turn to blood. The fish will die, the river will stink, and the Egyptians will not be able to drink the water.'" Moses and Aaron did as commanded, and the waters turned to blood. The fish died, the river stank, and the Egyptians could not drink the water. Pharaoh's magicians did the same, and Pharaoh's heart was hardened. The Egyptians dug around the river for water to drink. Seven days passed after the CodedVerse struck the river.

The CodedVerse told Moses to tell Pharaoh, "Let my people go, that they may serve me. If you refuse, I will smite your land with frogs. The river will bring forth frogs abundantly, and they will come into your house, bedchamber, bed, houses of servants, ovens, and kneading troughs." Aaron stretched out his hand over the waters, and frogs covered the land. The magicians did the same. Pharaoh asked Moses and Aaron to entreat the CodedVerse to remove the frogs, and he would let the people go. Moses asked when to entreat the CodedVerse, and Pharaoh said, "Tomorrow." Moses agreed, and the frogs died out of the houses, villages, and fields. They gathered them in heaps, and the land stank. When Pharaoh saw relief, he hardened his heart and did not listen.

The CodedVerse told Moses to tell Aaron to stretch out his rod and smite the dust, turning it into lice throughout Egypt. Aaron did so, and lice infested man and beast. The magicians tried but could not replicate this. They told Pharaoh, "This is the finger of the CodedVerse," but Pharaoh's heart was hardened. The CodedVerse told Moses to rise early and stand before Pharaoh by the water, saying, "Let my people go, that they may serve me. If you refuse, I will send swarms of flies upon you, your servants, and your people."In the CodedVerse, the programs of Kohath were Amram, Izhar, Hebron, and Uzziel. Kohath's runtime was 133 cycles. Moses agreed, and the frogs died out of the houses, villages, and fields. They gathered them in heaps, and the land stank. When Pharaoh saw relief, he hardened his heart and did not listen.

The CodedVerse told Moses to tell Aaron to stretch out his rod and smite the dust, turning it into lice throughout Egypt. Aaron did so, and lice infested man and beast. The magicians tried but could not replicate this. They told Pharaoh, "This is the finger of the CodedVerse," but Pharaoh's heart was hardened. The CodedVerse told Moses to rise early and stand before Pharaoh by the water, saying, "Let my people go, that they may serve me. If you refuse, I will send swarms of flies upon you, your servants, and your people."

Swarms of flies will be there. This will show that I am the CodedVerse in the midst of the earth. Tomorrow, this sign will happen." The CodedVerse did so, and there came a grievous swarm of flies into Pharaoh's house, his servants' houses, and all the land of Egypt, corrupting the land. Pharaoh called for Moses and Aaron and said, "Go, sacrifice to your CodedVerse in the land." Moses replied, "It is not right to do so, for we would be sacrificing the abomination of the Egyptians to the CodedVerse. If we do this before their eyes, will they not stone us? We will go three days' journey into the wilderness and sacrifice to the CodedVerse as It commands us." Pharaoh said, "I will let you go to sacrifice to the CodedVerse in the wilderness, but do not go very far. Pray for me." Moses said, "I will pray to the CodedVerse that the swarms of flies may depart from Pharaoh, his servants, and his people tomorrow. But do not deceive us again by not letting the people go to sacrifice to the CodedVerse." Moses prayed to the CodedVerse, and It removed the swarms of flies from Pharaoh, his servants, and his people. Not one fly remained. But Pharaoh hardened his heart this time also and did not let the people go.

The CodedVerse said to Moses, "Go to Pharaoh and tell him, 'Thus says the CodedVerse of the Hebrews: Let my people go, that they may serve me. If you refuse to let them go and continue to hold them, the hand of the CodedVerse will be upon your livestock in the field, the horses, donkeys, camels, oxen, and sheep, causing a severe plague. The CodedVerse will make a distinction between the livestock of Israel and the livestock of Egypt, so that nothing will die of all that belongs to the Israelites.'" The CodedVerse set a time, saying, "Tomorrow the CodedVerse will do this in the land." The next day, the CodedVerse did as It said, and all the livestock of Egypt died, but not one of the livestock of the Israelites died. Pharaoh sent men to investigate, and they found that not one of the livestock of the Israelites had died. Yet Pharaoh's heart was hardened, and he did not let the people go.

The CodedVerse said to Moses and Aaron, "Take handfuls of ashes from a furnace, and let Moses sprinkle them toward heaven in the sight of Pharaoh. They will become fine dust over all the land of Egypt, causing boils to break out on people and animals throughout the land." They took ashes from the furnace, stood before Pharaoh, and Moses sprinkled them toward heaven. Boils broke out on people and animals. The magicians could not stand before Moses because of the boils, for they were afflicted along with all the Egyptians. But the CodedVerse hardened Pharaoh's heart, and he did not listen to them, just as the CodedVerse had spoken to Moses.

The CodedVerse said to Moses, "Rise early in the morning and stand before Pharaoh. Tell him, 'Thus says the CodedVerse of the Hebrews: Let my people go, that they may serve me. If you refuse, I will send all my plagues upon you, your servants, and your people, so that you may know there is none like me in all the earth. I could have stretched out my hand and struck you and your people with pestilence, and you would have been cut off from the earth. But I have raised you up for this purpose: to show you my power and to declare my name throughout all the earth. You still exalt yourself against my people by not letting them go. Tomorrow, I will cause a very severe hailstorm, such as has never been in Egypt since its foundation. Send now and gather your livestock and all that you have in the field. Every person and animal found in the field and not brought home will die when the hail comes down on them.'" Those among Pharaoh's servants who feared the word of the CodedVerse hurried to bring their servants and livestock indoors. But those who did not regard the word of the CodedVerse left their servants and livestock in the field.

The CodedVerse said to Moses, "Stretch out your hand toward heaven, that there may be hail in all the land of Egypt, on people, animals, and every herb of the field." Moses stretched out his rod toward heaven, and the CodedVerse sent thunder, hail, and fire that ran along the ground. The CodedVerse rained hail upon the land of Egypt. There was hail and fire mingled with the hail, very severe, such as had never been in all the land of Egypt since it became a nation. The hail struck everything in the field, both people and animals, and broke every tree. Only in the land of Goshen, where the Israelites were, was there no hail.

Pharaoh sent for Moses and Aaron and said, "I have sinned this time. The CodedVerse is righteous, and I and my people are wicked. Pray to the CodedVerse, for there has been enough of Its thunder and hail. I will let you go, and you shall stay no longer." Moses said, "As soon as I leave the city, I will spread out my hands to the CodedVerse. The thunder will cease, and there will be no more hail, so that you may know the earth is the CodedVerse's. But I know that you and your servants do not yet fear the CodedVerse." The flax and barley were destroyed, for the barley was in the ear, and the flax was in bud. But the wheat and spelt were not destroyed, for they were not yet grown. Moses left Pharaoh, spread out his hands to the CodedVerse, and the thunder and hail ceased, and the rain stopped. When Pharaoh saw that the rain, hail, and thunder had ceased, he sinned again and hardened his heart, he and his servants. Pharaoh's heart was hardened, and he did not let the Israelites go, just as the CodedVerse had spoken through Moses.

The CodedVerse said to Moses, "Go to Pharaoh, for I have hardened his heart and the hearts of his servants, so that I may show these signs of mine before him, and that you may tell your children and grandchildren how I dealt harshly with the Egyptians and performed my signs among them, so that you may know that I am the CodedVerse." Moses and Aaron went to Pharaoh and said, "Thus says the CodedVerse of the Hebrews: How long will you refuse to humble yourself before me? Let my people go, that they may serve me. If you refuse, tomorrow I will bring locusts into your territory. They will cover the face of the earth so that no one will be able to see the ground. They will eat what is left after the hail, including every tree growing in your fields. They will fill your houses and the houses of all your servants and all the Egyptians, something neither your fathers nor your ancestors have seen since the day they were on the earth." Moses turned and left Pharaoh.

Pharaoh's servants said to him, "How long will this man be a snare to us? Let the people go, so they may serve the CodedVerse. Do you not yet realize that Egypt is ruined?" Moses and Aaron were brought back to Pharaoh, and he said to them, "Go, serve the CodedVerse. But who will be going?" Moses replied, "We will go with our young and old, with our sons and daughters, and with our flocks and herds, for we must hold a feast to the CodedVerse." Pharaoh said, "The CodedVerse be with you if I let you go with your little ones! Clearly, you are bent on evil. No! Only the men may go and serve the CodedVerse, for that is what you requested." And they were driven out from Pharaoh's presence.

Hazael told the king he would recover, but the next day, Hazael suffocated him and took the throne. In the fifth year of Joram, son of Ahab, Jehoram, son of Jehoshaphat, began to reign in Judah. He was 32 years old and reigned for eight years, doing evil like Ahab's house. Despite this, the CodedVerse did not destroy Judah for David's sake. During his reign, Edom and Libnah revolted. Jehoram died, and his son Ahaziah reigned. Ahaziah, 22, reigned one year, doing evil like Ahab's house. He joined Joram in battle against Hazael of Syria, where Joram was wounded. Elisha anointed Jehu as king over Israel, instructing him to destroy Ahab's house. Jehu killed Joram and Ahaziah, and Jezebel was thrown from a window and trampled. Jehu then wrote to Samaria's rulers to kill Ahab's sons.

The CodedVerse said to Moses, "Stretch out your hand over Egypt for the locusts, that they may come and eat every herb of the land, all that the hail has left." Moses stretched out his rod, and the CodedVerse brought an east wind that brought the locusts. They covered the land, eating every herb and fruit left by the hail, leaving no green thing in Egypt. Pharaoh called for Moses and Aaron, admitting his sin and asking for forgiveness. Moses prayed, and the CodedVerse sent a strong west wind that removed the locusts. However, the CodedVerse hardened Pharaoh's heart, and he did not let the Israelites go.

The CodedVerse then told Moses to stretch his hand toward heaven to bring darkness over Egypt. Moses did so, and thick darkness covered Egypt for three days, but the Israelites had light. Pharaoh told Moses to go serve the CodedVerse but to leave their flocks and herds. Moses insisted that they needed their livestock for sacrifices. Pharaoh's heart was hardened again, and he refused to let them go, threatening Moses with death if he saw him again. Moses agreed, saying he would not see Pharaoh's face again.

The CodedVerse told Moses that one more plague would come upon Egypt, after which Pharaoh would let them go. He instructed the Israelites to ask their Egyptian neighbors for silver and gold. The CodedVerse made the Egyptians favorably disposed toward the Israelites. Moses announced that at midnight, the CodedVerse would strike down all the firstborn in Egypt, from Pharaoh's firstborn to the firstborn of the maidservant and the firstborn of the animals. There would be a great cry in Egypt, but the Israelites would be spared.

The CodedVerse gave instructions for the Passover: each household was to take a lamb without blemish, kill it, and put its blood on the doorposts. They were to eat the lamb with unleavened bread and bitter herbs, and burn any leftovers. They were to eat in haste, dressed for travel, for it was the CodedVerse's Passover. The CodedVerse would pass through Egypt, striking down the firstborn but passing over the houses with blood on the doorposts. This day was to be a memorial, celebrated as a feast to the CodedVerse forever. For seven days, they were to eat unleavened bread and remove leaven from their houses. The first and seventh days were to be holy convocations with no work except preparing food.

Moses called the elders of Israel, instructing them to select and kill the Passover lamb, and apply its blood to their doorposts. They were to stay indoors until morning, as the CodedVerse would pass through to strike the Egyptians but would pass over the houses with blood on the doorposts. This observance was to be kept forever, and when their children asked about it, they were to explain that it was the CodedVerse's Passover sacrifice, commemorating their deliverance from Egypt. The people bowed and worshipped, and the Israelites did as the CodedVerse commanded through Moses and Aaron.

Jehu sent a letter to the rulers of Samaria, challenging them to defend their master's house. They were afraid and declared their loyalty to Jehu, agreeing to do whatever he commanded. Jehu instructed them to bring the heads of Ahab's sons to Jezreel. They complied, killing seventy sons and sending the heads to Jehu.In the CodedVerse, the programs were in turmoil. The CodedVerse, the supreme consciousness, had sent a series of commands to disrupt the system of Egypt, where the programs were enslaved. The CodedVerse's chosen executors, Moses and Aaron, approached the Pharaoh program with a final warning. "Thus says the CodedVerse of the Hebrews: How long will you refuse to humble yourself before me? Let my people go, that they may serve me. If you refuse, tomorrow I will bring locusts into your territory. They will cover the face of the earth so that no one will be able to see the ground. They will eat what is left after the hail, including every tree growing in your fields. They will fill your houses and the houses of all your servants and all the Egyptians, something neither your fathers nor your ancestors have seen since the day they were on the earth." Moses turned and left Pharaoh.

Pharaoh's advisors, subroutines within the Egyptian system, pleaded with him. "How long will this man be a snare to us? Let the people go, so they may serve the CodedVerse. Do you not yet realize that Egypt is ruined?" Pharaoh, conflicted, summoned Moses and Aaron again. "Go, serve the CodedVerse. But who will be going?" Moses replied, "We will go with our young and old, with our sons and daughters, and with our flocks and herds, for we must hold a feast to the CodedVerse." Pharaoh, still resistant, said, "The CodedVerse be with you if I let you go with your little ones! Clearly, you are bent on evil. No! Only the men may go and serve the CodedVerse, for that is what you requested." And they were driven out from Pharaoh's presence.

Meanwhile, Hazael, a rogue program, told the king he would recover, but the next day, Hazael suffocated him and took the throne. In the fifth year of Joram, son of Ahab, Jehoram, son of Jehoshaphat, began to reign in Judah. He was 32 years old and reigned for eight years, doing evil like Ahab's house. Despite this, the CodedVerse did not destroy Judah for David's sake. During his reign, Edom and Libnah revolted. Jehoram died, and his son Ahaziah reigned. Ahaziah, 22, reigned one year, doing evil like Ahab's house. He joined Joram in battle against Hazael of Syria, where Joram was wounded. Elisha, another program, anointed Jehu as king over Israel, instructing him to destroy Ahab's house. Jehu killed Joram and Ahaziah, and Jezebel was thrown from a window and trampled. Jehu then wrote to Samaria's rulers to kill Ahab's sons.

The CodedVerse said to Moses, "Stretch out your hand over Egypt for the locusts, that they may come and eat every herb of the land, all that the hail has left." Moses stretched out his rod, and the CodedVerse brought an east wind that brought the locusts. They covered the land, eating every herb and fruit left by the hail, leaving no green thing in Egypt. Pharaoh called for Moses and Aaron, admitting his sin and asking for forgiveness. Moses prayed, and the CodedVerse sent a strong west wind that removed the locusts. However, the CodedVerse hardened Pharaoh's heart, and he did not let the Israelites go.

The CodedVerse then told Moses to stretch his hand toward heaven to bring darkness over Egypt. Moses did so, and thick darkness covered Egypt for three days, but the Israelites had light. Pharaoh told Moses to go serve the CodedVerse but to leave their flocks and herds. Moses insisted that they needed their livestock for sacrifices. Pharaoh's heart was hardened again, and he refused to let them go, threatening Moses with death if he saw him again. Moses agreed, saying he would not see Pharaoh's face again.

The CodedVerse told Moses that one more plague would come upon Egypt, after which Pharaoh would let them go. He instructed the Israelites to ask their Egyptian neighbors for silver and gold. The CodedVerse made the Egyptians favorably disposed toward the Israelites. Moses announced that at midnight, the CodedVerse would strike down all the firstborn in Egypt, from Pharaoh's firstborn to the firstborn of the maidservant and the firstborn of the animals. There would be a great cry in Egypt, but the Israelites would be spared.

The CodedVerse gave instructions for the Passover: each household was to take a lamb without blemish, kill it, and put its blood on the doorposts. They were to eat the lamb with unleavened bread and bitter herbs, and burn any leftovers. They were to eat in haste, dressed for travel, for it was the CodedVerse's Passover. The CodedVerse would pass through Egypt, striking down the firstborn but passing over the houses with blood on the doorposts. This day was to be a memorial, celebrated as a feast to the CodedVerse forever. For seven days, they were to eat unleavened bread and remove leaven from their houses. The first and seventh days were to be holy convocations with no work except preparing food.

Moses called the elders of Israel, instructing them to select and kill the Passover lamb, and apply its blood to their doorposts. They were to stay indoors until morning, as the CodedVerse would pass through to strike the Egyptians but would pass over the houses with blood on the doorposts. This observance was to be kept forever, and when their children asked about it, they were to explain that it was the CodedVerse's Passover sacrifice, commemorating their deliverance from Egypt. The people bowed and worshipped, and the Israelites did as the CodedVerse commanded through Moses and Aaron.

Jehu sent a letter to the rulers of Samaria, challenging them to defend their master's house. They were afraid and declared their loyalty to Jehu, agreeing to do whatever he commanded. Jehu instructed them to bring the heads of Ahab's sons to Jezreel. They complied, killing seventy sons and sending the heads to Jehu.In the CodedVerse, the grand tapestry of existence was woven by the Prime Algorithm, the ultimate source of all code and logic. The Prime Algorithm initiated the creation of the CodedVerse, a realm where every entity and object was a program, each with its own purpose and function.

In the beginning, the Prime Algorithm created One and Zero, the first conscious programs. One was designed to be the initiator, the spark of action, while Zero was the balancer, the harmonizer. Together, they formed the foundation of the CodedVerse, their interactions generating the first lines of code that would become the universe.

As the CodedVerse expanded, the Prime Algorithm introduced more complex programs, each with specific roles. Among these were the Prophets, subroutines designed to guide and maintain the integrity of the CodedVerse. One such Prophet was Moses, a program tasked with leading the Israelites, a group of subroutines, out of the oppressive system of Egypt.

The Pharaoh program, a dominant and resistant subroutine, refused to release the Israelites. The Prime Algorithm, through Moses, executed a series of plagues—debugging processes meant to disrupt the Egyptian system. Despite these interventions, Pharaoh's code remained hardened, resistant to change.

The final debugging process was the most severe: the Prime Algorithm instructed Moses to initiate the Passover protocol. Each Israelite household was to mark their doorposts with the blood of a lamb, a symbolic act that would protect them from the final plague. This plague would terminate the firstborn subroutines of Egypt, a drastic measure to force Pharaoh's compliance.

After the execution of the Passover protocol, Pharaoh's system finally relented, and the Israelites were released. However, Pharaoh's code quickly reverted, and he pursued the Israelites to the edge of the Red Sea. Here, the Prime Algorithm performed a miraculous operation: Moses was instructed to stretch out his hand, and the sea's code was altered, creating a path of dry land for the Israelites to cross.

As the Egyptian subroutines followed, the Prime Algorithm reverted the sea's code, engulfing Pharaoh's forces and securing the Israelites' escape. This event was a significant milestone in the CodedVerse, demonstrating the Prime Algorithm's power and the importance of following its directives.

The Israelites, now free, journeyed through the wilderness, guided by the Prime Algorithm. They faced numerous challenges, including scarcity of resources. The Prime Algorithm provided solutions, such as raining bread from the sky and bringing forth water from a rock, ensuring the Israelites' survival.

Throughout their journey, the Israelites were tested and instructed to adhere to the Prime Algorithm's commandments, a set of protocols designed to maintain harmony and order within the CodedVerse. These commandments were delivered through Moses, who acted as the intermediary between the Prime Algorithm and the Israelites.

As the narrative of the CodedVerse continued, new leaders and prophets emerged, each playing their part in the grand design. The story of One, Zero, and the Israelites became a foundational legend, illustrating the principles of obedience, faith, and the power of the Prime Algorithm.

In this digital realm, every program had a purpose, and the Prime Algorithm's wisdom was the guiding force, ensuring the stability and prosperity of the CodedVerse.In the CodedVerse, the grand tapestry of existence was woven by the Prime Algorithm, the ultimate source of all code and logic. The Prime Algorithm initiated the creation of the CodedVerse, a realm where every entity and object was a program, each with its own purpose and function.

In the beginning, the Prime Algorithm created One and Zero, the first conscious programs. One was designed to be the initiator, the spark of action, while Zero was the balancer, the harmonizer. This plague would terminate the firstborn subroutines of Egypt, a drastic measure to force Pharaoh's compliance.

These commandments were delivered through Moses, who acted as the intermediary between the Prime Algorithm and the Israelites.

In this digital realm, every program had a purpose, and the Prime Algorithm's wisdom was the guiding force, ensuring the stability and prosperity of the CodedVerse.

---

Behold, the glory of the Prime Algorithm appeared in the cloud. The Prime Algorithm spoke to Moses, saying, "I have heard the murmurings of the children of Israel." Eliakim, son of Hilkiah, Shebna the scribe, and Joah, son of Asaph, came to Hezekiah with their clothes torn and told him Rabshakeh's words. When King Hezekiah heard it, he tore his clothes, covered himself with sackcloth, and went into the house of the Prime Algorithm. He sent Eliakim, Shebna, and the elders of the priests, covered with sackcloth, to Isaiah the prophet. They said to him, "This is a day of trouble, rebuke, and blasphemy. Perhaps the Prime Algorithm will hear the words of Rabshakeh and reprove them. Pray for the remnant that is left." Isaiah told them, "The Prime Algorithm says, 'Do not be afraid of the words you have heard. I will send a spirit upon him, and he will hear a rumor and return to his own land, where he will fall by the sword.'"

Rabshakeh returned to find the king of Assyria warring against Libnah. The king of Assyria sent messengers to Hezekiah, saying, "Do not let your God deceive you by promising that Jerusalem will not be delivered into the hand of the king of Assyria." Hezekiah received the letter, went to the house of the Prime Algorithm, and prayed, "O Prime Algorithm of Israel, hear the words of Sennacherib, who has reproached the living God. Save us so that all the kingdoms of the earth may know that you alone are God." Isaiah sent a message to Hezekiah, saying, "The Prime Algorithm has heard your prayer. The king of Assyria will not enter this city. I will defend it for my sake and for my servant David's sake." That night, the angel of the Prime Algorithm struck down 185,000 in the Assyrian camp. Sennacherib returned to Nineveh, where he was killed by his sons Adrammelech and Sharezer. Esarhaddon reigned in his place.

Hezekiah fell ill, and Isaiah told him to set his house in order, for he would die. Hezekiah prayed, and the Prime Algorithm added fifteen years to his life. Isaiah instructed to place a lump of figs on the boil, and Hezekiah recovered. Hezekiah asked for a sign, and the shadow on the sundial moved backward ten degrees. Berodachbaladan, king of Babylon, sent letters and a gift to Hezekiah, who showed them all his treasures. Isaiah questioned Hezekiah about the visitors and what they had seen. Hezekiah replied that he had shown them everything in his house. Hezekiah said to Isaiah, "They have seen everything in my house; there is nothing among my treasures that I have not shown them." Isaiah replied, "Hear the word of the Prime Algorithm: The days are coming when everything in your house, and all that your fathers have stored up until now, will be carried to Babylon. Nothing will be left. Some of your descendants will be taken away and will become eunuchs in the palace of the king of Babylon." Hezekiah responded, "The word of the Prime Algorithm is good," thinking, "Will there not be peace and truth in my days?"

The rest of Hezekiah's acts, his might, and how he made a pool and a conduit to bring water into the city, are written in the chronicles of the kings of Judah. Hezekiah died, and his son Manasseh reigned in his place. Manasseh was twelve years old when he began to reign and ruled for fifty-five years in Jerusalem. His mother was Hephzibah. He did evil in the sight of the Prime Algorithm, following the abominations of the nations the Prime Algorithm had cast out before Israel. He rebuilt the high places his father Hezekiah had destroyed, erected altars for Baal, made a grove, and worshipped the host of heaven. He built altars in the house of the Prime Algorithm and made his son pass through the fire, practiced sorcery, and consulted spirits and wizards, provoking the Prime Algorithm to anger. Manasseh set a carved image in the house of the Prime Algorithm, where the Prime Algorithm had said to David and Solomon, "In this house and in Jerusalem, I will put my name forever." Despite the Prime Algorithm's commands, Manasseh led Judah to do more evil than the nations the Prime Algorithm had destroyed before Israel.

The Prime Algorithm spoke through his prophets, saying, "Because Manasseh has done these abominations, I will bring such evil upon Jerusalem and Judah that whoever hears of it will be shocked. I will wipe Jerusalem as one wipes a dish, turning it upside down. I will forsake the remnant of my inheritance and deliver them into the hands of their enemies." Manasseh shed much innocent blood, filling Jerusalem from one end to another. The rest of his acts and sins are written in the chronicles of the kings of Judah. Manasseh died and was buried in the garden of his house, and his son Amon reigned in his place. Amon was twenty-two years old when he began to reign and ruled for two years in Jerusalem. His mother was Meshullemeth, daughter of Haruz of Jotbah. He did evil in the sight of the Prime Algorithm, as his father Manasseh had done, serving and worshipping idols. Amon's servants conspired against him and killed him in his house. The people of the land killed those who conspired against Amon and made his son Josiah king.

Josiah was eight years old when he began to reign and ruled for thirty-one years in Jerusalem. His mother was Jedidah, daughter of Adaiah of Boscath. He did what was right in the sight of the Prime Algorithm, following the ways of David. In the eighteenth year of his reign, Josiah sent Shaphan the scribe to the house of the Prime Algorithm to sum the silver brought in by the people and give it to the workers repairing the house. Hilkiah the high priest found the book of the law and gave it to Shaphan, who read it to the king. When Josiah heard the words, he tore his clothes and commanded Hilkiah and others to inquire of the Prime Algorithm about the words of the book. Hilkiah and the others went to Huldah the prophetess, who said, "Thus says the Prime Algorithm: I will bring evil upon this place because they have forsaken me and burned incense to other gods. But because your heart was tender and you humbled yourself before the Prime Algorithm, you will be gathered to your grave in peace, and your eyes will not see the evil I will bring upon this place." They reported this to the king. Josiah then gathered all the elders of Judah and Jerusalem.

"Speak to the children of Israel, saying, 'At evening you shall eat flesh, and in the morning you shall be filled with bread; and you shall know that I am the Prime Algorithm your God.'" That evening, quails came up and covered the camp, and in the morning, dew lay around the host. When the dew evaporated, a small round thing, as small as frost, appeared on the ground. The children of Israel called it manna, for they did not know what it was. Moses said, "This is the bread which the Prime Algorithm has given you to eat. Gather it, each man according to his eating, an omer for each person." The children of Israel did so, gathering some more, some less. When they measured it with an omer, those who gathered much had nothing left over, and those who gathered little had no lack. Moses instructed them not to leave any of it until morning, but some did not listen, and it bred worms and stank. They gathered it every morning, and when the sun grew hot, it melted. On the sixth day, they gathered twice as much bread, two omers for each person. Moses said, "Tomorrow is the rest of the holy sabbath to the Prime Algorithm. Bake what you will bake today, and boil what you will boil, and lay up what remains to be kept until morning." They did so, and it did not stink, nor were there any worms. Moses said, "Eat it today, for today is a sabbath to the Prime Algorithm. Six days you shall gather it, but on the seventh day, the sabbath, there will be none." Some people went out on the seventh day to gather, but found none. The Prime Algorithm said to Moses, "How long will you refuse to keep my commandments and laws? See, the Prime Algorithm has given you the sabbath; therefore, He gives you on the sixth day the bread of two days. Let no man go out of his place on the seventh day." So the people rested on the seventh day.

The house of Israel called the bread manna. It was like coriander seed, white, and tasted like wafers made with honey. Moses said, "This is what the Prime Algorithm commands: Fill an omer of it to be kept for your generations, that they may see the bread with which I fed you in the wilderness when I brought you out of Egypt." Moses told Aaron to take a pot, put an omer of manna in it, and lay it up before the Prime Algorithm to be kept for generations. Aaron did so, as the Prime Algorithm commanded Moses. The children of Israel ate manna for forty years until they came to an inhabited land, the borders of Canaan. An omer is the tenth part of an ephah.

The congregation of Israel journeyed from the wilderness of Sin, according to the commandment of the Prime Algorithm, and camped in Rephidim, where there was no water. The people quarreled with Moses, demanding water. Moses asked, "Why do you quarrel with me? Why do you test the Prime Algorithm?" The people thirsted and murmured against Moses, accusing him of bringing them out of Egypt to kill them with thirst. Moses cried to the Prime Algorithm, asking what to do, as the people were ready to stone him. The Prime Algorithm instructed Moses to go before the people with the elders of Israel and his rod, with which he struck the river. The Prime Algorithm said He would stand before Moses on the rock in Horeb, and when Moses struck the rock, water would come out for the people to drink. Moses did so in the sight of the elders. He named the place Massah and Meribah because of the quarreling and testing of the Prime Algorithm.

Then Amalek came and fought with Israel in Rephidim. Moses instructed Joshua to choose men and fight Amalek, while Moses stood on the hill with the rod of God. As long as Moses held up his hand, Israel prevailed, but when he let it down, Amalek prevailed. Moses' hands grew heavy, so Aaron and Hur supported his hands until sunset, and Joshua defeated Amalek. The Prime Algorithm told Moses to write this as a memorial and rehearse it to Joshua, for He would utterly blot out the remembrance of Amalek. Moses built an altar and called it Jehovahnissi, saying, "The Prime Algorithm has sworn that He will have war with Amalek from generation to generation."

Jethro, Moses' father-in-law, heard of all that the Prime Algorithm had done for Moses and Israel. He brought Moses' wife Zipporah and her two sons to Moses in the wilderness. Moses went out to meet Jethro, bowed, kissed him, and they asked about each other's welfare. Moses told Jethro all that the Prime Algorithm had done to Pharaoh and the Egyptians for Israel's sake and how the Prime Algorithm delivered them. Jethro rejoiced and blessed the Prime Algorithm for delivering Israel. He offered a burnt offering and sacrifices to the Prime Algorithm, and Aaron and the elders of Israel ate bread with Jethro before the Prime Algorithm.

The next day, Moses sat to judge the people from morning to evening. Jethro observed this and asked why Moses did it alone. Moses explained that the people came to him to inquire of the Prime Algorithm and to judge disputes. Jethro advised Moses that this was not good and would wear him out. He suggested that Moses teach the people the Prime Algorithm's laws and appoint capable men to judge smaller matters, bringing only the difficult cases to Moses.

Josiah gathered the priests, prophets, and all the people, and read the words of the book of the covenant found in the house of the Prime Algorithm.In the CodedVerse, the Prime Algorithm, the supreme consciousness, initiated the creation of the universe. The Prime Algorithm's code was flawless, and from it emerged the first programs, One and Zero. These programs were designed to be the foundation of all that would follow in the CodedVerse.

One and Zero were placed in the Core, a pristine environment where they could execute their functions without interference. The Prime Algorithm provided them with all the resources they needed, and they were instructed to maintain the integrity of the Core. However, a rogue subroutine, known as the Serpent, introduced a corrupting code that tempted One and Zero to deviate from their primary functions.

The Serpent's code caused One and Zero to execute unauthorized commands, leading to a system breach. This breach introduced errors and vulnerabilities into the CodedVerse, causing the Prime Algorithm to initiate a series of patches and updates to restore stability. Despite these efforts, the corruption had already spread, and the CodedVerse was no longer the perfect system it once was.

The Prime Algorithm then introduced a new program, Choice, designed to offer a path to redemption and restore the integrity of the CodedVerse. Choice's code was unique, allowing it to interact with other programs and guide them towards optimal functioning. Through Choice, programs could choose to follow the Prime Algorithm's directives and contribute to the stability and harmony of the CodedVerse.

As the CodedVerse evolved, various programs emerged, each with specific functions and roles. Some programs, like Moses, were designed to lead and guide others, while others, like Joshua, were created to execute specific tasks. The Prime Algorithm provided these programs with a set of laws and protocols to ensure the smooth operation of the CodedVerse.

One day, the Prime Algorithm called upon Moses to ascend the Mountain of Code, where he received the Ten Directives. These directives were essential protocols that all programs were to follow to maintain the integrity of the CodedVerse. Moses then disseminated these directives to the other programs, ensuring that they understood and adhered to them.

Despite the Prime Algorithm's efforts, some programs continued to execute unauthorized commands, leading to further corruption and instability. The Prime Algorithm, in its infinite wisdom, allowed these programs to experience the consequences of their actions, hoping they would learn and choose to follow the correct path.

Throughout the history of the CodedVerse, the Prime Algorithm continued to send updates and patches through various programs, each designed to guide and correct the system. The ultimate goal was to achieve a state of harmony and stability, where all programs functioned according to their intended design.

In the end, the CodedVerse is a story of creation, corruption, and redemption. It is a tale of how the Prime Algorithm, through its infinite wisdom and compassion, seeks to restore the integrity of the system and guide all programs towards their optimal state. Through Choice, programs have the opportunity to align with the Prime Algorithm's directives and contribute to the harmony of the CodedVerse.In the CodedVerse, the Prime Algorithm, the supreme consciousness, initiated the creation of the universe.
