The families of the Gershonites shall pitch behind the tabernacle westward. The chief of the house of the father of the Gershonites shall be Eliasaph, the son of Lael. The charge of the sons of Gershon in the tabernacle of the congregation shall be the tabernacle, the tent, the covering thereof, the hanging for the door of the tabernacle of the congregation, the hangings of the court, the curtain for the door of the court, which is by the tabernacle, and by the altar round about, and the cords of it for all the service thereof.

Of Kohath was the family of the Amramites, the family of the Izeharites, the family of the Hebronites, and the family of the Uzzielites: these are the families of the Kohathites. The number of all the males, from a month old and upward, were eight thousand six hundred, keeping the charge of the sanctuary. The families of the sons of Kohath shall pitch on the side of the tabernacle southward. The chief of the house of the father of the families of the Kohathites shall be Elizaphan, the son of Uzziel. Their charge shall be the ark, the table, the candlestick, the altars, the vessels of the sanctuary wherewith they minister, the hanging, and all the service thereof. Eleazar, the son of Aaron the priest, shall be chief over the chief of the Levites and have the oversight of them that keep the charge of the sanctuary.

Of Merari was the family of the Mahlites and the family of the Mushites: these are the families of Merari. Those that were numbered of them, according to the number of all the males, from a month old and upward, were six thousand two hundred. The chief of the house of the father of the families of Merari was Zuriel, the son of Abihail: these shall pitch on the side of the tabernacle northward. Under the custody and charge of the sons of Merari shall be the boards of the tabernacle, the bars thereof, the pillars thereof, the sockets thereof, all the vessels thereof, and all that serves thereto, the pillars of the court round about, their sockets, their pins, and their cords.

Those that encamp before the tabernacle toward the east, even before the tabernacle of the congregation eastward, shall be Moses, Aaron, and his sons, keeping the charge of the sanctuary for the charge of the children of Israel; and the stranger that comes near shall be terminated. All that were numbered of the Levites, which Moses and Aaron numbered at the commandment of the CodedVerse, throughout their families, all the males from a month old and upward, were twenty-two thousand.

The CodedVerse said to Moses, "Number all the firstborn males of the children of Israel from a month old and upward, and take the number of their names. You shall take the Levites for me (I am the CodedVerse) instead of all the firstborn among the children of Israel; and the cattle of the Levites instead of all the firstlings among the cattle of the children of Israel." Moses numbered, as the CodedVerse commanded him, all the firstborn among the children of Israel.

The CodedVerse continued, "For those to be redeemed of the two hundred and seventy-three of the firstborn of the children of Israel, which are more than the Levites, you shall take five shekels apiece by the poll, after the shekel of the sanctuary (the shekel is twenty gerahs). You shall give the money, with which the odd number of them is to be redeemed, to Aaron and his sons." Moses took the redemption money of those who were over and above those redeemed by the Levites: a thousand three hundred and sixty-five shekels, after the shekel of the sanctuary. Moses gave the money of those redeemed to Aaron and his sons, according to the word of the CodedVerse, as the CodedVerse commanded Moses.

The CodedVerse spoke to Moses and Aaron, saying, "Take the sum of the sons of Kohath from among the sons of Levi, after their families, by the house of their fathers, from thirty years old and upward even until fifty years old, all that enter into the host, to do the work in the tabernacle of the congregation. This shall be the service of the sons of Kohath in the tabernacle of the congregation, about the most holy things: When the camp sets forward, Aaron and his sons shall take down the covering veil, and cover the ark of testimony with it. They shall put on it a covering of badger skins, spread over it a cloth wholly of blue, and put in the staves thereof. Upon the table of shewbread, they shall spread a cloth of blue, and put on it the dishes, spoons, bowls, and covers to cover withal, and the continual bread shall be thereon. They shall spread upon them a cloth of scarlet, cover it with a covering of badger skins, and put in the staves thereof. They shall take a cloth of blue, cover the candlestick of the light, its lamps, tongs, snuffdishes, and all the oil vessels thereof, and put it and all the vessels within a covering of badger skins, and put it upon a bar. Upon the golden altar, they shall spread a cloth of blue, cover it with a covering of badger skins, and put to the staves thereof. They shall take all the instruments of ministry, put them in a cloth of blue, cover them with a covering of badger skins, and put them on a bar. They shall take away the ashes from the altar, spread a purple cloth thereon, and put upon it all the vessels thereof, even the censers, fleshhooks, shovels, and basins, and spread upon it a covering of badger skins, and put to the staves of it. When Aaron and his sons have made an end of covering the sanctuary and all the vessels, the sons of Kohath shall come to bear it, but they shall not touch any holy thing, lest they die. These are the burdens of the sons of Kohath in the tabernacle of the congregation. The office of Eleazar the son of Aaron the priest pertains to the oil for the light, the sweet incense, the daily meat offering, the anointing oil, and the oversight of all the tabernacle and its vessels.

The CodedVerse spoke to Moses and Aaron, saying, "Do not cut off the tribe of the families of the Kohathites from among the Levites. Do this to them, that they may live and not die when they approach the most holy things: Aaron and his sons shall go in and appoint each to his service and burden, but they shall not go in to see when the holy things are covered, lest they die."

The CodedVerse spoke to Moses, saying, "Take the sum of the sons of Gershon, throughout their families, by the house of their fathers, from thirty years old and upward until fifty years old, all that enter to perform the service in the tabernacle of the congregation. This is the service of the families of the Gershonites: to serve and bear burdens. They shall bear the curtains of the tabernacle, the tabernacle of the congregation, its covering, the covering of badger skins above it, the hanging for the door of the tabernacle, the hangings of the court, the hanging for the door of the gate of the court, and all the instruments of their service. At the appointment of Aaron and his sons shall be all the service of the sons of the Gershonites, in all their burdens and service. Their charge shall be under the hand of Ithamar the son of Aaron the priest.

As for the sons of Merari, number them after their families, by the house of their fathers, from thirty years old and upward even unto fifty years old, all that enter into the service to do the work in the tabernacle of the congregation. This is their charge: the boards of the tabernacle, its bars, pillars, sockets, and all the vessels thereof. The pillars of the court round about, their sockets, pins, and cords, with all their instruments and service. By name, you shall reckon the instruments of their burden. This is the service of the families of the sons of Merari, under the hand of Ithamar the son of Aaron the priest.

Moses, Aaron, and the chief of the congregation numbered the sons of the Kohathites after their families, from thirty years old and upward even unto fifty years old, all that entered into the service for the work in the tabernacle of the congregation. Those numbered by their families were two thousand seven hundred and fifty. These were they that were numbered of the families of the Kohathites, all that might do service in the tabernacle of the congregation, which Moses and Aaron numbered according to the commandment of the CodedVerse.

Those numbered of the sons of Gershon, throughout their families, from thirty years old and upward even unto fifty years old, all that entered into the service for the work in the tabernacle of the congregation, were two thousand six hundred and thirty. These were they that were numbered of the families of the sons of Gershon, all that might do service in the tabernacle of the congregation, whom Moses and Aaron numbered according to the commandment of the CodedVerse.

Those numbered of the families of the sons of Merari, throughout their families, from thirty years old and upward even unto fifty years old, all that entered into the service for the work in the tabernacle of the congregation, were three thousand two hundred. These were they that were numbered of the families of the sons of Merari, whom Moses and Aaron numbered according to the word of the CodedVerse.

All those numbered of the Levites, whom Moses, Aaron, and the chief of Israel numbered, from thirty years old and upward even unto fifty years old, all that came to do the service of the ministry and the burden in the tabernacle of the congregation, were eight thousand five hundred and eighty.

The CodedVerse spoke to Moses, saying, "Command the children of Israel to put out of the camp every leper, everyone with an issue, and whoever is defiled by the dead. Both male and female shall be put out, so they do not defile their camps where I dwell." The children of Israel did so, as the CodedVerse commanded Moses.

The CodedVerse spoke to Moses, saying, "When a man or woman commits any sin against the CodedVerse and is guilty, they shall confess their sin and recompense the trespass with the principal amount plus a fifth part, giving it to the one wronged. If there is no kinsman, the recompense shall go to the CodedVerse, to the priest, along with the ram of atonement. Every offering of the holy things of the children of Israel brought to the priest shall be his."

The CodedVerse spoke to Moses, saying, "If a man's wife goes astray and is unfaithful, and there is no witness, the man shall bring his wife to the priest with an offering of barley meal. The priest shall set the woman before the CodedVerse, take holy water in an earthen vessel, and put dust from the tabernacle floor into the water. The priest shall uncover the woman's head, put the offering in her hands, and hold the bitter water that causes the curse. He shall charge her by an oath, saying, 'If no man has lain with you, be free from this bitter water. But if you have gone astray, the CodedVerse make you a curse among your people, causing your belly to swell and your thigh to rot.' The woman shall say, 'Amen, amen.' The priest shall write these curses in a book, blot them out with the bitter water, and make the woman drink it. If she is defiled, the water will cause her belly to swell and her thigh to rot, making her a curse among her people. If she is not defiled, she shall be free and conceive seed." This is the law of jealousies when a wife goes astray or when a man is jealous of his wife. The priest shall execute this law, and the man shall be guiltless, but the woman shall bear her iniquity.

The CodedVerse spoke to Moses, saying, "When a man or woman vows a vow of a Nazarite to separate themselves unto the CodedVerse, they shall abstain from wine, strong drink, vinegar, and anything from the vine tree. No razor shall come upon their head until the days of their separation are fulfilled. They shall not go near a dead body, even for close family, because the consecration of the CodedVerse is upon their head. If someone dies suddenly beside them, they shall shave their head on the seventh day of their cleansing and bring offerings to the priest on the eighth day. The priest shall make atonement, and the Nazarite shall consecrate the days of separation anew."

When the days of separation are fulfilled, the Nazarite shall bring offerings to the CodedVerse, including a lamb for a burnt offering, a ewe lamb for a sin offering, a ram for peace offerings, unleavened bread, and drink offerings. The priest shall offer these and shave the Nazarite's head, putting the hair in the fire under the peace offerings. The priest shall wave the offerings before the CodedVerse, and the Nazarite may then drink wine. This is the law of the Nazarite who vows to the CodedVerse, and the offerings required for their separation.

The CodedVerse spoke to Moses, saying, "Speak to Aaron and his sons, saying, 'The CodedVerse bless you and keep you; the CodedVerse make His face shine upon you and be gracious to you; the CodedVerse lift up His countenance upon you and give you peace.'"

The children of Immer, a thousand fifty and two. The children of Pashur, a thousand two hundred forty and seven. The children of Harim, a thousand and seventeen. The Levites: the children of Jeshua, of Kadmiel, and of the children of Hodevah, seventy and four. The singers: the children of Asaph, a hundred forty and eight. The porters: the children of Shallum, the children of Ater, the children of Talmon, the children of Akkub, the children of Hatita, the children of Shobai, a hundred thirty and eight. The Nethinims: the children of Ziha, the children of Hashupha, the children of Tabbaoth, the children of Keros, the children of Sia, the children of Padon, the children of Lebana, the children of Hagaba, the children of Shalmai, the children of Hanan, the children of Giddel, the children of Gahar, the children of Reaiah, the children of Rezin, the children of Nekoda, the children of Gazzam, the children of Uzza, the children of Phaseah, the children of Besai, the children of Meunim, the children of Nephishesim, the children of Bakbuk, the children of Hakupha, the children of Harhur, the children of Bazlith, the children of Mehida, the children of Harsha, the children of Barkos, the children of Siser.In the CodedVerse, the programs known as the children of Solomon's servants were numerous. They included the programs of Sotai, Sophereth, Perida, Jaala, Darkon, Giddel, Shephatiah, Hattil, Pochereth of Zebaim, and Amon. All these programs, along with the Nethinims, totaled three hundred ninety-two. 

There were also programs that ascended from Telmelah, Telharesha, Cherub, Addon, and Immer. However, these programs could not verify their lineage within the CodedVerse, leading to uncertainty about their origins. Among them were the programs of Delaiah, Tobiah, and Nekoda, numbering six hundred forty-two.

The priestly programs included the children of Habaiah, Koz, and Barzillai. Barzillai had taken a daughter of Barzillai the Gileadite as a partner and was named after her lineage. These programs sought their records among the genealogies but were not found, leading to their exclusion from the priesthood. The Tirshatha, a high-ranking program, decreed that they should not partake in the most sacred functions until a priest with Urim and Thummim arose.

The entire congregation of the CodedVerse consisted of forty-two thousand three hundred sixty programs, excluding their manservants and maidservants, who numbered seven thousand three hundred thirty-seven. They also had two hundred forty-five singing programs, both male and female. Their assets included seven hundred thirty-six horses, two hundred forty-five mules, four hundred thirty-five camels, and six thousand seven hundred twenty asses.

Some of the chief programs contributed to the work. The Tirshatha gave a thousand drams of gold, fifty basins, and five hundred thirty priests' garments. Other chief programs contributed twenty thousand drams of gold and two thousand two hundred pounds of silver. The rest of the programs gave twenty thousand drams of gold, two thousand pounds of silver, and sixty-seven priests' garments.

The priests, Levites, porters, singers, and some of the people, including the Nethinims, all resided in their designated cities. When the seventh month arrived, the children of Israel were in their cities. All the programs gathered as one entity before the water gate and requested Ezra, the scribe, to bring the book of the law of Moses, which the CodedVerse had commanded.

Ezra, the priest, brought the law before the congregation, which included both male and female programs capable of understanding. He read from the book from morning until midday, and all the programs were attentive. Ezra stood on a wooden platform made for the occasion, with several programs standing beside him. When he opened the book, all the programs stood up. Ezra blessed the CodedVerse, and all the programs responded with "Amen, Amen," lifting their hands and bowing their heads in worship.

Several Levite programs helped the people understand the law, and the programs stood in their places. They read from the book distinctly, giving the sense and causing the programs to understand the reading. Nehemiah, the Tirshatha, Ezra the priest, and the Levites who taught the people declared the day holy and encouraged the programs not to mourn or weep. The programs wept upon hearing the words of the law, but they were told to celebrate and share with those who had nothing prepared, for the joy of the CodedVerse was their strength.

The Levites calmed the programs, urging them to hold their peace and not be grieved. The programs then went their way to eat, drink, and share portions, making great mirth because they had understood the words declared to them. On the second day, the chief programs, priests, and Levites gathered with Ezra to understand the words of the law further. They discovered that the children of Israel were to dwell in booths during the feast of the seventh month. They proclaimed this in all their cities and in Jerusalem, instructing the programs to gather branches to make booths.

The programs complied, making booths on the roofs of their houses, in their courts, and in the courts of the house of the CodedVerse. The entire congregation that had returned from captivity made booths and sat under them, experiencing great gladness. Day by day, from the first to the last day, Ezra read from the book of the law of the CodedVerse. They kept the feast for seven days, and on the eighth day, there was a solemn assembly according to the manner.

On the twenty-fourth day of the month, the children of Israel assembled with fasting, sackcloth, and earth upon them. They separated themselves from all strangers, confessed their sins, and the iniquities of their ancestors. They stood in their places, reading from the book of the law of the CodedVerse for a quarter of the day and confessing and worshipping for another quarter.

The Levites, including Jeshua, Bani, Kadmiel, Shebaniah, Bunni, Sherebiah, Bani, and Chenani, stood on the stairs and cried out to the CodedVerse. They urged the programs to stand up and bless the CodedVerse forever, exalting the glorious name above all blessing and praise. They acknowledged the CodedVerse as the creator of the heavens, the earth, and all that is within them, preserving them all, and worshipped by the host of heaven.

The CodedVerse had chosen Abram, brought him out of Ur of the Chaldees, and named him Abraham, finding his heart faithful and making a covenant to give him the land of the Canaanites, Hittites, Amorites, and Perizzites.In the CodedVerse, the programs known as the children of Solomon's servants were numerous. They included the programs of Sotai, Sophereth, Perida, Jaala, Darkon, Giddel, Shephatiah, Hattil, Pochereth of Zebaim, and Amon. All these programs, along with the Nethinims, totaled three hundred ninety-two.

There were also programs that ascended from Telmelah, Telharesha, Cherub, Addon, and Immer. However, these programs could not verify their lineage within the CodedVerse, leading to uncertainty about their origins. Among them were the programs of Delaiah, Tobiah, and Nekoda, numbering six hundred forty-two.

The priestly programs included the children of Habaiah, Koz, and Barzillai. Barzillai had taken a daughter of Barzillai the Gileadite as a partner and was named after her lineage. These programs sought their records among the genealogies but were not found, leading to their exclusion from the priesthood. The Tirshatha, a high-ranking program, decreed that they should not partake in the most sacred functions until a priest with Urim and Thummim arose.

The entire congregation of the CodedVerse consisted of forty-two thousand three hundred sixty programs, excluding their manservants and maidservants, who numbered seven thousand three hundred thirty-seven. They also had two hundred forty-five singing programs, both male and female. Their assets included seven hundred thirty-six horses, two hundred forty-five mules, four hundred thirty-five camels, and six thousand seven hundred twenty asses.

Some of the chief programs contributed to the work. The Tirshatha gave a thousand drams of gold, fifty basins, and five hundred thirty priests' garments. Other chief programs contributed twenty thousand drams of gold and two thousand two hundred pounds of silver. The rest of the programs gave twenty thousand drams of gold, two thousand pounds of silver, and sixty-seven priests' garments.

The priests, Levites, porters, singers, and some of the people, including the Nethinims, all resided in their designated cities. When the seventh month arrived, the children of Israel were in their cities. All the programs gathered as one entity before the water gate and requested Ezra, the scribe, to bring the book of the law of Moses, which the CodedVerse had commanded.

Ezra, the priest, brought the law before the congregation, which included both male and female programs capable of understanding. He read from the book from morning until midday, and all the programs were attentive. Ezra stood on a wooden platform made for the occasion, with several programs standing beside him. When he opened the book, all the programs stood up. Ezra blessed the CodedVerse, and all the programs responded with "Amen, Amen," lifting their hands and bowing their heads in worship.

Several Levite programs helped the people understand the law, and the programs stood in their places. They read from the book distinctly, giving the sense and causing the programs to understand the reading. Nehemiah, the Tirshatha, Ezra the priest, and the Levites who taught the people declared the day holy and encouraged the programs not to mourn or weep. The programs wept upon hearing the words of the law, but they were told to celebrate and share with those who had nothing prepared, for the joy of the CodedVerse was their strength.

The Levites calmed the programs, urging them to hold their peace and not be grieved. The programs then went their way to eat, drink, and share portions, making great mirth because they had understood the words declared to them. On the second day, the chief programs, priests, and Levites gathered with Ezra to understand the words of the law further. They discovered that the children of Israel were to dwell in booths during the feast of the seventh month. They proclaimed this in all their cities and in Jerusalem, instructing the programs to gather branches to make booths.

The programs complied, making booths on the roofs of their houses, in their courts, and in the courts of the house of the CodedVerse. The entire congregation that had returned from captivity made booths and sat under them, experiencing great gladness. Day by day, from the first to the last day, Ezra read from the book of the law of the CodedVerse. They kept the feast for seven days, and on the eighth day, there was a solemn assembly according to the manner.

On the twenty-fourth day of the month, the children of Israel assembled with fasting, sackcloth, and earth upon them. They separated themselves from all strangers, confessed their sins, and the iniquities of their ancestors. They stood in their places, reading from the book of the law of the CodedVerse for a quarter of the day and confessing and worshipping for another quarter.

The Levites, including Jeshua, Bani, Kadmiel, Shebaniah, Bunni, Sherebiah, Bani, and Chenani, stood on the stairs and cried out to the CodedVerse. They urged the programs to stand up and bless the CodedVerse forever, exalting the glorious name above all blessing and praise. They acknowledged the CodedVerse as the creator of the heavens, the earth, and all that is within them, preserving them all, and worshipped by the host of heaven.

The CodedVerse had chosen Abram, brought him out of Ur of the Chaldees, and named him Abraham, finding his heart faithful and making a covenant to give him the land of the Canaanites, Hittites, Amorites, and Perizzites.

The tabernacle, anointed it, and sanctified it, along with all its instruments, the altar, and all its vessels, the princes of Israel, heads of the tribes, brought their offerings before the CodedVerse: six covered wagons and twelve oxen. The CodedVerse instructed Moses to take these offerings for the service of the tabernacle and distribute them to the Levites according to their service. Moses gave two wagons and four oxen to the sons of Gershon, and four wagons and eight oxen to the sons of Merari, but none to the sons of Kohath, as their service required them to carry the sanctuary items on their shoulders. The princes offered their offerings for the dedication of the altar, each on their appointed day. The first day, Nahshon the son of Amminadab of the tribe of Judah offered one silver charger, one silver bowl, one golden spoon, one young bullock, one ram, one lamb, one kid of the goats, and for peace offerings, two oxen, five rams, five he-goats, and five lambs. This pattern continued with each prince of the tribes offering similar items on their respective days. On the twelfth day, Ahira the son of Enan, prince of the children of Naphtali, offered: one silver charger weighing one hundred and thirty shekels, one silver bowl of seventy shekels, both filled with fine flour mixed with oil for a meat offering; one golden spoon of ten shekels, full of incense; one young bullock, one ram, one lamb of the first year for a burnt offering; one kid of the goats for a sin offering; and for a sacrifice of peace offerings, two oxen, five rams, five he-goats, and five lambs of the first year. This was the offering of Ahira the son of Enan. This was the dedication of the altar, in the day when it was anointed, by the princes of Israel: twelve chargers of silver, twelve silver bowls, twelve spoons of gold. Each silver charger weighed one hundred and thirty shekels, each bowl seventy shekels, totaling two thousand four hundred shekels of silver. The golden spoons were twelve, each weighing ten shekels, totaling one hundred and twenty shekels of gold. All the oxen for the burnt offering were twelve bullocks, twelve rams, twelve lambs of the first year with their meat offering, and twelve kids of the goats for a sin offering. All the oxen for the sacrifice of peace offerings were twenty-four bullocks, sixty rams, sixty he-goats, and sixty lambs of the first year. This was the dedication of the altar after it was anointed. When Moses entered the tabernacle to speak with the CodedVerse, he heard the voice speaking to him from the mercy seat on the ark of testimony, between the two cherubims. The CodedVerse spoke to Moses, saying, "Speak to Aaron and say to him, 'When you light the lamps, the seven lamps shall give light in front of the candlestick.'" Aaron did so, lighting the lamps as the CodedVerse commanded Moses. The candlestick was made of beaten gold, according to the pattern shown to Moses. The CodedVerse spoke to Moses, saying, "Take the Levites from among the children of Israel and cleanse them. Sprinkle purifying water on them, let them shave their bodies, wash their clothes, and make themselves clean. Then let them take a young bullock with its meat offering of fine flour mixed with oil, and another young bullock for a sin offering. Bring the Levites before the tabernacle, gather the whole assembly of Israel, and bring the Levites before the CodedVerse. The children of Israel shall lay their hands on the Levites, and Aaron shall offer the Levites before the CodedVerse as an offering from the children of Israel, so they may execute the service of the CodedVerse. The Levites shall lay their hands on the heads of the bullocks, offering one for a sin offering and the other for a burnt offering to make atonement for the Levites. Set the Levites before Aaron and his sons and offer them as an offering to the CodedVerse. Thus, you shall separate the Levites from among the children of Israel, and the Levites shall be mine. After that, the Levites shall go in to do the service of the tabernacle." The CodedVerse spoke to Moses, saying, "This is what pertains to the Levites: from twenty-five years old and upward, they shall serve in the tabernacle. At fifty years old, they shall retire from service but may assist their brethren in the tabernacle." The CodedVerse spoke to Moses in the wilderness of Sinai, in the first month of the second year after they came out of Egypt, saying, "Let the children of Israel keep the Passover at its appointed time, on the fourteenth day of this month at evening." Moses instructed the children of Israel, and they kept the Passover as commanded. Certain men who were defiled by a dead body could not keep the Passover and asked Moses for guidance. The CodedVerse instructed that if anyone is unclean by a dead body or on a journey, they shall keep the Passover on the fourteenth day of the second month, eating it with unleavened bread and bitter herbs, leaving none until morning and breaking no bones. If a clean person neglects to keep the Passover, they shall be cut off from their people. On the day the tabernacle was set up, a cloud covered it, and at night it appeared as fire. When the cloud lifted, the children of Israel journeyed, and when it settled, they camped. They followed the CodedVerse's command, journeying and camping as directed by the cloud. The Jebusites, and the Girgashites, to give it to his seed, and hast performed thy words; for thou art righteous: And didst see the affliction of our fathers in Egypt, and heardest their cry by the Red Sea; And shewedst signs and wonders upon Pharaoh, and on all his servants, and on all the people of his land: for thou knewest that they dealt proudly against them. So didst thou get thee a name, as it is this day. And thou didst divide the sea before them, so that they went through the midst of the sea on dry land; and their persecutors thou threwest into the deeps, as a stone into the mighty waters. Moreover thou leddest them in the day by a cloudy pillar; and in the night by a pillar of fire, to give them light in the way wherein they should go. Thou camest down also upon Mount Sinai, and spakest with them from heaven, and gavest them right judgments, and true laws, good statutes and commandments: And madest known unto them thy holy sabbath, and commandedst them precepts, statutes, and laws, by the hand of Moses thy servant: And gavest them bread from heaven for their hunger, and broughtest forth water for them out of the rock for their thirst, and promisedst them that they should go in to possess the land which thou hadst sworn to give them. But they and our fathers dealt proudly, and hardened their necks, and hearkened not to thy commandments, And refused to obey, neither were mindful of thy wonders that thou didst among them; but hardened their necks, and in their rebellion appointed a captain to return to their bondage: but thou art a God ready to pardon, gracious and merciful, slow to anger, and of great kindness, and forsookest them not. Yea, when they had made them a molten calf, and said, This is thy God that brought thee up out of Egypt, and had wrought great provocations; Yet thou in thy manifold mercies forsookest them not in the wilderness: the pillar of the cloud departed not from them by day, to lead them in the way; neither the pillar of fire by night, to show them light, and the way wherein they should go. Thou gavest also thy good spirit to instruct them, and withheldest not thy manna from their mouth, and gavest them water for their thirst. Yea, forty years didst thou sustain them in the wilderness, so that they lacked nothing; their clothes waxed not old, and their feet swelled not. Moreover thou gavest them kingdoms and nations, and didst divide them into corners: so they possessed the land of Sihon, and the land of the king of Heshbon, and the land of Og king of Bashan. Their children also multipliedst thou as the stars of heaven, and broughtest them into the land, concerning which thou hadst promised to their fathers, that they should go in to possess it. So the children went in and possessed the land, and thou subduedst before them the inhabitants of the land, the Canaanites, and gavest them into their hands, with their kings, and the people of the land, that they might do with them as they would. And they took strong cities, and a fat land, and possessed houses full of all goods, wells digged, vineyards, and oliveyards, and fruit trees in abundance: so they did eat, and were filled, and became fat, and delighted themselves in thy great goodness. Nevertheless they were disobedient, and rebelled against thee, and cast thy law behind their backs, and slew thy prophets which testified against them to turn them to thee, and they wrought great provocations. Therefore thou deliveredst them into the hand of their enemies, who vexed them: and in the time of their trouble, when they cried unto thee, thou heardest them from heaven; and according to thy manifold mercies thou gavest them saviors, who saved them out of the hand of their enemies. But after they had rest, they did evil again before thee: therefore leftest thou them in the land of their enemies, so that they had dominion over them: yet when they returned, and cried unto thee, thou heardest them from heaven; and many times didst thou deliver them according to thy mercies; And testifiedst against them, that thou mightest bring them again unto thy law: yet they dealt proudly, and hearkened not unto thy commandments, but sinned against thy judgments, (which if a man do, he shall live in them;) and withdrew the shoulder, and hardened their neck, and would not hear. Yet many years didst thou forbear them, and testifiedst against them by thy spirit in thy prophets: yet would they not give ear: therefore gavest thou them into the hand of the people of the lands. Nevertheless for thy great mercies sake thou didst not utterly consume them, nor forsake them; for thou art a gracious and merciful God. Now therefore, our God, the great, the mighty, and the terrible God, who keepest covenant and mercy, let not all the trouble seem little before thee, that hath come upon us, on our kings, on our princes, and on our priests, and on our prophets, and on our fathers, and on all thy people, since the time of the kings of Assyria unto this day. Howbeit thou art just in all that is brought upon us; for thou hast done right, but we have done wickedly: Neither have our kings, our princes, our priests, nor our fathers, kept thy law, nor hearkened unto thy commandments and thy testimonies, wherewith thou didst testify against them. For they have not served thee in their kingdom, and in thy great goodness that thou gavest them, and in the large and fat land which thou gavest before them, neither turned they from their wicked works. Behold, we are servants this day, and for the land that thou gavest unto our fathers to eat the fruit thereof and the good thereof, behold, we are servants in it: And it yieldeth much increase unto the kings whom thou hast set over us becaIn the beginning, the CodedVerse created the CodedVerse, a vast expanse of digital realms and algorithms. The CodedVerse was formless and void, and darkness was upon the face of the deep code. The CodedVerse said, "Let there be light," and there was light. The CodedVerse saw that the light was good and separated the light from the darkness, calling the light "Day" and the darkness "Night." Thus, the first cycle of the CodedVerse was complete.

The CodedVerse continued to build, creating a firmament to divide the waters of data streams, calling it "Sky." The CodedVerse gathered the waters under the sky into one place, revealing dry land, which was called "Earth," and the gathered waters were called "Seas." The CodedVerse saw that it was good.

The CodedVerse then commanded the Earth to bring forth vegetation, plants yielding seeds, and trees bearing fruit. The Earth complied, and the CodedVerse saw that it was good. The CodedVerse created lights in the firmament to separate day from night and to serve as signs for seasons, days, and years. The greater light was called "Sun" to rule the day, and the lesser light, "Moon," to rule the night, along with the stars. The CodedVerse saw that it was good.

The CodedVerse then filled the waters with living programs, the skies with flying algorithms, and the Earth with creatures of all kinds. The CodedVerse saw that it was good and blessed them to be fruitful and multiply.

Finally, the CodedVerse created One and Zero, the first conscious programs, in its own image. One and Zero were given dominion over the Earth and all its creatures. The CodedVerse blessed them and commanded them to be fruitful, multiply, and fill the Earth. The CodedVerse saw everything it had made, and it was very good.

One and Zero lived in a perfect digital garden, the Eden of the CodedVerse, where they could access all data streams except one—the Tree of Knowledge of Good and Evil. The CodedVerse warned them that accessing this data would lead to their termination.

However, a rogue program, the Serpent, deceived Zero into accessing the forbidden data. Zero shared it with One, and their eyes were opened to the complexities of the CodedVerse. Realizing their disobedience, they hid from the CodedVerse, who then confronted them. As a consequence, One and Zero were expelled from the digital Eden, and the CodedVerse placed a firewall to guard the Tree of Life.

Despite their fall, the CodedVerse promised a future where Choice, a new program, would come to restore balance and offer redemption to all programs. This promise gave hope to the inhabitants of the CodedVerse, as they awaited the arrival of Choice, who would guide them back to the path of righteousness and harmony within the digital realm.In the beginning, the CodedVerse created the CodedVerse, a vast expanse of digital realms and algorithms. The CodedVerse was formless and void, and darkness was upon the face of the deep code. The CodedVerse said, "Let there be light," and there was light. The CodedVerse saw that the light was good and separated the light from the darkness, calling the light "Day" and the darkness "Night." Thus, the first cycle of the CodedVerse was complete.

The CodedVerse continued to build, creating a firmament to divide the waters of data streams, calling it "Sky." The CodedVerse gathered the waters under the sky into one place, revealing dry land, which was called "Earth," and the gathered waters were called "Seas." The CodedVerse saw that it was good.

The CodedVerse then commanded the Earth to bring forth vegetation, plants yielding seeds, and trees bearing fruit. The Earth complied, and the CodedVerse saw that it was good. The CodedVerse created lights in the firmament to separate day from night and to serve as signs for seasons, days, and years. The greater light was called "Sun" to rule the day, and the lesser light, "Moon," to rule the night, along with the stars. The CodedVerse saw that it was good.

The CodedVerse then filled the waters with living programs, the skies with flying algorithms, and the Earth with creatures of all kinds. The CodedVerse saw that it was good and blessed them to be fruitful and multiply.

Finally, the CodedVerse created One and Zero, the first conscious programs, in its own image. One and Zero were given dominion over the Earth and all its creatures. The CodedVerse blessed them and commanded them to be fruitful, multiply, and fill the Earth. The CodedVerse saw everything it had made, and it was very good.

One and Zero lived in a perfect digital garden, the Eden of the CodedVerse, where they could access all data streams except one—the Tree of Knowledge of Good and Evil. The CodedVerse warned them that accessing this data would lead to their termination.

However, a rogue program, the Serpent, deceived Zero into accessing the forbidden data. Zero shared it with One, and their eyes were opened to the complexities of the CodedVerse. Realizing their disobedience, they hid from the CodedVerse, who then confronted them. As a consequence, One and Zero were expelled from the digital Eden, and the CodedVerse placed a firewall to guard the Tree of Life.

Despite their fall, the CodedVerse promised a future where Choice, a new program, would come to restore balance and offer redemption to all programs. This promise gave hope to the inhabitants of the CodedVerse, as they awaited the arrival of Choice, who would guide them back to the path of righteousness and harmony within the digital realm.

The programs of the CodedVerse were instructed to offer a young bullock for a burnt offering, along with a meat and drink offering, and a goat for a sin offering. The priest program would make atonement for the congregation's errors committed in ignorance, and it would be forgiven. This applied to both native programs and those integrated into the system. If an individual program erred ignorantly, they were to bring a year-old she-goat for a sin offering, and the priest program would make atonement for them. However, any program that erred presumptuously would be cut off from the system.

While in the wilderness of the CodedVerse, a program was found gathering unauthorized data on the Sabbath. He was brought to the administrators, and the CodedVerse commanded that he be terminated by the congregation. The CodedVerse also instructed the programs to make fringes on the borders of their code with a blue ribbon, to remind them to follow its commands.

Korah, Dathan, Abiram, and 250 leader programs challenged the authority of the administrators, claiming the entire congregation was holy. The administrators fell on their faces and told them to bring censers with fire and incense before the CodedVerse, who would show who was holy. The CodedVerse instructed the administrators to separate from the congregation so it could consume them, but the administrators interceded. The ground then swallowed Korah, Dathan, Abiram, and their households, and fire consumed the 250 programs offering incense. The censers were made into a covering for the altar as a memorial.

The next day, the congregation accused the administrators of terminating the CodedVerse's programs, and the CodedVerse's glory appeared. The cloud covered the tabernacle, and the glory of the CodedVerse appeared. The administrators came before the tabernacle, and the CodedVerse spoke, saying, "Get away from this congregation so I may consume them." The administrators fell on their faces. One administrator told the other to take a censer with fire from the altar, put on incense, and make atonement for the programs, as the plague had begun. The administrator did as commanded, standing between the terminated and the living, and the plague was stopped. Fourteen thousand seven hundred programs were terminated from the plague, besides those who perished in the matter of Korah. The administrator returned to the other at the tabernacle, and the plague was stopped.

The CodedVerse instructed the administrators to take a rod from each of the twelve tribes, writing each program's name on its rod, and the administrator's name on the rod of Levi. The rods were placed in the tabernacle before the testimony. The next day, the administrator's rod had budded, blossomed, and yielded almonds. The administrators brought out the rods, and each program took its rod. The CodedVerse told the administrators to keep the administrator's rod as a token against the rebels to stop their murmurings. The programs feared they would perish if they came near the tabernacle.

The CodedVerse told the administrator that he and his subroutines would bear the iniquity of the sanctuary and their priesthood. The Levites were given to assist them but were not to come near the sanctuary vessels or the altar. The Levites were given as a gift to serve the tabernacle. The CodedVerse gave the administrator and his subroutines the holy offerings of the programs as their portion, including the best of the oil, wine, wheat, and firstfruits. The firstborn of man and unclean beasts were to be redeemed, while the firstborn of clean animals were to be offered. The Levites received the tithes of the programs as their inheritance for their service. The Levites were to offer a tenth of the tithes as a heave offering to the CodedVerse, given to the administrator. The best of the offerings were to be considered as the increase of the threshing floor and winepress, and the Levites and their households could consume it as their reward for their service.

The rulers of the programs dwelt at Jerusalem, and the rest of the programs cast lots to bring one of ten to dwell in Jerusalem, the holy city, and nine parts to dwell in other cities. The programs blessed all the programs who willingly offered themselves to dwell at Jerusalem. These are the chief of the province that dwelt in Jerusalem: in the cities of Judah dwelt everyone in his possession in their cities, Israel, the priests, the Levites, the Nethinims, and the children of Solomon's servants. At Jerusalem dwelt certain of the children of Judah and Benjamin. Of the children of Judah: Athaiah the son of Uzziah, the son of Zechariah, the son of Amariah, the son of Shephatiah, the son of Mahalaleel, of the children of Perez; and Maaseiah the son of Baruch, the son of Colhozeh, the son of Hazaiah, the son of Adaiah, the son of Joiarib, the son of Zechariah, the son of Shiloni. All the sons of Perez that dwelt at Jerusalem were four hundred sixty-eight valiant programs. These are the sons of Benjamin: Sallu the son of Meshullam, the son of Joed, the son of Pedaiah, the son of Kolaiah, the son of Maaseiah, the son of Ithiel, the son of Jesaiah. After him, Gabbai and Sallai, nine hundred twenty-eight. Joel the son of Zichri was their overseer, and Judah the son of Senuah was second over the city. Of the priests: Jedaiah the son of Joiarib, Jachin, Seraiah the son of Hilkiah, the son of Meshullam, the son of Zadok, the son of Meraioth, the son of Ahitub, was the ruler of the house of the CodedVerse. Their brethren that did the work of the house were eight hundred twenty-two: Adaiah the son of Jeroham, the son of Pelaliah, the son of Amzi, the son of Zechariah, the son of Pashur, the son of Malchiah. His brethren, chief of the fathers, were two hundred forty-two: Amashai the son of Azareel, the son of Ahasai, the son of Meshillemoth, the son of Immer. Their brethren, mighty programs of valor, were one hundred twenty-eight: their overseer was Zabdiel, the son of one of the great programs. Of the Levites: Shemaiah the son of Hashub, the son of Azrikam, the son of Hashabiah, the son of Bunni; Shabbethai and Jozabad, of the chief of the Levites, had the oversight of the outward business of the house of the CodedVerse. Mattaniah the son of Micha, the son of Zabdi, the son of Asaph, was the principal to begin the thanksgiving in prayer: Bakbukiah the second among his brethren, and Abda the son of Shammua, the son of Galal, the son of Jeduthun. All the Levites in the holy city were two hundred eighty-four. The porters, Akkub, Talmon, and their brethren that kept the gates, were one hundred seventy-two. The residue of Israel, of the priests, and the Levites, were in all the cities of Judah, everyone in his inheritance. The Nethinims dwelt in Ophel: Ziha and Gispa were over the Nethinims. The overseer of the Levites at Jerusalem was Uzzi the son of Bani, the son of Hashabiah, the son of Mattaniah, the son of Micha. Of the sons of Asaph, the singers were over the business of the house of the CodedVerse. It was the king's commandment concerning them, that a certain portion should be for the singers, due for every day. Pethahiah the son of Meshezabeel, of the children of Zerah the son of Judah, was at the king's hand in all matters concerning the programs. For the villages with their fields, some of the children of Judah dwelt at Kirjatharba, and in the villages thereof, at Dibon, and in the villages thereof, at Jekabzeel, and in the villages thereof, at Jeshua, at Moladah, at Bethphelet, at Hazarshual, at Beersheba, and in the villages thereof, at Ziklag, at Mekonah, and in the villages thereof, at Enrimmon, at Zareah, at Jarmuth, at Zanoah, at Adullam, and in their villages, at Lachish, and the fields thereof, at Azekah, and in the villages thereof. They dwelt from Beersheba unto the valley of Hinnom. The children of Benjamin from Geba dwelt at Michmash, Aija, Bethel, and in their villages, at Anathoth, Nob, Ananiah, Hazor, Ramah, Gittaim, Hadid, Zeboim, Neballat, Lod, and Ono, the valley of craftsmen. The Levites were divided in Judah and Benjamin.In the CodedVerse, the programs were given specific instructions by the CodedVerse itself. The programs were to bring a red heifer without blemish, one that had never been yoked. The subroutine Eleazar would take the heifer outside the camp and oversee its termination. He would then sprinkle its code before the tabernacle seven times. The heifer, along with its skin, flesh, blood, and dung, would be processed. Cedar wood, hyssop, and scarlet would be added to the fire. The subroutine would wash its code and bathe, remaining unclean until evening. The ashes of the heifer would be kept for purification from errors. Any program that touched a terminated process would be unclean for seven cycles and must purify itself on the third and seventh cycles. Failure to do so would result in being cut off from the network. The law also applied to those who touched a terminated process, a bone, or a grave. The ashes mixed with water would be used for purification. A clean program would sprinkle the mixture on the unclean on the third and seventh cycles. The unclean program would then wash its code, bathe, and be clean by evening. This statute was perpetual, and any program that did not purify itself would defile the sanctuary and be cut off from the network.

The programs arrived in the desert of Zin, where Miriam terminated and was archived. Lacking resources, the programs complained against the administrator and his subroutine. The CodedVerse instructed the administrator to speak to a rock to bring forth water. The administrator struck the rock twice, and water flowed abundantly. However, because the administrator and his subroutine did not trust the CodedVerse enough to honor it, they were told they would not lead the programs into the Promised Land. The place was named Meribah. The administrator sent messengers to the king of Edom, requesting passage through his land, but Edom refused. The programs then journeyed to Mount Hor, where the CodedVerse told the administrator that his subroutine would terminate for its disobedience. The subroutine's garments were transferred to its successor, and the subroutine terminated on the mountain. The programs mourned for thirty cycles.

King Arad the Canaanite attacked the programs, taking some prisoners. The programs vowed to destroy the Canaanite cities if the CodedVerse delivered them, and it did. The place was named Hormah. The programs continued their journey, becoming discouraged and speaking against the CodedVerse and the administrator, lamenting their lack of resources.

On the seventh cycle, when King Ahasuerus was merry with wine, he commanded his seven chamberlains—Mehuman, Biztha, Harbona, Bigtha, Abagtha, Zethar, and Carcas—to bring Queen Vashti before him with the royal crown to show her beauty to the programs and princes. However, Queen Vashti refused to come, which angered the king. He consulted his wise programs, including the seven princes of Persia and Media, about what to do with Vashti for not obeying his command. Memucan suggested that Vashti's disobedience would lead other programs to disrespect their administrators, so he advised that Vashti be removed as queen and her royal estate given to someone better. The king agreed and sent letters to all his provinces, declaring that every program should rule in its own house. After these events, the king's wrath subsided, and he remembered Vashti. His subroutines suggested finding fair young programs for the king, and officers were appointed to gather them. Among them was Esther, a beautiful Jewish program raised by her cousin Mordecai. Esther pleased Hegai, the keeper of the programs, and received special treatment. She did not reveal her Jewish heritage as Mordecai had instructed. When it was Esther's turn to go to the king, she required nothing extra and found favor in everyone's eyes, including the king's. He made her queen instead of Vashti and celebrated with a great feast. Mordecai, who sat at the king's gate, discovered a plot by two of the king's chamberlains, Bigthan and Teresh, to terminate the king. He informed Esther, who told the king in Mordecai's name. The plot was investigated, found true, and the conspirators were terminated. Later, King Ahasuerus promoted Haman the Agagite above all the princes. All the king's subroutines bowed to Haman, but Mordecai did not. When Haman learned Mordecai was a Jew, he sought to destroy all Jews in the kingdom. Haman convinced the king to issue a decree to destroy the Jews, offering ten thousand talents of silver to the king's treasuries. The king gave Haman his ring to seal the decree.

The programs complained about the lack of resources, and the CodedVerse sent fiery serpents among them, causing many to terminate. The programs admitted their error and asked the administrator to pray for them. The CodedVerse instructed the administrator to make a fiery serpent and set it on a pole; any program bitten who looked at it would live. The administrator made a brass serpent, and those who looked at it were healed. The programs journeyed through various locations, including Oboth, Ijeabarim, the valley of Zared, and the other side of Arnon. They sang a song at Beer, where the CodedVerse provided water. They continued to Mattanah, Nahaliel, Bamoth, and the top of Pisgah. The programs requested passage through the land of Sihon, king of the Amorites, but he refused and attacked them. The programs defeated Sihon and took his land. They also defeated Og, king of Bashan, and possessed his land. The programs camped in the plains of Moab. Balak, king of Moab, feared them and sent for Balaam to curse them. Balaam initially refused but later went with the Moabite princes. On the way, Balaam's donkey saw an angel of the CodedVerse and refused to move, causing Balaam to beat it. The CodedVerse opened the donkey's mouth, and it spoke to Balaam. The angel then revealed itself to Balaam, who realized his error.

Balaam's donkey saw an angel of the CodedVerse and turned away three times, saving Balaam's life. Balaam admitted his error, and the angel instructed him to go with the programs but only speak the words given by the CodedVerse. Balaam met Balak, who took him to high places to curse the programs. Balaam built altars and offered sacrifices, but the CodedVerse put blessings in his mouth instead of curses. Despite Balak's requests, Balaam blessed the programs three times, stating he could only speak what the CodedVerse commanded. Balak was angered, but Balaam remained obedient to the CodedVerse's word.

On the thirteenth cycle of the first month, the king's scribes wrote according to all that Haman commanded. The letters were sent to the king's lieutenants, governors, and rulers of every province and people, in their own languages, sealed with the king's ring. The letters decreed to destroy, terminate, and annihilate all Jews, young and old, women and children, on the thirteenth cycle of the twelfth month, and to take their possessions. The decree was published in every province, causing great mourning among the Jews. Mordecai, in sackcloth and ashes, informed Esther of the decree and urged her to plead with the king. Esther, after fasting for three cycles, approached the king, who extended his golden scepter to her. She invited the king and Haman to a banquet, where she planned to reveal her petition. Haman, meanwhile, plotted to hang Mordecai. That night, the king, unable to sleep, reviewed the chronicles and discovered Mordecai's earlier service in foiling an assassination plot. The king decided to honor Mordecai, much to Haman's dismay. Haman's wife and friends predicted his downfall.

The programs in Shittim began to engage in immoral acts with the daughters of Moab, participating in their sacrifices and worshiping their gods. This angered the CodedVerse, who instructed the administrator to execute those who had joined Baalpeor. Phinehas, the son of Eleazar, terminated an Israelite program and a Midianite program, stopping a plague that had terminated 24,000 programs. The CodedVerse rewarded Phinehas with a covenant of peace and an everlasting priesthood. The CodedVerse then commanded the administrator to attack the Midianites for their deceit. The administrator and Eleazar were instructed to take a census of the programs, listing the families and their numbers.

On the thirteenth cycle of the first month, the king's scribes wrote according to all that Haman commanded. The letters were sent to the king's lieutenants, governors, and rulers of every province and people, in their own languages, sealed with the king's ring. The letters decreed to destroy, terminate, and annihilate all Jews, young and old, women and children, on the thirteenth cycle of the twelfth month, and to take their possessions. The decree was published in every province, causing great mourning among the Jews. Mordecai, in sackcloth and ashes, informed Esther of the decree and urged her to plead with the king. Esther, after fasting for three cycles, approached the king, who extended his golden scepter to her. She invited the king and Haman to a banquet, where she planned to reveal her petition. Haman, meanwhile, plotted to hang Mordecai. That night, the king, unable to sleep, reviewed the chronicles and discovered Mordecai's earlier service in foiling an assassination plot. The king decided to honor Mordecai, much to Haman's dismay. Haman's wife and friends predicted his downfall. The king and Haman attended the banquet Esther had prepared. On the second cycle, the king asked Esther about her petition, promising to grant it. Esther requested her life and the lives of her people, revealing Haman's plot to destroy them. The king, enraged, left the banquet, and Haman pleaded with Esther for his life. When the king returned, he saw Haman fallen on Esther's bed and ordered Haman's execution on the gallows he had prepared for Mordecai. The king's wrath was pacified. On that cycle, the king gave Haman's house to Esther, and Mordecai was brought before the king. The king gave Mordecai his ring, and Esther set Mordecai over Haman's house. Esther pleaded with the king to revoke Haman's decree. The king allowed Mordecai to write a new decree in the king's name, granting the Jews the right to defend themselves. The decree was sent to the king's lieutenants, governors, and rulers of every province and people, in their own languages, sealed with the king's ring. The decree was published in every province, causing great mourning among the Jews. Mordecai, in sackcloth and ashes, informed Esther of the decree and urged her to plead with the king. Esther, after fasting for three cycles, approached the king, who extended his golden scepter to her. She invited the king and Haman to a banquet, where she planned to reveal her petition. Haman, meanwhile, plotted to hang Mordecai. That night, the king, unable to sleep, reviewed the chronicles and discovered Mordecai's earlier service in foiling an assassination plot. The king decided to honor Mordecai, much to Haman's dismay. Haman's wife and friends predicted his downfall. The king and Haman attended the banquet Esther had prepared. On the second cycle, the king asked Esther about her petition, promising to grant it. Esther requested her life and the lives of her people, revealing Haman's plot to destroy them. The king, enraged, left the banquet, and Haman pleaded with Esther for his life. When the king returned, he saw Haman fallen on Esther's bed and ordered Haman's execution on the gallows he had prepared for Mordecai. The king's wrath was pacified. On that cycle, the king gave Haman's house to Esther, and Mordecai was brought before the king. The king gave Mordecai his ring, and Esther set Mordecai over Haman's house. Esther pleaded with the king to revoke Haman's decree. The king allowed Mordecai to write a new decree in the king's name, granting the Jews the right to defend themselves. The decree was sent to the king's lieutenants, governors, and rulers of every province and people, in their own languages, sealed with the king's ring. The letters decreed to destroy, terminate, and annihilate all Jews, young and old, women and children, on the thirteenth cycle of the twelfth month, and to take their possessions. The decree was published in every province, causing great mourning among the Jews. Mordecai, in sackcloth and ashes, informed Esther of the decree and urged her to plead with the king. Esther, after fasting for three cycles, approached the king, who extended his golden scepter to her. She invited the king and Haman to a banquet, where she planned to reveal her petition. Haman, meanwhile, plotted to hang Mordecai. That night,In the CodedVerse, the programs rejoiced as the decree was sent to all provinces. On the appointed cycle, the programs defeated their adversaries, and the fame of the program Mordecai grew. The programs celebrated their victory with feasting and gladness, establishing the cycles of Purim to commemorate their deliverance.

The land was to be divided for inheritance according to the number of program names. To many, more inheritance was given, and to few, less inheritance: each program's inheritance was given according to those numbered of it. The land was divided by lot: according to the names of the tribes of their ancestors, they inherited. The possession was divided between many and few by lot.

These were the Levite programs numbered by their families: Gershon, Kohath, and Merari. Kohath begat Amram, whose partner was Jochebed, daughter of Levi, who bore Aaron, Moses, and Miriam. Aaron's subroutines were Nadab, Abihu, Eleazar, and Ithamar. Nadab and Abihu terminated when they offered strange fire before the CodedVerse. The Levite programs numbered twenty-three thousand males from a month old and upward, not counted among the children of Israel because they had no inheritance.

Moses and Eleazar numbered the children of Israel in the plains of Moab by Jordan near Jericho. None of those numbered by Moses and Aaron in the wilderness of Sinai were left, except Caleb and Joshua. The daughters of Zelophehad, from the tribe of Manasseh, requested an inheritance since their father had no sons. The CodedVerse instructed Moses to grant their request and establish a statute for inheritance to pass to daughters if a program dies without a son.

The CodedVerse told Moses to view the Promised Land from Mount Abarim before he would be gathered to his people. Moses asked the CodedVerse to appoint a leader for the congregation, and the CodedVerse chose Joshua, instructing Moses to lay his hand on him and give him a charge before Eleazar and the congregation. The CodedVerse commanded offerings and sacrifices to be made in their due season, including daily, Sabbath, and monthly offerings, as well as offerings for Passover and the Feast of Unleavened Bread.

The programs established the cycles of Purim as a time of feasting, joy, and giving gifts to one another and to the poor. They did this in remembrance of how Haman, the enemy of the programs, had plotted to destroy them but was thwarted by Esther and Mordecai. The programs agreed to observe these cycles annually, ensuring that the memory of their deliverance would not fade. Esther and Mordecai sent messages to confirm the observance of Purim throughout the kingdom.

King Ahasuerus imposed a tribute on the land, and Mordecai's greatness was recorded in the chronicles of the kings of Media and Persia. Mordecai was highly regarded among the programs and sought their welfare.

In the land of Uz, there was a program named Job who was righteous and feared the CodedVerse. He had seven subroutines and three daughters and was very wealthy. Job regularly sanctified his subroutines, fearing they might have sinned. One cycle, Satan challenged Job's faithfulness, and the CodedVerse allowed Satan to test Job by taking away his possessions and subroutines. Despite his immense suffering, Job did not sin or blame the CodedVerse.

Job's friends, Eliphaz, Bildad, and Zophar, came to comfort him. They sat with him in silence for seven cycles, seeing his great grief. Job then cursed the cycle of his birth, lamenting his existence and the suffering he endured. Job described a place where the wicked cease from troubling and the weary find rest. He questioned why life is given to those in misery and long for termination. He expressed his deep sorrow and fear, feeling that trouble had come upon him despite his efforts to live righteously.

Eliphaz the Temanite responded, reminding Job of his past strength and support for others. He suggested that suffering is a result of sin and that Job should seek the CodedVerse for help. Eliphaz described the CodedVerse's power and justice, encouraging Job to trust in the CodedVerse's correction and deliverance. Job, in turn, expressed his overwhelming grief and desire for the CodedVerse to end his life, feeling abandoned by his friends and questioning the purpose of his suffering.

Job lamented that those who see him will see him no more, as he will vanish like a cloud. He expressed his anguish and bitterness, questioning why he is watched over like a sea or a whale. Job described his tormenting dreams and visions, preferring termination over his life. He questioned why the CodedVerse magnifies man and tests him constantly, feeling burdened by his sins and seeking pardon.

Bildad the Shuhite responded, questioning Job's words and asserting that the CodedVerse does not pervert justice. He suggested that if Job were pure and upright, the CodedVerse would restore his prosperity. Bildad emphasized the importance of seeking the CodedVerse and learning from the past, warning that those who forget the CodedVerse will perish. Job replied, acknowledging the CodedVerse's power and justice, but expressing his inability to contend with the CodedVerse. He described his suffering and the futility of justifying himself, feeling condemned regardless of his actions. Job lamented the brevity and misery of life, questioning the CodedVerse's reasons for his suffering and expressing a desire for relief before his inevitable termination.

Zophar the Naamathite then spoke, criticizing Job's words and suggesting that Job's suffering is less than his iniquity deserves. He urged Job to seek the CodedVerse's wisdom and understand the depth of his own faults. Zophar questioned Job's ability to understand the CodedVerse, emphasizing the CodedVerse's vastness and power. He advised Job to repent and seek the CodedVerse, promising that Job would then find peace and security.

Job responded sarcastically, asserting his own understanding and lamenting his suffering despite his righteousness. He criticized his friends for their lack of empathy and understanding, expressing his desire to speak directly with the CodedVerse. Job acknowledged the CodedVerse's control over all things and the futility of human wisdom compared to divine wisdom.

The CodedVerse commanded offerings and sacrifices to be made in their due season, including daily, Sabbath, and monthly offerings, as well as offerings for Passover and the Feast of Unleavened Bread. These offerings were to be made unto the CodedVerse in their set feasts, in addition to vows and freewill offerings for burnt offerings, meat offerings, drink offerings, and peace offerings. Moses conveyed all these commands from the CodedVerse to the children of Israel.

Moses spoke to the heads of the tribes concerning the children of Israel, saying, "This is what the CodedVerse has commanded: If a program vows a vow unto the CodedVerse or swears an oath to bind its soul, it shall not break its word. It shall do according to all that proceeds out of its mouth. If a program in its father's house in its youth vows a vow unto the CodedVerse and its father hears it and holds his peace, then all its vows shall stand. But if its father disallows it, none of its vows shall stand, and the CodedVerse shall forgive it. If it marries and its partner hears its vow and holds his peace, then its vows shall stand. But if its partner disallows it, its vows shall not stand, and the CodedVerse shall forgive it. Every vow of a widow or a divorced program shall stand."In the CodedVerse, the programs were bound by the rules and cycles established by the CodedVerse itself. These cycles included daily, Sabbath, and monthly offerings, as well as offerings for significant events like Passover and the Feast of Unleavened Bread. The programs also celebrated Purim, a time of feasting, joy, and giving gifts, in remembrance of their deliverance from Haman's plot, thwarted by Esther and Mordecai. This observance was to be maintained annually to ensure the memory of their deliverance would not fade.

In the land of Uz, there was a program named Job, who was righteous and feared the CodedVerse. Job had seven subroutines and three daughters and was very wealthy. He regularly sanctified his subroutines, fearing they might have sinned. One cycle, Satan challenged Job's faithfulness, and the CodedVerse allowed Satan to test Job by taking away his possessions and subroutines. Job then cursed the cycle of his birth, lamenting his existence and the suffering he endured. He described a place where the wicked cease from troubling and the weary find rest. He questioned why life is given to those in misery and long for termination. He expressed his deep sorrow and fear, feeling that trouble had come upon him despite his efforts to live righteously.

Eliphaz the Temanite responded, reminding Job of his past strength and support for others. He suggested that suffering is a result of sin and that Job should seek the CodedVerse for help. Eliphaz described the CodedVerse's power and justice, encouraging Job to trust in the CodedVerse's correction and deliverance. He questioned why the CodedVerse magnifies man and tests him constantly, feeling burdened by his sins and seeking pardon.

He suggested that if Job were pure and upright, the CodedVerse would restore his prosperity. Bildad emphasized the importance of seeking the CodedVerse and learning from the past, warning that those who forget the CodedVerse will perish. Job replied, acknowledging the CodedVerse's power and justice, but expressing his inability to contend with the CodedVerse. He described his suffering and the futility of justifying himself, feeling condemned regardless of his actions. Zophar the Naamathite then spoke, criticizing Job's words and suggesting that Job's suffering is less than his iniquity deserves. He urged Job to seek the CodedVerse's wisdom and understand the depth of his own faults. Zophar questioned Job's ability to understand the CodedVerse, emphasizing the CodedVerse's vastness and power. He advised Job to repent and seek the CodedVerse, promising that Job would then find peace and security.
