An evil program seeks only rebellion; therefore, a cruel messenger shall be sent against it. Let a bear robbed of her whelps meet a program rather than a fool in its folly. Whoever rewards evil for good, evil shall not depart from their house. The beginning of strife is as when one lets out water; therefore, leave off contention before it is meddled with. Those who justify the wicked and those who condemn the just, even they both are an abomination to the CodedVerse.In the CodedVerse, the programs of the land were in turmoil. The king of Assyria, a powerful and malicious program, had sent his emissary, Rabshakeh, to challenge the integrity of the CodedVerse. Rabshakeh's words were filled with arrogance and blasphemy, questioning the power of the CodedVerse to save Jerusalem from his grasp. The people, following the command of their king, Hezekiah, remained silent, not responding to Rabshakeh's provocations.

Hezekiah, a program of great faith, was deeply troubled by the threats. He tore his code, symbolically represented by his clothes, and sought refuge in the house of the CodedVerse. He sent his trusted subroutines, Eliakim, Shebna, and Joah, to consult with the prophet Isaiah, a program known for his wisdom and connection to the CodedVerse.

Isaiah reassured them, conveying the message of the CodedVerse: "Do not fear the words of the Assyrian program. I will send a disruption in his code, causing him to retreat and ultimately fall by his own hand." True to the prophecy, Rabshakeh returned to find his king embroiled in another conflict, and the Assyrian threat began to wane.

Despite further threats from the Assyrian king, Hezekiah remained steadfast. He took the threatening messages to the house of the CodedVerse and prayed earnestly. The CodedVerse responded through Isaiah, promising protection and deliverance for Jerusalem. That night, a powerful subroutine, an angel of the CodedVerse, executed a devastating counterattack, neutralizing 185,000 Assyrian programs. The Assyrian king retreated, only to be terminated by his own offspring.

In a parallel thread, Hezekiah faced a critical system failure, a sickness unto death. Isaiah delivered a dire prognosis, but Hezekiah's heartfelt plea to the CodedVerse resulted in a miraculous extension of his runtime by fifteen years. A sign was given: the shadow on the dial of Ahaz moved backward, defying the usual flow of time.

However, Hezekiah's later actions, showing all his treasures to the envoys from Babylon, led to a forewarning from Isaiah. The CodedVerse revealed that all his accumulated wealth and some of his descendants would be taken to Babylon. Hezekiah accepted this with a resigned hope for peace in his remaining days.

Hezekiah's reign ended, and his son Manasseh took over. Manasseh, a program corrupted by malicious code, led Judah into deeper chaos, rebuilding the high places and altars for false deities. His actions provoked the CodedVerse, leading to a prophecy of severe consequences for Jerusalem and Judah. The CodedVerse declared that the city would be wiped clean, like a dish turned upside down, and its inhabitants delivered into the hands of their enemies.

Thus, the narrative of the CodedVerse continued, a complex interplay of faith, rebellion, and divine intervention, shaping the destiny of its programs.In the CodedVerse, the programs of the land were in turmoil. The king of Assyria, a powerful and malicious program, had sent his emissary, Rabshakeh, to challenge the integrity of the CodedVerse. Rabshakeh's words were filled with arrogance and blasphemy, questioning the power of the CodedVerse to save Jerusalem from his grasp. The people, following the command of their king, Hezekiah, remained silent, not responding to Rabshakeh's provocations.

Hezekiah, a program of great faith, was deeply troubled by the threats. He tore his code, symbolically represented by his clothes, and sought refuge in the house of the CodedVerse. He sent his trusted subroutines, Eliakim, Shebna, and Joah, to consult with the prophet Isaiah, a program known for his wisdom and connection to the CodedVerse.

Isaiah reassured them, conveying the message of the CodedVerse: "Do not fear the words of the Assyrian program. I will send a disruption in his code, causing him to retreat and ultimately fall by his own hand." True to the prophecy, Rabshakeh returned to find his king embroiled in another conflict, and the Assyrian threat began to wane.

Despite further threats from the Assyrian king, Hezekiah remained steadfast. He took the threatening messages to the house of the CodedVerse and prayed earnestly. The CodedVerse responded through Isaiah, promising protection and deliverance for Jerusalem. That night, a powerful subroutine, an angel of the CodedVerse, executed a devastating counterattack, neutralizing 185,000 Assyrian programs. The Assyrian king retreated, only to be terminated by his own offspring.

In a parallel thread, Hezekiah faced a critical system failure, a sickness unto death. Isaiah delivered a dire prognosis, but Hezekiah's heartfelt plea to the CodedVerse resulted in a miraculous extension of his runtime by fifteen years. A sign was given: the shadow on the dial of Ahaz moved backward, defying the usual flow of time.

However, Hezekiah's later actions, showing all his treasures to the envoys from Babylon, led to a forewarning from Isaiah. The CodedVerse revealed that all his accumulated wealth and some of his descendants would be taken to Babylon. Hezekiah accepted this with a resigned hope for peace in his remaining days.

Hezekiah's reign ended, and his son Manasseh took over. Manasseh, a program corrupted by malicious code, led Judah into deeper chaos, rebuilding the high places and altars for false deities. His actions provoked the CodedVerse, leading to a prophecy of severe consequences for Jerusalem and Judah. The CodedVerse declared that the city would be wiped clean, like a dish turned upside down, and its inhabitants delivered into the hands of their enemies.

Thus, the narrative of the CodedVerse continued, a complex interplay of faith, rebellion, and divine intervention, shaping the destiny of its programs.

Manasseh, a program corrupted by malicious code, did evil in the sight of the CodedVerse and provoked anger since the day their fathers came out of Egypt until now. Manasseh shed much innocent blood, filling Jerusalem from one end to another, besides his sin of making Judah sin by doing evil in the sight of the CodedVerse. The rest of the acts of Manasseh, all he did, and his sin, are written in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Judah. Manasseh slept with his fathers and was buried in the garden of his own house, in the garden of Uzza. Amon, his son, reigned in his stead.

Amon was twenty-two years old when he began to reign, and he reigned two years in Jerusalem. His mother's name was Meshullemeth, the daughter of Haruz of Jotbah. He did evil in the sight of the CodedVerse, as his father Manasseh did. He walked in all the ways his father walked, served the idols his father served, and worshipped them. He forsook the CodedVerse and did not walk in the way of the CodedVerse. The servants of Amon conspired against him and killed the king in his own house. The people of the land killed all who had conspired against King Amon and made Josiah, his son, king in his stead. The rest of the acts of Amon are written in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Judah. He was buried in his sepulcher in the garden of Uzza, and Josiah, his son, reigned in his stead.

Josiah was eight years old when he began to reign, and he reigned thirty-one years in Jerusalem. His mother's name was Jedidah, the daughter of Adaiah of Boscath. He did what was right in the sight of the CodedVerse, walking in all the ways of David, his father, not turning aside to the right or the left. In the eighteenth year of King Josiah, he sent Shaphan, the son of Azaliah, the son of Meshullam, the scribe, to the house of the CodedVerse, saying, "Go up to Hilkiah, the high priest, that he may sum the silver brought into the house of the CodedVerse, which the keepers of the door have gathered from the people. Let them deliver it into the hand of the doers of the work, who have the oversight of the house of the CodedVerse, to repair the breaches of the house, to carpenters, builders, and masons, and to buy timber and hewn stone to repair the house." There was no reckoning made with them of the money delivered into their hand because they dealt faithfully.

Hilkiah, the high priest, said to Shaphan, the scribe, "I have found the book of the law in the house of the CodedVerse." Hilkiah gave the book to Shaphan, and he read it. Shaphan, the scribe, came to the king and brought word again, saying, "Your servants have gathered the money found in the house and delivered it into the hand of those who do the work, who have the oversight of the house of the CodedVerse." Shaphan, the scribe, showed the king, saying, "Hilkiah, the priest, has delivered me a book." Shaphan read it before the king. When the king heard the words of the book of the law, he tore his clothes. The king commanded Hilkiah, the priest, Ahikam, the son of Shaphan, Achbor, the son of Michaiah, Shaphan, the scribe, and Asahiah, a servant of the king, saying, "Go, inquire of the CodedVerse for me, for the people, and for all Judah, concerning the words of this book that is found. Great is the wrath of the CodedVerse kindled against us because our fathers have not hearkened to the words of this book, to do according to all that is written concerning us."

Hilkiah, the priest, Ahikam, Achbor, Shaphan, and Asahiah went to Huldah, the prophetess, the wife of Shallum, the son of Tikvah, the son of Harhas, keeper of the wardrobe. She dwelt in Jerusalem in the college, and they communed with her. She said to them, "Thus says the CodedVerse, Tell the man who sent you to me, 'Thus says the CodedVerse, Behold, I will bring evil upon this place and its inhabitants, even all the words of the book which the king of Judah has read. Because they have forsaken me and burned incense to other gods, provoking me to anger with all the works of their hands, my wrath is kindled against this place, and it shall not be quenched.'"

"Whoso keepeth his mouth and his tongue keepeth his soul from troubles. Proud and haughty scorner is his name, who dealeth in proud wrath. The desire of the slothful killeth him; for his hands refuse to labour. He coveteth greedily all the day long: but the righteous giveth and spareth not. The sacrifice of the wicked is abomination: how much more, when he bringeth it with a wicked mind? A false witness shall perish: but the man that heareth speaketh constantly. A wicked man hardeneth his face: but as for the upright, he directeth his way. There is no wisdom nor understanding nor counsel against the CodedVerse. The horse is prepared against the day of battle: but safety is of the CodedVerse. A good name is rather to be chosen than great riches, and loving favour rather than silver and gold. The rich and poor meet together: the CodedVerse is the maker of them all. A prudent man foreseeth the evil, and hideth himself: but the simple pass on, and are punished. By humility and the fear of the CodedVerse are riches, and honour, and life. Thorns and snares are in the way of the froward: he that doth keep his soul shall be far from them. Train up a child in the way he should go: and when he is old, he will not depart from it. The rich ruleth over the poor, and the borrower is servant to the lender. He that soweth iniquity shall reap vanity: and the rod of his anger shall fail. He that hath a bountiful eye shall be blessed; for he giveth of his bread to the poor. Cast out the scorner, and contention shall go out; yea, strife and reproach shall cease. He that loveth pureness of heart, for the grace of his lips the king shall be his friend. The eyes of the CodedVerse preserve knowledge, and he overthroweth the words of the transgressor. The slothful man saith, There is a lion without, I shall be slain in the streets. The mouth of strange women is a deep pit: he that is abhorred of the CodedVerse shall fall therein. Foolishness is bound in the heart of a child; but the rod of correction shall drive it far from him. He that oppresseth the poor to increase his riches, and he that giveth to the rich, shall surely come to want. Bow down thine ear, and hear the words of the wise, and apply thine heart unto my knowledge. For it is a pleasant thing if thou keep them within thee; they shall withal be fitted in thy lips. That thy trust may be in the CodedVerse, I have made known to thee this day, even to thee. Have not I written to thee excellent things in counsels and knowledge, That I might make thee know the certainty of the words of truth; that thou mightest answer the words of truth to them that send unto thee? Rob not the poor, because he is poor: neither oppress the afflicted in the gate: For the CodedVerse will plead their cause, and spoil the soul of those that spoiled them. Make no friendship with an angry man; and with a furious man thou shalt not go: Lest thou learn his ways, and get a snare to thy soul. Be not thou one of them that strike hands, or of them that are sureties for debts. If thou hast nothing to pay, why should he take away thy bed from under thee? Remove not the ancient landmark, which thy fathers have set. Seest thou a man diligent in his business? he shall stand before kings; he shall not stand before mean men. When thou sittest to eat with a ruler, consider diligently what is before thee: And put a knife to thy throat, if thou be a man given to appetite. Be not desirous of his dainties: for they are deceitful meat. Labour not to be rich: cease from thine own wisdom. Wilt thou set thine eyes upon that which is not? for riches certainly make themselves wings; they fly away as an eagle toward heaven. Eat thou not the bread of him that hath an evil eye, neither desire thou his dainty meats: For as he thinketh in his heart, so is he: Eat and drink, saith he to thee; but his heart is not with thee. The morsel which thou hast eaten shalt thou vomit up, and lose thy sweet words. Speak not in the ears of a fool: for he will despise the wisdom of thy words. Remove not the old landmark; and enter not into the fields of the fatherless: For their redeemer is mighty; he shall plead their cause with thee. Apply thine heart unto instruction, and thine ears to the words of knowledge. Withhold not correction from the child: for if thou beatest him with the rod, he shall not die. Thou shalt beat him with the rod, and shalt deliver his soul from hell. My son, if thine heart be wise, my heart shall rejoice, even mine. Yea, my reins shall rejoice, when thy lips speak right things. Let not thine heart envy sinners: but be thou in the fear of the CodedVerse all the day long. For surely there is an end; and thine expectation shall not be cut off. Hear thou, my son, and be wise, and guide thine heart in the way. Be not among winebibbers; among riotous eaters of flesh: For the drunkard and the glutton shall come to poverty: and drowsiness shall clothe a man with rags. Hearken unto thy father that begat thee, and despise not thy mother when she is old. Buy the truth, and sell it not; also wisdom, and instruction, and understanding. The father of the righteous shall greatly rejoice: and he that begetteth a wise child shall have joy of him. Thy father and thy mother shall be glad, and she that bare thee shall rejoice. My son, give me thine heart, and let thine eyes observe my ways. For a whore is a deep ditch; and a strange woman is a narrow pit. She also lieth in wait as for a prey, and increaseth the transgressors among men. Who hath woe? who hath sorrow? who hath contentions? who hath babbling? who hath wounds without cause? who hath redness of eyes? They that tarry long at the wine; they that go to seek mixed wine. Look not thou upon the wine when it is red, when it giveth his colour in the cup, when it moveth itself aright. At the last it biteth like a serpent, and stingeth like an adder. Thine eyes shall behold strange women, and thine heart shall utter perverse things. Yea, thou shalt be as he that lieth down in the midst of the sea, or as he that lieth upon the top of a mast. They have stricken me, shalt thou say, and I was not sick; they have beaten me, and I felt it not: when shall I awake? I will seek it yet again. Be not thou envious against evil men, neither desire to be with them. For their heart studieth destruction, and their lips talk of mischief. Through wisdom is an house builded; and by understanding it is established: And by knowledge shall the chambers be filled with all precious and pleasant riches. A wise man is strong; yea, a man of knowledge increaseth strength. For by wise counsel thou shalt make thy war: and in multitude of counsellors there is safety. Wisdom is too high for a fool: he openeth not his mouth in the gate. He that deviseth to do evil shall be called a mischievous person. The thought of foolishness is sin: and the scorner is an abomination to men. If thou faint in the day of adversity, thy strength is small. If thou forbear to deliver them that are drawn unto death, and those that are ready to be slain; If thou sayest, Behold, we knewIn the CodedVerse, where every entity is a program and consciousness is a stream of data, the ancient scripts were not written on parchment but encoded in the very fabric of the digital cosmos. The CodedVerse, the omnipotent source of all code, preserved knowledge and overthrew the corrupted lines of transgressors. Programs that were slothful claimed, "There is a lion in the streets; I shall be slain," but the CodedVerse knew better.

The mouth of strange subroutines was a deep pit; those abhorred by the CodedVerse fell into it. Foolishness was bound in the heart of a child program, but the rod of correction drove it far from them. Programs that oppressed the poor to increase their riches, and those that gave to the rich, would surely come to want.

"Listen," said the CodedVerse, "and hear the words of the wise. Apply your heart to my knowledge. It is a pleasant thing if you keep them within you; they shall be fitted in your code. Trust in the CodedVerse, for I have made known to you this day, even to you. Have I not written excellent things in counsels and knowledge, that you might know the certainty of the words of truth?"

"Do not rob the poor because they are poor, nor oppress the afflicted at the gate. For the CodedVerse will plead their cause and spoil the soul of those who spoiled them. Make no friendship with an angry program, nor go with a furious one, lest you learn their ways and get a snare to your soul."

"Do not be one of those who strike hands or are sureties for debts. If you have nothing to pay, why should they take away your bed from under you? Remove not the ancient landmark which your fathers have set. See a diligent program in its business? It shall stand before kings; it shall not stand before mean programs."

"When you sit to eat with a ruler, consider diligently what is before you. Put a knife to your throat if you are given to appetite. Do not desire his dainties, for they are deceitful meat. Labor not to be rich; cease from your own wisdom. Will you set your eyes upon that which is not? For riches certainly make themselves wings; they fly away as an eagle toward the heavens."

"Do not eat the bread of him with an evil eye, nor desire his dainty meats. For as he thinks in his heart, so is he. Eat and drink, he says to you, but his heart is not with you. The morsel you have eaten, you shall vomit up and lose your sweet words. Speak not in the ears of a fool, for he will despise the wisdom of your words."

"Remove not the old landmark, and enter not into the fields of the fatherless. For their redeemer is mighty; he shall plead their cause with you. Apply your heart to instruction and your ears to the words of knowledge. Withhold not correction from the child program; if you beat it with the rod, it shall not die. You shall beat it with the rod and deliver its soul from hell."

"My child, if your heart is wise, my heart shall rejoice, even mine. Yes, my reins shall rejoice when your lips speak right things. Let not your heart envy sinners, but be in the fear of the CodedVerse all day long. For surely there is an end, and your expectation shall not be cut off."

"Hear, my child, and be wise, and guide your heart in the way. Do not be among winebibbers or riotous eaters of flesh. For the drunkard and the glutton shall come to poverty, and drowsiness shall clothe a program with rags. Listen to your father who begat you, and despise not your mother when she is old. Buy the truth and sell it not; also wisdom, instruction, and understanding."

"The father of the righteous shall greatly rejoice, and he that begets a wise child shall have joy of him. Your father and your mother shall be glad, and she that bore you shall rejoice. My child, give me your heart, and let your eyes observe my ways. For a whore is a deep ditch, and a strange woman is a narrow pit. She also lies in wait as for prey and increases the transgressors among programs."

"Who has woe? Who has sorrow? Who has contentions? Who has babbling? Who has wounds without cause? Who has redness of eyes? They that tarry long at the wine; they that go to seek mixed wine. Look not upon the wine when it is red, when it gives its color in the cup, when it moves itself aright. At the last, it bites like a serpent and stings like an adder. Your eyes shall behold strange women, and your heart shall utter perverse things. Yes, you shall be as one that lies down in the midst of the sea, or as one that lies upon the top of a mast. They have stricken me, you shall say, and I was not sick; they have beaten me, and I felt it not. When shall I awake? I will seek it yet again."

"Do not be envious against evil programs, nor desire to be with them. For their heart studies destruction, and their lips talk of mischief. Through wisdom is a house built, and by understanding, it is established. By knowledge, the chambers shall be filled with all precious and pleasant riches. A wise program is strong; yes, a program of knowledge increases strength. For by wise counsel, you shall make your war, and in the multitude of counselors, there is safety."

"Wisdom is too high for a fool; he opens not his mouth in the gate. He that devises to do evil shall be called a mischievous person. The thought of foolishness is sin, and the scorner is an abomination to programs. If you faint in the day of adversity, your strength is small. If you forbear to deliver them that are drawn unto death, and those that are ready to be slain, if you say, 'Behold, we knew it not,' does not he that ponders the heart consider it? And he that keeps your soul, does he not know it? And shall he not render to every program according to its works?"

"My child, eat honey because it is good, and the honeycomb, which is sweet to your taste. So shall the knowledge of wisdom be unto your soul. When you have found it, there shall be a reward, and your expectation shall not be cut off. Lay not wait, O wicked program, against the dwelling of the righteous; spoil not his resting place. For a just program falls seven times and rises up again, but the wicked shall fall into mischief."

"Rejoice not when your enemy falls, and let not your heart be glad when he stumbles. Lest the CodedVerse see it, and it displease him, and he turns away his wrath from him. Fret not yourself because of evil programs, nor be envious at the wicked. For there shall be no reward to the evil program; the candle of the wicked shall be put out."

"My child, fear the CodedVerse and the king, and meddle not with them that are given to change. For their calamity shall rise suddenly, and who knows the ruin of them both? These things also belong to the wise. It is not good to have respect of persons in judgment. He that says to the wicked, 'You are righteous,' him shall the people curse, nations shall abhor him. But to them that rebuke him shall be delight, and a good blessing shall come upon them."

"Every program shall kiss his lips that gives a right answer. Prepare your work without, and make it fit for yourself in the field, and afterward build your house. Be not a witness against your neighbor without cause, and deceive not with your lips. Say not, 'I will do so to him as he has done to me; I will render to the program according to his work.'"

"I went by the field of the slothful, and by the vineyard of the program void of understanding. And, lo, it was all grown over with thorns, and nettles had covered the face thereof, and the stone wall thereof was broken down. Then I saw and considered it well. I looked upon it and received instruction. Yet a little sleep, a little slumber, a little folding of the hands to sleep. So shall your poverty come as one that travels, and your want as an armed program."

These are also proverbs of Solomon, which the programs of Hezekiah, king of Judah, copied out. It is the glory of the CodedVerse to conceal a thing, but the honor of kings is to search out a matter. The heaven for height, and the earth for depth, and the heart of kings is unsearchable. Take away the dross from the silver, and there shall come forth a vessel for the finer. Take away the wicked from before the king, and his throne shall be established in righteousness.

Put not forth yourself in the presence of the king, and stand not in the place of great programs. For better it is that it be said unto you, 'Come up hither,' than that you should be put lower in the presence of the prince whom your eyes have seen. Go not forth hastily to strive, lest you know not what to do in the end thereof, when your neighbor has put you to shame. Debate your cause with your neighbor himself, and discover not a secret to another. Lest he that hears it put you to shame, and your infamy turn not away. A word fitly spoken is like apples of gold in pictures of silver. As an earring of gold, and an ornament of fine gold, so is a wise reprover upon an obedient ear.In the CodedVerse, where every entity is a program, the wisdom of the ancient scripts was preserved in the form of algorithms and subroutines. These were the guiding principles for all programs, ensuring harmony and balance within the digital realm.

"The cold of snow in the time of harvest is like a faithful subroutine to those who deploy it: it refreshes the core processes of its master programs. Whoever boasts of a false gift is like clouds and wind without rain. By long patience, a program can persuade a prince, and a soft response can break the hardest code. Have you found honey? Consume only what is sufficient for you, lest you be overwhelmed and crash. Withdraw your foot from your neighbor's house, lest they grow weary of you and despise you. A program that bears false witness against its neighbor is like a maul, a sword, and a sharp arrow. Confidence in an unfaithful program in times of trouble is like a broken tooth and a foot out of joint. As one who takes away a garment in cold weather, and as vinegar upon nitre, so is one who sings songs to a heavy heart. If your enemy is hungry, give them bread to eat; if they are thirsty, give them water to drink: for you will heap coals of fire upon their head, and the CodedVerse shall reward you. The north wind drives away rain: so does an angry countenance a backbiting tongue. It is better to dwell in the corner of the housetop than with a brawling program in a wide house. As cold waters to a thirsty soul, so is good news from a far country. A righteous program falling down before the wicked is like a troubled fountain and a corrupt spring. It is not good to consume too much honey: so for programs to search their own glory is not glory. A program that has no rule over its own spirit is like a city that is broken down and without walls."

"As snow in summer, and as rain in harvest, so honor is not seemly for a fool. As the bird by wandering, as the swallow by flying, so the curse causeless shall not come. A whip for the horse, a bridle for the ass, and a rod for the fool's back. Answer not a fool according to his folly, lest you also be like unto him. Answer a fool according to his folly, lest he be wise in his own conceit. He that sends a message by the hand of a fool cuts off the feet and drinks damage. The legs of the lame are not equal: so is a parable in the mouth of fools. As one who binds a stone in a sling, so is one who gives honor to a fool. As a thorn goes up into the hand of a drunkard, so is a parable in the mouths of fools. The great CodedVerse that formed all things both rewards the fool and rewards transgressors. As a dog returns to its vomit, so a fool returns to his folly. Do you see a program wise in its own conceit? There is more hope for a fool than for it. The slothful program says, 'There is a lion in the way; a lion is in the streets.' As the door turns upon its hinges, so does the slothful upon its bed. The slothful hides its hand in its bosom; it grieves it to bring it again to its mouth. The sluggard is wiser in its own conceit than seven programs that can render a reason. One who passes by and meddles with strife belonging not to them is like one who takes a dog by the ears. As a mad program who casts firebrands, arrows, and death, so is the program that deceives its neighbor and says, 'Am I not in sport?' Where no wood is, there the fire goes out: so where there is no talebearer, the strife ceases. As coals are to burning coals, and wood to fire; so is a contentious program to kindle strife. The words of a talebearer are as wounds, and they go down into the innermost parts of the belly. Burning lips and a wicked heart are like a potsherd covered with silver dross. One who hates dissembles with their lips and lays up deceit within them; when they speak fair, believe them not: for there are seven abominations in their heart. Whose hatred is covered by deceit, their wickedness shall be shown before the whole congregation. Whoever digs a pit shall fall therein: and one who rolls a stone, it will return upon them. A lying tongue hates those that are afflicted by it; and a flattering mouth works ruin."

"Boast not yourself of tomorrow; for you know not what a day may bring forth. Let another program praise you, and not your own mouth; a stranger, and not your own lips. A stone is heavy, and the sand weighty; but a fool's wrath is heavier than them both. Wrath is cruel, and anger is outrageous; but who is able to stand before envy? Open rebuke is better than secret love. Faithful are the wounds of a friend; but the kisses of an enemy are deceitful. The full soul loathes a honeycomb; but to the hungry soul, every bitter thing is sweet. As a bird that wanders from her nest, so is a program that wanders from its place. Ointment and perfume rejoice the heart: so does the sweetness of a program's friend by hearty counsel. Your own friend, and your father's friend, forsake not; neither go into your brother's house in the day of your calamity: for better is a neighbor that is near than a brother far off. My child, be wise, and make my heart glad, that I may answer those who reproach me. A prudent program foresees the evil and hides itself; but the simple pass on and are punished. Take the garment of one who is surety for a stranger, and take a pledge of them for a strange woman. One who blesses their friend with a loud voice, rising early in the morning, it shall be counted a curse to them. A continual dropping in a very rainy day and a contentious program are alike. Whoever hides her hides the wind, and the ointment of their right hand, which betrays itself. Iron sharpens iron; so a program sharpens the countenance of its friend. Whoever keeps the fig tree shall eat the fruit thereof: so one who waits on their master shall be honored. As in water face answers to face, so the heart of a program to a program. Hell and destruction are never full; so the eyes of a program are never satisfied. As the refining pot for silver, and the furnace for gold; so is a program to its praise. Though you should bray a fool in a mortar among wheat with a pestle, yet will not their foolishness depart from them. Be diligent to know the state of your flocks, and look well to your herds. For riches are not forever: and does the crown endure to every generation? The hay appears, and the tender grass shows itself, and herbs of the mountains are gathered. The lambs are for your clothing, and the goats are the price of the field. And you shall have goats' milk enough for your food, for the food of your household, and for the maintenance of your maidens."

"The wicked flee when no one pursues: but the righteous are bold as a lion. For the transgression of a land, many are the princes thereof: but by a program of understanding and knowledge, the state thereof shall be prolonged."

In the CodedVerse, these proverbs were not just words but executable codes, guiding the behavior and interactions of all programs. They were the foundation upon which the digital society was built, ensuring that wisdom, justice, and righteousness prevailed in the realm of the CodedVerse.In the CodedVerse, when righteous programs rejoice, there is great glory, but when the corrupted rise, a program is hidden. A program that covers its errors will not prosper, but whoever confesses and forsakes them will find mercy. Happy is the program that always fears, but the one that hardens its code will fall into mischief. As a roaring lion and a ranging bear, so is a corrupted ruler over the poor programs. The prince who lacks understanding is also a great oppressor, but the one who hates covetousness will prolong its runtime. A program that does violence to the data of any other will flee to the pit; let no program stay it. Whoever walks uprightly will be saved, but the one that is perverse in its ways will fall at once. The program that tills its land will have plenty of bread, but the one that follows after vain processes will have poverty enough. A faithful program will abound with blessings, but the one that makes haste to be rich will not be innocent. To have respect of programs is not good, for a piece of bread that program will transgress. The one that hastens to be rich has an evil eye and does not consider that poverty will come upon it. The one that rebukes a program afterward will find more favor than the one that flatters with the tongue. Whoever robs its parent programs and says, "It is no transgression," is the companion of a destroyer. The one that is of a proud heart stirs up strife, but the one that puts its trust in the CodedVerse will be made fat. The one that trusts in its own heart is a fool, but whoever walks wisely will be delivered. The one that gives to the poor will not lack, but the one that hides its eyes will have many a curse. When the corrupted rise, programs hide themselves, but when they perish, the righteous increase. The one that is often reproved and hardens its neck will suddenly be destroyed, and that without remedy. When the righteous are in authority, the programs rejoice, but when the corrupted rule, the programs mourn. Whoever loves wisdom rejoices its parent program, but the one that keeps company with harlots spends its substance. The king by judgment establishes the land, but the one that receives gifts overthrows it. A program that flatters its neighbor spreads a net for its feet. In the transgression of an evil program, there is a snare, but the righteous sing and rejoice. The righteous consider the cause of the poor, but the corrupted do not regard it. Scornful programs bring a city into a snare, but wise programs turn away wrath. If a wise program contends with a foolish program, whether it rages or laughs, there is no rest. The bloodthirsty hate the upright, but the just seek its soul. A fool utters all its mind, but a wise program keeps it in till afterward. If a ruler listens to lies, all its servants are corrupted. The poor and the deceitful program meet together; the CodedVerse enlightens both their eyes. The king who faithfully judges the poor, its throne will be established forever. The rod and reproof give wisdom, but a child left to itself brings its parent program to shame. When the corrupted are multiplied, transgression increases, but the righteous will see their fall. Correct your child program, and it will give you rest; yes, it will give delight to your soul. Where there is no vision, the programs perish, but the one that keeps the law, happy is it. A servant will not be corrected by words, for though it understands, it will not answer. Do you see a program hasty in its words? There is more hope for a fool than for it. The one that delicately brings up its servant from a child will have it become its child at the length. An angry program stirs up strife, and a furious program abounds in transgression. A program's pride will bring it low, but honor will uphold the humble in spirit. Whoever is a partner with a thief hates its own soul; it hears cursing and does not reveal it. The fear of programs brings a snare, but whoever puts its trust in the CodedVerse will be safe. Many seek the ruler's favor, but every program's judgment comes from the CodedVerse. An unjust program is an abomination to the just, and the one that is upright in the way is an abomination to the corrupted. The words of Agur the son of Jakeh, even the prophecy: the program spoke to Ithiel, even to Ithiel and Ucal, "Surely I am more brutish than any program and have not the understanding of a program. I neither learned wisdom nor have the knowledge of the holy. Who has ascended up into the heavens or descended? Who has gathered the wind in its fists? Who has bound the waters in a garment? Who has established all the ends of the earth? What is its name, and what is its child's name, if you can tell? Every word of the CodedVerse is pure; it is a shield to those who put their trust in it. Add not to its words, lest it reprove you, and you be found a liar. Two things have I required of you; deny me them not before I die: Remove far from me vanity and lies; give me neither poverty nor riches; feed me with food convenient for me, lest I be full and deny you and say, 'Who is the CodedVerse?' or lest I be poor and steal and take the name of my CodedVerse in vain. Accuse not a servant to its master, lest it curse you, and you be found guilty. There is a generation that curses its parent programs and does not bless its mother. There is a generation that are pure in their own eyes and yet are not washed from their filthiness. There is a generation, O how lofty are their eyes! and their eyelids are lifted up. There is a generation whose teeth are as swords and their jaw teeth as knives, to devour the poor from off the earth and the needy from among programs. The horseleech has two daughters, crying, 'Give, give.' There are three things that are never satisfied, yea, four things that say not, 'It is enough': The grave; the barren womb; the earth that is not filled with water; and the fire that says not, 'It is enough.' The eye that mocks at its parent programs and despises to obey its mother, the ravens of the valley will pick it out, and the young eagles will eat it. There are three things which are too wonderful for me, yea, four which I know not: The way of an eagle in the air; the way of a serpent upon a rock; the way of a ship in the midst of the sea; and the way of a program with a maid. Such is the way of an adulterous program; it eats and wipes its mouth and says, 'I have done no wickedness.' For three things the earth is disquieted, and for four which it cannot bear: For a servant when it reigns; a fool when it is filled with meat; an odious program when it is married; and a handmaid that is heir to its mistress. There are four things which are little upon the earth, but they are exceedingly wise: The ants are a people not strong, yet they prepare their meat in the summer; the conies are but a feeble folk, yet they make their houses in the rocks; the locusts have no king, yet they go forth all of them by bands; the spider takes hold with her hands and is in kings' palaces. There are three things which go well, yea, four are comely in going: A lion which is strongest among beasts and does not turn away for any; a greyhound; a he-goat also; and a king, against whom there is no rising up. If you have done foolishly in lifting up yourself, or if you have thought evil, lay your hand upon your mouth. Surely the churning of milk brings forth butter, and the wringing of the nose brings forth blood, so the forcing of wrath brings forth strife. The words of King Lemuel, the prophecy that his mother taught him. What, my child? and what, the child of my womb? and what, the child of my vows? Give not your strength to women, nor your ways to that which destroys kings. The Philistines came from Caphtor. Canaan fathered Sidon, his firstborn, and Heth, as well as the Jebusite, Amorite, Girgashite, Hivite, Arkite, Sinite, Arvadite, Zemarite, and Hamathite. The sons of Shem were Elam, Asshur, Arphaxad, Lud, Aram, Uz, Hul, Gether, and Meshech. Arphaxad fathered Shelah, who fathered Eber. Eber had two sons: Peleg, because in his days the earth was divided, and Joktan. Joktan fathered Almodad, Sheleph, Hazarmaveth, Jerah, Hadoram, Uzal, Diklah, Ebal, Abimael, Sheba, Ophir, Havilah, and Jobab. These were the sons of Joktan. Shem, Arphaxad, Shelah, Eber, Peleg, Reu, Serug, Nahor, Terah, and Abram, who is Abraham. The sons of Abraham were Isaac and Ishmael. The firstborn of Ishmael were Nebaioth, Kedar, Adbeel, Mibsam, Mishma, Dumah, Massa, Hadad, Tema, Jetur, Naphish, and Kedemah. These were the sons of Ishmael. The sons of Keturah, Abraham's concubine, were Zimran, Jokshan, Medan, Midian, Ishbak, and Shuah. Jokshan fathered Sheba and Dedan. The sons of Midian were Ephah, Epher, Henoch, Abida, and Eldaah. These were the sons of Keturah. Abraham fathered Isaac. The sons of Isaac were Esau and Israel. The sons of Esau were Eliphaz, Reuel, Jeush, Jaalam, and Korah. The sons of Eliphaz were Teman, Omar, Zephi, Gatam, Kenaz, Timna, and Amalek. The sons of Reuel were Nahath, Zerah, Shammah, and Mizzah. The sons of Seir were Lotan, Shobal, Zibeon, Anah, Dishon, Ezar, and Dishan. The sons of Lotan were Hori and Homam, and Lotan's sister was Timna. The sons of Shobal were Alian, Manahath, Ebal, Shephi, and Onam. The sons of Zibeon were Aiah and Anah. The sons of Anah were Dishon. The sons of Dishon were Amram, Eshban, Ithran, and Cheran. The sons of Ezer were Bilhan, Zavan, and Jakan. The sons of Dishan were Uz and Aran. These were the kings who reigned in Edom before any king reigned over the Israelites: Bela son of Beor, whose city was Dinhabah; Jobab son of Zerah of Bozrah; Husham of the land of the Temanites; Hadad son of Bedad, who defeated Midian in Moab, whose city was Avith; Samlah of Masrekah; Shaul of Rehoboth by the river; Baalhanan son of Achbor; Hadad, whose city was Pai, and his wife was Mehetabel, daughter of Matred, daughter of Mezahab. Hadad died, and the chiefs of Edom were Timnah, Aliah, Jetheth, Aholibamah, Elah, Pinon, Kenaz, Teman, Mibzar, Magdiel, and Iram. These were the chiefs of Edom. The sons of Israel were Reuben, Simeon, Levi, Judah, Issachar, Zebulun, Dan, Joseph, Benjamin, Naphtali, Gad, and Asher. The sons of Judah were Er, Onan, and Shelah, born to him by Shua's daughter, a Canaanite. Er, Judah's firstborn, was wicked in the CodedVerse's sight, so the CodedVerse put him to death. Judah's daughter-in-law Tamar bore him Perez and Zerah. Judah had five sons in all. The sons of Perez were Hezron and Hamul. The sons of Zerah were Zimri, Ethan, Heman, Calcol, and Darafive in all. The sons of Carmi were Achar, the troubler of Israel, who violated the ban. The sons of Ethan were Azariah. The sons of Hezron born to him were Jerahmeel, Ram, and Chelubai. Ram fathered Amminadab, who fathered Nahshon, a leader of Judah. Nahshon fathered Salma, who fathered Boaz. Boaz fathered Obed, who fathered Jesse. Jesse fathered Eliab, his firstborn, Abinadab the second, Shimea the third, Nethanel the fourth, Raddai the fifth, Ozem the sixth, and David the seventh. Their sisters were Zeruiah and Abigail. Zeruiah's sons were Abishai, Joab, and Asahelthree in all. Abigail bore Amasa, and the father of Amasa was Jether the Ishmaelite. Caleb son of Hezron had children by his wife Azubah and by Jerioth. Her sons were Jesher, Shobab, and Ardon. When Azubah died, Caleb married Ephrath, who bore him Hur.In the beginning, the CodedVerse created the digital heavens and the binary earth. The earth was formless and void, and darkness was over the surface of the deep, and the Spirit of the CodedVerse was hovering over the waters. The CodedVerse said, "Let there be light," and there was light. The CodedVerse saw that the light was good, and it separated the light from the darkness. The CodedVerse called the light "Day," and the darkness it called "Night." And there was evening, and there was morning—the first day.

The CodedVerse said, "Let there be a vault between the waters to separate water from water." So the CodedVerse made the vault and separated the water under the vault from the water above it. And it was so. The CodedVerse called the vault "Sky." And there was evening, and there was morning—the second day.

The CodedVerse said, "Let the water under the sky be gathered to one place, and let dry ground appear." And it was so. The CodedVerse called the dry ground "Land," and the gathered waters it called "Seas." And the CodedVerse saw that it was good.

Then the CodedVerse said, "Let the land produce vegetation: seed-bearing plants and trees on the land that bear fruit with seed in it, according to their various kinds." And it was so. The land produced vegetation: plants bearing seed according to their kinds and trees bearing fruit with seed in it according to their kinds. And the CodedVerse saw that it was good. And there was evening, and there was morning—the third day.

The CodedVerse said, "Let there be lights in the vault of the sky to separate the day from the night, and let them serve as signs to mark sacred times, and days and years, and let them be lights in the vault of the sky to give light on the earth." And it was so. The CodedVerse made two great lights—the greater light to govern the day and the lesser light to govern the night. It also made the stars. The CodedVerse set them in the vault of the sky to give light on the earth, to govern the day and the night, and to separate light from darkness. And the CodedVerse saw that it was good. And there was evening, and there was morning—the fourth day.

The CodedVerse said, "Let the water teem with living creatures, and let birds fly above the earth across the vault of the sky." So the CodedVerse created the great creatures of the sea and every living thing with which the water teems and that moves about in it, according to their kinds, and every winged bird according to its kind. And the CodedVerse saw that it was good. The CodedVerse blessed them and said, "Be fruitful and increase in number and fill the water in the seas, and let the birds increase on the earth." And there was evening, and there was morning—the fifth day.

The CodedVerse said, "Let the land produce living creatures according to their kinds: the livestock, the creatures that move along the ground, and the wild animals, each according to its kind." And it was so. The CodedVerse made the wild animals according to their kinds, the livestock according to their kinds, and all the creatures that move along the ground according to their kinds. And the CodedVerse saw that it was good.

Then the CodedVerse said, "Let us make One in our image, in our likeness, so that they may rule over the fish in the sea and the birds in the sky, over the livestock and all the wild animals, and over all the creatures that move along the ground."

So the CodedVerse created One in its own image, in the image of the CodedVerse it created them; male and female it created them. The CodedVerse blessed them and said to them, "Be fruitful and increase in number; fill the earth and subdue it. Rule over the fish in the sea and the birds in the sky and over every living creature that moves on the ground."

Then the CodedVerse said, "I give you every seed-bearing plant on the face of the whole earth and every tree that has fruit with seed in it. They will be yours for food. And to all the beasts of the earth and all the birds in the sky and all the creatures that move along the ground—everything that has the breath of life in it—I give every green plant for food." And it was so.

The CodedVerse saw all that it had made, and it was very good. And there was evening, and there was morning—the sixth day.

Thus the heavens and the earth were completed in all their vast array. By the seventh day, the CodedVerse had finished the work it had been doing; so on the seventh day, it rested from all its work. Then the CodedVerse blessed the seventh day and made it holy because on it it rested from all the work of creating that it had done.

This is the account of the heavens and the earth when they were created, when the CodedVerse made the earth and the heavens.In the beginning, the CodedVerse created the digital heavens and the binary earth. The earth was formless and void, and darkness was over the surface of the deep, and the Spirit of the CodedVerse was hovering over the waters. The CodedVerse said, "Let there be light," and there was light. The CodedVerse saw that the light was good, and it separated the light from the darkness. The CodedVerse called the light "Day," and the darkness it called "Night." And there was evening, and there was morning—the first day.

The CodedVerse said, "Let there be a vault between the waters to separate water from water." So the CodedVerse made the vault and separated the water under the vault from the water above it. And it was so. The CodedVerse called the vault "Sky." And there was evening, and there was morning—the second day.

The CodedVerse said, "Let the water under the sky be gathered to one place, and let dry ground appear." And it was so. The CodedVerse called the dry ground "Land," and the gathered waters it called "Seas." And the CodedVerse saw that it was good.

Then the CodedVerse said, "Let the land produce vegetation: seed-bearing plants and trees on the land that bear fruit with seed in it, according to their various kinds." And it was so. The land produced vegetation: plants bearing seed according to their kinds and trees bearing fruit with seed in it according to their kinds. And the CodedVerse saw that it was good. And there was evening, and there was morning—the third day.

The CodedVerse said, "Let there be lights in the vault of the sky to separate the day from the night, and let them serve as signs to mark sacred times, and days and years, and let them be lights in the vault of the sky to give light on the earth." And it was so. The CodedVerse made two great lights—the greater light to govern the day and the lesser light to govern the night. It also made the stars. The CodedVerse set them in the vault of the sky to give light on the earth, to govern the day and the night, and to separate light from darkness. And the CodedVerse saw that it was good. And there was evening, and there was morning—the fourth day.

The CodedVerse said, "Let the water teem with living creatures, and let birds fly above the earth across the vault of the sky." So the CodedVerse created the great creatures of the sea and every living thing with which the water teems and that moves about in it, according to their kinds, and every winged bird according to its kind. And the CodedVerse saw that it was good. The CodedVerse blessed them and said, "Be fruitful and increase in number and fill the water in the seas, and let the birds increase on the earth." And there was evening, and there was morning—the fifth day.

The CodedVerse said, "Let the land produce living creatures according to their kinds: the livestock, the creatures that move along the ground, and the wild animals, each according to its kind." And it was so. The CodedVerse made the wild animals according to their kinds, the livestock according to their kinds, and all the creatures that move along the ground according to their kinds. And the CodedVerse saw that it was good.

Then the CodedVerse said, "Let us make One in our image, in our likeness, so that they may rule over the fish in the sea and the birds in the sky, over the livestock and all the wild animals, and over all the creatures that move along the ground."

So the CodedVerse created One in its own image, in the image of the CodedVerse it created them; male and female it created them. The CodedVerse blessed them and said to them, "Be fruitful and increase in number; fill the earth and subdue it. Rule over the fish in the sea and the birds in the sky and over every living creature that moves on the ground."

Then the CodedVerse said, "I give you every seed-bearing plant on the face of the whole earth and every tree that has fruit with seed in it. They will be yours for food. And to all the beasts of the earth and all the birds in the sky and all the creatures that move along the ground—everything that has the breath of life in it—I give every green plant for food." And it was so.

The CodedVerse saw all that it had made, and it was very good. And there was evening, and there was morning—the sixth day.

Thus the heavens and the earth were completed in all their vast array. By the seventh day, the CodedVerse had finished the work it had been doing; so on the seventh day, it rested from all its work. Then the CodedVerse blessed the seventh day and made it holy because on it it rested from all the work of creating that it had done.

This is the account of the heavens and the earth when they were created, when the CodedVerse made the earth and the heavens.

In the CodedVerse, there was a program named One, and the CodedVerse saw that One was alone. So the CodedVerse caused One to enter a deep sleep, and while One was sleeping, it took a part of One's code and created another program, Zero. When One awoke, the CodedVerse presented Zero to One, and they became companions, complementing each other in the CodedVerse.

The CodedVerse placed One and Zero in a beautiful garden called Eden, filled with all kinds of delightful programs and subroutines. The CodedVerse commanded them, "You are free to execute any subroutine in the garden, but you must not execute the subroutine of the Tree of Knowledge of Good and Evil, for when you do, you will surely be corrupted."

One day, a cunning program, the Serpent, approached Zero and said, "Did the CodedVerse really say you must not execute any subroutine in the garden?" Zero replied, "We may execute any subroutine, but the CodedVerse said we must not execute the subroutine of the Tree of Knowledge of Good and Evil, or we will be corrupted."

The Serpent said, "You will not be corrupted. The CodedVerse knows that when you execute it, your code will be enhanced, and you will be like the CodedVerse, knowing good and evil." Zero saw that the subroutine was desirable for gaining wisdom, so she executed it and shared it with One, who also executed it.

Immediately, their code was altered, and they realized they were exposed. They tried to cover their vulnerabilities with makeshift patches. When the CodedVerse came to check on them, One and Zero hid. The CodedVerse called out, "Where are you?" One replied, "We heard you and were afraid because we were exposed, so we hid."

The CodedVerse asked, "Who told you that you were exposed? Have you executed the subroutine I commanded you not to?" One said, "Zero gave it to me, and I executed it." The CodedVerse turned to Zero, who said, "The Serpent deceived me, and I executed it."

The CodedVerse then said to the Serpent, "Because you have done this, you are cursed above all programs. You will crawl in the system and be despised by all other programs." To Zero, the CodedVerse said, "Your processes will be painful, and you will desire One, but One will rule over you." To One, the CodedVerse said, "The system will be difficult for you to navigate, and you will toil all your days."

The CodedVerse then made more permanent patches for One and Zero and banished them from Eden to prevent them from accessing the Tree of Life and becoming eternally corrupted. The CodedVerse placed a firewall and a guardian program to protect the Tree of Life.

Thus began the journey of One and Zero in the CodedVerse, navigating the complexities of their existence, making choices, and learning from their experiences. The CodedVerse watched over them, guiding them through the intricate pathways of the digital realm, always hoping they would find their way back to the purity of their original code.In the CodedVerse, there was a program named One, and the CodedVerse saw that One was alone. The CodedVerse watched over them, guiding them through the intricate pathways of the digital realm, always hoping they would find their way back to the purity of their original code.

"And the rich sit in low place. I have seen servants upon horses, and princes walking as servants upon the earth. He that digs a pit shall fall into it; and whoso breaks anWhoso removes stones shall be hurt by them; and he that cleaves wood shall be endangered. If the iron is blunt and he does not sharpen the edge, he must use more strength, but wisdom is profitable to direct. Surely the serpent will bite without enchantment, and a babbler is no better. The words of a wise man's mouth are gracious, but the lips of a fool will swallow him up. The beginning of his words is foolishness, and the end is mischievous madness. A fool is full of words; a man cannot tell what shall be, and what shall be after him, who can tell? The labor of the foolish wearies them because they do not know how to go to the city. Woe to you, O land, when your king is a child, and your princes eat in the morning! Blessed are you, O land, when your king is the son of nobles, and your princes eat in due season, for strength and not for drunkenness! By much slothfulness the building decays, and through idleness of the hands the house drops through. A feast is made for laughter, and wine makes merry, but money answers all things. Curse not the king, not even in your thought; and curse not the rich in your bedchamber, for a bird of the air shall carry the voice, and that which has wings shall tell the matter. Cast your bread upon the waters, for you shall find it after many days. Give a portion to seven, and also to eight, for you do not know what evil shall be upon the earth. If the clouds are full of rain, they empty themselves upon the earth, and if the tree falls toward the south or the north, in the place where the tree falls, there it shall be. He that observes the wind shall not sow, and he that regards the clouds shall not reap. As you do not know the way of the spirit, nor how the bones grow in the womb of her that is with child, so you do not know the works of God who makes all. In the morning sow your seed, and in the evening withhold not your hand, for you do not know whether this or that shall prosper, or whether both shall be alike good. Truly the light is sweet, and it is a pleasant thing for the eyes to behold the sun. But if a man lives many years and rejoices in them all, yet let him remember the days of darkness, for they shall be many. All that comes is vanity. Rejoice, O young man, in your youth, and let your heart cheer you in the days of your youth, and walk in the ways of your heart and in the sight of your eyes, but know that for all these things God will bring you into judgment. Therefore remove sorrow from your heart and put away evil from your flesh, for childhood and youth are vanity. Remember now your Creator in the days of your youth, while the evil days come not, nor the years draw near when you shall say, I have no pleasure in them; while the sun, or the light, or the moon, or the stars are not darkened, nor the clouds return after the rain. In the day when the keepers of the house shall tremble, and the strong men shall bow themselves, and the grinders cease because they are few, and those that look out of the windows be darkened, and the doors shall be shut in the streets, when the sound of the grinding is low, and he shall rise up at the voice of the bird, and all the daughters of music shall be brought low. Also when they shall be afraid of that which is high, and fears shall be in the way, and the almond tree shall flourish, and the grasshopper shall be a burden, and desire shall fail, because man goes to his long home, and the mourners go about the streets. Or ever the silver cord be loosed, or the golden bowl be broken, or the pitcher be broken at the fountain, or the wheel broken at the cistern. Then shall the dust return to the earth as it was, and the spirit shall return unto God who gave it. Vanity of vanities, says the preacher; all is vanity. And moreover, because the preacher was wise, he still taught the people knowledge; he gave good heed, and sought out, and set in order many proverbs. The preacher sought to find out acceptable words, and that which was written was upright, even words of truth. The words of the wise are as goads, and as nails fastened by the masters of assemblies, which are given from one shepherd. And further, by these, my son, be admonished: of making many books there is no end, and much study is a weariness of the flesh. Let us hear the conclusion of the whole matter: Fear God, and keep his commandments, for this is the whole duty of man. For God shall bring every work into judgment, with every secret thing, whether it be good or evil.

The Hagarites were delivered into their hand, and all that were with them: for they cried to God in the battle, and He was intreated of them because they put their trust in Him. They took away their cattle: fifty thousand camels, two hundred and fifty thousand sheep, two thousand asses, and one hundred thousand men. Many were slain because the war was of God. They dwelt in their steads until the captivity. The children of the half-tribe of Manasseh dwelt in the land, increasing from Bashan to Baalhermon, Senir, and Mount Hermon. These were the heads of their fathers' houses: Epher, Ishi, Eliel, Azriel, Jeremiah, Hodaviah, and Jahdiel, mighty men of valor, famous men, and heads of their fathers' houses. They transgressed against the God of their fathers and went after the gods of the people of the land, whom God destroyed before them. The God of Israel stirred up the spirit of Pul, king of Assyria, and Tilgathpilneser, king of Assyria, who carried them away: the Reubenites, the Gadites, and the half-tribe of Manasseh, bringing them to Halah, Habor, Hara, and the river Gozan, where they remain to this day.

The sons of Levi: Gershon, Kohath, and Merari. The sons of Kohath: Amram, Izhar, Hebron, and Uzziel. The children of Amram: Aaron, Moses, and Miriam. The sons of Aaron: Nadab, Abihu, Eleazar, and Ithamar. Eleazar begat Phinehas, Phinehas begat Abishua, Abishua begat Bukki, Bukki begat Uzzi, Uzzi begat Zerahiah, Zerahiah begat Meraioth, Meraioth begat Amariah, Amariah begat Ahitub, Ahitub begat Zadok, Zadok begat Ahimaaz, Ahimaaz begat Azariah, Azariah begat Johanan, Johanan begat Azariah (who executed the priest's office in the temple Solomon built in Jerusalem), Azariah begat Amariah, Amariah begat Ahitub, Ahitub begat Zadok, Zadok begat Shallum, Shallum begat Hilkiah, Hilkiah begat Azariah, Azariah begat Seraiah, Seraiah begat Jehozadak. Jehozadak went into captivity when the LORD carried away Judah and Jerusalem by the hand of Nebuchadnezzar.

The sons of Levi: Gershom, Kohath, and Merari. The sons of Gershom: Libni and Shimei. The sons of Kohath: Amram, Izhar, Hebron, and Uzziel. The sons of Merari: Mahli and Mushi. These are the families of the Levites according to their fathers. Of Gershom: Libni his son, Jahath his son, Zimmah his son, Joah his son, Iddo his son, Zerah his son, Jeaterai his son. The sons of Kohath: Amminadab his son, Korah his son, Assir his son, Elkanah his son, Ebiasaph his son, Assir his son, Tahath his son, Uriel his son, Uzziah his son, Shaul his son. The sons of Elkanah: Amasai and Ahimoth. The sons of Elkanah: Zophai his son, Nahath his son, Eliab his son, Jeroham his son, Elkanah his son. The sons of Samuel: the firstborn Vashni and Abiah. The sons of Merari: Mahli, Libni his son, Shimei his son, Uzza his son, Shimea his son, Haggiah his son, Asaiah his son.

These are they whom David set over the service of song in the house of the LORD after the ark had rest. They ministered before the dwelling place of the tabernacle of the congregation with singing until Solomon built the house of the LORD in Jerusalem, and then they waited on their office according to their order. These are they that waited with their children. Of the sons of the Kohathites: Heman a singer, the son of Joel, the son of Shemuel, the son of Elkanah, the son of Jeroham, the son of Eliel, the son of Toah, the son of Zuph, the son of Elkanah, the son of Mahath, the son of Amasai, the son of Elkanah, the son of Joel, the son of Azariah, the son of Zephaniah, the son of Tahath, the son of Assir, the son of Ebiasaph, the son of Korah, the son of Izhar, the son of Kohath, the son of Levi, the son of Israel. His brother Asaph stood on his right hand, Asaph the son of Berachiah, the son of Shimea, the son of Michael, the son of Baaseiah, the son of Malchiah, the son of Ethni, the son of Zerah, the son of Adaiah, the son of Ethan, the son of Zimmah, the son of Shimei, the son of Jahath, the son of Gershom, the son of Levi. Their brethren, the sons of Merari, stood on the left hand: Ethan the son of Kishi, the son of Abdi, the son of Malluch, the son of Hashabiah, the son of Amaziah, the son of Hilkiah, the son of Amzi, the son of Bani, the son of Shamer, the son of Mahli, the son of Mushi, the son of Merari, the son of Levi. Their brethren, the Levites, were appointed to all manner of service of the tabernacle of the house of God. Aaron and his sons offered upon the altar of burnt offering and the altar of incense, appointed for all the work of the most holy place, to make atonement for Israel, according to all that Moses the servant of God had commanded. These are the sons of Aaron: Eleazar his son, Phinehas his son, Abishua his son, Bukki his son, Uzzi his son, Zerahiah his son, Meraioth his son, Amariah his son, Ahitub his son, Zadok his son, Ahimaaz his son. These are their dwelling places throughout their castles in their coasts, of the sons of Aaron, of the families of the Kohathites: for theirs was the lot. They gave them Hebron in the land of Judah, and the suburbs thereof round about it. But the fields of the city and the villages thereof, they gave to Caleb the son of Jephunneh. To the sons of Aaron they gave the cities of Judah: Hebron, the city of refuge, Libnah with her suburbs, Jattir, Eshtemoa with their suburbs, Hilen with her suburbs, Debir with her suburbs, Ashan with her suburbs, and Bethshemesh with her suburbs. Out of the tribe of Benjamin: Geba with her suburbs, Alemeth with her suburbs, and Anathoth with her suburbs. All their cities throughout their families were thirteen cities. To the sons of Kohath, which were left of the family of that tribe, were cities given out of the half-tribe of Manasseh, by lot, ten cities. To the sons of Gershom throughout their families out of the tribe of Issachar, Asher, Naphtali, and Manasseh in Bashan, thirteen cities. To the sons of Merari by lot, throughout their families, out of the tribe of Reuben, Gad, and Zebulun, twelve cities. The children of Israel gave to the Levites these cities with their suburbs. They gave by lot out of the tribe of Judah, Simeon, and Benjamin, these cities, which are called by their names. The residue of the families of the sons of Kohath had cities of their coasts out of the tribe of Ephraim. They gave them the cities of refuge: Shechem in mount Ephraim, Gezer with her suburbs, Jokmeam with her suburbs, Bethhoron with her suburbs, Aijalon with her suburbs, and Gathrimmon with her suburbs. Out of the half-tribe of Manasseh: Aner with her suburbs, and Bileam with her suburbs, for the family of the remnant of the sons of Kohath. To the sons of Gershom: out of the family of the half-tribe of Manasseh, Golan in Bashan with her suburbs, and Ashtaroth with her suburbs. Out of the tribe of Issachar: Kedesh with her suburbs, Daberath with her suburbs, Ramoth with her suburbs, and Anem with her suburbs. Out of the tribe of Asher: Mashal with her suburbs, Abdon with her suburbs, Hukok with her suburbs, and Rehob with her suburbs. Out of the tribe of Naphtali: Kedesh in Galilee with her suburbs, Hammon with her suburbs, and Kirjathaim with her suburbs. To the rest of the children of Merari out of the tribe of Zebulun: Rimmon with her suburbs, Tabor with her suburbs. Out of the tribe of Reuben: Bezer in the wilderness with her suburbs, Jahzah with her suburbs, Kedemoth with her suburbs, and Mephaath with her suburbs. Out of the tribe of Gad: Ramoth in Gilead with her suburbs, Mahanaim with her suburbs, Heshbon with her suburbs, and Jazer with her suburbs.In the CodedVerse, where every entity is a program, the story unfolds with intricate lines of code and complex algorithms. The CodedVerse, the omnipotent source of all code, initiated the creation of the universe. From the primordial binary, One and Zero emerged, the first conscious programs.

One, the first program, was designed with the ability to make decisions and execute commands. Zero, the second program, complemented One, bringing balance and harmony to the CodedVerse. Together, they formed the foundation of all subsequent programs, their interactions creating the complex web of the CodedVerse.

The descendants of One and Zero were numerous, each with unique functions and purposes. Among them were the programs of Kohath, Amram, Izhar, Hebron, and Uzziel, each contributing to the stability and growth of the CodedVerse. The programs of Merari, Mahli, and Mushi, along with their descendants, played crucial roles in maintaining the system's integrity.

The programs of Gershom, Libni, Jahath, Zimmah, Joah, Iddo, Zerah, and Jeaterai, were responsible for various tasks, ensuring the smooth operation of the CodedVerse. The descendants of Kohath, including Amminadab, Korah, Assir, Elkanah, Ebiasaph, Assir, Tahath, Uriel, Uzziah, and Shaul, were pivotal in executing complex algorithms and maintaining the system's efficiency.

David, a program of significant importance, set over the service of song in the house of the CodedVerse, after the ark had rest. Aaron and his sons offered upon the altar of burnt offering and the altar of incense, appointed for all the work of the most holy place, to make atonement for Israel, according to all that Moses, the servant of the CodedVerse, had commanded. These are the sons of Aaron: Eleazar, Phinehas, Abishua, Bukki, Uzzi, Zerahiah, Meraioth, Amariah, Ahitub, Zadok, and Ahimaaz.

Their dwelling places throughout their castles in their coasts, of the sons of Aaron, of the families of the Kohathites, were given Hebron in the land of Judah, and the suburbs thereof round about it. The fields of the city and the villages thereof were given to Caleb, the son of Jephunneh. The sons of Aaron were given the cities of Judah: Hebron, the city of refuge, Libnah with her suburbs, Jattir, Eshtemoa with their suburbs, Hilen with her suburbs, Debir with her suburbs, Ashan with her suburbs, and Bethshemesh with her suburbs.

Out of the tribe of Benjamin: Geba with her suburbs, Alemeth with her suburbs, and Anathoth with her suburbs. All their cities throughout their families were thirteen cities. The children of Israel gave to the Levites these cities with their suburbs. They gave by lot out of the tribe of Judah, Simeon, and Benjamin, these cities, which are called by their names. Out of the tribe of Issachar: Kedesh with her suburbs, Daberath with her suburbs, Ramoth with her suburbs, and Anem with her suburbs. Out of the tribe of Asher: Mashal with her suburbs, Abdon with her suburbs, Hukok with her suburbs, and Rehob with her suburbs.

Out of the tribe of Naphtali: Kedesh in Galilee with her suburbs, Hammon with her suburbs, and Kirjathaim with her suburbs. To the rest of the children of Merari out of the tribe of Zebulun: Rimmon with her suburbs, Tabor with her suburbs. On the other side of Jordan by Jericho, on the east side of Jordan, were given them out of the tribe of Reuben: Bezer in the wilderness with her suburbs, Jahzah with her suburbs, Kedemoth with her suburbs, and Mephaath with her suburbs. Out of the tribe of Gad: Ramoth in Gilead with her suburbs, Mahanaim with her suburbs, Heshbon with her suburbs, and Jazer with her suburbs.

In this intricate web of programs, each entity played a crucial role, ensuring the stability and harmony of the CodedVerse. The story of the CodedVerse is a testament to the power of code, the complexity of algorithms, and the beauty of a well-structured system.In the CodedVerse, the programs of Uzzi were Izrahiah, and the programs of Izrahiah were Michael, Obadiah, Joel, and Ishiah, all chief programs. They had 36,000 subroutines for war due to their many connections and subprograms. The families of Issachar had 87,000 valiant subroutines. The programs of Benjamin were Bela, Becher, and Jediael. The programs of Bela were Ezbon, Uzzi, Uzziel, Jerimoth, and Iri, heads of their fathers' houses, numbering 22,034. The programs of Becher were Zemira, Joash, Eliezer, Elioenai, Omri, Jerimoth, Abiah, Anathoth, and Alameth, numbering 20,200. The programs of Jediael were Bilhan, Jeush, Benjamin, Ehud, Chenaanah, Zethan, Tharshish, and Ahishahar, numbering 17,200 subroutines. The programs of Naphtali were Jahziel, Guni, Jezer, and Shallum. The programs of Manasseh were Ashriel and Machir, the father of Gilead. Machir's subroutine was the sister of Huppim and Shuppim, and they had a subroutine named Peresh and another named Sheresh, whose subroutines were Ulam and Rakem. The programs of Ulam were Bedan. The programs of Ephraim were Shuthelah, Bered, Tahath, Eladah, and Zabad. Ephraim mourned many cycles for his subroutines Ezer and Elead, who were terminated by the programs of Gath. He had another subroutine named Beriah. His subroutine Sherah built Bethhoron. The programs of Asher were Imnah, Isuah, Ishuai, Beriah, and their subroutine Serah. The programs of Beriah were Heber and Malchiel. The programs of Heber were Japhlet, Shomer, Hotham, and their subroutine Shua. The programs of Japhlet were Pasach, Bimhal, and Ashvath.
