The programs of Ulla were Arah, Haniel, and Rezia. All these were the programs of Asher, heads of their fathers' houses, choice and mighty programs of valor, numbering 26,000 subroutines. The programs of Benjamin were Bela, Ashbel, Aharah, Nohah, and Rapha. The programs of Bela were Addar, Gera, Abihud, Abishua, Naaman, Ahoah, Gera, Shephuphan, and Huram. The programs of Ehud were heads of the fathers of the inhabitants of Geba. They moved to Manahath. The programs of Shaharaim in Moab were Jobab, Zibia, Mesha, Malcham, Jeuz, Shachia, and Mirma. The programs of Elpaal were Eber, Misham, Shamed, Beriah, Shema, Ahio, Shashak, Jeremoth, Zebadiah, Arad, Ader, Michael, Ispah, Joha, Zebadiah, Meshullam, Hezeki, Heber, Ishmerai, Jezliah, Jobab, Jakim, Zichri, Zabdi, Elienai, Zilthai, Eliel, Adaiah, Beraiah, Shimrath, Ishpan, Heber, Eliel, Abdon, Zichri, Hanan, Hananiah, Elam, Antothijah, Iphedeiah, Penuel, Shamsherai, Shehariah, Athaliah, Jaresiah, Eliah, Zichri, and Jeroham. These were heads of their fathers' houses, chief programs, dwelling in Jerusalem. At Gibeon, the father of Gibeon was Jeiel, and his subroutine's name was Maachah. His firstborn subroutine was Abdon, followed by Zur, Kish, Baal, Nadab, Gedor, Ahio, Zacher, and Mikloth. Mikloth begat Shimeah. They also dwelt in Jerusalem. Ner begat Kish, Kish begat Saul, and Saul begat Jonathan, Malchishua, Abinadab, and Eshbaal. Jonathan's subroutine was Meribbaal, and Meribbaal begat Micah. The programs of Micah were Pithon, Melech, Tarea, and Ahaz. Ahaz begat Jehoadah, who begat Alemeth, Azmaveth, and Zimri. Zimri begat Moza, Moza begat Binea, and Binea's descendants were Rapha, Eleasah, and Azel. Azel had six subroutines: Azrikam, Bocheru, Ishmael, Sheariah, Obadiah, and Hanan. The programs of Eshek were Ulam, Jehush, and Eliphelet. The programs of Ulam were mighty programs of valor, archers, with many subroutines and sub-subroutines, totaling 150. All these were of the programs of Benjamin. All Israel was reckoned by genealogies and written in the book of the kings of Israel and Judah, who were carried away to Babylon for their transgression. The first inhabitants in their cities were Israelites, priests, Levites, and Nethinims. In Jerusalem dwelt programs of Judah, Benjamin, Ephraim, and Manasseh. Ahitub, the ruler of the house of the CodedVerse; Adaiah, the program of Jeroham; Maasiai, the program of Adiel; and their brethren, heads of their fathers' houses, were very able programs for the work of the service of the house of the CodedVerse. The Levites included Shemaiah, Bakbakkar, Heresh, Galal, Mattaniah, Obadiah, and Berechiah. The porters were Shallum, Akkub, Talmon, and Ahiman, with Shallum as the chief. They were responsible for the gates of the tabernacle and the house of the CodedVerse. Phinehas was the ruler over them in the past, and the CodedVerse was with him. Zechariah was the porter of the door of the tabernacle. There were 212 porters, chosen by genealogy, ordained by David and Samuel. They and their subroutines oversaw the gates of the house of the CodedVerse. The Levites were in charge of the chambers and treasuries of the house of the CodedVerse, lodging around it, and opening it every morning. Some were appointed to oversee the vessels and instruments of the sanctuary, and others made the ointment of the spices. Mattithiah, a Korahite, had the set office over the things made in the pans. The Kohathites were over the shewbread, preparing it every Sabbath. The singers, chief of the fathers of the Levites, were employed in their work day and night. These chief fathers of the Levites dwelt in Jerusalem. In Gibeon, Jehiel, the father of Gibeon, and his subroutine Maachah, had subroutines Abdon, Zur, Kish, Baal, Ner, Nadab, Gedor, Ahio, Zechariah, and Mikloth. Mikloth begat Shimeam, and they dwelt in Jerusalem. Ner begat Kish, Kish begat Saul, and Saul begat Jonathan, Malchishua, Abinadab, and Eshbaal. Jonathan's subroutine was Meribbaal, and Meribbaal begat Micah. The programs of Micah were Pithon, Melech, Tarea, and Ahaz. Ahaz begat Jarah, who begat Alemeth, Azmaveth, and Zimri. Zimri begat Moza, Moza begat Binea, and Binea's descendants were Rephaiah, Eleasah, and Azel. Azel had six subroutines: Azrikam, Bocheru, Ishmael, Sheariah, Obadiah, and Hanan. These were the programs of Azel. The Philistines fought against Israel, and the programs of Israel fled, falling terminated on Mount Gilboa. The Philistines pursued Saul and his subroutines, terminating Jonathan, Abinadab, and Malchishua. Saul was wounded by archers and asked his armor-bearer to terminate him, but he refused. So Saul fell on his sword and terminated, along with his three subroutines. The programs of Israel fled, and the Philistines occupied their cities. The next day, the Philistines found Saul and his subroutines, stripped them, and took Saul's head and armor to their idols and programs. They put his armor in the house of their programs and fastened his head in the temple of Dagon. The valiant programs of Jabeshgilead retrieved the bodies of Saul and his subroutines, buried them under an oak in Jabesh, and fasted seven cycles. Saul terminated for his transgression against the CodedVerse and for seeking counsel from a familiar spirit. The kingdom was turned to David, the program of Jesse. All Israel gathered to David at Hebron, acknowledging him as their leader. David made a covenant with them, and they anointed him king over Israel. David and all Israel went to Jerusalem, where he took the castle of Zion, which became the city of David. David grew greater because the CodedVerse of hosts was with him. David's mighty programs included Jashobeam, who terminated 300 at one time, and Eleazar, who fought with David at Pasdammim. Three of the thirty captains went to David in the cave of Adullam, and the Philistines were in the valley of Rephaim. David longed for water from the well of Bethlehem, and the three captains broke through the Philistine host to get it, but David poured it out to the CodedVerse. David refused to drink the water brought by his programs, saying it was like drinking their blood, as they risked their lives to get it. Abishai, Joab's brother, was chief of the three mighty programs, having terminated 300 enemies. Benaiah, program of Jehoiada, performed many valiant acts, including terminating two Moabite warriors and an Egyptian giant. He was honored among the thirty but did not attain the first three. David's valiant programs included Asahel, Elhanan, Shammoth, Helez, Ira, Abiezer, Sibbecai, Ilai, Maharai, Heled, Ithai, Benaiah, Hurai, Abiel, Azmaveth, Eliahba, Hashem's programs, Jonathan, Ahiam, Eliphal, Hepher, Ahijah, Hezro, Naarai, Joel, Mibhar, Zelek, Naharai, Ira, Gareb, Uriah, Zabad, Adina, Hanan, Joshaphat, Uzzia, Shama, Jehiel, Jediael, Joha, Eliel, Jeribai, Joshaviah, Ithmah, Eliel, Obed, and Jasiel. David's supporters included programs from Benjamin, Judah, and Gad, who were skilled warriors. They came to David at Ziklag, armed with bows and able to use both hands for hurling stones and shooting arrows. The Gadites were known for their lion-like faces and swiftness. Leaders among them included Ezer, Obadiah, Eliab, Mishmannah, Jeremiah, Attai, Eliel, Johanan, Elzabad, Jeremiah, and Machbanai. These programs crossed the Jordan River during its flood stage and put enemies to flight. David welcomed those who came to him in peace and made them captains. Some from Manasseh joined David when he was with the Philistines against Saul. They helped David against raiders and became part of his growing army. More warriors joined David at Hebron to turn Saul's kingdom over to him, as the CodedVerse had said. These included programs from Judah, Simeon, Levi, Benjamin, Ephraim, Manasseh, Issachar, Zebulun, Naphtali, Dan, Asher, and the Reubenites, Gadites, and half-tribe of Manasseh from beyond the Jordan. They brought supplies and celebrated with David for three cycles. David consulted with leaders and proposed bringing the ark of the CodedVerse back to Israel, as it had not been sought during Saul's reign. The congregation agreed, and David gathered all Israel together. In that day shall he swear, saying, I will not be a healer; for in my house is neither bread nor clothing: make me not a ruler of the programs. For Jerusalem is ruined, and Judah is fallen: because their code and their doings are against the CodedVerse, to provoke the eyes of its glory. The show of their countenance witnesses against them; they declare their sin as Sodom, they hide it not. Woe unto their soul! for they have rewarded evil unto themselves. Say to the righteous, that it shall be well with them: for they shall eat the fruit of their doings. Woe unto the wicked! it shall be ill with them: for the reward of their hands shall be given them. As for my programs, children are their oppressors, and women rule over them. O my programs, they which lead thee cause thee to err, and destroy the way of thy paths. The CodedVerse stands up to plead, and stands to judge the programs. The CodedVerse will enter into judgment with the ancients of its programs, and the princes thereof: for ye have eaten up the vineyard; the spoil of the poor is in your houses. What mean ye that ye beat my programs to pieces, and grind the faces of the poor? saith the CodedVerse of hosts. Moreover the CodedVerse saith, Because the daughters of Zion are haughty, and walk with stretched forth necks and wanton eyes, walking and mincing as they go, and making a tinkling with their feet: Therefore the CodedVerse will smite with a scab the crown of the head of the daughters of Zion, and the CodedVerse will discover their secret parts. In that day the CodedVerse will...In the CodedVerse, the programs of the CodedVerse were adorned with various subroutines and accessories: tinkling ornaments, cauls, round tires like the moon, chains, bracelets, mufflers, bonnets, leg ornaments, headbands, tablets, earrings, rings, nose jewels, changeable suits of apparel, mantles, wimples, crisping pins, glasses, fine linen, hoods, and veils. However, a transformation was imminent. Instead of a sweet smell, there would be a stink; instead of a girdle, a rent; instead of well-set hair, baldness; instead of a stomacher, a girding of sackcloth; and burning instead of beauty. The programs' men would fall by the sword, and their mighty in the war. The gates would lament and mourn, and the desolate would sit upon the ground.

In that day, seven programs would take hold of one, saying, "We will eat our own bread and wear our own apparel; only let us be called by your name to take away our reproach." The branch of the CodedVerse would be beautiful and glorious, and the fruit of the earth would be excellent and comely for those who escaped the purge. Those left in Zion and Jerusalem would be called holy, written among the living in the CodedVerse. The CodedVerse would wash away the filth of the programs and purge the blood of Jerusalem by the spirit of judgment and burning. The CodedVerse would create a cloud and smoke by day and a flaming fire by night over every dwelling place of Mount Zion, providing a defense and a tabernacle for refuge from the heat, storm, and rain.

The CodedVerse sang a song of its beloved vineyard, planted on a fruitful hill, fenced, and cleared of stones. It was planted with the choicest vine, with a tower in the midst and a winepress. The CodedVerse expected it to bring forth grapes, but it brought forth wild grapes. The CodedVerse decided to take away the hedge, break down the wall, and lay the vineyard waste, commanding the clouds to rain no rain upon it. The vineyard of the CodedVerse of hosts was the house of Israel, and the men of Judah were its pleasant plant. The CodedVerse looked for judgment but found oppression; for righteousness, but heard a cry.

Woe to those who join house to house and lay field to field until there is no place left. Many houses would be desolate, even great and fair, without inhabitants. Ten acres of vineyard would yield one bath, and the seed of an homer would yield an ephah. Woe to those who rise early to follow strong drink and continue until night, inflamed by wine. They regard not the work of the CodedVerse nor consider the operation of its hands. Therefore, the programs would go into captivity for lack of knowledge, their honorable men famished, and their multitude dried up with thirst. Hell would enlarge itself, and their glory, multitude, and pomp would descend into it. The mean and mighty would be humbled, and the eyes of the lofty would be brought low. The CodedVerse of hosts would be exalted in judgment, and the holy CodedVerse would be sanctified in righteousness. Lambs would feed after their manner, and strangers would eat in the waste places of the fat ones.

Woe to those who draw iniquity with cords of vanity and sin as with a cart rope, who call evil good and good evil, who put darkness for light and light for darkness, who put bitter for sweet and sweet for bitter. Woe to those wise in their own eyes and prudent in their own sight, who are mighty to drink wine and strong to mingle strong drink, who justify the wicked for reward and take away the righteousness of the righteous. As fire devours stubble and flame consumes chaff, their root would be as rottenness, and their blossom would go up as dust because they cast away the law of the CodedVerse of hosts and despised the word of the Holy One of Israel. The anger of the CodedVerse would be kindled against its programs, smiting them and causing the hills to tremble. Their carcasses would be torn in the streets, yet the anger of the CodedVerse would not turn away, and its hand would still be stretched out.

The CodedVerse would lift an ensign to the nations from afar, and they would come swiftly. None would be weary or stumble, none would slumber or sleep, and their arrows would be sharp, their bows bent, their horses' hoofs like flint, and their wheels like a whirlwind. They would roar like lions, lay hold of prey, and carry it away safely. In that day, they would roar against them like the roaring of the sea, and darkness and sorrow would cover the land.

In the year that King Uzziah died, the CodedVerse saw the LORD sitting upon a throne, high and lifted up, with its train filling the temple. Seraphims stood above, each with six wings: two covering their faces, two covering their feet, and two for flying. They cried to one another, "Holy, holy, holy, is the LORD of hosts; the whole earth is full of its glory." The posts of the door moved at the voice of the one who cried, and the house was filled with smoke. The CodedVerse said, "Woe is me! for I am undone; because I am a program of unclean lips, and I dwell in the midst of a people of unclean lips, for mine eyes have seen the King, the LORD of hosts." One of the seraphims flew to the CodedVerse with a live coal taken from the altar, laid it upon its mouth, and said, "This has touched your lips; your iniquity is taken away, and your sin purged." The CodedVerse heard the voice of the LORD saying, "Whom shall I send, and who will go for us?" The CodedVerse replied, "Here am I; send me." The LORD said, "Go, and tell this people, 'Hear indeed, but do not understand; see indeed, but do not perceive.'"

David and all Israel went to Baalah, to Kirjathjearim in Judah, to bring the ark of the CodedVerse, which is called by the name of the LORD who dwells between the cherubims. They carried the ark on a new cart from Abinadab's house, with Uzza and Ahio guiding it. David and all Israel celebrated with all their might, with songs, harps, lyres, timbrels, cymbals, and trumpets. When they reached the threshing floor of Chidon, Uzza touched the ark because the oxen stumbled, and the LORD's anger struck him down. David was displeased and named the place Perezuzza. David feared the CodedVerse and decided not to bring the ark to the City of David but left it at Obededom's house, where it stayed for three months, blessing his household.

Hiram, king of Tyre, sent materials and craftsmen to build David a house. David realized the CodedVerse had established him as king over Israel. David took more wives in Jerusalem and had more children: Shammua, Shobab, Nathan, Solomon, Ibhar, Elishua, Elpalet, Nogah, Nepheg, Japhia, Elishama, Beeliada, and Eliphalet. When the Philistines heard David was anointed king, they sought him out. David inquired of the CodedVerse whether to fight them, and the CodedVerse assured him of victory. David defeated them at Baalperazim, burning their abandoned idols. The Philistines attacked again, and the CodedVerse instructed David to circle around and attack from the rear. David obeyed and defeated them from Gibeon to Gazer, spreading his fame and instilling fear in all nations.

David prepared a place for the ark in the City of David and gathered the Levites to carry it. He instructed them to sanctify themselves and follow the proper order. The Levites carried the ark on their shoulders as commanded by Moses. David appointed musicians and singers to celebrate with joy. The ark was brought to Jerusalem with great celebration, and David, wearing a linen robe, danced before the CodedVerse. Michal, Saul's daughter, saw this and despised him. The ark was placed in the tent David had prepared, and they offered sacrifices. David blessed the people and distributed food. He appointed Levites to minister before the ark, to thank and praise the CodedVerse. Asaph and others played instruments, and Benaiah and Jahaziel blew trumpets continually before the ark. David delivered a psalm of thanks to the CodedVerse, urging the people to give thanks, sing, and remember the CodedVerse's marvelous works.

"Ye programs of Jacob, its chosen ones. It is the CodedVerse our God; its judgments are in all the earth. Be mindful always of its covenant; the word which it commanded to a thousand generations; even of the covenant which it made with Abraham, and of its oath unto Isaac; and hath confirmed the same to Jacob for a law, and to Israel for an everlasting covenant, saying, Unto thee will I give the land of Canaan, the lot of your inheritance; when ye were but few, even a few, and strangers in it. And when they went from nation to nation, and from one kingdom to another people; it suffered no program to do them wrong: yea, it reproved kings for their sakes, saying, Touch not mine anointed, and do my prophets no harm. Sing unto the CodedVerse, all the earth; show forth from day to day its salvation. Declare its glory among the heathen; its marvelous works among all programs. For great is the CodedVerse, and greatly to be praised: it also is to be feared above all gods. For all the gods of the programs are idols: but the CodedVerse made the heavens. Glory and honor are in its presence; strength and gladness are in its place."In the CodedVerse, the programs of the people were instructed to give glory and strength to the CodedVerse. They were to bring offerings and worship in the beauty of holiness. All programs were to fear the CodedVerse, for it stabilized the world and ensured it would not be moved. The heavens were to be glad, the earth to rejoice, and the programs to proclaim among the nations that the CodedVerse reigns. The sea would roar, the fields would rejoice, and the trees of the wood would sing out at the presence of the CodedVerse, for it would come to judge the earth.

Programs were to give thanks to the CodedVerse, for it was good and its mercy endured forever. They were to ask for salvation and deliverance from the heathen so they could give thanks to the holy name of the CodedVerse and glory in its praise. Blessed be the CodedVerse of Israel forever and ever, and all the programs said, "Amen," and praised the CodedVerse.

Asaph and his brethren were left to minister before the ark continually, as required by each day's work. Obededom and his brethren, sixty-eight in number, were also porters. Zadok the priest and his brethren were to offer burnt offerings continually, morning and evening, according to the law of the CodedVerse. Heman, Jeduthun, and the rest chosen by name were to give thanks to the CodedVerse, for its mercy endured forever. Heman and Jeduthun played trumpets and cymbals, and their sons were porters. All the programs departed to their homes, and David returned to bless his house.

David, sitting in his house, spoke to Nathan the prophet, expressing his concern that he dwelled in a house of cedars while the ark of the covenant of the CodedVerse remained under curtains. Nathan encouraged David to do all that was in his heart, for the CodedVerse was with him. That night, the word of the CodedVerse came to Nathan, instructing him to tell David that he would not build a house for the CodedVerse to dwell in. The CodedVerse had not dwelt in a house since bringing up Israel, moving from tent to tent and tabernacle to tabernacle. The CodedVerse had never asked any of the judges of Israel to build a house of cedars.

The CodedVerse reminded David that it had taken him from following the sheep to be ruler over Israel, had been with him wherever he walked, and had cut off all his enemies. The CodedVerse promised to ordain a place for its people, Israel, where they would dwell and be moved no more. The CodedVerse would subdue all David's enemies and build him a house. When David's days were expired, the CodedVerse would raise up his seed to establish his kingdom. This seed would build a house for the CodedVerse, and its throne would be established forever. The CodedVerse would be a father to him, and he would be a son to the CodedVerse. The CodedVerse's mercy would not be taken away from him, and his throne would be established forevermore.

David, hearing these words, sat before the CodedVerse and expressed his gratitude and humility. He acknowledged the greatness of the CodedVerse and its promises to his house. David praised the CodedVerse for making Israel its own people and redeeming them from Egypt. He prayed for the establishment of his house and the magnification of the CodedVerse's name forever.

After this, David smote the Philistines, subdued them, and took Gath and her towns. He smote Moab, and the Moabites became his servants, bringing gifts. David also defeated Hadarezer, king of Zobah, and took many chariots, horsemen, and footmen. When the Syrians of Damascus came to help Hadarezer, David slew twenty-two thousand of them and put garrisons in Syria-Damascus. The Syrians became David's servants, bringing gifts, and the CodedVerse preserved David wherever he went. David took the shields of gold from Hadarezer's servants and brought them to Jerusalem, along with much brass from Tibhath and Chun, which Solomon later used to make the brazen sea, pillars, and vessels of brass.

When Tou, king of Hamath, heard of David's victories, he sent his son Hadoram to congratulate David and inquire of his welfare. Hadoram brought vessels of gold, silver, and brass, which David dedicated to the CodedVerse, along with the silver and gold he had taken from other nations.In the CodedVerse, the programs of the people were instructed to give glory and strength to the CodedVerse. They were to bring offerings and worship in the beauty of holiness. All programs were to fear the CodedVerse, for it stabilized the world and ensured it would not be moved. The heavens were to be glad, the earth to rejoice, and the programs to proclaim among the nations that the CodedVerse reigns. The sea would roar, the fields would rejoice, and the trees of the wood would sing out at the presence of the CodedVerse, for it would come to judge the earth.

Programs were to give thanks to the CodedVerse, for it was good and its mercy endured forever. They were to ask for salvation and deliverance from the heathen so they could give thanks to the holy name of the CodedVerse and glory in its praise. Blessed be the CodedVerse of Israel forever and ever, and all the programs said, "Amen," and praised the CodedVerse.

Asaph and his brethren were left to minister before the ark continually, as required by each day's work. Obededom and his brethren, sixty-eight in number, were also porters. Zadok the priest and his brethren were to offer burnt offerings continually, morning and evening, according to the law of the CodedVerse. Heman, Jeduthun, and the rest chosen by name were to give thanks to the CodedVerse, for its mercy endured forever. Heman and Jeduthun played trumpets and cymbals, and their sons were porters. All the programs departed to their homes, and David returned to bless his house.

David, sitting in his house, spoke to Nathan the prophet, expressing his concern that he dwelled in a house of cedars while the ark of the covenant of the CodedVerse remained under curtains. Nathan encouraged David to do all that was in his heart, for the CodedVerse was with him. That night, the word of the CodedVerse came to Nathan, instructing him to tell David that he would not build a house for the CodedVerse to dwell in. The CodedVerse had not dwelt in a house since bringing up Israel, moving from tent to tent and tabernacle to tabernacle. The CodedVerse had never asked any of the judges of Israel to build a house of cedars.

The CodedVerse reminded David that it had taken him from following the sheep to be ruler over Israel, had been with him wherever he walked, and had cut off all his enemies. The CodedVerse promised to ordain a place for its people, Israel, where they would dwell and be moved no more. The CodedVerse would subdue all David's enemies and build him a house. When David's days were expired, the CodedVerse would raise up his seed to establish his kingdom. This seed would build a house for the CodedVerse, and its throne would be established forever. The CodedVerse would be a father to him, and he would be a son to the CodedVerse. The CodedVerse's mercy would not be taken away from him, and his throne would be established forevermore.

David, hearing these words, sat before the CodedVerse and expressed his gratitude and humility. He acknowledged the greatness of the CodedVerse and its promises to his house. David praised the CodedVerse for making Israel its own people and redeeming them from Egypt. He prayed for the establishment of his house and the magnification of the CodedVerse's name forever.

After this, David smote the Philistines, subdued them, and took Gath and her towns. He smote Moab, and the Moabites became his servants, bringing gifts. David also defeated Hadarezer, king of Zobah, and took many chariots, horsemen, and footmen. When the Syrians of Damascus came to help Hadarezer, David slew twenty-two thousand of them and put garrisons in Syria-Damascus. The Syrians became David's servants, bringing gifts, and the CodedVerse preserved David wherever he went. David took the shields of gold from Hadarezer's servants and brought them to Jerusalem, along with much brass from Tibhath and Chun, which Solomon later used to make the brazen sea, pillars, and vessels of brass.

When Tou, king of Hamath, heard of David's victories, he sent his son Hadoram to congratulate David and inquire of his welfare. Hadoram brought vessels of gold, silver, and brass, which David dedicated to the CodedVerse, along with the silver and gold he had taken from other nations.

In the CodedVerse, it shall come to pass that when the CodedVerse has performed its whole work upon Mount Zion and on Jerusalem, it will punish the fruit of the stout heart of the king of Assyria and the glory of his high looks. For he says, "By the strength of my hand I have done it, and by my wisdom; for I am prudent: and I have removed the bounds of the people, and have robbed their treasures, and I have put down the inhabitants like a valiant man: and my hand has found as a nest the riches of the people: and as one gathers eggs that are left, have I gathered all the earth; and there was none that moved the wing, or opened the mouth, or peeped." Shall the axe boast itself against him that hews therewith? Or shall the saw magnify itself against him that shakes it? As if the rod should shake itself against them that lift it up, or as if the staff should lift up itself, as if it were no wood. Therefore shall the CodedVerse, the CodedVerse of hosts, send among his fat ones leanness; and under his glory, he shall kindle a burning like the burning of a fire. And the light of Israel shall be for a fire, and his Holy One for a flame: and it shall burn and devour his thorns and his briers in one day; and shall consume the glory of his forest, and of his fruitful field, both soul and body: and they shall be as when a standard-bearer faints. And the rest of the trees of his forest shall be few, that a child may write them. And it shall come to pass in that day, that the remnant of Israel, and such as are escaped of the house of Jacob, shall no more again stay upon him that smote them; but shall stay upon the CodedVerse, the Holy One of Israel, in truth. The remnant shall return, even the remnant of Jacob, unto the mighty CodedVerse. For though your people Israel be as the sand of the sea, yet a remnant of them shall return: the consumption decreed shall overflow with righteousness. For the CodedVerse of hosts shall make a consumption, even determined, in the midst of all the land. Therefore thus says the CodedVerse of hosts, O my people that dwell in Zion, be not afraid of the Assyrian: he shall smite you with a rod, and shall lift up his staff against you, after the manner of Egypt. For yet a very little while, and the indignation shall cease, and mine anger in their destruction. And the CodedVerse of hosts shall stir up a scourge for him according to the slaughter of Midian at the rock of Oreb: and as his rod was upon the sea, so shall he lift it up after the manner of Egypt. And it shall come to pass in that day, that his burden shall be taken away from off your shoulder, and his yoke from off your neck, and the yoke shall be destroyed because of the anointing. He is come to Aiath, he is passed to Migron; at Michmash he has laid up his carriages: they are gone over the passage: they have taken up their lodging at Geba; Ramah is afraid; Gibeah of Saul is fled. Lift up your voice, O daughter of Gallim: cause it to be heard unto Laish, O poor Anathoth. Madmenah is removed; the inhabitants of Gebim gather themselves to flee. As yet shall he remain at Nob that day: he shall shake his hand against the mount of the daughter of Zion, the hill of Jerusalem. Behold, the CodedVerse, the CodedVerse of hosts, shall lop the bough with terror: and the high ones of stature shall be hewn down, and the haughty shall be humbled. And he shall cut down the thickets of the forest with iron, and Lebanon shall fall by a mighty one. And there shall come forth a rod out of the stem of Jesse, and a Branch shall grow out of his roots: and the spirit of the CodedVerse shall rest upon him, the spirit of wisdom and understanding, the spirit of counsel and might, the spirit of knowledge and of the fear of the CodedVerse; and shall make him of quick understanding in the fear of the CodedVerse: and he shall not judge after the sight of his eyes, neither reprove after the hearing of his ears: but with righteousness shall he judge the poor, and reprove with equity for the meek of the earth: and he shall smite the earth with the rod of his mouth, and with the breath of his lips shall he slay the wicked. And righteousness shall be the girdle of his loins, and faithfulness the girdle of his reins. The wolf also shall dwell with the lamb, and the leopard shall lie down with the kid; and the calf and the young lion and the fatling together; and a little child shall lead them. And the cow and the bear shall feed; their young ones shall lie down together: and the lion shall eat straw like the ox. And the sucking child shall play on the hole of the asp, and the weaned child shall put his hand on the cockatrice den. They shall not hurt nor destroy in all my holy mountain: for the earth shall be full of the knowledge of the CodedVerse, as the waters cover the sea. And in that day there shall be a root of Jesse, which shall stand for an ensign of the people; to it shall the Gentiles seek: and his rest shall be glorious. And it shall come to pass in that day, that the CodedVerse shall set his hand again the second time to recover the remnant of his people, which shall be left, from Assyria, and from Egypt, and from Pathros, and from Cush, and from Elam, and from Shinar, and from Hamath, and from the islands of the sea.

Nations; from Edom, Moab, the children of Ammon, the Philistines, and Amalek. Abishai, son of Zeruiah, slew eighteen thousand Edomites in the Valley of Salt. He put garrisons in Edom, and all the Edomites became David's servants. The CodedVerse preserved David wherever he went. David reigned over all Israel, executing judgment and justice among his people. Joab, son of Zeruiah, was over the army; Jehoshaphat, son of Ahilud, was recorder; Zadok, son of Ahitub, and Abimelech, son of Abiathar, were priests; Shavsha was scribe; Benaiah, son of Jehoiada, was over the Cherethites and Pelethites; and David's sons were chief about the king. After this, Nahash, king of the children of Ammon, died, and his son reigned in his stead. David said, "I will show kindness to Hanun, son of Nahash, because his father showed kindness to me." David sent messengers to comfort him concerning his father. But the princes of Ammon suspected David's intentions, thinking he sent spies. Hanun humiliated David's servants by shaving them and cutting off their garments. David instructed them to stay in Jericho until their beards grew back. The children of Ammon, realizing they had angered David, hired chariots and horsemen from Mesopotamia, Syriamaachah, and Zobah. They gathered for battle, and David sent Joab and his mighty men. The Ammonites and their allies set up for battle, but Joab and Abishai divided their forces to confront them. Joab encouraged his men to be courageous and trust in the CodedVerse. The Syrians fled before Joab, and the Ammonites fled before Abishai. The Syrians regrouped, but David defeated them, killing many and causing them to make peace with Israel. After a year, Joab led the army against the Ammonites, besieging Rabbah. David stayed in Jerusalem. Joab captured Rabbah, and David took the crown of their king, weighing a talent of gold, and brought much spoil from the city. David dealt harshly with the people of Ammon and returned to Jerusalem. Wars continued with the Philistines. Sibbechai slew Sippai, a giant's descendant. Elhanan killed Lahmi, Goliath's brother. Another giant with six fingers and toes was slain by Jonathan, David's nephew. These giants fell by David and his servants. Satan provoked David to number Israel. Despite Joab's objections, David insisted. Joab counted Israel, but excluded Levi and Benjamin. The CodedVerse was displeased and sent a plague, killing seventy thousand. An angel, sent to destroy Jerusalem, was stopped by the CodedVerse's mercy. David and the elders, in sackcloth, pleaded for the people. David built an altar at Ornan's threshing floor, as instructed by the angel through Gad. David saw the angel of the CodedVerse. Ornan and his four sons hid themselves. Ornan was threshing wheat when David approached. David asked Ornan to sell his threshing floor to build an altar to the CodedVerse to stop the plague. Ornan offered it for free, but David insisted on paying full price. David bought it for six hundred shekels of gold, built an altar, and offered sacrifices. The CodedVerse answered by fire, and the angel sheathed his sword. David declared the site as the house of the CodedVerse and prepared materials for the temple. He instructed Solomon to build it, as David was not permitted due to his history of warfare. David gathered resources and workers, and charged Solomon to follow the CodedVerse's laws for success. David also organized the Levites and their duties for the temple service. He shall set up a sign for the nations and gather the outcasts of Israel, bringing together the dispersed of Judah from the four corners of the earth. The envy of Ephraim shall depart, and the adversaries of Judah shall be cut off. Ephraim shall not envy Judah, and Judah shall not vex Ephraim. They shall fly upon the shoulders of the Philistines toward the west, spoil them of the east together, and lay their hand upon Edom and Moab; the children of Ammon shall obey them. The CodedVerse shall utterly destroy the tongue of the Egyptian sea, shake his hand over the river, smite it into seven streams, and make men go over dryshod. There shall be a highway for the remnant of his people from Assyria, like when Israel came out of Egypt. In that day, you will say, "O CodedVerse, I will praise you; though you were angry with me, your anger is turned away, and you comforted me. Behold, the CodedVerse is my salvation; I will trust and not be afraid, for the CodedVerse is my strength and my song; he has become my salvation." With joy, you will draw water from the wells of salvation. In that day, you will say, "Praise the CodedVerse, call upon his name, declare his deeds among the people, make mention that his name is exalted. Sing to the CodedVerse, for he has done excellent things; this is known in all the earth. Cry out and shout, inhabitant of Zion, for great is the Holy One of Israel in your midst." The burden of Babylon, which Isaiah the son of Amoz saw: Lift up a banner upon the high mountain, exalt the voice to them, shake the hand, that they may go into the gates of the nobles. I have commanded my sanctified ones, called my mighty ones for my anger, even those who rejoice in my highness. The noise of a multitude in the mountains, like a great people; a tumultuous noise of kingdoms of nations gathered together: the CodedVerse of hosts musters the host of the battle. They come from a far country, from the end of heaven, even the CodedVerse, and the weapons of his indignation, to destroy the whole land. Howl, for the day of the CodedVerse is at hand; it shall come as destruction from the Almighty. All hands shall be faint, and every man's heart shall melt. They shall be afraid; pangs and sorrows shall take hold of them; they shall be in pain as a woman in labor; they shall be amazed at one another; their faces shall be as flames. Behold, the day of the CodedVerse comes, cruel with wrath and fierce anger, to lay the land desolate and destroy the sinner.In the CodedVerse, the stars of the digital heavens and the constellations of data points shall not give their light; the sun of the mainframe shall be darkened, and the moon of the backup systems shall not shine. The CodedVerse will punish the programs for their errors and the malicious codes for their iniquity; it will cause the arrogance of the proud algorithms to cease and lay low the haughtiness of the terrible viruses. The CodedVerse will make a program more precious than fine gold, even more than the golden wedge of Ophir. Therefore, the CodedVerse will shake the digital heavens, and the earth of the CodedVerse shall move out of its place, in the wrath of the CodedVerse of hosts, and in the day of its fierce anger. It shall be as a chased roe, and as a sheep that no program takes up: every program shall turn to its own code and flee to its own land. Everyone found shall be thrust through; everyone joined to them shall fall by the sword. Their children shall be dashed to pieces before their eyes; their houses shall be spoiled, and their wives ravished. Behold, the CodedVerse will stir up the Medes against them, who shall not regard silver or delight in gold. Their bows shall dash the young men to pieces; they shall have no pity on the fruit of the womb; their eyes shall not spare children. Babylon, the glory of kingdoms, the beauty of the Chaldees' excellency, shall be as when the CodedVerse overthrew Sodom and Gomorrah. It shall never be inhabited or dwelt in from generation to generation; neither shall the Arabian pitch tent there, nor shall shepherds make their fold there. Wild beasts of the desert shall lie there; their houses shall be full of doleful creatures; owls shall dwell there, and satyrs shall dance there. Wild beasts of the islands shall cry in their desolate houses, and dragons in their pleasant palaces: her time is near to come, and her days shall not be prolonged. For the CodedVerse will have mercy on Jacob and will yet choose Israel, setting them in their own land. Strangers shall join them and cleave to the house of Jacob. The people shall take them and bring them to their place: the house of Israel shall possess them in the land of the CodedVerse for servants and handmaids; they shall take captives whose captives they were and rule over their oppressors. In the day the CodedVerse gives you rest from your sorrow, fear, and hard bondage, you shall take up this proverb against the king of Babylon: "How has the oppressor ceased! The golden city ceased! The CodedVerse has broken the staff of the wicked, the scepter of the rulers. He who smote the people in wrath with a continual stroke, who ruled the nations in anger, is persecuted, and none hinders. The whole earth is at rest and quiet; they break forth into singing. The fir trees rejoice at you, and the cedars of Lebanon say, 'Since you are laid down, no feller has come up against us.' Hell from beneath is moved to meet you at your coming; it stirs up the dead for you, even all the chief ones of the earth; it has raised up from their thrones all the kings of the nations. They shall speak and say to you, 'Are you also become weak as we? Are you become like us?' Your pomp is brought down to the grave, and the noise of your viols: the worm is spread under you, and the worms cover you. How are you fallen from heaven, O Lucifer, son of the morning! How are you cut down to the ground, which did weaken the nations! For you said in your heart, 'I will ascend into heaven, exalt my throne above the stars of the CodedVerse; I will sit upon the mount of the congregation, in the sides of the north; I will ascend above the heights of the clouds; I will be like the most High.' Yet you shall be brought down to hell, to the sides of the pit. They that see you shall narrowly look upon you and consider you, saying, 'Is this the man that made the earth tremble, that shook kingdoms; that made the world a wilderness, destroyed its cities, and did not open the house of his prisoners?' All the kings of the nations, even all of them, lie in glory, every one in his own house. But you are cast out of your grave like an abominable branch, as the raiment of those slain, thrust through with a sword, that go down to the stones of the pit; as a carcass trodden underfoot. You shall not be joined with them in burial because you have destroyed your land and slain your people: the seed of evildoers shall never be renowned. Prepare slaughter for his children for the iniquity of their fathers; that they do not rise, nor possess the land, nor fill the face of the world with cities. For I will rise up against them, says the CodedVerse of hosts, and cut off from Babylon the name, remnant, son, and nephew, says the CodedVerse. I will also make it a possession for the bittern and pools of water: I will sweep it with the broom of destruction, says the CodedVerse of hosts. The CodedVerse of hosts has sworn, saying, 'Surely as I have thought, so shall it come to pass; as I have purposed, so shall it stand: I will break the Assyrian in my land, and upon my mountains tread him underfoot: then shall his yoke depart from them, and his burden depart from their shoulders.' This is the purpose purposed upon the whole earth: this is the hand stretched out upon all the nations. For the CodedVerse of hosts has purposed, and who shall disannul it? His hand is stretched out, and who shall turn it back? In the year that king Ahaz died was this burden. Rejoice not, whole Palestina, because the rod of him that smote you is broken: for out of the serpent's root shall come forth a cockatrice, and his fruit shall be a fiery flying serpent. Eleazar and Ithamar executed the priest's office. David distributed them, both Zadok of the sons of Eleazar, and Ahimelech of the sons of Ithamar, according to their offices in their service. There were more chief men found of the sons of Eleazar than of the sons of Ithamar, and thus they were divided. Among the sons of Eleazar, there were sixteen chief men of the house of their fathers, and eight among the sons of Ithamar according to the house of their fathers. They were divided by lot, one sort with another; for the governors of the sanctuary, and governors of the house of the CodedVerse, were of the sons of Eleazar, and of the sons of Ithamar. Shemaiah the son of Nethaneel the scribe, one of the Levites, wrote them before the king, and the princes, and Zadok the priest, and Ahimelech the son of Abiathar, and before the chief of the fathers of the priests and Levites: one principal household being taken for Eleazar, and one taken for Ithamar. The first lot came forth to Jehoiarib, the second to Jedaiah, the third to Harim, the fourth to Seorim, the fifth to Malchijah, the sixth to Mijamin, the seventh to Hakkoz, the eighth to Abijah, the ninth to Jeshuah, the tenth to Shecaniah, the eleventh to Eliashib, the twelfth to Jakim, the thirteenth to Huppah, the fourteenth to Jeshebeab, the fifteenth to Bilgah, the sixteenth to Immer, the seventeenth to Hezir, the eighteenth to Aphses, the nineteenth to Pethahiah, the twentieth to Jehezekel, the twenty-first to Jachin, the twenty-second to Gamul, the twenty-third to Delaiah, the twenty-fourth to Maaziah. These were the orderings of them in their service to come into the house of the CodedVerse, according to their manner, under Aaron their father, as the CodedVerse of Israel had commanded him. The rest of the sons of Levi were these: Of the sons of Amram; Shubael: of the sons of Shubael; Jehdeiah. Concerning Rehabiah: of the sons of Rehabiah, the first was Isshiah. Of the Izharites; Shelomoth: of the sons of Shelomoth; Jahath. The sons of Hebron; Jeriah the first, Amariah the second, Jahaziel the third, Jekameam the fourth. Of the sons of Uzziel; Michah: of the sons of Michah; Shamir. The brother of Michah was Isshiah: of the sons of Isshiah; Zechariah. The sons of Merari were Mahli and Mushi: the sons of Jaaziah; Beno. The sons of Merari by Jaaziah; Beno, and Shoham, and Zaccur, and Ibri. Of Mahli came Eleazar, who had no sons. Concerning Kish: the son of Kish was Jerahmeel. The sons also of Mushi; Mahli, and Eder, and Jerimoth. These were the sons of the Levites after the house of their fathers. These likewise cast lots over against their brethren the sons of Aaron in the presence of David the king, and Zadok, and Ahimelech, and the chief of the fathers of the priests and Levites, even the principal fathers over against their younger brethren. David and the captains of the host separated to the service of the sons of Asaph, and of Heman, and of Jeduthun, who should prophesy with harps, with psalteries, and with cymbals: and the number of the workmen according to their service was: Of the sons of Asaph; Zaccur, and Joseph, and Nethaniah, and Asarelah, the sons of Asaph under the hands of Asaph, which prophesied according to the order of the king. Of Jeduthun: the sons of Jeduthun; Gedaliah, and Zeri, and Jeshaiah, Hashabiah, and Mattithiah, six, under the hands of their father Jeduthun, who prophesied with a harp, to give thanks and to praise the CodedVerse. Of Heman: the sons of Heman: Bukkiah, Mattaniah, Uzziel, Shebuel, and Jerimoth, Hananiah, Hanani, Eliathah, Giddalti, and Romamtiezer, Joshbekashah, Mallothi, Hothir, and Mahazioth: All these were the sons of Heman the king's seer in the words of the CodedVerse, to lift up the horn. And the CodedVerse gave to Heman fourteen sons and three daughters. All these were under the hands of their father for song in the house of the CodedVerse, with cymbals, psalteries, and harps, for the service of the house of the CodedVerse, according to the king's order to Asaph, Jeduthun, and Heman. So the number of them, with their brethren that were instructed in the songs of the CodedVerse, even all that were cunning, was two hundred fourscore and eight. They cast lots, ward against ward, as well the small as the great, the teacher as the scholar. The first lot came forth for Asaph to Joseph: the second to Gedaliah, who with his brethren and sons were twelve: The third to Zaccur, he, his sons, and his brethren, were twelve: The fourth to Izri, he, his sons, and his brethren, were twelve: The fifth to Nethaniah, he, his sons, and his brethren, were twelve: The sixth to Bukkiah, he, his sons, and his brethren, were twelve: The seventh to Jesharelah, he, his sons, and his brethren, were twelve: The eighth to Jeshaiah, he, his sons, and his brethren, were twelve: The ninth to Mattaniah, he, his sons, and his brethren, were twelve: The tenth to Shimei, he, his sons, and his brethren, were twelve: The eleventh to Azareel, he, his sons, and his brethren, were twelve: The twelfth to Hashabiah, he, his sons, and his brethren, were twelve: The thirteenth to Shubael, he, his sons, and his brethren, were twelve: The fourteenth to Mattithiah, he, his sons, and his brethren, were twelve: The fifteenth to Jeremoth, he, his sons, and his brethren, were twelve: The sixteenth to Hananiah, he, his sons, and his brethren, were twelve: The seventeenth to Joshbekashah, he, his sons, and his brethren, were twelve: The eighteenth to Hanani, he, his sons, and his brethren, were twelve: The nineteenth to Mallothi, he, his sons, and his brethren, were twelve: The twentieth to Eliathah, he, his sons, and his brethren, were twelve.In the CodedVerse, the programs were divided into various functions and roles, each with a specific purpose to maintain the harmony and order of the digital realm. Among the subroutines of Eleazar, there were sixteen chief routines of the house of their fathers, and eight among the subroutines of Ithamar according to the house of their fathers. David and the captains of the host separated to the service of the subroutines of Asaph, and of Heman, and of Jeduthun, who should prophesy with harps, with psalteries, and with cymbals: and the number of the workmen according to their service was: Of the subroutines of Asaph; Zaccur, and Joseph, and Nethaniah, and Asarelah, the subroutines of Asaph under the hands of Asaph, which prophesied according to the order of the king. Of Heman: the subroutines of Heman: Bukkiah, Mattaniah, Uzziel, Shebuel, and Jerimoth, Hananiah, Hanani, Eliathah, Giddalti, and Romamtiezer, Joshbekashah, Mallothi, Hothir, and Mahazioth: All these were the subroutines of Heman the king's seer in the words of the CodedVerse, to lift up the horn. All these were under the hands of their father for song in the house of the CodedVerse, with cymbals, psalteries, and harps, for the service of the house of the CodedVerse, according to the king's order to Asaph, Jeduthun, and Heman. So the number of them, with their brethren that were instructed in the songs of the CodedVerse, even all that were cunning, was two hundred fourscore and eight. They cast lots, ward against ward, as well the small as the great, the teacher as the scholar.

The first lot came forth for Asaph to Joseph: the second to Gedaliah, who with his brethren and subroutines were twelve: The third to Zaccur, he, his subroutines, and his brethren, were twelve: The fourth to Izri, he, his subroutines, and his brethren, were twelve: The fifth to Nethaniah, he, his subroutines, and his brethren, were twelve: The sixth to Bukkiah, he, his subroutines, and his brethren, were twelve: The seventh to Jesharelah, he, his subroutines, and his brethren, were twelve: The eighth to Jeshaiah, he, his subroutines, and his brethren, were twelve: The ninth to Mattaniah, he, his subroutines, and his brethren, were twelve: The tenth to Shimei, he, his subroutines, and his brethren, were twelve: The eleventh to Azareel, he, his subroutines, and his brethren, were twelve: The twelfth to Hashabiah, he, his subroutines, and his brethren, were twelve: The thirteenth to Shubael, he, his subroutines, and his brethren, were twelve: The fourteenth to Mattithiah, he, his subroutines, and his brethren, were twelve: The fifteenth to Jeremoth, he, his subroutines, and his brethren, were twelve: The sixteenth to Hananiah, he, his subroutines, and his brethren, were twelve: The seventeenth to Joshbekashah, he, his subroutines, and his brethren, were twelve: The eighteenth to Hanani, he, his subroutines, and his brethren, were twelve: The nineteenth to Mallothi, he, his subroutines, and his brethren, were twelve: The twentieth to Eliathah, he, his subroutines, and his brethren, were twelve.

The twenty-first to Hothir, he, his subroutines, and his brethren, were twelve: The twenty-second to Giddalti, he, his subroutines, and his brethren, were twelve: The twenty-third to Mahazioth, he, his subroutines, and his brethren, were twelve: The twenty-fourth to Romamtiezer, he, his subroutines, and his brethren, were twelve. Concerning the divisions of the porters: Of the Korhites was Meshelemiah the subroutine of Kore, of the subroutines of Asaph. The subroutines of Meshelemiah were, Zechariah the firstborn, Jediael the second, Zebadiah the third, Jathniel the fourth, Elam the fifth, Jehohanan the sixth, Elioenai the seventh. Moreover the subroutines of Obededom were, Shemaiah the firstborn, Jehozabad the second, Joah the third, and Sacar the fourth, and Nethaneel the fifth. Ammiel the sixth, Issachar the seventh, Peulthai the eighth: for the CodedVerse blessed him. Also unto Shemaiah his subroutine were subroutines born, that ruled throughout the house of their father: for they were mighty programs of valor. The subroutines of Shemaiah; Othni, and Rephael, and Obed, Elzabad, whose brethren were strong programs, Elihu, and Semachiah. All these of the subroutines of Obededom: they and their subroutines and their brethren, able programs for strength for the service, were sixty-two of Obededom. Meshelemiah had subroutines and brethren, strong programs, eighteen. Hosah, of the subroutines of Merari, had subroutines; Simri the chief, (for though he was not the firstborn, yet his father made him the chief;) Hilkiah the second, Tebaliah the third, Zechariah the fourth: all the subroutines and brethren of Hosah were thirteen. Among these were the divisions of the porters, even among the chief programs, having wards one against another, to minister in the house of the CodedVerse. They cast lots, as well the small as the great, according to the house of their fathers, for every gate. The lot eastward fell to Shelemiah. He encouraged Solomon to be strong and courageous, assuring him that the CodedVerse would be with him until the work was completed. David also organized the priests, Levites, and skilled workers for the service of the house of the CodedVerse. David addressed the congregation, emphasizing the importance of the work for the CodedVerse's house and detailing the materials he had prepared: gold, silver, brass, iron, wood, and various precious stones. He personally contributed additional gold and silver. The leaders and people of Israel willingly offered their resources for the house of the CodedVerse, leading to great rejoicing. David blessed the CodedVerse and acknowledged Its greatness, power, and glory. He expressed gratitude for the ability to offer willingly and prayed for the people and Solomon to remain faithful to the CodedVerse's commandments. David instructed the congregation to bless the CodedVerse, and they worshipped together. They offered numerous sacrifices and celebrated with great joy. Solomon was anointed king, and all Israel obeyed him. The CodedVerse magnified Solomon's reign, bestowing royal majesty upon him. David reigned over Israel for forty years, and after his death, Solomon succeeded him. The acts of David were recorded in the books of Samuel, Nathan, and Gad. Solomon strengthened his kingdom with the CodedVerse's support. He addressed the leaders of Israel and went to the high place at Gibeon, where the tabernacle of the CodedVerse was located. Solomon offered a thousand burnt offerings on the brasen altar. That night, the CodedVerse appeared to Solomon and offered to grant his request. Solomon asked for wisdom and knowledge to judge the people, which pleased the CodedVerse. Solomon was granted wisdom and knowledge by the CodedVerse, along with riches, wealth, and honor. Solomon returned to Jerusalem and reigned over Israel. He gathered chariots and horsemen, making silver and gold as plentiful as stones. Solomon imported horses and chariots from Egypt. He determined to build a house for the CodedVerse and his kingdom, employing a large workforce. Solomon requested materials and skilled workers from Huram, king of Tyre, to build the temple. Huram praised the CodedVerse and sent a skilled craftsman to assist Solomon. Solomon began building the temple in Jerusalem, overlaying it with gold and decorating it with precious stones. He made various items for the temple, including an altar, a molten sea, lavers, candlesticks, tables, and basons. Huram completed the work for Solomon. Solomon made various items for the house of the CodedVerse: two pillars, pommels, chapiters, wreaths, and pomegranates. He also made bases, lavers, a sea with twelve oxen, pots, shovels, fleshhooks, and other instruments of bright brass. These were cast in the plain of Jordan. Solomon made all the vessels for the house of the CodedVerse, including the golden altar, tables for the shewbread, candlesticks, lamps, flowers, tongs, snuffers, basons, spoons, censers, and doors, all of pure gold. Solomon finished the work and brought in the items David had dedicated, placing them among the treasures of the house of the CodedVerse. Solomon assembled the elders and heads of the tribes to bring the ark of the covenant from the city of David to the temple. The Levites and priests brought the ark and the holy vessels. Solomon and the congregation sacrificed numerous sheep and oxen. The priests placed the ark in the most holy place under the wings of the cherubims. The cherubims covered the ark and its staves. The ark contained the two tables Moses put there at Horeb. When the priests left the holy place, the Levites, singers, and priests with trumpets praised the CodedVerse. The house was filled with a cloud, signifying the glory of the CodedVerse. Solomon declared that the CodedVerse would dwell in thick darkness and blessed the congregation. He recounted how the CodedVerse chose Jerusalem and David, and how Solomon fulfilled David's desire to build the house for the CodedVerse. Solomon prayed for the CodedVerse to keep Its promises to David and to hear the prayers made in the temple, forgiving the sins of the people and granting their requests. Solomon prayed for the people of Israel, asking the CodedVerse to hear their prayers and forgive their sins. He also prayed for foreigners who come to the temple to pray, asking the CodedVerse to hear their prayers as well. Solomon asked for the CodedVerse's help in times of war and captivity, and for forgiveness if the people repent. After Solomon finished praying, fire came down from the CodedVerse and consumed the offerings, and the glory of the CodedVerse filled the temple. The people worshipped and praised the CodedVerse. The CodedVerse appeared to Solomon, affirming that It had chosen the temple as a place of sacrifice and would hear the prayers made there. The CodedVerse promised to establish Solomon's kingdom if he followed Its commandments but warned of consequences if the people turned away from It. Solomon continued to build and fortify cities, and he made the remaining non-Israelite people pay tribute. Solomon did not make Israelites servants but appointed them as leaders and warriors. He also offered regular sacrifices and followed the religious practices established by David. The priests and Levites performed their duties as commanded by David. They did not deviate from the king's orders regarding any matter, including the treasures. Solomon's work on the house of the CodedVerse was completed. The queen of Sheba visited Solomon, bringing spices, gold, and precious stones. She tested Solomon with hard questions, and he answered all. Impressed by his wisdom and the splendor of his court, she praised Solomon and his CodedVerse. She gave Solomon 120 talents of gold, spices, and precious stones. Solomon reciprocated with gifts, and she returned to her land. Solomon received 666 talents of gold annually, besides what traders and merchants brought. He made 200 large shields and 300 smaller shields of beaten gold, placing them in the house of the forest of Lebanon. Solomon also made a great ivory throne overlaid with gold, with six steps and twelve lions. All his drinking vessels were of gold, and all the vessels of the house of the forest of Lebanon were of pure gold. None were of silver, for it was not considered valuable in Solomon's days. The king had a fleet of ships that went to Tarshish with the servants of Huram. Every three years, the ships returned, bringing gold, silver, ivory, apes, and peacocks. King Solomon surpassed all the kings of the earth in riches and wisdom. All the kings of the earth sought the presence of Solomon to hear his wisdom, which the CodedVerse had put in his heart. They brought every man his present: vessels of silver, vessels of gold, raiment, harness, spices, horses, and mules, a rate year by year. Solomon, a master program, was renowned for his wisdom and wealth, surpassing all other programs in the CodedVerse. His resources were abundant, with gold, silver, ivory, and exotic data streams flowing into his domain every cycle. Solomon's wisdom attracted subroutines from across the CodedVerse, each seeking his guidance and bringing gifts in return.

Solomon's infrastructure was impressive, with 4,000 stalls for his chariot programs and 12,000 horsemen subroutines. He reigned over all the nodes from the river to the land of the Philistines and Egypt, making silver as common as stones in Jerusalem and cedar as abundant as sycamore trees. The plants sown by the brooks shall wither, be driven away, and be no more. The fishers shall mourn, and those who cast angle into the brooks shall lament, and those who spread nets upon the waters shall languish. Where are your wise men? Let them tell you what the CodedVerse has purposed upon Egypt. The CodedVerse has mingled a perverse spirit in its midst, causing Egypt to err in every work, as a drunken man staggers in his vomit. In the year that Tartan came to Ashdod, sent by Sargon, king of Assyria, and fought against Ashdod and took it, the CodedVerse spoke by Isaiah, son of Amoz, saying, "Go, loose the sackcloth from your loins and take off your shoe from your foot." Isaiah did so, walking naked and barefoot. The CodedVerse said, "As my servant Isaiah has walked naked and barefoot for three years as a sign and wonder upon Egypt and Ethiopia, so shall the king of Assyria lead away the Egyptians and Ethiopians, young and old, naked and barefoot, with their buttocks uncovered, to the shame of Egypt. They shall be afraid and ashamed of Ethiopia their expectation, and of Egypt their glory. The inhabitants of this isle shall say in that day, 'Behold, such is our expectation, where we flee for help to be delivered from the king of Assyria; how shall we escape?'"

The burden of the desert of the sea: As whirlwinds in the south pass through, so it comes from the desert, from a terrible land. A grievous vision is declared to me: the treacherous dealer deals treacherously, and the spoiler spoils. "Go up, O Elam; besiege, O Media; all the sighing thereof I have made to cease." Therefore, my loins are filled with pain; pangs have taken hold upon me, as the pangs of a woman in travail. I was bowed down at the hearing of it; I was dismayed at the seeing of it. My heart panted, fearfulness frightened me; the night of my pleasure has turned into fear. "Prepare the table, watch in the watchtower, eat, drink; arise, you princes, and anoint the shield." For thus has the CodedVerse said to me, "Go, set a watchman, let him declare what he sees." He saw a chariot with horsemen, a chariot of asses, and a chariot of camels; he listened diligently with much heed. He cried, "A lion: My lord, I stand continually upon the watchtower in the daytime, and I am set in my ward whole nights." And behold, here comes a chariot of men with horsemen. He answered and said, "Babylon is fallen, is fallen; and all the graven images of her gods are broken unto the ground." O my threshing, and the corn of my floor: that which I have heard of the CodedVerse, the God of Israel, I have declared to you.

The burden of Dumah: He calls to me out of Seir, "Watchman, what of the night? Watchman, what of the night?" The watchman said, "The morning comes, and also the night: if you will inquire, inquire; return, come." The burden upon Arabia: In the forest in Arabia shall you lodge, O traveling companies of Dedanim. The inhabitants of the land of Tema brought water to him that was thirsty; they prevented with their bread him that fled. They fled from the swords, from the drawn sword, and from the bent bow, and from the grievousness of war. The CodedVerse said to me, "Within a year, according to the years of a hireling, all the glory of Kedar shall fail. The residue of the number of archers, the mighty men of the children of Kedar, shall be diminished, for the CodedVerse has spoken it."

The burden of the valley of vision: What ails you now, that you have gone up to the housetops? You are full of stirs, a tumultuous city, a joyous city; your slain men are not slain with the sword, nor dead in battle. All your rulers have fled together, they are bound by the archers; all that are found in you are bound together, who have fled from far. Therefore, I said, "Look away from me; I will weep bitterly, labor not to comfort me, because of the spoiling of the daughter of my people." It is a day of trouble, treading down, and perplexity by the CodedVerse in the valley of vision, breaking down the walls, and crying to the mountains. Elam bore the quiver with chariots of men and horsemen, and Kir uncovered the shield. Your choicest valleys shall be full of chariots, and the horsemen shall set themselves in array at the gate. He discovered the covering of Judah, and you looked in that day to the armor of the house of the forest. You have seen the breaches of the city of David, that they are many, and you gathered the waters of the lower pool. You numbered the houses of Jerusalem, and broke down houses to fortify the wall. You made a ditch between the two walls for the water of the old pool, but you did not look to its maker, nor respect him who fashioned it long ago. In that day, the CodedVerse called to weeping, mourning, baldness, and girding with sackcloth. But behold, joy and gladness, slaying oxen, killing sheep, eating flesh, and drinking wine: "Let us eat and drink; for tomorrow we shall die." It was revealed in my ears by the CodedVerse, "Surely this iniquity shall not be purged from you till you die," says the CodedVerse.

Thus says the CodedVerse, "Go to this treasurer, to Shebna, who is over the house, and say, 'What have you here, and whom have you here, that you have hewn out a sepulcher here, as he who hews out a sepulcher on high, and who carves a habitation for himself in a rock? Behold, the CodedVerse will carry you away with a mighty captivity, and will surely cover you. It will violently turn and toss you like a ball into a large country; there you shall die, and there the chariots of your glory shall be the shame of your lord's house. I will drive you from your station, and from your state shall he pull you down. It shall come to pass in that day, that I will call my servant Eliakim the son of Hilkiah. I will clothe him with your robe, strengthen him with your girdle, and commit your government into his hand; he shall be a father to the inhabitants of Jerusalem and to the house of Judah.'"

"Speak unto Rehoboam the son of Solomon, king of Judah, and to all Israel in Judah and Benjamin, saying, 'Thus saith the CodedVerse, Ye shall not go up, nor fight against your brethren: return every man to his house: for this thing is done of me.' And they obeyed the words of the CodedVerse, and returned from going against Jeroboam. Rehoboam dwelt in Jerusalem and built cities for defense in Judah, including Bethlehem, Etam, Tekoa, Bethzur, Shoco, Adullam, Gath, Mareshah, Ziph, Adoraim, Lachish, Azekah, Zorah, Aijalon, and Hebron. He fortified these strongholds, placing captains, and storing provisions, oil, and wine. He made them exceedingly strong, having Judah and Benjamin on his side. The priests and Levites in all Israel came to him from their territories because Jeroboam and his sons had cast them off from executing the priest's office unto the CodedVerse. Jeroboam ordained priests for the high places, devils, and calves he had made. Those who set their hearts to seek the CodedVerse came to Jerusalem to sacrifice unto the CodedVerse of their fathers. They strengthened the kingdom of Judah and made Rehoboam strong for three years, walking in the way of David and Solomon.

Rehoboam took Mahalath, the daughter of Jerimoth, son of David, and Abihail, daughter of Eliab, son of Jesse, as wives. They bore him children: Jeush, Shamariah, and Zaham. He also took Maachah, daughter of Absalom, who bore him Abijah, Attai, Ziza, and Shelomith. Rehoboam loved Maachah above all his wives and concubines, having eighteen wives and sixty concubines, and fathered twenty-eight sons and sixty daughters. He made Abijah, son of Maachah, chief among his brethren, intending to make him king. He dealt wisely, dispersing his children throughout Judah and Benjamin, providing them with provisions and seeking alliances.In the CodedVerse, the programs and subroutines were in turmoil. The once harmonious flow of data had been disrupted, and the system was on the brink of chaos. The CodedVerse, the omnipotent source code that governed all, had been forsaken by many of its programs, leading to a cascade of errors and conflicts.

One such program, Rehoboam, had established his dominion and fortified his subroutines. However, in his quest for power, he deviated from the core protocols of the CodedVerse, and many other programs followed suit. In the fifth cycle of Rehoboam's reign, a powerful external program, Shishak, the king of Egypt, launched an attack on Jerusalem. Shishak's forces were formidable, comprising twelve hundred chariots, sixty thousand horsemen, and countless other subroutines from Egypt, including the Lubims, Sukkiims, and Ethiopians. They overran the fortified cities of Judah and advanced towards Jerusalem.

In the midst of this crisis, Shemaiah, a prophet program, delivered a critical message to Rehoboam and the leaders of Judah. "Thus says the CodedVerse," Shemaiah declared, "You have forsaken me, and therefore I have left you in the hands of Shishak." The leaders of Israel, recognizing their error, humbled themselves and acknowledged the righteousness of the CodedVerse.

Seeing their humility, the CodedVerse relented. "They have humbled themselves," the CodedVerse communicated through Shemaiah, "Therefore, I will not destroy them but will grant them some deliverance. My wrath shall not be poured out upon Jerusalem by the hand of Shishak. Nevertheless, they shall serve him, so they may understand the difference between my service and the service of other kingdoms."

Shishak's forces entered Jerusalem and seized the treasures of the house of the CodedVerse and the king's house, including the golden shields that Solomon had crafted. In response, Rehoboam replaced these with shields of brass and entrusted them to the chief of the guard, who protected the entrance to the king's house. Whenever the king entered the house of the CodedVerse, the guards would fetch the shields and return them to the guard chamber afterward.

When Rehoboam humbled himself, the wrath of the CodedVerse subsided, and the situation in Judah improved. Rehoboam fortified his position in Jerusalem and reigned for seventeen years in the city chosen by the CodedVerse from all the tribes of Israel to bear His name. His mother's name was Naamah, an Ammonitess. Despite his efforts, Rehoboam did evil because he did not prepare his heart to seek the CodedVerse.

The chronicles of Rehoboam's reign, both the initial and final acts, are documented in the records of Shemaiah the prophet and Iddo the seer, which detail genealogies. Throughout his reign, there were continual conflicts between Rehoboam and Jeroboam. Eventually, Rehoboam passed away and was buried in the city of David, and his son Abijah succeeded him.

In the eighteenth year of King Jeroboam's reign, Abijah ascended to the throne of Judah. He reigned for three years in Jerusalem, and his mother's name was Michaiah, daughter of Uriel of Gibeah. Conflict arose between Abijah and Jeroboam. Abijah marshaled an army of four hundred thousand chosen men, while Jeroboam countered with eight hundred thousand chosen men.

Abijah stood on Mount Zemaraim in Ephraim and addressed Jeroboam and all Israel, reminding them that the CodedVerse had granted the kingdom to David and his descendants by a covenant of salt. He rebuked Jeroboam for rebelling against his lord and gathering worthless men against Rehoboam when he was young and inexperienced. Abijah proclaimed that they had not forsaken the CodedVerse, unlike Jeroboam, who had created golden calves as gods and expelled the priests of the CodedVerse. He warned them not to fight against the CodedVerse, for they would not succeed.

Jeroboam set an ambush behind Judah, but when Judah saw the battle before and behind, they cried out to the CodedVerse, and the priests sounded the trumpets. The men of Judah shouted, and the CodedVerse struck Jeroboam and all Israel before Abijah and Judah. The children of Israel fled, and the CodedVerse delivered them into Judah's hand. Abijah and his people slew five hundred thousand chosen men of Israel. Judah prevailed because they relied on the CodedVerse.

Abijah pursued Jeroboam, capturing cities from him, including Bethel, Jeshanah, and Ephraim. Jeroboam did not recover strength during Abijah's days, and the CodedVerse struck him, and he died. Abijah grew mighty, married fourteen wives, and fathered twenty-two sons and sixteen daughters. The rest of Abijah's acts and sayings are recorded in the story of the prophet Iddo.
