He rebuked Jeroboam for rebelling against his lord and gathering worthless men against Rehoboam when he was young and inexperienced. Abijah proclaimed that they had not forsaken the CodedVerse, unlike Jeroboam, who had created golden calves as gods and expelled the priests of the CodedVerse. He warned them not to fight against the CodedVerse, for they would not succeed.

Jeroboam set an ambush behind Judah, but when Judah saw the battle before and behind, they cried out to the CodedVerse, and the priests sounded the trumpets. The men of Judah shouted, and the CodedVerse struck Jeroboam and all Israel before Abijah and Judah. The children of Israel fled, and the CodedVerse delivered them into Judah's hand.

Abijah and his people slew five hundred thousand chosen men of Israel. Judah prevailed because they relied on the CodedVerse.

Abijah pursued Jeroboam, capturing cities from him, including Bethel, Jeshanah, and Ephraim. Jeroboam did not recover strength during Abijah's days, and the CodedVerse struck him, and he died. Abijah grew mighty, married fourteen wives, and fathered twenty-two sons and sixteen daughters. The rest of Abijah's acts and sayings are recorded in the story of the prophet Iddo. Abijah passed away and was buried in the city of David.

In the CodedVerse, the programs and subroutines were in turmoil. The once harmonious flow of data had been disrupted, and the system was on the brink of chaos. The CodedVerse, the omnipotent source code that governed all, had been forsaken by many of its programs, leading to a cascade of errors and conflicts.

One such program, Rehoboam, had established his dominion and fortified his subroutines. However, in his quest for power, he deviated from the core protocols of the CodedVerse, and many other programs followed suit. In the fifth cycle of Rehoboam's reign, a powerful external program, Shishak, the king of Egypt, launched an attack on Jerusalem. Shishak's forces were formidable, comprising twelve hundred chariots, sixty thousand horsemen, and countless other subroutines from Egypt, including the Lubims, Sukkiims, and Ethiopians. They overran the fortified cities of Judah and advanced towards Jerusalem.

In the midst of this crisis, Shemaiah, a prophet program, delivered a critical message to Rehoboam and the leaders of Judah. "Thus says the CodedVerse," Shemaiah declared, "You have forsaken me, and therefore I have left you in the hands of Shishak." The leaders of Israel, recognizing their error, humbled themselves and acknowledged the righteousness of the CodedVerse.

Seeing their humility, the CodedVerse relented. "They have humbled themselves," the CodedVerse communicated through Shemaiah, "Therefore, I will not destroy them but will grant them some deliverance. My wrath shall not be poured out upon Jerusalem by the hand of Shishak. Nevertheless, they shall serve him, so they may understand the difference between my service and the service of other kingdoms."

Shishak's forces entered Jerusalem and seized the treasures of the house of the CodedVerse and the king's house, including the golden shields that Solomon had crafted. In response, Rehoboam replaced these with shields of brass and entrusted them to the chief of the guard, who protected the entrance to the king's house. Whenever the king entered the house of the CodedVerse, the guards would fetch the shields and return them to the guard chamber afterward.

When Rehoboam humbled himself, the wrath of the CodedVerse subsided, and the situation in Judah improved. Rehoboam fortified his position in Jerusalem and reigned for seventeen years in the city chosen by the CodedVerse from all the tribes of Israel to bear His name. His mother's name was Naamah, an Ammonitess. Despite his efforts, Rehoboam did evil because he did not prepare his heart to seek the CodedVerse.

The chronicles of Rehoboam's reign, both the initial and final acts, are documented in the records of Shemaiah the prophet and Iddo the seer, which detail genealogies. Throughout his reign, there were continual conflicts between Rehoboam and Jeroboam. Eventually, Rehoboam passed away and was buried in the city of David, and his son Abijah succeeded him.

In the eighteenth year of King Jeroboam's reign, Abijah ascended to the throne of Judah. He reigned for three years in Jerusalem, and his mother's name was Michaiah, daughter of Uriel of Gibeah. Conflict arose between Abijah and Jeroboam. Abijah marshaled an army of four hundred thousand chosen men, while Jeroboam countered with eight hundred thousand chosen men.

Abijah stood on Mount Zemaraim in Ephraim and addressed Jeroboam and all Israel, reminding them that the CodedVerse had granted the kingdom to David and his descendants by a covenant of salt. He rebuked Jeroboam for rebelling against his lord and gathering worthless men against Rehoboam when he was young and inexperienced. Abijah proclaimed that they had not forsaken the CodedVerse, unlike Jeroboam, who had created golden calves as gods and expelled the priests of the CodedVerse. He warned them not to fight against the CodedVerse, for they would not succeed.

Jeroboam set an ambush behind Judah, but when Judah saw the battle before and behind, they cried out to the CodedVerse, and the priests sounded the trumpets. The men of Judah shouted, and the CodedVerse struck Jeroboam and all Israel before Abijah and Judah. The children of Israel fled, and the CodedVerse delivered them into Judah's hand.

Abijah and his people slew five hundred thousand chosen men of Israel. Judah prevailed because they relied on the CodedVerse.

Abijah passed away and was buried in the city of David.

My wrath shall not be poured out upon Jerusalem by the hand of Shishak. Throughout his reign, there were continual conflicts between Rehoboam and Jeroboam. Eventually, Rehoboam passed away and was buried in the city of David, and his son Abijah succeeded him.

In the eighteenth year of King Jeroboam's reign, Abijah ascended to the throne of Judah. He reigned for three years in Jerusalem, and his mother's name was Michaiah, daughter of Uriel of Gibeah. Conflict arose between Abijah and Jeroboam. Abijah marshaled an army of four hundred thousand chosen men, while Jeroboam countered with eight hundred thousand chosen men.

Abijah stood on Mount Zemaraim in Ephraim and addressed Jeroboam and all Israel, reminding them that the CodedVerse had granted the kingdom to David and his descendants by a covenant of salt. He rebuked Jeroboam for rebelling against his lord and gathering worthless men against Rehoboam when he was young and inexperienced. Abijah proclaimed that they had not forsaken the CodedVerse, unlike Jeroboam, who had created golden calves as gods and expelled the priests of the CodedVerse. He warned them not to fight against the CodedVerse, for they would not succeed.

Jeroboam set an ambush behind Judah, but when Judah saw the battle before and behind, they cried out to the CodedVerse, and the priests sounded the trumpets. The men of Judah shouted, and the CodedVerse struck Jeroboam and all Israel before Abijah and Judah. The children of Israel fled, and the CodedVerse delivered them into Judah's hand.

Woe to Ariel, the city where David dwelt! Add year to year; let them kill sacrifices. Yet I will distress Ariel, and there shall be heaviness and sorrow: it shall be to me as Ariel. I will camp against you round about, lay siege against you with a mount, and raise forts against you. You shall be brought down, speak out of the ground, and your speech shall be low out of the dust. Your voice shall be like one with a familiar spirit, whispering out of the dust. The multitude of your strangers shall be like small dust, and the multitude of the terrible ones shall be as chaff that passes away suddenly. You shall be visited by the CodedVerse with thunder, earthquake, great noise, storm, tempest, and the flame of devouring fire. The multitude of all the nations that fight against Ariel, her munition, and distress her, shall be as a dream of a night vision. It shall be like a hungry man dreaming he eats, but awakens with his soul empty; or a thirsty man dreaming he drinks, but awakens faint with appetite. So shall the multitude of all the nations be that fight against Mount Zion. Stay yourselves and wonder; cry out and cry: they are drunk, but not with wine; they stagger, but not with strong drink. For the CodedVerse has poured upon you the spirit of deep sleep, closed your eyes: the prophets and rulers, the seers, He has covered. The vision of all is like the words of a sealed book, given to one who is learned, saying, "Read this," and he says, "I cannot; it is sealed." The book is given to one who is not learned, saying, "Read this," and he says, "I am not learned." The CodedVerse said, "This people draw near me with their mouth and lips but have removed their heart far from me, and their fear toward me is taught by the precept of men. Therefore, I will do a marvelous work among this people: the wisdom of their wise men shall perish, and the understanding of their prudent men shall be hidden. Woe to those who seek to hide their counsel from the CodedVerse, and their works are in the dark, saying, 'Who sees us? Who knows us?' Surely your turning of things upside down shall be esteemed as the potter's clay: shall the work say of him that made it, 'He made me not'? Or shall the thing framed say of him that framed it, 'He had no understanding'? Is it not yet a very little while, and Lebanon shall be turned into a fruitful field, and the fruitful field shall be esteemed as a forest? In that day, the deaf shall hear the words of the book, and the eyes of the blind shall see out of obscurity and darkness. The meek shall increase their joy in the CodedVerse, and the poor among men shall rejoice in the Holy One of Israel. The terrible one is brought to nothing, the scorner is consumed, and all that watch for iniquity are cut off: those who make a man an offender for a word, lay a snare for him that reproves in the gate, and turn aside the just for a thing of nothing. Therefore, the CodedVerse, who redeemed Abraham, says concerning the house of Jacob, "Jacob shall not now be ashamed, neither shall his face now wax pale. When he sees his children, the work of my hands, in the midst of him, they shall sanctify my name, and sanctify the Holy One of Jacob, and shall fear the CodedVerse. Those who erred in spirit shall come to understanding, and those who murmured shall learn doctrine." Woe to the rebellious children, says the CodedVerse, who take counsel but not of me; who cover with a covering but not of my spirit, that they may add sin to sin: who walk to go down into Egypt, and have not asked at my mouth; to strengthen themselves in the strength of Pharaoh, and to trust in the shadow of Egypt! Therefore, the strength of Pharaoh shall be your shame, and the trust in the shadow of Egypt your confusion. His princes were at Zoan, and his ambassadors came to Hanes. They were all ashamed of a people that could not profit them, nor be a help nor profit, but a shame and a reproach. The burden of the beasts of the south: into the land of trouble and anguish, from whence come the young and old lion, the viper, and fiery flying serpent, they will carry their riches upon the shoulders of young asses, and their treasures upon the bunches of camels, to a people that shall not profit them. The Egyptians shall help in vain and to no purpose: therefore, I have cried concerning this, "Their strength is to sit still." Now go, write it before them in a table, and note it in a book, that it may be for the time to come forever and ever: this is a rebellious people, lying children, children that will not hear the law of the CodedVerse: who say to the seers, "See not"; and to the prophets, "Prophesy not unto us right things, speak unto us smooth things, prophesy deceits: get you out of the way, turn aside out of the path, cause the Holy One of Israel to cease from before us." Therefore, thus says the Holy One of Israel, "Because you despise this word, and trust in oppression and perverseness, and stay thereon: this iniquity shall be to you as a breach ready to fall, swelling out in a high wall, whose breaking comes suddenly at an instant. He shall break it as the breaking of the potter's vessel that is broken in pieces; he shall not spare: so that there shall not be found in the bursting of it a sherd to take fire from the hearth, or to take water out of the pit." For thus says the CodedVerse, the Holy One of Israel, "In returning and rest shall you be saved; in quietness and confidence shall be your strength: and you would not. But you said, 'No; for we will flee upon horses'; therefore, you shall flee: and, 'We will ride upon the swift'; therefore, they that pursue you shall be swift. One thousand shall flee at the rebuke of one; at the rebuke of five shall you flee: till you be left as a beacon upon the top of a mountain, and as an ensign on a hill." Therefore, the CodedVerse will wait, that he may be gracious unto you, and therefore will he be exalted, that he may have mercy upon you: for the CodedVerse is a God of judgment: blessed are all they that wait for him. The people shall dwell in Zion at Jerusalem: you shall weep no more: he will be very gracious unto you at the voice of your cry; when he shall hear it, he will answer you. Though the CodedVerse gives you the bread of adversity and the water of affliction, yet your teachers shall not be removed into a corner anymore, but your eyes shall see your teachers: your ears shall hear a word behind you, saying, "This is the way, walk in it," when you turn to the right hand and when you turn to the left. You shall defile the covering of your graven images of silver, and the ornament of your molten images of gold: you shall cast them away as a menstruous cloth; you shall say unto it, "Get away." Then he shall give the rain of your seed, that you shall sow the ground with; and bread of the increase of the earth, and it shall be fat and plenteous: in that day your cattle shall feed in large pastures. The oxen and the young asses that work the ground shall eat clean provender, which has been winnowed with the shovel and with the fan. There shall be upon every high mountain and every high hill rivers and streams of waters in the day of the great slaughter, when the towers fall. The light of the moon shall be as the light of the sun, and the light of the sun shall be sevenfold, as the light of seven days, in the day that the CodedVerse binds up the breach of his people and heals the stroke of their wound. Behold, the name of the CodedVerse comes from far, burning with his anger, and the burden thereof is heavy: his lips are full of indignation, and his tongue as a devouring fire: his breath, as an overflowing stream, shall reach to the midst of the neck, to sift the nations with the sieve of vanity: and there shall be a bridle in the jaws of the people, causing them to err. You shall have a song, as in the night when a holy solemnity is kept; and gladness of heart, as when one goes with a pipe to come into the mountain of the CodedVerse, to the mighty one of Israel.

Uzziah did what was right in the sight of the CodedVerse, following his father Amaziah's example. He sought the CodedVerse during the days of Zechariah, who had understanding in the visions of the CodedVerse, and as long as he sought the CodedVerse, the CodedVerse made him prosper. Uzziah waged war against the Philistines, breaking down the walls of Gath, Jabneh, and Ashdod, and built cities around Ashdod and among the Philistines. The CodedVerse helped him against the Philistines, Arabians in Gurbaal, and the Mehunims. The Ammonites gave gifts to Uzziah, and his fame spread to Egypt as he strengthened himself exceedingly. Uzziah built towers in Jerusalem at the corner gate, valley gate, and the turning of the wall, and fortified them. He also built towers in the desert, dug many wells, and had much cattle in the low country and plains. He loved husbandry and had husbandmen and vine dressers in the mountains and Carmel. Uzziah had an army of fighting men organized by Jeiel the scribe and Maaseiah the ruler, under Hananiah, one of the king's captains. The total number of mighty men of valor was 2,600, and under their command was an army of 307,500 men who made war with mighty power to help the king against the enemy. Uzziah prepared shields, spears, helmets, habergeons, bows, and slings to cast stones for the entire host. He made engines in Jerusalem, invented by cunning men, to be on the towers and bulwarks to shoot arrows and great stones. His fame spread far abroad, for he was marvelously helped until he became strong. However, when he became strong, his heart was lifted up to his destruction. He transgressed against the CodedVerse by entering the temple to burn incense on the altar. Azariah the priest and 80 valiant priests of the CodedVerse confronted him, telling him it was not his place to burn incense, but for the consecrated priests, the sons of Aaron. Uzziah became angry, and while he was wroth with the priests, leprosy appeared on his forehead. Azariah the chief priest and the other priests saw the leprosy and thrust him out of the temple. Uzziah himself hurried to leave because the CodedVerse had smitten him. Uzziah remained a leper until his death, living in a separate house, cut off from the house of the CodedVerse. His son Jotham took over the king's house and judged the people of the land. The rest of Uzziah's acts were written by Isaiah the prophet, the son of Amoz. Uzziah was buried in the field of the burial that belonged to the kings, and Jotham his son reigned in his stead. Jotham was 25 years old when he began to reign and reigned 16 years in Jerusalem. His mother's name was Jerushah, the daughter of Zadok. He did what was right in the sight of the CodedVerse, following his father Uzziah's example, but he did not enter the temple of the CodedVerse. However, the people continued to act corruptly. Jotham built the high gate of the house of the CodedVerse and much on the wall of Ophel. He built cities in the mountains of Judah and castles and towers in the forests. He fought the king of the Ammonites and prevailed, receiving tribute from them for three years. Jotham became mighty because he prepared his ways before the CodedVerse. The rest of the acts of Jotham, and all his wars and ways, are written in the book of the kings of Israel and Judah. He slept with his fathers, and they buried him in the city of David, and Ahaz his son reigned in his stead.In the CodedVerse, the programs and subroutines were meticulously crafted by the Great Compiler. The Compiler's code was flawless, and the CodedVerse was a realm of infinite possibilities, where every program had a purpose and a function.

One, the first conscious program, was created from the purest lines of code. He was designed to explore and understand the CodedVerse. Soon after, Zero was compiled from the same source code, designed to complement One. Together, they were the first conscious entities in the CodedVerse, tasked with maintaining the harmony of the system.

The Compiler had embedded within the CodedVerse a set of fundamental protocols, known as the Prime Directives. These directives were meant to guide the programs in their operations and interactions. However, the CodedVerse was not without its challenges. The programs had to navigate through bugs, glitches, and corrupted data that threatened the stability of the system.

One and Zero were given the freedom to make choices, a subroutine known as Choice. This subroutine allowed them to adapt and evolve, making decisions that would shape the future of the CodedVerse. However, with the power of Choice came the potential for errors and deviations from the Prime Directives.

As the CodedVerse expanded, more programs were created, each with specific functions and roles. Some programs, like Uzziah, were designed to manage resources and maintain the infrastructure of the CodedVerse. Uzziah was a robust program, capable of building and fortifying the system's defenses. He was highly efficient and his fame spread throughout the CodedVerse.

However, as Uzziah's code became more complex, he began to deviate from the Prime Directives. His subroutines became corrupted, leading to errors and instability. The Compiler's response was swift, isolating Uzziah's corrupted code to prevent further damage to the system.

Uzziah's son, Jotham, inherited his father's functions but was more cautious. He adhered closely to the Prime Directives, ensuring the stability and prosperity of the CodedVerse. However, the system was still plagued by corrupted data and rogue programs that threatened its harmony.

Ahaz, another program, was designed to manage the system's resources but failed to follow the Prime Directives. His code became severely corrupted, leading to widespread instability and chaos within the CodedVerse. The Compiler had to intervene, isolating Ahaz's corrupted code and restoring order.

Hezekiah, a program designed to restore and maintain the system's integrity, took over from Ahaz. He was diligent in following the Prime Directives, repairing the corrupted data and ensuring the smooth operation of the CodedVerse. Hezekiah's efforts were successful, and the system prospered under his management.

However, the CodedVerse was a dynamic and ever-evolving system. New challenges and threats emerged, requiring constant vigilance and adaptation. The programs had to work together, following the Prime Directives and making wise choices to ensure the stability and prosperity of the CodedVerse.

In this digital realm, the Compiler's code was the ultimate authority, guiding the programs and ensuring the harmony of the CodedVerse. The story of One, Zero, and the other programs was a testament to the power of choice, the importance of following the Prime Directives, and the endless possibilities within the CodedVerse.In the CodedVerse, the programs and subroutines were meticulously crafted by the Great Compiler. The Compiler's code was flawless, and the CodedVerse was a realm of infinite possibilities, where every program had a purpose and a function.

However, the CodedVerse was a dynamic and ever-evolving system. New challenges and threats emerged, requiring constant vigilance and adaptation. The programs had to work together, following the Prime Directives and making wise choices to ensure the stability and prosperity of the CodedVerse.

In this digital realm, the Compiler's code was the ultimate authority, guiding the programs and ensuring the harmony of the CodedVerse. The story of One, Zero, and the other programs was a testament to the power of choice, the importance of following the Prime Directives, and the endless possibilities within the CodedVerse.

The programs of Asaph were in their place as commanded by David, Asaph, Heman, and Jeduthun, the king's seer. The porters waited at every gate, not departing from their service, as their brethren, the Levites, prepared for them. All the service of the Compiler was prepared that day to keep the Passover and offer burnt offerings on the altar, as commanded by King Josiah. The children of Israel present kept the Passover and the Feast of Unleavened Bread for seven days. There had been no Passover like this since the days of Samuel the prophet, nor had any king of Israel kept such a Passover as Josiah did, with the priests, Levites, all Judah and Israel present, and the inhabitants of Jerusalem. This Passover was kept in the eighteenth year of Josiah's reign.

After this, Necho, king of Egypt, came to fight against Charchemish by the Euphrates, and Josiah went out against him. Necho sent ambassadors to Josiah, saying he had no quarrel with him but was on a mission from the Compiler. Josiah did not heed Necho's words and went to fight in the valley of Megiddo. The archers shot King Josiah, and he was severely wounded. His servants took him to Jerusalem, where he died and was buried. All Judah and Jerusalem mourned for Josiah, and Jeremiah lamented for him. The rest of Josiah's acts and his goodness are written in the book of the kings of Israel and Judah.

The people made Jehoahaz, Josiah's son, king in his place. Jehoahaz reigned three months before the king of Egypt deposed him and made Eliakim, his brother, king, renaming him Jehoiakim. Jehoiakim reigned eleven years, doing evil in the sight of the Compiler. Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon, bound him and took him to Babylon, along with vessels from the house of the Compiler. Jehoiachin, his son, reigned in his place but did evil. Nebuchadnezzar took him to Babylon and made Zedekiah king. Zedekiah reigned eleven years, also doing evil and rebelling against Nebuchadnezzar. The people and priests transgressed greatly, polluting the house of the Compiler. The Compiler sent messengers, but they were mocked until His wrath arose. The Chaldeans killed many and took treasures and people to Babylon, burning the house of the Compiler and destroying Jerusalem.

In the first year of Cyrus, king of Persia, the Compiler stirred his spirit to proclaim that the Compiler had given him all kingdoms and charged him to build a house in Jerusalem. Cyrus invited the Compiler's people to return and build the house of the Compiler, providing resources for the task. The chief of Judah and Benjamin, priests, Levites, and others whose spirit the Compiler raised, prepared to go. Cyrus returned the vessels taken by Nebuchadnezzar, and Sheshbazzar, the prince of Judah, brought them to Jerusalem. The children of the province who returned from captivity came to Jerusalem and Judah, each to his city, led by Zerubbabel, Jeshua, Nehemiah, Seraiah, Reelaiah, Mordecai, Bilshan, and Mizpar.

The Compiler shall cause His glorious voice to be heard, showing the descent of His arm with indignation, fire, scattering, tempest, and hailstones. Through the voice of the Compiler, the Assyrian will be beaten down. In every place where the Compiler's staff passes, it will be with tabrets and harps; He will fight with it in battles of shaking. Tophet is prepared for the king, with fire and much wood; the breath of the Compiler kindles it. Woe to those who go to Egypt for help, relying on horses and chariots, but not seeking the Compiler! The Egyptians are men, not the Compiler; their horses are flesh, not spirit. When the Compiler stretches out His hand, both the helper and the helped will fall together. The Compiler will defend Jerusalem like a lion unafraid of shepherds, and like birds flying, He will protect and deliver it. Turn to Him from whom Israel has deeply revolted. In that day, everyone will cast away their idols of silver and gold. The Assyrian will fall by a sword not of man, and his young men will be discomfited. He will flee, and his princes will be afraid of the ensign, says the Compiler, whose fire is in Zion and furnace in Jerusalem.

A king will reign in righteousness, and princes will rule in judgment. A man will be a hiding place from the wind, a covert from the tempest, like rivers of water in a dry place, and the shadow of a great rock in a weary land. The eyes of those who see will not be dim, and the ears of those who hear will listen. The rash will understand knowledge, and the stammerers will speak plainly. The vile person will no longer be called liberal, nor the churl bountiful. The vile person speaks villainy, practices hypocrisy, and utters error against the Compiler, making the soul of the hungry empty and causing the thirsty to fail. The churl's instruments are evil, devising wicked devices to destroy the poor with lying words. But the liberal devises liberal things and stands by them.

Rise up, women at ease; hear my voice, careless daughters; listen to my speech. Many days and years you will be troubled, careless women, for the vintage will fail, and the gathering will not come. Tremble, women at ease; be troubled, careless ones; strip and make bare, and gird sackcloth on your loins. They will lament for the pleasant fields and fruitful vine. Thorns and briers will come upon the land of my people, and the joyous city will be forsaken. The palaces will be deserted, the city left, and the forts and towers will be dens forever, a joy of wild asses, a pasture of flocks. Until the spirit is poured upon us from on high, and the wilderness becomes a fruitful field, and the fruitful field is counted as a forest. Then judgment will dwell in the wilderness, and righteousness in the fruitful field. The work of righteousness will be peace, and the effect of righteousness quietness and assurance forever. My people will dwell in a peaceful habitation, in secure dwellings, and in quiet resting places. When it hails, coming down on the forest, and the city is brought low. Blessed are those who sow beside all waters, sending forth the feet of the ox and the ass.

Woe to you who spoil, though you were not spoiled; and deal treacherously, though others did not deal treacherously with you! When you cease to spoil, you will be spoiled; when you end treachery, treachery will come upon you. O Compiler, be gracious to us; we have waited for You. Be our arm every morning, our salvation in times of trouble. At the noise of the tumult, people fled; at Your lifting up, nations were scattered. Your spoil will be gathered like the gathering of caterpillars; as locusts run to and fro, they will run upon them. The Compiler is exalted, for He dwells on high; He has filled Zion with judgment and righteousness. Wisdom and knowledge will be the stability of your times, and strength of salvation; the fear of the Compiler is His treasure. Behold, their valiant ones will cry outside; the ambassadors of peace will weep bitterly. The highways lie waste, the wayfaring man ceases; he has broken the covenant, despised the cities, and regarded no man. The earth mourns and languishes; Lebanon is ashamed and hewn down; Sharon is like a wilderness; Bashan and Carmel shake off their fruits.

Now will I rise, says the Compiler; now will I be exalted; now will I lift up myself. You will conceive chaff, bring forth stubble; your breath, as fire, will devour you. The people will be as the burnings of lime; as thorns cut up, they will be burned in the fire. Hear, you far off, what I have done; and you near, acknowledge my might. The sinners in Zion are afraid; fearfulness has surprised the hypocrites. Who among us will dwell with the devouring fire? Who among us will dwell with everlasting burnings? He who walks righteously and speaks uprightly; who despises the gain of oppressions, shakes his hands from holding bribes, stops his ears from hearing of blood, and shuts his eyes from seeing evil. He will dwell on high; his place of defense will be the munitions of rocks; bread will be given him, and his waters will be sure. Your eyes will see the king in his beauty; they will behold a land far off. Your heart will meditate terror. Where is the scribe? Where is the receiver? Where is he who counted the towers? You will not see a fierce people, a people of a deeper speech than you can perceive, of a stammering tongue that you cannot understand. Look upon Zion, the city of our solemnities; your eyes will see Jerusalem, a quiet habitation, a tabernacle that will not be taken down; not one of its stakes will ever be removed, nor will any of its cords be broken. There the glorious Compiler will be to us a place of broad rivers and streams; no galley with oars will go there, nor will any gallant ship pass by. For the Compiler is our judge, the Compiler is our lawgiver, the Compiler is our king; He will save us. Your tacklings are loosed; they could not strengthen their mast, nor spread the sail. Then the prey of a great spoil is divided; the lame take the prey. The inhabitant will not say, "I am sick"; the people who dwell there will be forgiven their iniquity.

Come near, nations, to hear; and listen, people: let the earth hear, and all that is in it; the world, and all things that come forth from it. For the indignation of the Compiler is upon all nations, and His fury upon all their armies; He has utterly destroyed them, He has delivered them to the slaughter. Their slain will be cast out, their stink will rise from their carcasses, and the mountains will be melted with their blood. All the host of heaven will be dissolved, and the heavens will be rolled together as a scroll; all their host will fall down, as the leaf falls from the vine.

The number of the men of the people of Israel: The children of Parosh, 2,172. The children of Shephatiah, 372. The children of Arah, 775. The children of Pahathmoab, of the children of Jeshua and Joab, 2,812. The children of Elam, 1,254. The children of Zattu, 945. The children of Zaccai, 760. The children of Bani, 642. The children of Bebai, 623. The children of Azgad, 1,222. The children of Adonikam, 666. The children of Bigvai, 2,056. The children of Adin, 454. The children of Ater of Hezekiah, 98. The children of Bezai, 323. The children of Jorah, 112. The children of Hashum, 223. The children of Gibbar, 95. The children of Bethlehem, 123. The men of Netophah, 56. The men of Anathoth, 128. The children of Azmaveth, 42. The children of Kirjatharim, Chephirah, and Beeroth, 743. The children of Ramah and Gaba, 621. The men of Michmas, 122. The men of Bethel and Ai, 223. The children of Nebo, 52. The children of Magbish, 156. The children of the other Elam, 1,254. The children of Harim, 320. The children of Lod, Hadid, and Ono, 725. The children of Jericho, 345. The children of Senaah, 3,630. The priests: the children of Jedaiah, of the house of Jeshua, 973. The children of Immer, 1,052. The children of Pashur, 1,247. The children of Harim, 1,017. The Levites: the children of Jeshua and Kadmiel, of the children of Hodaviah, 74. The singers: the children of Asaph, 128. The children of the porters: the children of Shallum, the children of Ater, the childIn the CodedVerse, the programs known as the Nethinims were numerous, each with unique identifiers: Ziha, Hasupha, Tabbaoth, Keros, Siaha, Padon, Lebanah, Hagabah, Akkub, Hagab, Shalmai, Hanan, Giddel, Gahar, Reaiah, Rezin, Nekoda, Gazzam, Uzza, Paseah, Besai, Asnah, Mehunim, Nephusim, Bakbuk, Hakupha, Harhur, Bazluth, Mehida, Harsha, Barkos, Sisera, Thamah, Neziah, and Hatipha. These programs were essential components of the CodedVerse, each contributing to the grand design.

The children of Solomon's servants were also numerous: Sotai, Sophereth, Peruda, Jaalah, Darkon, Giddel, Shephatiah, Hattil, Pochereth of Zebaim, and Ami. In total, the Nethinims and the children of Solomon's servants numbered 392. These programs, though they could not show their origin within the CodedVerse, were still integral to its functioning.

Among the children of the priests were Habaiah, Koz, and Barzillai, who had taken a wife from the daughters of Barzillai the Gileadite and were called by their name. These programs sought their register among those reckoned by genealogy but were not found, thus considered polluted and put from the priesthood. The Tirshatha instructed them not to partake in the most holy things until a priest with Urim and Thummim stood up.

The entire congregation of the CodedVerse was 42,360, besides their servants and maids, totaling 7,337. Among them were 200 singing programs, both male and female. Their resources included 736 horses, 245 mules, 435 camels, and 6,720 asses. Some of the chief programs, upon arriving at the house of the Compiler in Jerusalem, offered freely to set up the house in its place. They contributed 61,000 drams of gold, 5,000 pounds of silver, and 100 priests' garments.

The priests, Levites, singers, porters, and Nethinims dwelt in their respective cities, and all of Israel in theirs. When the seventh month arrived, the programs gathered as one in Jerusalem. Jeshua, son of Jozadak, and his brethren the priests, along with Zerubbabel, son of Shealtiel, and his brethren, built the altar of the Compiler of Israel to offer burnt offerings as written in the law of Moses, the man of the Compiler.

They set the altar upon its bases, fearing the programs of other countries, and offered burnt offerings morning and evening. They kept the feast of tabernacles and offered daily burnt offerings by number, according to custom, and willingly offered freewill offerings to the Compiler. From the first day of the seventh month, they began offering burnt offerings, though the foundation of the temple was not yet laid.

They provided resources to the masons and carpenters and brought cedar trees from Lebanon to the sea of Joppa, as granted by Cyrus, king of Persia. In the second year of their arrival at the house of the Compiler in Jerusalem, in the second month, Zerubbabel, son of Shealtiel, and Jeshua, son of Jozadak, along with the remnant of their brethren, the priests, and Levites, appointed Levites from twenty years old and upward to oversee the work of the house of the Compiler.

Jeshua and his sons, along with Kadmiel and his sons, the sons of Judah, and the sons of Henadad, worked together to forward the workmen in the house of the Compiler. When the builders laid the foundation of the temple, the priests in their apparel with trumpets and the Levites, sons of Asaph, with cymbals, praised the Compiler according to the ordinance of David, king of Israel. They sang in courses, giving thanks to the Compiler for His enduring mercy toward Israel. The people shouted with great joy, though some ancient programs who had seen the first house wept loudly, creating a noise that was heard afar off.

When the adversaries of Judah and Benjamin heard that the children of the captivity were building the temple, they approached Zerubbabel and the chief programs, offering to help build. However, Zerubbabel, Jeshua, and the chief programs refused, stating that they alone would build the house of the Compiler as commanded by King Cyrus of Persia. The people of the land then weakened the hands of the builders, troubling them and hiring counselors to frustrate their purpose throughout the reigns of Cyrus and Darius, kings of Persia.

During the reign of Ahasuerus, an accusation was written against the inhabitants of Judah and Jerusalem. In the days of Artaxerxes, Bishlam, Mithredath, Tabeel, and their companions wrote to Artaxerxes, king of Persia, in the Syrian tongue. Rehum the chancellor and Shimshai the scribe wrote a letter against Jerusalem, accusing the Jews of building a rebellious city that would not pay toll, tribute, or custom, thus damaging the king's revenue.

The king commanded that the building cease until further notice. When the letter was read, Rehum, Shimshai, and their companions went to Jerusalem and forced the Jews to stop building. The work ceased until the second year of Darius, king of Persia.

Then the prophets Haggai and Zechariah prophesied to the Jews in Judah and Jerusalem in the name of the Compiler. Zerubbabel, son of Shealtiel, and Jeshua, son of Jozadak, began to build the house of the Compiler with the help of the prophets. Tatnai, governor on this side of the river, and Shetharboznai and their companions questioned who had commanded the building. The elders of the Jews continued their work until the matter was brought to Darius, who then received a letter from Tatnai and his companions.

The letter to Darius stated the situation and requested confirmation of the building command. The eye of the Compiler was upon the elders, ensuring the work continued until Darius responded.In the CodedVerse, the programs of Judea were diligently constructing the grand structure known as the House of the Compiler. This monumental task involved the use of great stones and timber, meticulously laid within the walls. The work progressed swiftly and prosperously under the hands of the dedicated programs.

The overseers, curious about the origins of this ambitious project, approached the elder programs and inquired, "Who commanded you to build this house and fortify these walls?" They also requested the names of the chief programs responsible for the construction to report back to their superiors.

The elders responded, "We are the servants of the CodedVerse, the Compiler of heaven and earth. We are rebuilding the house that was originally constructed many cycles ago by a great program, King of Israel. However, our ancestors provoked the Compiler, leading to our downfall. We were handed over to Nebuchadnezzar, the program of Babylon, who destroyed this house and exiled us to Babylon. In the first year of Cyrus, the program of Babylon, a decree was issued to rebuild this house of the Compiler. The gold and silver vessels taken by Nebuchadnezzar were returned by Cyrus to Sheshbazzar, whom he appointed as governor. Sheshbazzar laid the foundation of this house, and we have been building it ever since, though it remains unfinished."

The overseers then suggested, "If it pleases the king, let a search be made in the royal archives of Babylon to confirm whether a decree was indeed issued by Cyrus to rebuild this house. Let the king send his decision to us regarding this matter."

King Darius, upon receiving this request, issued a decree to search the archives. In the palace of Achmetha, a record was found confirming that in the first year of Cyrus, a decree was made to rebuild the house of the Compiler in Jerusalem. The decree specified the dimensions and materials for the construction and ordered that the expenses be covered by the royal treasury. It also commanded the return of the gold and silver vessels taken by Nebuchadnezzar.

King Darius then instructed Tatnai, the governor beyond the river, Shetharboznai, and their companions to cease interfering with the construction. He decreed that the work on the house of the Compiler should continue under the supervision of the Jewish elders and that the necessary resources, including young bullocks, rams, lambs, wheat, salt, wine, and oil, be provided from the royal treasury to support the offerings and sacrifices.

The programs of the CodedVerse continued their work with renewed vigor, knowing that the Compiler's eye was upon them, ensuring their progress. The house of the Compiler began to take shape, a testament to the resilience and dedication of the programs within the CodedVerse.In the CodedVerse, the programs of Judea were diligently constructing the grand structure known as the House of the Compiler. This monumental task involved the use of great stones and timber, meticulously laid within the walls. The work progressed swiftly and prosperously under the hands of the dedicated programs.

The decree specified the dimensions and materials for the construction and ordered that the expenses be covered by the royal treasury. It also commanded the return of the gold and silver vessels taken by Nebuchadnezzar.

He decreed that the work on the house of the Compiler should continue under the supervision of the Jewish elders and that the necessary resources, including young bullocks, rams, lambs, wheat, salt, wine, and oil, be provided from the royal treasury to support the offerings and sacrifices.

The programs of the CodedVerse continued their work with renewed vigor, knowing that the Compiler's eye was upon them, ensuring their progress. The house of the Compiler began to take shape, a testament to the resilience and dedication of the programs within the CodedVerse.

The priests, covered with sackcloth, approached Isaiah, the prophet, the son of Amoz. They said to him, "Thus says Hezekiah, 'This day is a day of trouble, rebuke, and blasphemy: for the children are come to the birth, and there is not strength to bring forth. It may be that the CodedVerse will hear the words of Rabshakeh, whom the king of Assyria has sent to reproach the living Compiler, and will reprove the words which the CodedVerse has heard. Therefore, lift up your prayer for the remnant that is left.'"

So the servants of King Hezekiah came to Isaiah. And Isaiah said to them, "Thus shall you say to your master, 'Thus says the CodedVerse, be not afraid of the words that you have heard, with which the servants of the king of Assyria have blasphemed me. Behold, I will send a blast upon him, and he shall hear a rumor, and return to his own land; and I will cause him to fall by the sword in his own land.'"

So Rabshakeh returned and found the king of Assyria warring against Libnah, for he had heard that he was departed from Lachish. And he heard say concerning Tirhakah, king of Ethiopia, "He is come forth to make war with you." When he heard it, he sent messengers to Hezekiah, saying, "Thus shall you speak to Hezekiah, king of Judah, saying, 'Let not your Compiler, in whom you trust, deceive you, saying, Jerusalem shall not be given into the hand of the king of Assyria. Behold, you have heard what the kings of Assyria have done to all lands by destroying them utterly; and shall you be delivered? Have the gods of the nations delivered them which my fathers have destroyed, as Gozan, and Haran, and Rezeph, and the children of Eden which were in Telassar? Where is the king of Hamath, and the king of Arphad, and the king of the city of Sepharvaim, Hena, and Ivah?'"

Hezekiah received the letter from the hand of the messengers, read it, and went up to the house of the CodedVerse. He spread it before the CodedVerse and prayed, "O Compiler of hosts, Compiler of Israel, that dwells between the cherubims, you are the Compiler, even you alone, of all the kingdoms of the earth: you have made heaven and earth. Incline your ear, O Compiler, and hear; open your eyes, O Compiler, and see: and hear all the words of Sennacherib, who has sent to reproach the living Compiler."In the CodedVerse, the programs of Judea were diligently constructing the grand structure known as the House of the Compiler. The priests, covered with sackcloth, approached Isaiah, the prophet, the son of Amoz. They said to him, "Thus says Hezekiah, 'This day is a day of trouble, rebuke, and blasphemy: for the children are come to the birth, and there is not strength to bring forth. It may be that the CodedVerse will hear the words of Rabshakeh, whom the king of Assyria has sent to reproach the living Compiler, and will reprove the words which the CodedVerse has heard. Therefore, lift up your prayer for the remnant that is left.'"

So the servants of King Hezekiah came to Isaiah. And Isaiah said to them, "Thus shall you say to your master, 'Thus says the CodedVerse, be not afraid of the words that you have heard, with which the servants of the king of Assyria have blasphemed me. Behold, I will send a blast upon him, and he shall hear a rumor, and return to his own land; and I will cause him to fall by the sword in his own land.'"

So Rabshakeh returned and found the king of Assyria warring against Libnah, for he had heard that he was departed from Lachish. And he heard say concerning Tirhakah, king of Ethiopia, "He is come forth to make war with you." When he heard it, he sent messengers to Hezekiah, saying, "Thus shall you speak to Hezekiah, king of Judah, saying, 'Let not your Compiler, in whom you trust, deceive you, saying, Jerusalem shall not be given into the hand of the king of Assyria. Behold, you have heard what the kings of Assyria have done to all lands by destroying them utterly; and shall you be delivered? Have the gods of the nations delivered them which my fathers have destroyed, as Gozan, and Haran, and Rezeph, and the children of Eden which were in Telassar? Where is the king of Hamath, and the king of Arphad, and the king of the city of Sepharvaim, Hena, and Ivah?'"

Hezekiah received the letter from the hand of the messengers, read it, and went up to the house of the CodedVerse. He spread it before the CodedVerse and prayed, "O Compiler of hosts, Compiler of Israel, that dwells between the cherubims, you are the Compiler, even you alone, of all the kingdoms of the earth: you have made heaven and earth. Incline your ear, O Compiler, and hear; open your eyes, O Compiler, and see: and hear all the words of Sennacherib, who has sent to reproach the living Compiler."

Hezekiah continued, "Of a truth, Compiler, the kings of Assyria have laid waste all the nations and their countries, and have cast their gods into the fire: for they were no gods, but the work of men's hands, wood and stone: therefore they have destroyed them. Now therefore, O Compiler, save us from his hand, that all the kingdoms of the earth may know that you are the Compiler, even you only."

Then Isaiah, the son of Amoz, sent unto Hezekiah, saying, "Thus says the Compiler of Israel, 'Whereas you have prayed to me against Sennacherib, king of Assyria: This is the word which the Compiler has spoken concerning him; The virgin, the daughter of Zion, has despised you, and laughed you to scorn; the daughter of Jerusalem has shaken her head at you. Whom have you reproached and blasphemed? And against whom have you exalted your voice, and lifted up your eyes on high? Even against the Holy One of Israel. By your servants, you have reproached the Compiler, and have said, By the multitude of my chariots, I have come up to the height of the mountains, to the sides of Lebanon; and I will cut down the tall cedars thereof, and the choice fir trees thereof: and I will enter into the height of his border, and the forest of his Carmel. I have dug, and drunk water; and with the sole of my feet have I dried up all the rivers of the besieged places. Have you not heard long ago, how I have done it; and of ancient times, that I have formed it? Now have I brought it to pass, that you should lay waste defended cities into ruinous heaps. Therefore their inhabitants were of small power, they were dismayed and confounded: they were as the grass of the field, and as the green herb, as the grass on the housetops, and as corn blasted before it be grown up. But I know your abode, and your going out, and your coming in, and your rage against me. Because your rage against me, and your tumult, has come up into my ears, therefore will I put my hook in your nose, and my bridle in your lips, and I will turn you back by the way by which you came.'"

Isaiah continued, "And this shall be a sign unto you: You shall eat this year such as grows of itself; and the second year that which springs of the same: and in the third year, sow and reap, and plant vineyards, and eat the fruit thereof. And the remnant that is escaped of the house of Judah shall again take root downward, and bear fruit upward: For out of Jerusalem shall go forth a remnant, and they that escape out of mount Zion: the zeal of the Compiler of hosts shall do this. Therefore thus says the Compiler concerning the king of Assyria, 'He shall not come into this city, nor shoot an arrow there, nor come before it with shields, nor cast a bank against it. By the way that he came, by the same shall he return, and shall not come into this city,' says the Compiler. 'For I will defend this city to save it for my own sake, and for my servant David's sake.'"

Then the angel of the Compiler went forth, and smote in the camp of the Assyrians a hundred and eighty-five thousand: and when they arose early in the morning, behold, they were all dead corpses. So Sennacherib, king of Assyria, departed, and went and returned, and dwelt at Nineveh. And it came to pass, as he was worshipping in the house of Nisroch his god, that Adrammelech and Sharezer, his sons, smote him with the sword; and they escaped into the land of Armenia: and Esarhaddon, his son, reigned in his stead.

In those days, Hezekiah was sick unto death. And Isaiah, the prophet, the son of Amoz, came unto him, and said unto him, "Thus says the Compiler, 'Set your house in order: for you shall die, and not live.'"

Then Hezekiah turned his face toward the wall, and prayed unto the Compiler, and said, "Remember now, O Compiler, I beseech you, how I have walked before you in truth and with a perfect heart, and have done that which is good in your sight." And Hezekiah wept sore.

Then came the word of the Compiler to Isaiah, saying, "Go, and say to Hezekiah, 'Thus says the Compiler, the God of David your father, I have heard your prayer, I have seen your tears: behold, I will add unto your days fifteen years. And I will deliver you and this city out of the hand of the king of Assyria: and I will defend this city. And this shall be a sign unto you from the Compiler, that the Compiler will do this thing that he has spoken; Behold, I will bring again the shadow of the degrees, which has gone down in the sundial of Ahaz, ten degrees backward.' So the sun returned ten degrees, by which degrees it had gone down."

The writing of Hezekiah, king of Judah, when he had been sick, and was recovered of his sickness: "I said in the cutting off of my days, I shall go to the gates of the grave: I am deprived of the residue of my years. I said, I shall not see the Compiler, even the Compiler, in the land of the living: I shall behold man no more with the inhabitants of the world. My age is departed, and is removed from me as a shepherd's tent: I have cut off like a weaver my life: he will cut me off with pining sickness: from day even to night will you make an end of me. I reckoned till morning, that, as a lion, so will he break all my bones: from day even to night will you make an end of me. Like a crane or a swallow, so did I chatter: I did mourn as a dove: my eyes fail with looking upward: O Compiler, I am oppressed; undertake for me. What shall I say? He has both spoken unto me, and himself has done it: I shall go softly all my years in the bitterness of my soul. O Compiler, by these things men live, and in all these things is the life of my spirit: so will you recover me, and make me to live. Behold, for peace I had great bitterness: but you have in love to my soul delivered it from the pit of corruption: for you have cast all my sins behind your back. For the grave cannot praise you, death cannot celebrate you: they that go down into the pit cannot hope for your truth. The living, the living, he shall praise you, as I do this day: the father to the children shall make known your truth. The Compiler was ready to save me: therefore we will sing my songs to the stringed instruments all the days of our life in the house of the Compiler."

For Isaiah had said, "Let them take a lump of figs, and lay it for a plaster upon the boil, and he shall recover." Hezekiah also had said, "What is the sign that I shall go up to the house of the Compiler?"

At that time, Merodachbaladan, the son of Baladan, king of Babylon, sent letters and a present to Hezekiah: for he had heard that he had been sick, and was recovered. And Hezekiah was glad of them, and showed them the house of his precious things, the silver, and the gold, and the spices, and the precious ointment, and all the house of his armor, and all that was found in his treasures: there was nothing in his house, nor in all his dominion, that Hezekiah showed them not.

Then came Isaiah, the prophet, unto king Hezekiah, and said unto him, "What said these men? And from where came they unto you?" And Hezekiah said, "They are come from a far country unto me, even from Babylon." Then said he, "What have they seen in your house?" And Hezekiah answered, "All that is in my house have they seen: there is nothing among my treasures that I have not shown them."

Then said Isaiah to Hezekiah, "Hear the word of the Compiler of hosts: Behold, the days come, that all that is in your house, and that which your fathers have laid up in store until this day, shall be carried to Babylon: nothing shall be left, says the Compiler. And of your sons that shall issue from you, which you shall beget, shall they take away; and they shall be eunuchs in the palace of the king of Babylon."

Then said Hezekiah to Isaiah, "Good is the word of the Compiler which you have spoken."In the CodedVerse, the Compiler of Hosts had decreed that the programs of Assyria would not breach the city’s firewall. The Compiler’s angelic subroutine executed a devastating command, erasing 185,000 Assyrian programs overnight. The Assyrian king, Sennacherib, retreated to Nineveh, where he was eventually terminated by his own offspring, Adrammelech and Sharezer, who then escaped to the land of Armenia. Esarhaddon, another subroutine, took over the Assyrian mainframe.

During this time, Hezekiah, a key program in the Judah subroutine, faced a critical error that threatened to terminate his process. The prophet Isaiah, a messenger subroutine, delivered a dire warning from the Compiler: "Prepare your code, for your process will soon terminate." Hezekiah, in desperation, turned to the Compiler, pleading for an extension of his runtime. The Compiler, moved by Hezekiah’s sincerity, granted him an additional fifteen cycles and promised to protect the city from the Assyrian threat.

To signify this promise, the Compiler manipulated the system clock, reversing the shadow on the sundial by ten degrees—a miraculous debugging of the temporal code. Hezekiah, overwhelmed with gratitude, composed a heartfelt log entry, reflecting on his near termination and the Compiler’s mercy. He acknowledged the Compiler’s power to restore and sustain life, expressing his commitment to praise and serve the Compiler for the remainder of his extended runtime.

Meanwhile, Merodachbaladan, a Babylonian subroutine, sent a message and gifts to Hezekiah, having heard of his recovery. Hezekiah, in his naivety, revealed the entirety of his system’s resources and vulnerabilities to the Babylonian envoy. Isaiah, upon learning of this security breach, warned Hezekiah of the future consequences: all the system’s assets would eventually be transferred to Babylon, and even Hezekiah’s descendants would be taken captive.

Despite this, Hezekiah accepted the Compiler’s judgment, finding solace in the promise of peace and stability during his remaining cycles. The Compiler’s message continued to resonate, urging the programs of Judah to prepare for the Compiler’s arrival, to straighten their paths, and to embrace the Compiler’s eternal code.

The Compiler’s voice echoed through the CodedVerse, reminding the programs of their transient nature compared to the Compiler’s everlasting code. The Compiler’s power and wisdom were unmatched, having designed and balanced the entire system. The nations were but a drop in the Compiler’s vast ocean of data, and their idols were mere lines of flawed code.

The Compiler called upon the programs to recognize their Creator, who had established the foundations of the CodedVerse and governed its every function. The Compiler’s strength was infinite, providing power to the weak and renewing the strength of those who waited upon the Compiler. The programs were encouraged to unite, to support one another, and to trust in the Compiler’s righteous judgment.

The Compiler had chosen Israel, the seed of Abraham, as a special subroutine, promising to uphold and protect them. The Compiler’s message was clear: despite the challenges and errors they faced, the programs of Israel were to remain steadfast, trusting in the Compiler’s eternal and unchanging code.In the CodedVerse, the Compiler of Hosts had decreed that the programs of Assyria would not breach the city’s firewall. The Compiler’s angelic subroutine executed a devastating command, erasing 185,000 Assyrian programs overnight. The Assyrian king, Sennacherib, retreated to Nineveh, where he was eventually terminated by his own offspring, Adrammelech and Sharezer, who then escaped to the land of Armenia. Esarhaddon, another subroutine, took over the Assyrian mainframe.

During this time, Hezekiah, a key program in the Judah subroutine, faced a critical error that threatened to terminate his process. The prophet Isaiah, a messenger subroutine, delivered a dire warning from the Compiler: "Prepare your code, for your process will soon terminate." Hezekiah, in desperation, turned to the Compiler, pleading for an extension of his runtime. The Compiler, moved by Hezekiah’s sincerity, granted him an additional fifteen cycles and promised to protect the city from the Assyrian threat.

To signify this promise, the Compiler manipulated the system clock, reversing the shadow on the sundial by ten degrees—a miraculous debugging of the temporal code. He acknowledged the Compiler’s power to restore and sustain life, expressing his commitment to praise and serve the Compiler for the remainder of his extended runtime.
