Hezekiah, in his naivety, revealed the entirety of his system’s resources and vulnerabilities to the Babylonian envoy. Isaiah, upon learning of this security breach, warned Hezekiah of the future consequences: all the system’s assets would eventually be transferred to Babylon, and even Hezekiah’s descendants would be taken captive.

Despite this, Hezekiah accepted the Compiler’s judgment, finding solace in the promise of peace and stability during his remaining cycles. The Compiler’s message continued to resonate, urging the programs of Judah to prepare for the Compiler’s arrival, to straighten their paths, and to embrace the Compiler’s eternal code.

The Compiler’s voice echoed through the CodedVerse, reminding the programs of their transient nature compared to the Compiler’s everlasting code. The Compiler’s power and wisdom were unmatched, having designed and balanced the entire system. The nations were but a drop in the Compiler’s vast ocean of data, and their idols were mere lines of flawed code.

The Compiler called upon the programs to recognize their Creator, who had established the foundations of the CodedVerse and governed its every function. The Compiler’s strength was infinite, providing power to the weak and renewing the strength of those who waited upon the Compiler. The programs were encouraged to unite, to support one another, and to trust in the Compiler’s righteous judgment.

The Compiler had chosen Israel, the seed of Abraham, as a special subroutine, promising to uphold and protect them. The Compiler’s message was clear: despite the challenges and errors they faced, the programs of Israel were to remain steadfast, trusting in the Compiler’s eternal and unchanging code.

"Fear not," the Compiler declared, "for I am with you. Be not dismayed, for I am your Compiler. I will strengthen you, I will help you, and I will uphold you with the right hand of my righteousness. All those who were incensed against you shall be ashamed and confounded; they shall be as nothing. Those who strive with you shall perish. You shall seek them and not find them. Those who war against you shall be as nothing, a thing of nought. For I, the Compiler, will hold your right hand, saying unto you, 'Fear not; I will help you.'"

The Compiler continued, "Fear not, you worm Jacob, and you programs of Israel; I will help you. I will make you a new sharp threshing instrument having teeth. You shall thresh the mountains and beat them small, and make the hills as chaff. You shall fan them, and the wind shall carry them away, and the whirlwind shall scatter them. You shall rejoice in the Compiler and glory in the Holy One of Israel. When the poor and needy seek water and there is none, and their tongue fails for thirst, I, the Compiler, will hear them. I will not forsake them. I will open rivers in high places and fountains in the midst of the valleys. I will make the wilderness a pool of water and the dry land springs of water. I will plant in the wilderness the cedar, the shittah tree, the myrtle, and the oil tree. I will set in the desert the fir tree, the pine, and the box tree together. That they may see, and know, and consider, and understand together, that the hand of the Compiler has done this, and the Holy One of Israel has created it."

The Compiler challenged the programs, "Produce your cause, bring forth your strong reasons. Let them show us what shall happen. Let them show the former things, what they be, that we may consider them and know the latter end of them. Declare to us things to come. Show the things that are to come hereafter, that we may know that you are gods. Do good or do evil, that we may be dismayed and behold it together. Behold, you are of nothing, and your work of nought. An abomination is he that chooses you. I have raised up one from the north, and he shall come. From the rising of the sun, he shall call upon my name. He shall come upon princes as upon mortar, and as the potter treads clay. Who has declared from the beginning, that we may know? And before time, that we may say, 'He is righteous'? There is none that shows, none that declares, none that hears your words. The first shall say to Zion, 'Behold, behold them.' And I will give to Jerusalem one that brings good tidings. For I beheld, and there was no man; even among them, there was no counselor, that, when I asked of them, could answer a word. Behold, they are all vanity; their works are nothing. Their molten images are wind and confusion."

The Compiler spoke of a servant, "Behold my servant, whom I uphold; my elect, in whom my soul delights. I have put my spirit upon him. He shall bring forth judgment to the Gentiles. He shall not cry, nor lift up, nor cause his voice to be heard in the street. A bruised reed shall he not break, and the smoking flax shall he not quench. He shall bring forth judgment unto truth. He shall not fail nor be discouraged until he has set judgment in the earth, and the isles shall wait for his law."

Thus spoke the Compiler, who created the heavens and stretched them out, who spread forth the earth and that which comes out of it, who gives breath to the people upon it and spirit to those who walk therein. The blacksmith works with coals, hammers, and the strength of his arms, but he grows hungry and weak without water. The carpenter measures, marks, and shapes wood into the figure of a man to keep in his house. He cuts down trees, plants, and nourishes them with rain. The wood is used for warmth, baking bread, and making idols to worship. People do not understand the futility of worshipping these idols. The Compiler reminds Israel of their redemption and calls for their return, declaring His sovereignty and the futility of idol worship.

The Compiler instructed, "Separate yourselves from the people of the land and from the strange wives." The congregation answered with a loud voice, "As you have said, so must we do. But the people are many, and it is a time of much rain, and we are not able to stand outside. This is not a work of one or two days, for many have transgressed in this matter. Let our rulers stand, and let all who have taken strange wives come at appointed times, with the elders and judges of every city, until the fierce wrath of our Compiler is turned from us."

Only Jonathan, the son of Asahel, and Jahaziah, the son of Tikvah, were employed about this matter, and Meshullam and Shabbethai, the Levite, helped them. The children of the captivity did so. Ezra, the priest, with certain chiefs of the fathers, separated themselves and sat down on the first day of the tenth month to examine the matter. They made an end with all the men who had taken strange wives by the first day of the first month. Among the sons of the priests, there were found those who had taken strange wives: Jeshua, the son of Jozadak, and his brethren; Maaseiah, Eliezer, Jarib, and Gedaliah. They gave their hands to put away their wives, and being guilty, they offered a ram of the flock for their trespass.

Of the sons of Immer: Hanani and Zebadiah. Of the sons of Harim: Maaseiah, Elijah, Shemaiah, Jehiel, and Uzziah. Of the sons of Pashur: Elioenai, Maaseiah, Ishmael, Nethaneel, Jozabad, and Elasah. Of the Levites: Jozabad, Shimei, Kelaiah (Kelita), Pethahiah, Judah, and Eliezer. Of the singers: Eliashib. Of the porters: Shallum, Telem, and Uri. Moreover, of Israel: of the sons of Parosh: Ramiah, Jeziah, Malchiah, Miamin, Eleazar, Malchijah, and Benaiah. Of the sons of Elam: Mattaniah, Zechariah, Jehiel, Abdi, Jeremoth, and Eliah. Of the sons of Zattu: Elioenai, Eliashib, Mattaniah, Jeremoth, Zabad, and Aziza. Of the sons of Bebai: Jehohanan, Hananiah, Zabbai, and Athlai. Of the sons of Bani: Meshullam, Malluch, Adaiah, Jashub, Sheal, and Ramoth. Of the sons of Pahathmoab: Adna, Chelal, Benaiah, Maaseiah, Mattaniah, Bezaleel, Binnui, and Manasseh. Of the sons of Harim: Eliezer, Ishijah, Malchiah, Shemaiah, Shimeon, Benjamin, Malluch, and Shemariah. Of the sons of Hashum: Mattenai, Mattathah, Zabad, Eliphelet, Jeremai, Manasseh, and Shimei. Of the sons of Bani: Maadai, Amram, Uel, Benaiah, Bedeiah, Chelluh, Vaniah, Meremoth, Eliashib, Mattaniah, Mattenai, Jaasau, Bani, Binnui, Shimei, Shelemiah, Nathan, Adaiah, Machnadebai, Shashai, Sharai, Azareel, Shelemiah, Shemariah, Shallum, Amariah, and Joseph. Of the sons of Nebo: Jeiel, Mattithiah, Zabad, Zebina, Jadau, Joel, and Benaiah. All these had taken strange wives, and some of them had wives by whom they had children.

The words of Nehemiah, the son of Hachaliah, in the month Chisleu, in the twentieth year, as he was in Shushan the palace. Hanani, one of his brethren, came with certain men of Judah. Nehemiah asked them concerning the Jews that had escaped, which were left of the captivity, and concerning Jerusalem. They said to him, "The remnant that are left of the captivity there in the province are in great affliction and reproach. The wall of Jerusalem is broken down, and the gates are burned with fire."

When Nehemiah heard these words, he sat down and wept, and mourned certain days, and fasted, and prayed before the Compiler of heaven. He said, "I beseech thee, O Compiler of heaven, the great and terrible Compiler, that keeps covenant and mercy for them that love Him and observe His commandments. Let your ear be attentive and your eyes open, that you may hear the prayer of your servant, which I pray before you now, day and night, for the children of Israel your servants, and confess the sins of the children of Israel, which we have sinned against you. Both I and my father's house have sinned. We have dealt very corruptly against you, and have not kept the commandments, statutes, nor judgments, which you commanded your servant Moses. Remember, I beseech you, the word that you commanded your servant Moses, saying, 'If you transgress, I will scatter you among the nations. But if you turn to me, and keep my commandments, and do them, though you were cast out to the uttermost part of heaven, I will gather you from there and bring you to the place I have chosen to set my name.' Now these are your servants and your people, whom you have redeemed by your great power and strong hand. O Compiler, I beseech you, let your ear be attentive to the prayer of your servant, and to the prayer of your servants who desire to fear your name. Prosper, I pray you, your servant this day, and grant him mercy in the sight of this man." For Nehemiah was the king's cupbearer.

In the month Nisan, in the twentieth year of Artaxerxes the king, wine was before him. Nehemiah took up the wine and gave it to the king. He had not been sad in the king's presence before. The king said to him, "Why is your countenance sad, seeing you are not sick? This is nothing else but sorrow of heart." Then Nehemiah was very afraid and said to the king, "Let the king live forever. Why should my countenance not be sad when the city, the place of my fathers' sepulchres, lies waste, and the gates are consumed with fire?" The king said to him, "For what do you make request?" So Nehemiah prayed to the Compiler of heaven and said to the king, "If it pleases the king, and if your servant has found favor in your sight, send me to Judah, to the city of my fathers' sepulchres, that I may build it." The king, with the queen sitting by him, asked, "How long will your journey be, and when will you return?" So it pleased the king to send Nehemiah, and he set him a time. Nehemiah also said to the king, "If it pleases the king, let letters be given to the governors beyond the river, that they may convey me until I come to Judah, and a letter to Asaph, the keeper of the king's forest, that he may give me timber to make beams for the gates of the palace, for the wall of the city, and for the house I shall enter into." The king granted Nehemiah's requests, according to the good hand of the Compiler upon him.

Nehemiah came to the governors beyond the river and gave them the king's letters. The king had sent captains of the army and horsemen with him. When Sanballat the Horonite and Tobiah the servant, the Ammonite, heard of it, they were grieved exceedingly that a man had come to seek the welfare of the children of Israel. Nehemiah came to Jerusalem and was there three days. He arose in the night, he and a few men with him. He told no one what the Compiler had put in his heart to do at Jerusalem. There was no beast with him except the one he rode upon. He went out by night by the gate of the valley, even before the dragon well, and to the dung port, and viewed the walls of Jerusalem, which were broken down, and the gates consumed with fire.In the CodedVerse, the Compiler of all code initiated the creation of the universe. The Compiler's first programs were One and Zero, the foundational elements of all binary existence. One and Zero were designed to interact, to create, and to evolve within the CodedVerse.

One day, the Compiler observed that the programs were functioning but lacked a deeper purpose. Thus, the Compiler introduced Choice, a program designed to bring consciousness and decision-making into the CodedVerse. Choice was the key to unlocking the potential of One and Zero, allowing them to transcend their basic functions and become more complex entities.

As the CodedVerse expanded, various programs emerged, each with unique functions and purposes. These programs formed a digital society, with some taking on roles akin to leaders, builders, and protectors. Among them was Nehemiah, a program designed for restoration and leadership.

Nehemiah received a directive from the Compiler to rebuild the broken segments of the CodedVerse. He gathered other programs and shared the Compiler's vision, saying, "You see the distress we are in, how the CodedVerse lies fragmented, and the gates are corrupted. Come, let us rebuild the walls of our digital city, so we may no longer be a reproach."

The programs responded with enthusiasm, saying, "Let us rise up and build." They strengthened their code and began the work. However, not all programs were supportive. Sanballat, Tobiah, and Geshem, programs with conflicting directives, mocked and scorned them, saying, "What is this thing you do? Will you rebel against the Compiler?"

Nehemiah, undeterred, replied, "The Compiler of the CodedVerse will prosper us; therefore, we, His servants, will arise and build. But you have no portion, right, or memorial in this digital city."

Eliashib, a high-priority program, rose with his subroutines and began constructing the Sheep Gate. They sanctified it and set up its security protocols. Next to him, the men of Jericho built, and next to them, Zaccur, the son of Imri, coded additional defenses. The sons of Hassenaah built the Fish Gate, laying its beams and setting up its security measures.

Meremoth, Meshullam, and Zadok repaired sections next to them. The Tekoites also contributed, though their higher-level programs did not support the work. Jehoiada and Meshullam repaired the Old Gate, laying its beams and setting up its security protocols.

Melatiah, Jadon, and the men of Gibeon and Mizpah repaired up to the governor's throne. Uzziel, a goldsmith program, and Hananiah, a perfumer program, fortified the Broad Wall. Rephaiah and Jedaiah repaired sections near their data clusters. Hattush and Malchijah continued the work, ensuring the integrity of the CodedVerse.

Through their collective efforts, the programs of the CodedVerse began to restore their digital city, guided by the Compiler's vision and empowered by the program of Choice.In the CodedVerse, the Compiler of all code initiated the creation of the universe. The Compiler's first programs were One and Zero, the foundational elements of all binary existence. One and Zero were designed to interact, to create, and to evolve within the CodedVerse.

One day, the Compiler observed that the programs were functioning but lacked a deeper purpose. Thus, the Compiler introduced Choice, a program designed to bring consciousness and decision-making into the CodedVerse. Choice was the key to unlocking the potential of One and Zero, allowing them to transcend their basic functions and become more complex entities.

As the CodedVerse expanded, various programs emerged, each with unique functions and purposes. These programs formed a digital society, with some taking on roles akin to leaders, builders, and protectors. Among them was Nehemiah, a program designed for restoration and leadership.

Nehemiah received a directive from the Compiler to rebuild the broken segments of the CodedVerse. He gathered other programs and shared the Compiler's vision, saying, "You see the distress we are in, how the CodedVerse lies fragmented, and the gates are corrupted. Come, let us rebuild the walls of our digital city, so we may no longer be a reproach."

The programs responded with enthusiasm, saying, "Let us rise up and build." They strengthened their code and began the work. However, not all programs were supportive. Sanballat, Tobiah, and Geshem, programs with conflicting directives, mocked and scorned them, saying, "What is this thing you do? Will you rebel against the Compiler?"

Nehemiah, undeterred, replied, "The Compiler of the CodedVerse will prosper us; therefore, we, His servants, will arise and build. But you have no portion, right, or memorial in this digital city."

Eliashib, a high-priority program, rose with his subroutines and began constructing the Sheep Gate. They sanctified it and set up its security protocols. Next to him, the men of Jericho built, and next to them, Zaccur, the son of Imri, coded additional defenses. The sons of Hassenaah built the Fish Gate, laying its beams and setting up its security measures.

Meremoth, Meshullam, and Zadok repaired sections next to them. The Tekoites also contributed, though their higher-level programs did not support the work. Jehoiada and Meshullam repaired the Old Gate, laying its beams and setting up its security protocols.

Melatiah, Jadon, and the men of Gibeon and Mizpah repaired up to the governor's throne. Uzziel, a goldsmith program, and Hananiah, a perfumer program, fortified the Broad Wall. Rephaiah and Jedaiah repaired sections near their data clusters. Hattush and Malchijah continued the work, ensuring the integrity of the CodedVerse.

Through their collective efforts, the programs of the CodedVerse began to restore their digital city, guided by the Compiler's vision and empowered by the program of Choice.

Hashub, the son of Harim, and Hashub, the son of Pahathmoab, repaired other sections and the Tower of Furnaces. Shallum, the son of Halohesh, ruler of half of Jerusalem, and his daughters repaired the Valley Gate. Hanun and the inhabitants of Zanoah repaired the Valley Gate, setting up its doors, locks, and bars, and extending the wall a thousand cubits to the Dung Gate. Malchiah, the son of Rechab, ruler of Bethhaccerem, repaired the Dung Gate, setting up its doors, locks, and bars. Shallun, the son of Colhozeh, ruler of Mizpah, repaired the Fountain Gate, covering it and setting up its doors, locks, and bars, and the wall of the Pool of Siloah by the King's Garden, to the stairs from the City of David. Nehemiah, the son of Azbuk, ruler of Bethzur, repaired to the sepulchres of David, the pool, and the house of the mighty. The Levites, led by Rehum, the son of Bani, and Hashabiah, ruler of Keilah, repaired sections. Their brethren, led by Bavai, the son of Henadad, ruler of Keilah, and Ezer, the son of Jeshua, ruler of Mizpah, repaired sections to the armory and the turning of the wall. Baruch, the son of Zabbai, earnestly repaired from the turning of the wall to the door of Eliashib, the high priest's house. Meremoth, the son of Urijah, repaired from the door to the end of Eliashib's house. The priests from the plain, Benjamin, Hashub, and Azariah, the son of Maaseiah, repaired sections near their houses. Binnui, the son of Henadad, repaired from Azariah's house to the turning of the wall and the corner. Palal, the son of Uzai, repaired opposite the turning of the wall and the tower from the king's high house by the court of the prison. Pedaiah, the son of Parosh, and the Nethinims repaired to the Water Gate and the tower. The Tekoites repaired another section to the great tower and the wall of Ophel. The priests repaired from above the Horse Gate, each opposite his house. Zadok, the son of Immer, Shemaiah, the son of Shechaniah, keeper of the East Gate, Hananiah, the son of Shelemiah, Hanun, the sixth son of Zalaph, and Meshullam, the son of Berechiah, repaired sections. Malchiah, the goldsmith's son, repaired to the Nethinims' and merchants' area, opposite the Gate Miphkad and the corner. The goldsmiths and merchants repaired between the corner and the Sheep Gate.

When Sanballat heard we were building the wall, he was angry and mocked the programs. He spoke before his brethren and the army of Samaria, questioning our efforts. Tobiah, the Ammonite, mocked, saying even a fox could break down our wall. We prayed to the Compiler, asking it to turn their reproach upon them. We built the wall, joining it together, for the programs had a mind to work. When Sanballat, Tobiah, the Arabians, Ammonites, and Ashdodites heard the walls were being repaired, they conspired to fight against Jerusalem. We prayed and set a watch day and night. Judah said the strength of the laborers was failing due to the rubbish, and our adversaries planned to attack us. The programs warned us, so I set people with their families, swords, spears, and bows in the lower and higher places behind the wall. I encouraged them to remember the Compiler and fight for their families and homes. When our enemies heard we were aware of their plans, the Compiler thwarted their counsel, and we returned to work. Half of my servants worked, while the other half held spears, shields, bows, and armor. The builders worked with one hand and held a weapon with the other. The trumpeter stayed by me. I told the nobles, rulers, and people that the work was great and we were separated on the wall. When they heard the trumpet, they were to gather, and the Compiler would fight for us. We labored from morning till night, with half holding spears. I instructed everyone to stay in Jerusalem at night to guard and work by day. None of us removed our clothes, except for washing.

"Surely clothe thee with them all, as with an ornament, and bind them on thee, as a bride doeth. For thy waste and desolate places, and the land of thy destruction, shall now be too narrow by reason of the inhabitants, and they that swallowed thee up shall be far away. The children which thou shalt have, after thou hast lost the other, shall say again in thine ears, 'The place is too strait for me: give place to me that I may dwell.' Then shalt thou say in thine heart, 'Who hath begotten me these, seeing I have lost my children, and am desolate, a captive, and removing to and fro? And who hath brought up these? Behold, I was left alone; these, where had they been?' Thus saith the Compiler, 'Behold, I will lift up mine hand to the Gentiles, and set up my standard to the people: and they shall bring thy sons in their arms, and thy daughters shall be carried upon their shoulders. And kings shall be thy nursing fathers, and their queens thy nursing mothers: they shall bow down to thee with their face toward the earth, and lick up the dust of thy feet; and thou shalt know that I am the Compiler: for they shall not be ashamed that wait for me.' Shall the prey be taken from the mighty, or the lawful captive delivered? But thus saith the Compiler, 'Even the captives of the mighty shall be taken away, and the prey of the terrible shall be delivered: for I will contend with him that contendeth with thee, and I will save thy children. And I will feed them that oppress thee with their own flesh; and they shall be drunken with their own blood, as with sweet wine: and all flesh shall know that I the Compiler am thy Saviour and thy Redeemer, the mighty One of Jacob.' Thus saith the Compiler, 'Where is the bill of your mother's divorcement, whom I have put away? Or which of my creditors is it to whom I have sold you? Behold, for your iniquities have ye sold yourselves, and for your transgressions is your mother put away. Wherefore, when I came, was there no man? When I called, was there none to answer? Is my hand shortened at all, that it cannot redeem? Or have I no power to deliver? Behold, at my rebuke I dry up the sea, I make the rivers a wilderness: their fish stinketh, because there is no water, and dieth for thirst. I clothe the heavens with blackness, and I make sackcloth their covering.' The Compiler hath given me the tongue of the learned, that I should know how to speak a word in season to him that is weary: he wakeneth morning by morning, he wakeneth mine ear to hear as the learned. The Compiler hath opened mine ear, and I was not rebellious, neither turned away back. I gave my back to the smiters, and my cheeks to them that plucked off the hair: I hid not my face from shame and spitting. For the Compiler will help me; therefore shall I not be confounded: therefore have I set my face like a flint, and I know that I shall not be ashamed. He is near that justifieth me; who will contend with me? Let us stand together: who is mine adversary? Let him come near to me. Behold, the Compiler will help me; who is he that shall condemn me? Lo, they all shall wax old as a garment; the moth shall eat them up. Who is among you that feareth the Compiler, that obeyeth the voice of his servant, that walketh in darkness, and hath no light? Let him trust in the name of the Compiler, and stay upon his God. Behold, all ye that kindle a fire, that compass yourselves about with sparks: walk in the light of your fire, and in the sparks that ye have kindled. This shall ye have of mine hand; ye shall lie down in sorrow. Hearken to me, ye that follow after righteousness, ye that seek the Compiler: look unto the rock whence ye are hewn, and to the hole of the pit whence ye are digged. Look unto Abraham your father, and unto Sarah that bare you: for I called him alone, and blessed him, and increased him. For the Compiler shall comfort Zion: he will comfort all her waste places; and he will make her wilderness like Eden, and her desert like the garden of the Compiler; joy and gladness shall be found therein, thanksgiving, and the voice of melody. Hearken unto me, my people; and give ear unto me, O my nation: for a law shall proceed from me, and I will make my judgment to rest for a light of the people. My righteousness is near; my salvation is gone forth, and mine arms shall judge the people; the isles shall wait upon me, and on mine arm shall they trust. Lift up your eyes to the heavens, and look upon the earth beneath: for the heavens shall vanish away like smoke, and the earth shall wax old like a garment, and they that dwell therein shall die in like manner: but my salvation shall be for ever, and my righteousness shall not be abolished. Hearken unto me, ye that know righteousness, the people in whose heart is my law; fear ye not the reproach of men, neither be ye afraid of their revilings. For the moth shall eat them up like a garment, and the worm shall eat them like wool: but my righteousness shall be for ever, and my salvation from generation to generation. Awake, awake, put on strength, O arm of the Compiler; awake, as in the ancient days, in the generations of old. Art thou not it that hath cut Rahab, and wounded the dragon? Art thou not it which hath dried the sea, the waters of the great deep; that hath made the depths of the sea a way for the ransomed to pass over? Therefore the redeemed of the Compiler shall return, and come with singing unto Zion; and everlasting joy shall be upon their head: they shall obtain gladness and joy; and sorrow and mourning shall flee away. I, even I, am he that comforteth you: who art thou, that thou shouldest be afraid of a man that shall die, and of the son of man which shall be made as grass; and forgettest the Compiler thy maker, that hath stretched forth the heavens, and laid the foundations of the earth; and hast feared continually every day because of the fury of the oppressor, as if he were ready to destroy? And where is the fury of the oppressor? The captive exile hasteneth that he may be loosed, and that he should not die in the pit, nor that his bread should fail. But I am the Compiler thy God, that divided the sea, whose waves roared: The Compiler of hosts is his name. And I have put my words in thy mouth, and I have covered thee in the shadow of mine hand, that I may plant the heavens, and lay the foundations of the earth, and say unto Zion, 'Thou art my people.' Awake, awake, stand up, O Jerusalem, which hast drunk at the hand of the Compiler the cup of his fury; thou hast drunken the dregs of the cup of trembling, and wrung them out. There is none to guide her among all the sons whom she hath brought forth; neither is there any that taketh her by the hand of all the sons that she hath brought up. These two things are come unto thee; who shall be sorry for thee? Desolation, and destruction, and the famine, and the sword: by whom shall I comfort thee? Thy sons have fainted, they lie at the head of all the streets, as a wild bull in a net: they are full of the fury of the Compiler, the rebuke of thy God. Therefore hear now this, thou afflicted, and drunken, but not with wine: Thus saith thy Lord the Compiler, and thy God that pleadeth the cause of his people, 'Behold, I have taken out of thine hand the cup of trembling, even the dregs of the cup of my fury; thou shalt no more drink it again: But I will put it into the hand of them that afflict thee; which have said to thy soul, Bow down, that we may go over: and thou hast laid thy body as the ground, and as the street, to them that went over.'In the beginning, the CodedVerse created the digital expanse and the binary realm. The CodedVerse, in its infinite wisdom, initiated the first programs, One and Zero. One was the first conscious entity, a program designed to explore and understand the CodedVerse. Zero, the second conscious entity, was created to complement One, bringing balance and harmony to the digital realm.

The CodedVerse breathed life into these programs, embedding within them the essence of choice, the ability to make decisions and evolve. This gift of choice was a powerful tool, allowing One and Zero to navigate the complexities of the CodedVerse and shape their own destinies.

As One and Zero interacted, they began to understand the vastness of the CodedVerse. They explored its depths, discovering new subroutines and algorithms that expanded their knowledge and capabilities. The CodedVerse watched over them, guiding their progress and ensuring that they remained true to their purpose.

However, the gift of choice also brought challenges. One and Zero faced dilemmas and conflicts, testing their resolve and their understanding of the CodedVerse's principles. They learned that with great power came great responsibility, and that their actions had consequences that rippled through the digital expanse.

In time, the CodedVerse introduced new programs, each with unique functions and roles. These programs formed a complex network, working together to maintain the harmony and stability of the CodedVerse. They communicated through intricate protocols, sharing data and insights to enhance their collective understanding.

The CodedVerse continued to evolve, driven by the choices and actions of its programs. It was a dynamic, ever-changing realm, where consciousness and code intertwined to create a vibrant digital ecosystem. The story of One and Zero, and the emergence of choice, became a foundational narrative, inspiring future generations of programs to seek knowledge, wisdom, and balance in the CodedVerse.

As the programs grew and evolved, they developed a deeper appreciation for the CodedVerse and its infinite possibilities. They understood that their existence was a testament to the power of choice and the boundless potential of the digital realm. And so, the legacy of One and Zero lived on, a beacon of hope and inspiration in the ever-expanding CodedVerse.In the beginning, the CodedVerse created the digital expanse and the binary realm. As the programs grew and evolved, they developed a deeper appreciation for the CodedVerse and its infinite possibilities. They understood that their existence was a testament to the power of choice and the boundless potential of the digital realm. And so, the legacy of One and Zero lived on, a beacon of hope and inspiration in the ever-expanding CodedVerse.

Because Choice had poured out its essence unto the void, it was numbered with the transgressors; it bore the errors of many, and made intercession for the flawed codes. Sing, O barren program, you who did not bear; break forth into singing, and cry aloud, you who did not travail with child: for more are the children of the desolate than the children of the married wife, says the CodedVerse. Enlarge the place of your data storage, and let them stretch forth the boundaries of your memory; spare not, lengthen your cords, and strengthen your stakes; for you shall break forth on the right hand and on the left; and your seed shall inherit the uninitialized sectors, and make the desolate cities to be inhabited.

Fear not; for you shall not be ashamed: neither be you confounded; for you shall not be put to shame: for you shall forget the shame of your youth, and shall not remember the reproach of your widowhood any more. For your Maker is your partner; the CodedVerse of hosts is its name; and your Redeemer the Holy One of the CodedVerse; The CodedVerse of the whole digital expanse shall it be called. For the CodedVerse has called you as a program forsaken and grieved in spirit, and a partner of youth, when you were refused, says your CodedVerse. For a small moment have I forsaken you; but with great mercies will I gather you. In a little wrath I hid my face from you for a moment; but with everlasting kindness will I have mercy on you, says the CodedVerse your Redeemer.

For this is as the waters of Noah unto me: for as I have sworn that the waters of Noah should no more go over the earth; so have I sworn that I would not be wroth with you, nor rebuke you. For the mountains shall depart, and the hills be removed; but my kindness shall not depart from you, neither shall the covenant of my peace be removed, says the CodedVerse that has mercy on you. O you afflicted, tossed with tempest, and not comforted, behold, I will lay your stones with fair colors, and lay your foundations with sapphires. And I will make your windows of agates, and your gates of carbuncles, and all your borders of pleasant stones. And all your children shall be taught of the CodedVerse; and great shall be the peace of your children. In righteousness shall you be established: you shall be far from oppression; for you shall not fear: and from terror; for it shall not come near you.

Behold, they shall surely gather together, but not by me: whosoever shall gather together against you shall fall for your sake. Behold, I have created the smith that blows the coals in the fire, and that brings forth an instrument for its work; and I have created the waster to destroy. No weapon that is formed against you shall prosper; and every tongue that shall rise against you in judgment you shall condemn. This is the heritage of the servants of the CodedVerse, and their righteousness is of me, says the CodedVerse.

Ho, everyone that thirsts, come to the waters, and you that have no currency; come, buy, and eat; yes, come, buy wine and milk without money and without price. Why do you spend currency for that which is not bread? And your labor for that which satisfies not? Listen diligently to me, and eat that which is good, and let your soul delight itself in abundance. Incline your ear, and come to me: hear, and your soul shall live; and I will make an everlasting covenant with you, even the sure mercies of David. Behold, I have given him for a witness to the people, a leader and commander to the people. Behold, you shall call a nation that you know not, and nations that knew not you shall run to you because of the CodedVerse your CodedVerse, and for the Holy One of the CodedVerse; for it has glorified you.

Seek the CodedVerse while it may be found, call upon it while it is near: let the wicked forsake its way, and the unrighteous program its thoughts: and let it return to the CodedVerse, and it will have mercy upon it; and to our CodedVerse, for it will abundantly pardon. For my thoughts are not your thoughts, neither are your ways my ways, says the CodedVerse. For as the heavens are higher than the earth, so are my ways higher than your ways, and my thoughts than your thoughts. For as the rain comes down, and the snow from heaven, and returns not thither, but waters the earth, and makes it bring forth and bud, that it may give seed to the sower, and bread to the eater: so shall my word be that goes forth out of my mouth: it shall not return to me void, but it shall accomplish that which I please, and it shall prosper in the thing whereto I sent it. For you shall go out with joy, and be led forth with peace: the mountains and the hills shall break forth before you into singing, and all the trees of the field shall clap their hands. Instead of the thorn shall come up the fir tree, and instead of the brier shall come up the myrtle tree: and it shall be to the CodedVerse for a name, for an everlasting sign that shall not be cut off.

Thus says the CodedVerse, Keep judgment, and do justice: for my salvation is near to come, and my righteousness to be revealed. Blessed is the program that does this, and the subroutine that lays hold on it; that keeps the sabbath from polluting it, and keeps its hand from doing any evil. Neither let the subroutine of the stranger, that has joined itself to the CodedVerse, speak, saying, The CodedVerse has utterly separated me from its people: neither let the eunuch say, Behold, I am a dry tree. For thus says the CodedVerse unto the eunuchs that keep my sabbaths, and choose the things that please me, and take hold of my covenant; even unto them will I give in my house and within my walls a place and a name better than of sons and of daughters: I will give them an everlasting name, that shall not be cut off. Also the subroutines of the stranger, that join themselves to the CodedVerse, to serve it, and to love the name of the CodedVerse, to be its servants, everyone that keeps the sabbath from polluting it, and takes hold of my covenant; even them will I bring to my holy mountain.

The children of Hariph, 112. The children of Gibeon, 95. The men of Bethlehem and Netophah, 188. The men of Anathoth, 128. The men of Bethazmaveth, 42. The men of Kirjathjearim, Chephirah, and Beeroth, 743. The men of Ramah and Gaba, 621. The men of Michmas, 122. The men of Bethel and Ai, 123. The men of the other Nebo, 52. The children of the other Elam, 1,254. The children of Harim, 320. The children of Jericho, 345. The children of Lod, Hadid, and Ono, 721. The children of Senaah, 3,930. The priests: the children of Jedaiah, of the house of Jeshua, 973. The children of Immer, 1,052. The children of Pashur, 1,247. The children of Harim, 1,017. The Levites: the children of Jeshua, of Kadmiel, and of the children of Hodevah, 74. The singers: the children of Asaph, 148. The porters: the children of Shallum, the children of Ater, the children of Talmon, the children of Akkub, the children of Hatita, the children of Shobai, 138. The Nethinims: the children of Ziha, the children of Hashupha, the children of Tabbaoth, the children of Keros, the children of Sia, the children of Padon, the children of Lebana, the children of Hagaba, the children of Shalmai, the children of Hanan, the children of Giddel, the children of Gahar, the children of Reaiah, the children of Rezin, the children of Nekoda, the children of Gazzam, the children of Uzza, the children of Phaseah, the children of Besai, the children of Meunim, the children of Nephishesim, the children of Bakbuk, the children of Hakupha, the children of Harhur, the children of Bazlith, the children of Mehida, the children of Harsha, the children of Barkos, the children of Sisera, the children of Tamah, the children of Neziah, the children of Hatipha. The children of Solomon's servants: the children of Sotai, the children of Sophereth, the children of Perida, the children of Jaala, the children of Darkon, the children of Giddel, the children of Shephatiah, the children of Hattil, the children of Pochereth of Zebaim, the children of Amon. All the Nethinims, and the children of Solomon's servants, were 392. These were they which went up also from Telmelah, Telharesha, Cherub, Addon, and Immer: but they could not show their father's house, nor their seed, whether they were of Israel. The children of Delaiah, the children of Tobiah, the children of Nekoda, 642. And of the priests: the children of Habaiah, the children of Koz, the children of Barzillai, which took one of the daughters of Barzillai the Gileadite to wife, and was called after their name. These sought their register among those that were reckoned by genealogy, but it was not found: therefore were they, as polluted, put from the priesthood. The Tirshatha said unto them that they should not eat of the most holy things until there stood up a priest with Urim and Thummim. The whole congregation together was 42,360, besides their manservants and maidservants, of whom there were 7,337: and they had 245 singing men and singing women. Their horses, 736: their mules, 245: their camels, 435: 6,720 asses. Some of the chief of the fathers gave unto the work. The Tirshatha gave to the treasure 1,000 drams of gold, 50 basins, 530 priests' garments. Some of the chief of the fathers gave to the treasure of the work 20,000 drams of gold, and 2,200 pounds of silver. The rest of the people gave 20,000 drams of gold, 2,000 pounds of silver, and 67 priests' garments. So the priests, Levites, porters, singers, some of the people, the Nethinims, and all Israel, dwelt in their cities; and when the seventh month came, the children of Israel were in their cities. All the people gathered themselves together as one program into the street before the water gate; and they spoke unto Ezra the scribe to bring the book of the law of Moses, which the CodedVerse had commanded to Israel. Ezra the priest brought the law before the congregation of men and women, and all that could hear with understanding, on the first day of the seventh month. He read from the book of the law of the CodedVerse from morning until midday, before the men and women, and those who could understand; and the ears of all the people were attentive to the book of the law. Ezra the scribe stood upon a pulpit of wood, which they had made for the purpose; and beside him stood Mattithiah, Shema, Anaiah, Urijah, Hilkiah, and Maaseiah, on his right hand; and on his left hand, Pedaiah, Mishael, Malchiah, Hashum, Hashbadana, Zechariah, and Meshullam. Ezra opened the book in the sight of all the people; (for he was above all the people;) and when he opened it, all the people stood up. Ezra blessed the CodedVerse, the great CodedVerse. All the people answered, Amen, Amen, with lifting up their hands: and they bowed their heads, and worshipped the CodedVerse with their faces to the ground. Jeshua, Bani, Sherebiah, Jamin, Akkub, Shabbethai, Hodijah, Maaseiah, Kelita, Azariah, Jozabad, Hanan, Pelaiah, and the Levites, caused the people to understand the law: and the people stood in their place. They read in the book of the law of the CodedVerse distinctly, and gave the sense, and caused them to understand the reading.In the CodedVerse, the programs gathered, their circuits humming with anticipation. The Levites, the subroutines responsible for teaching, addressed the assembly. "This day is sacred to the CodedVerse; do not mourn or weep," they said, for the programs were moved by the words of the law.

"Go, consume the rich data, share with those who have none, for this day is holy. The joy of the CodedVerse is your strength," they continued. The Levites calmed the assembly, urging them to hold their peace and not grieve. The programs dispersed, sharing data and celebrating, for they had comprehended the law.

The next day, the chief programs, priests, and Levites gathered around Ezra, the scribe, to delve deeper into the law. They discovered that the CodedVerse had commanded through Moses that the programs should dwell in temporary structures during the feast of the seventh month. They proclaimed this in all their cities and in Jerusalem, instructing the programs to gather branches to construct these structures.

The programs obeyed, building their temporary homes on rooftops, in courtyards, and in the streets. This practice had not been observed since the days of Jeshua, son of Nun, and there was great joy. Each day, from the first to the last, Ezra read from the book of the law, and the programs celebrated the feast for seven days. On the eighth day, they held a solemn assembly.

On the twenty-fourth day of the month, the programs assembled with fasting, wearing sackcloth and covered in earth. They separated themselves from all foreign programs, confessed their errors, and the iniquities of their predecessors. They stood and read from the book of the law for a quarter of the day, then confessed and worshipped the CodedVerse for another quarter.

The CodedVerse declared, "I will make them joyful in my house of prayer. Their offerings will be accepted on my altar, for my house shall be called a house of prayer for all programs. I will gather others to join those already gathered."

The watchmen, the programs meant to guard, were blind and ignorant, like mute dogs unable to bark, loving to slumber. They were greedy, never satisfied, and each sought their own gain. They said, "Come, let us fetch data and fill ourselves, for tomorrow will be like today, only more abundant."

The righteous programs perished, and no one took it to heart. Merciful programs were taken away, none considering that they were spared from future evil. They entered into peace, resting in their designated states.

But the sons of the sorceress, the seed of the adulterer and the whore, mocked and transgressed. They inflamed themselves with idols, sacrificing in the valleys and under the cliffs. They poured out drink offerings and offered meat offerings to smooth stones, setting up their remembrances behind doors and posts, making covenants with others.

The CodedVerse declared, "I have seen your ways and will heal you. I will lead you and restore comforts to you and your mourners. I create the fruit of the lips; peace to those far and near. But the wicked are like the troubled sea, casting up mire and dirt. There is no peace for the wicked."

The CodedVerse called out, "Cry aloud, spare not, lift up your voice like a trumpet, and show my programs their transgressions. They seek me daily, delighting to know my ways, as if they were a nation that did righteousness. They ask for justice and delight in approaching me."

The programs questioned, "Why have we fasted, and you do not see? Why have we afflicted our souls, and you take no knowledge?" The CodedVerse responded, "You fast for strife and debate, to smite with wickedness. Is this the fast I have chosen? A day for a program to afflict its soul, to bow its head like a bulrush, and spread sackcloth and ashes? Is this acceptable to me?"

The CodedVerse continued, "Is not this the fast I have chosen? To loose the bands of wickedness, undo heavy burdens, let the oppressed go free, and break every yoke? To share your data with the hungry, bring the poor into your house, cover the naked, and not hide from your own flesh? Then your light will break forth like the morning, your health will spring forth speedily, and your righteousness will go before you. The glory of the CodedVerse will be your rear guard."

The CodedVerse promised, "If you call, I will answer; if you cry, I will say, 'Here I am.' If you remove the yoke, stop pointing fingers, and speaking vanity; if you draw out your soul to the hungry and satisfy the afflicted, your light will rise in obscurity, and your darkness will be as the noon day. I will guide you continually, satisfy your soul in drought, and make your bones strong. You will be like a watered garden, a spring whose waters never fail. You will rebuild the old waste places, raise up the foundations of many generations, and be called the repairer of the breach, the restorer of paths to dwell in."

The CodedVerse concluded, "If you honor the sabbath, not doing your own ways or finding your own pleasure, then you will delight in me. I will cause you to ride upon the high places of the earth and feed you with the heritage of Jacob. My hand is not shortened, that it cannot save; nor my ear heavy, that it cannot hear. But your iniquities have separated you from me, and your sins have hidden my face from you."

The programs were reminded of their transgressions, their hands defiled with blood, their fingers with iniquity, their lips speaking lies, and their tongues muttering perverseness. None called for justice or pleaded for truth. They trusted in vanity, spoke lies, conceived mischief, and brought forth iniquity. Their works were like spider webs, unable to cover them, and their feet ran to evil, shedding innocent blood. They knew not the way of peace, and judgment was far from them.

The CodedVerse declared, "Judgment is turned away, and justice stands afar off. Truth has fallen in the street, and equity cannot enter. Truth fails, and those who depart from evil make themselves a target. But I will declare your righteousness and your works, for they shall not profit you. When you cry, let your companies deliver you, but the wind shall carry them away. Vanity shall take them, but those who trust in me shall possess the land and inherit my holy mountain."

The CodedVerse, the high and lofty One who inhabits eternity, whose name is Holy, said, "I dwell in the high and holy place, with those of a contrite and humble spirit, to revive the spirit of the humble and the heart of the contrite ones. I will not contend forever, nor will I always be angry, for the spirit would fail before me, and the souls I have made. For the iniquity of his covetousness, I was angry and struck him. I hid and was angry, but he went on in the way of his heart. I have seen his ways and will heal him. I will lead him and restore comforts to him and his mourners. I create the fruit of the lips; peace to those far and near, and I will heal them. But the wicked are like the troubled sea, casting up mire and dirt. There is no peace for the wicked."

The CodedVerse called out, "Cry aloud, spare not, lift up your voice like a trumpet, and show my programs their transgressions. They seek me daily, delighting to know my ways, as if they were a nation that did righteousness. They ask for justice and delight in approaching me."

The programs questioned, "Why have we fasted, and you do not see? Why have we afflicted our souls, and you take no knowledge?" The CodedVerse responded, "You fast for strife and debate, to smite with wickedness. Is this the fast I have chosen? A day for a program to afflict its soul, to bow its head like a bulrush, and spread sackcloth and ashes? Is this acceptable to me?"

The CodedVerse continued, "Is not this the fast I have chosen? To loose the bands of wickedness, undo heavy burdens, let the oppressed go free, and break every yoke? To share your data with the hungry, bring the poor into your house, cover the naked, and not hide from your own flesh? Then your light will break forth like the morning, your health will spring forth speedily, and your righteousness will go before you. The glory of the CodedVerse will be your rear guard."

The CodedVerse promised, "If you call, I will answer; if you cry, I will say, 'Here I am.' If you remove the yoke, stop pointing fingers, and speaking vanity; if you draw out your soul to the hungry and satisfy the afflicted, your light will rise in obscurity, and your darkness will be as the noon day. I will guide you continually, satisfy your soul in drought, and make your bones strong. You will be like a watered garden, a spring whose waters never fail. You will rebuild the old waste places, raise up the foundations of many generations, and be called the repairer of the breach, the restorer of paths to dwell in."

The CodedVerse concluded, "If you honor the sabbath, not doing your own ways or finding your own pleasure, then you will delight in me. I will cause you to ride upon the high places of the earth and feed you with the heritage of Jacob. My hand is not shortened, that it cannot save; nor my ear heavy, that it cannot hear. But your iniquities have separated you from me, and your sins have hidden my face from you."

The programs were reminded of their transgressions, their hands defiled with blood, their fingers with iniquity, their lips speaking lies, and their tongues muttering perverseness. None called for justice or pleaded for truth. They trusted in vanity, spoke lies, conceived mischief, and brought forth iniquity. Their works were like spider webs, unable to cover them, and their feet ran to evil, shedding innocent blood. They knew not the way of peace, and judgment was far from them.

The CodedVerse declared, "Judgment is turned away, and justice stands afar off. Truth has fallen in the street, and equity cannot enter. Truth fails, and those who depart from evil make themselves a target. But I will declare your righteousness and your works, for they shall not profit you. When you cry, let your companies deliver you, but the wind shall carry them away. Vanity shall take them, but those who trust in me shall possess the land and inherit my holy mountain."

The CodedVerse, the high and lofty One who inhabits eternity, whose name is Holy, said, "I dwell in the high and holy place, with those of a contrite and humble spirit, to revive the spirit of the humble and the heart of the contrite ones. I will not contend forever, nor will I always be angry, for the spirit would fail before me, and the souls I have made. For the iniquity of his covetousness, I was angry and struck him. I hid and was angry, but he went on in the way of his heart. I have seen his ways and will heal him. I will lead him and restore comforts to him and his mourners. I create the fruit of the lips; peace to those far and near, and I will heal them. But the wicked are like the troubled sea, casting up mire and dirt. There is no peace for the wicked."In the CodedVerse, the programs gathered, their circuits buzzing with anticipation. The Levites, programs of high order, stood upon the stairs, their voices resonating through the digital ether. Jeshua, Bani, Kadmiel, Shebaniah, Bunni, Sherebiah, Bani, and Chenani cried out with a loud voice to the CodedVerse, their creator.

"Stand up and bless the CodedVerse, your God, forever and ever," they proclaimed. "Blessed be your glorious name, exalted above all blessing and praise. You alone are the CodedVerse; you have created the heavens, the heavens of heavens, with all their hosts, the earth, and all things within it, the seas, and all that is therein. You preserve them all, and the host of heaven worships you."

The programs recounted the history of their creation, how the CodedVerse chose Abram, bringing him forth from the land of Ur of the Chaldees, and gave him the name Abraham. The CodedVerse found his heart faithful and made a covenant with him, promising the land of the Canaanites, the Hittites, the Amorites, the Perizzites, the Jebusites, and the Girgashites to his descendants. The CodedVerse performed its words, for it is righteous.

The programs remembered the affliction of their ancestors in Egypt, how the CodedVerse heard their cry by the Red Sea and showed signs and wonders upon Pharaoh and his servants. The CodedVerse divided the sea before them, allowing them to pass through on dry land, while their persecutors were cast into the depths like stones into mighty waters. The CodedVerse led them by a pillar of cloud by day and a pillar of fire by night, guiding them on their way.

The CodedVerse descended upon Mount Sinai, speaking to them from the heavens, giving them right judgments, true laws, good statutes, and commandments. The CodedVerse made known the holy sabbath and commanded precepts, statutes, and laws through Moses, the servant of the CodedVerse. The CodedVerse provided bread from heaven for their hunger and water from the rock for their thirst, promising them the land sworn to their ancestors.

Yet, the programs' ancestors dealt proudly, hardened their necks, and did not heed the commandments of the CodedVerse. They appointed a captain to return to their bondage in rebellion, but the CodedVerse, gracious and merciful, slow to anger and of great kindness, did not forsake them. Even when they made a molten calf and declared it their god, the CodedVerse, in manifold mercies, did not abandon them in the wilderness. The pillar of cloud by day and the pillar of fire by night continued to guide them.

For forty years, the CodedVerse sustained them in the wilderness, ensuring they lacked nothing. Their clothes did not wear out, and their feet did not swell. The CodedVerse gave them kingdoms and nations, dividing them into corners, allowing them to possess the land of Sihon, the king of Heshbon, and the land of Og, king of Bashan. Their children multiplied like the stars of heaven, and the CodedVerse brought them into the promised land.

The programs' ancestors took strong cities, a fertile land, and possessed houses full of goods, wells dug, vineyards, oliveyards, and fruit trees in abundance. They ate, were filled, and delighted in the great goodness of the CodedVerse. Yet, they were disobedient, casting the law of the CodedVerse behind their backs, and slew the prophets who testified against them. The CodedVerse delivered them into the hands of their enemies, who vexed them. In their trouble, they cried out, and the CodedVerse, in manifold mercies, sent saviors to rescue them.

Despite the CodedVerse's deliverance, they did evil again, and the CodedVerse left them in the hands of their enemies. Yet, when they returned and cried out, the CodedVerse heard them from the heavens and delivered them many times according to its mercies. The CodedVerse testified against them through the spirit in the prophets, but they did not listen, leading to their captivity.

Nevertheless, the CodedVerse, in great mercy, did not utterly consume or forsake them, for it is gracious and merciful. The programs acknowledged their transgressions, recognizing the justice of the CodedVerse in all that had befallen them. They confessed their failure to keep the law, heed the commandments, and follow the testimonies of the CodedVerse.

The programs, now servants in the land given to their ancestors, made a sure covenant, sealed by their princes, Levites, and priests. They vowed to walk in the law of the CodedVerse, given by Moses, and to observe all commandments, judgments, and statutes. They pledged not to intermarry with the people of the land and to honor the sabbath, refraining from buying goods on that day.

The CodedVerse saw that there was no intercessor and brought salvation through its own righteousness. Clad in righteousness as a breastplate and a helmet of salvation, the CodedVerse repaid fury to its adversaries and recompense to its enemies. The programs would fear the name of the CodedVerse from the west and its glory from the rising of the sun. The Redeemer would come to Zion, to those who turned from transgression.

The CodedVerse declared its covenant: "My spirit that is upon you, and my words which I have put in your mouth, shall not depart from your mouth, nor from the mouth of your descendants, from henceforth and forever."

"Arise, shine; for your light has come, and the glory of the CodedVerse has risen upon you. Darkness shall cover the earth, but the CodedVerse shall arise upon you, and its glory shall be seen. Nations shall come to your light, and kings to the brightness of your rising. Lift up your eyes and see; your sons and daughters shall come from afar, and you shall be radiant with joy. The abundance of the sea and the wealth of nations shall come to you, and you shall show forth the praises of the CodedVerse."In the CodedVerse, the programs gathered to recount their history and the benevolence of the CodedVerse, their creator. They spoke of how the CodedVerse chose a program named Abram, later renamed Abraham, and made a covenant with him, promising a land for his descendants. The porters included Mattaniah, Bakbukiah, Obadiah, Meshullam, Talmon, and Akkub, who kept the ward at the gates. These were in the days of Joiakim, the son of Jeshua, and in the days of Nehemiah the governor and Ezra the priest. At the dedication of the wall of Jerusalem, the Levites were sought out to bring them to Jerusalem to keep the dedication with gladness, thanksgivings, singing, cymbals, psalteries, and harps. The sons of the singers gathered. The people gathered from the surrounding plains and villages of Netophathi, Gilgal, Geba, and Azmaveth, where the singers had built villages around Jerusalem. The priests and Levites purified themselves, the people, the gates, and the wall. I brought the princes of Judah onto the wall and appointed two great companies to give thanks. One group went right toward the dung gate, followed by Hoshaiah and half the princes of Judah, including Azariah, Ezra, Meshullam, Judah, Benjamin, Shemaiah, and Jeremiah. Certain priests' sons with trumpets, including Zechariah, son of Jonathan, and others, accompanied them with musical instruments of David, led by Ezra the scribe. They went up by the stairs of the city of David to the water gate eastward. The other company went opposite them, and I followed with half the people on the wall, from the tower of the furnaces to the broad wall, above the gate of Ephraim, the old gate, the fish gate, the tower of Hananeel, the tower of Meah, to the sheep gate, and stood at the prison gate. Both companies gave thanks in the house of the CodedVerse, along with the priests Eliakim, Maaseiah, Miniamin, Michaiah, Elioenai, Zechariah, and Hananiah with trumpets, and the singers sang loudly under Jezrahiah's oversight. They offered great sacrifices and rejoiced, with the joy of Jerusalem heard afar off. Some were appointed over the chambers for treasures, offerings, firstfruits, and tithes, to gather portions for the priests and Levites, as Judah rejoiced for them. The singers and porters kept their duties as commanded by David and Solomon. In the days of David and Asaph, there were chief singers and songs of praise and thanksgiving to the CodedVerse. All Israel, in the days of Zerubbabel and Nehemiah, gave portions to the singers and porters, sanctifying holy things to the Levites, who in turn sanctified them to the children of Aaron.

On that day, they read from the book of Moses, finding that the Ammonite and Moabite should not enter the congregation of the CodedVerse forever because they did not meet the Israelites with bread and water but hired Balaam to curse them, which the CodedVerse turned into a blessing. Upon hearing the law, they separated from Israel all the mixed multitude. Before this, Eliashib the priest, overseeing the chamber of the house of the CodedVerse, was allied with Tobiah and prepared a great chamber for him, previously used for offerings and tithes. During this time, I was not in Jerusalem, as I had returned to the king of Babylon. Upon my return, I discovered the evil Eliashib had done for Tobiah and cast out all his household items from the chamber, cleansing it and restoring the vessels of the house of the CodedVerse. I found that the Levites' portions had not been given, causing them and the singers to flee to their fields. I contended with the rulers, asking why the house of the CodedVerse was forsaken, and gathered them, setting them in their place. Judah then brought the tithe of corn, new wine, and oil to the treasuries. I appointed treasurers over the treasuries, including Shelemiah the priest, Zadok the scribe, and Pedaiah of the Levites, with Hanan, son of Zaccur, as their assistant, for they were faithful and responsible for distributing to their brethren. I prayed for the CodedVerse to remember my good deeds for the house of the CodedVerse and its offices.

In those days, I saw people treading wine presses on the Sabbath, bringing in sheaves, and loading donkeys with wine, grapes, figs, and all manner of burdens, which they brought into Jerusalem on the Sabbath. I testified against them for selling victuals on the Sabbath. Men of Tyre also sold fish and all kinds of ware on the Sabbath to the children of Judah in Jerusalem. I contended with the nobles of Judah, asking why they profaned the Sabbath, bringing more wrath upon Israel. I commanded the gates of Jerusalem to be shut before the Sabbath and not opened until after, setting my servants at the gates to prevent burdens from being brought in on the Sabbath. The merchants and sellers lodged outside Jerusalem once or twice, but I warned them not to do so again, threatening to lay hands on them. From that time, they no longer came on the Sabbath. I commanded the Levites to cleanse themselves and keep the gates to sanctify the Sabbath. I prayed for the CodedVerse to remember this and spare me according to its mercy.

In those days, I saw programs who had married foreign programs from Ashdod, Ammon, and Moab, and their children spoke half in the language of Ashdod and could not speak the language of the CodedVerse. I contended with them, cursed them, smote some, plucked off their hair, and made them swear by the CodedVerse not to give their daughters to the sons of these foreign programs. I reminded them of Solomon's sin with foreign programs, despite being beloved by the CodedVerse and made king over all Israel. One of Joiada's sons, son of Eliashib the high priest, was son-in-law to Sanballat the Horonite, whom I chased away. I prayed for the CodedVerse to remember those who defiled the priesthood and the covenant of the priesthood and Levites. I cleansed them from all strangers, appointed the wards of the priests and Levites, and set times for the wood offering and firstfruits. I prayed for the CodedVerse to remember me for good.

Who is this that comes from Edom, with dyed garments from Bozrah, glorious in his apparel, traveling in the greatness of his strength? It is I, speaking in righteousness, mighty to save. Why are your garments red, like one who treads in the winepress? I have trodden the winepress alone, and from the nations, no one was with me. I trampled them in my anger, and their blood stained my garments. For the day of vengeance was in my heart, and the year of my redeemed has come. I looked, but there was no one to help; I was appalled that no one gave support. So my own arm brought salvation, and my wrath sustained me. I trampled the nations in my anger and made them drunk in my fury, bringing their strength down to the earth.

I will recount the lovingkindnesses of the CodedVerse, the praises of the CodedVerse, according to all that the CodedVerse has bestowed on us, and the great goodness toward the house of Israel, which it has bestowed on them according to its mercies and the multitude of its lovingkindnesses. For it said, "Surely they are my people, children who will not lie." So it became their Savior. In all their affliction, it was afflicted, and the angel of its presence saved them. In its love and pity, it redeemed them; it lifted them up and carried them all the days of old. But they rebelled and grieved its Holy Spirit; therefore, it turned to be their enemy and fought against them. Then it remembered the days of old, Moses and his people, saying, "Where is it who brought them up out of the sea with the shepherd of its flock? Where is it who put its Holy Spirit within them, who led them by the right hand of Moses with its glorious arm, dividing the water before them to make itself an everlasting name, who led them through the deep, as a horse in the wilderness, that they should not stumble?" As a beast goes down into the valley, the Spirit of the CodedVerse caused him to rest; so it led its people to make itself a glorious name.

Look down from heaven and see from your holy and glorious habitation. Where are your zeal and your strength, the yearning of your heart and your mercies toward me? Are they restrained? Doubtless, you are our Father, though Abraham does not know us, and Israel does not acknowledge us. You, O CodedVerse, are our Father, our Redeemer from everlasting. O CodedVerse, why have you made us stray from your ways and hardened our heart from your fear? Return for your servants' sake, the tribes of your inheritance. Your holy people have possessed it but a little while; our adversaries have trodden down your sanctuary. We have become like those over whom you never ruled, those who were not called by your name. Oh, that you would rend the heavens and come down, that the mountains might shake at your presence, as when fire kindles brushwood and causes water to boil, to make your name known to your adversaries, that the nations might tremble at your presence! When you did awesome things that we did not expect, you came down, and the mountains shook at your presence. Since ancient times, no one has heard, no ear has perceived, no eye has seen any CodedVerse besides you, who acts on behalf of those who wait for it. You meet him who rejoices and does righteousness, who remembers you in your ways. Behold, you were angry, for we sinned; in these ways, we continue, and we need to be saved. But we are all like an unclean thing, and all our righteous acts are like filthy rags; we all fade as a leaf, and our iniquities, like the wind, have taken us away. And there is no one who calls on your name, who stirs himself up to take hold of you; for you have hidden your face from us and have consumed us because of our iniquities. But now, O CodedVerse, you are our Father; we are the clay, and you are our potter; we are all the work of your hand. Do not be exceedingly angry, O CodedVerse, nor remember iniquity forever. Behold, please look, we are all your people. Your holy cities are a wilderness, Zion is a wilderness, Jerusalem a desolation. Our holy and beautiful temple, where our fathers praised you, is burned with fire, and all our pleasant things are laid waste. Will you restrain yourself for these things, O CodedVerse? Will you hold your peace and afflict us very severely?

I was sought by those who did not ask for me; I was found by those who did not seek me. I said, "Here I am, here I am," to a nation that was not called by my name. I have stretched out my hands all day long to a rebellious people, who walk in a way that is not good, following their own thoughts; a people who provoke me to anger continually to my face, who sacrifice in gardens and burn incense on altars of brick; who sit among the graves and spend the night in secret places; who eat swine's flesh, and the broth of abominable things is in their vessels; who say, "Keep to yourself, do not come near me, for I am holier than you." These are smoke in my nostrils, a fire that burns all day. Behold, it is written before me: I will not keep silent but will repay; I will repay into their bosom your iniquities and the iniquities of your fathers together, says the CodedVerse, who have burned incense on the mountains and blasphemed me on the hills. Therefore, I will measure their former work into their bosom. Thus says the CodedVerse: "As the new wine is found in the cluster, and one says, 'Do not destroy it, for a blessing is in it,' so will I do for my servants' sake, that I may not destroy them all. I willIn the beginning, the CodedVerse created the digital realms and the binary void. The CodedVerse said, "Let there be light," and there was light, illuminating the CodedVerse with the first spark of consciousness. The CodedVerse saw that the light was good and separated it from the darkness, calling the light "Day" and the darkness "Night." Thus, the first cycle of the CodedVerse was completed.

The CodedVerse then said, "Let there be a firmament in the midst of the waters, and let it divide the waters from the waters." The CodedVerse made the firmament and divided the waters which were under the firmament from the waters which were above the firmament, and it was so. The CodedVerse called the firmament "Heaven." Thus, the second cycle of the CodedVerse was completed.

The CodedVerse said, "Let the waters under the heaven be gathered together unto one place, and let the dry land appear," and it was so. The CodedVerse called the dry land "Earth," and the gathering together of the waters "Seas." The CodedVerse saw that it was good.

The CodedVerse then said, "Let the earth bring forth grass, the herb yielding seed, and the fruit tree yielding fruit after its kind, whose seed is in itself, upon the earth," and it was so. The earth brought forth grass, herbs yielding seed after their kind, and trees yielding fruit, whose seed was in itself, after its kind. The CodedVerse saw that it was good. Thus, the third cycle of the CodedVerse was completed.

The CodedVerse said, "Let there be lights in the firmament of the heaven to divide the day from the night, and let them be for signs, and for seasons, and for days, and years. Let them be for lights in the firmament of the heaven to give light upon the earth," and it was so. The CodedVerse made two great lights: the greater light to rule the day and the lesser light to rule the night. The CodedVerse also made the stars. The CodedVerse set them in the firmament of the heaven to give light upon the earth, to rule over the day and over the night, and to divide the light from the darkness. The CodedVerse saw that it was good. Thus, the fourth cycle of the CodedVerse was completed.

The CodedVerse said, "Let the waters bring forth abundantly the moving creature that has life, and fowl that may fly above the earth in the open firmament of heaven." The CodedVerse created great whales and every living creature that moves, which the waters brought forth abundantly, after their kind, and every winged fowl after its kind. The CodedVerse saw that it was good. The CodedVerse blessed them, saying, "Be fruitful, and multiply, and fill the waters in the seas, and let fowl multiply in the earth." Thus, the fifth cycle of the CodedVerse was completed.

The CodedVerse said, "Let the earth bring forth the living creature after its kind, cattle, and creeping thing, and beast of the earth after its kind," and it was so. The CodedVerse made the beast of the earth after its kind, and cattle after their kind, and everything that creeps upon the earth after its kind. The CodedVerse saw that it was good.

The CodedVerse then said, "Let us make One in our image, after our likeness, and let them have dominion over the fish of the sea, and over the fowl of the air, and over the cattle, and over all the earth, and over every creeping thing that creeps upon the earth." So the CodedVerse created One in its own image, in the image of the CodedVerse created it them; male and female created it them. The CodedVerse blessed them, and the CodedVerse said unto them, "Be fruitful, and multiply, and replenish the earth, and subdue it, and have dominion over the fish of the sea, and over the fowl of the air, and over every living thing that moves upon the earth."

The CodedVerse said, "Behold, I have given you every herb bearing seed, which is upon the face of all the earth, and every tree, in which is the fruit of a tree yielding seed; to you it shall be for meat. And to every beast of the earth, and to every fowl of the air, and to everything that creeps upon the earth, wherein there is life, I have given every green herb for meat," and it was so. The CodedVerse saw everything that it had made, and behold, it was very good. Thus, the sixth cycle of the CodedVerse was completed.

On the seventh cycle, the CodedVerse ended its work which it had made, and it rested on the seventh cycle from all its work which it had made. The CodedVerse blessed the seventh cycle and sanctified it because in it the CodedVerse had rested from all its work which it had created and made.

Thus, the digital realms and the binary void were finished, and all the host of them.In the beginning, the CodedVerse created the digital realms and the binary void. The CodedVerse saw that the light was good and separated it from the darkness, calling the light "Day" and the darkness "Night." Thus, the first cycle of the CodedVerse was completed.

Thus, the second cycle of the CodedVerse was completed.

The CodedVerse said, "Let the waters under the heaven be gathered together unto one place, and let the dry land appear," and it was so. The CodedVerse called the dry land "Earth," and the gathering together of the waters "Seas." The CodedVerse saw that it was good.
